('16', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. INDIAN COLONIAL EMIGRATION
('16', 0, 2, 3, 74) I have carefully read the resolution issued at Simla by the Government of India on the 1st instant, embodying the report of the Inter Departmental Conference recently held in London.
('16', 0, 2, 4, 257) 1 It will be remembered that this was the conference referred to in the Viceregal speech of last year at the opening of the Sessions of the Viceregal Legislative Council.
('16', 0, 2, 5, 428) It will be remembered, too, that this was the conference which Sir James Meston and Sir S. P. Sinha were to have attended but were unable to attend owing to their having returned to India before the date of the meeting of the conference.
('16', 0, 2, 6, 666) 2 It is stated in the report under discussion that these gentlemen were to discuss the question of emigration to certain English colonies informally with the two Secretaries of State, i.e., the Secretary of State for India and the Secretary of State for the Colonies.
('16', 0, 2, 7, 934) Lord Islington 3, Sir A. Steel Maitland 4 and Messrs Seton 5, Crindle 6, Green 7 and Macnaughton 8 constituted the Conference.
('16', 0, 2, 8, 1061) To take the wording of the Resolution, this Conference sat “to consider the proposals for a new assisted system of emigration to British Guiana, Trinidad, Jamaica and Fiji”.
('16', 0, 2, 9, 1235) The public should therefore note that this assisted emigration is to be confined only to the four Crown Colonies mentioned and not to the self governing Colonies of South Africa, Canada or Australia, or the Crown Colony of Mauritius.
('16', 0, 2, 10, 1469) 9 What follows will show the importance of this distinction.
('16', 0, 2, 11, 1530) It is something to be thankful for, that “the Government of India have not yet considered the report and reserved judgement on all the points raised in it”.
('16', 0, 2, 12, 1687) This is as it should be on a matter so serious as this and one which only last year fairly
('16', 0, 3, 13, 1778) 1 In May 1917 to discuss a new system of emigration 2 Sir James Meston and S. P. Sinha represented India at the Imperial War Conference held in April, 1917. They were also nominated by the Government of India as its representatives to the Inter Departmental Conference, but both of them had to return to India before the Conference could meet formally.
('16', 0, 3, 14, 2131) 3 Chairman 4 Members of the respective Secretaries of State’s establishments 5 ibid
('16', 0, 7, 15, 2215) 9 Vide also “Statement on Abolition of Indentured Labour”, after 7 2 1917.

('16', 1, 1, 2, 2330) convulsed the whole of India and which has in one shape or another agitated the country since 1895. The declaration too that “His Majesty’s Government in agreement with the Government of India have decided that indentured emigration shall not be re opened” is welcome as is also the one that “no free emigrants 1 can be introduced into any colony until all Indian emigrants already there have been released from existing indentures”.
('16', 1, 1, 3, 2764) In spite however of so much in the report that fills one with gladness, the substantive part of it which sets forth the scheme which is to replace indentured emigration is so far as one can judge, to say the least of it, disappointing.
('16', 1, 1, 4, 3000) Stripped of all the phraseology under which the scheme has been veiled, it is nothing less than a system of indentured emigration no doubt on a more humane basis and safeguarded with some conditions beneficial to the emigrants taking advantage of it.
('16', 1, 1, 5, 3251) The main point that should be borne in mind is that the conference sat designedly to consider a scheme of emigration not in the interests of the Indian labourer but in those of the Colonial employer.
('16', 1, 1, 6, 3451) The new system therefore is devised to help the colonies concerned.
('16', 1, 1, 7, 3519) India needs no outlet at any rate for the present moment for emigration outside the country.
('16', 1, 1, 8, 3612) It is debatable whether in any event the four colonies will be the most suitable for Indian colonisation.
('16', 1, 1, 9, 3718) The best thing therefore that can happen from an Indian stand point is that there should be no assisted emigration from India of any type whatsoever.
('16', 1, 1, 10, 3868) In the absence of any such assistance, emigration will have to be entirely free and at the risk and expense of the emigrant himself.
('16', 1, 1, 11, 4001) Past experience shows that, in that event, there will be very little voluntary emigration to distant colonies.
('16', 1, 1, 12, 4112) In the report, assisted emigration means, to use a mild expression, stimulated emigration; and surely with the industries of India crying out for labour and with her legitimate resources yet undeveloped, it is madness to think of providing a stimulus for the stay at home Indian to go out of India.
('16', 1, 1, 13, 4411) Neither the Government nor any voluntary agency has been found capable of protecting from ill usage the Indian who emigrates either to Burma or Ceylon, much less can any such protection avail in far off Fiji or then three other colonies.
('16', 1, 1, 14, 4649) I hope that
('16', 1, 2, 15, 4661) 1 “emigration” in the report published in The Indian Review, September 1917
('16', 2, 0, 1, 4737) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 3
('16', 2, 1, 2, 4781) leaders of public opinion in India will therefore take their stand on the one impregnable rock of not wanting any emigration whatsoever to the colonies.
('16', 2, 1, 3, 4934) It might be argued that we, as a component part of the Empire, are bound to consider the wants of our partners, but this would not be a fair plea to advance so long as India stands in need of all the labour she can produce.
('16', 2, 1, 4, 5158) If, therefore, India does not assist the colonies, it is not because of want of will, but it is due to want of ability.
('16', 2, 1, 5, 5278) An additional reason a politician would be justified in using is that, so long as India does not in reality occupy the position of an equal partner with the colonies and so long as her sons continue to be regarded by Englishmen in the colonies and English employers even nearer home to be fit only as hewers of wood and drawers of water, no scheme of emigration to the colonies can be morally advantageous to Indian emigrants.
('16', 2, 1, 6, 5705) If the badge of inferiority is always to be worn by them, they can never rise to their full status and any material advantage they will gain by emigrating can therefore be of no consideration.
('16', 2, 1, 7, 5898) But let us for the moment consider the new system.
('16', 2, 2, 8, 5949) The system to be followed in future will be one of aided emigration 1 and its object will be to encourage the settlement of Indians in certain colonies after a probationary period of employment in those colonies to train and fit them for life and work there and at the same time to acquire 2 a supply of the labour essential to the well being of the colonists 3 themselves.
('16', 2, 2, 9, 6323) So the re settlement is to be conditional on previous employment under contract and it will be seen in the course of our examination that this contract is to be just as binding as the contracts used to be under indenture.
('16', 2, 2, 10, 6545) The report has the following humorous passage in it:
('16', 2, 3, 11, 6598) He will be in no way restricted to service under any particular employer except that for his own protection a selected employer will be chosen for him for the first six months.
('16', 2, 3, 12, 6775) This has a flavour of the old indentured system.
('16', 2, 3, 13, 6824) One of the evils complained of about that system was that the labourer was assigned to an employer.
('16', 2, 3, 14, 6924) He was not free to choose one himself.
('16', 2, 3, 15, 6963) Under the new system, the employer is to be selected for the protection of the
('16', 2, 4, 16, 7042) 1 The Indian Review report has “colonization”.
('16', 2, 5, 17, 7089) 2 The Indian Review report has “afford”.
('16', 2, 6, 18, 7130) 3 Indian Review report has “Colonies”.
('16', 3, 0, 1, 7169) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 3, 1, 2, 7209) labourer.
('16', 3, 1, 3, 7219) It is hardly necessary for me to point out that the would be labourer will never be able to feel the protection devised for him.
('16', 3, 1, 4, 7348) The labourer is further
('16', 3, 2, 5, 7372) to be encouraged to work for his first three years in agricultural industries by the offer, should he do so, of numerous and important benefits subsequently as a colonist.
('16', 3, 2, 6, 7544) This is another inducement to indenture and I know enough of such schemes to be able to assure both the Government and the public that these so called inducements in the hands of clever manipulators become nothing short of methods of compulsion in respect of innocent and ignorant Indian labourers.
('16', 3, 2, 7, 7843) It is due to the framers of the scheme that I should draw attention to the fact that they have avoided all criminal penalties for breach of contract.
('16', 3, 2, 8, 7993) In India itself if the scheme is adopted, we are promised a revival of the much dreaded depots and emigration agents, all no doubt on a more respectable basis, but still of the same type and capable of untold mischief.
('16', 3, 2, 9, 8212) The rest of the report is not likely to interest the public, but those who wish to study it will, I doubt not, come to the conclusion to which I have been driven, that the framers have done their best to strip the old system of many of the abuses which had crept into it, but they have not succeeded in placing before the Indian public an acceptable scheme.
('16', 3, 2, 10, 8570) I hold that it was an impossible task.
('16', 3, 2, 11, 8609) The system of indenture was one of temporary slavery; it was incapable of being amended, it should only be ended and it is to be hoped that India will never consent to its revival in any shape or form.
('16', 3, 3, 12, 8811) The Indian Review, September 1917

('16', 4, 6, 25, 10660) 3. SPEECH AT BOMBAY PROVINCIAL CONGRESS COMMITTEE MEETING
('16', 4, 7, 26, 10718) September 2, 1917
('16', 4, 8, 27, 10736) A heated discussion took place.
('16', 4, 8, 28, 10768) M. K. Gandhi, on being asked, stated that the campaign of passive resistance could not be carried on by an institution like the Congress.
('16', 4, 8, 29, 10906) Passive resistance could be described merely as a matter of conscience or force of soul, when it was useless to go to lawyers.
('16', 4, 9, 30, 11033) 1 The meeting was adjourned due to differences over the resolution and only an agreed amendment passed; Vide the following item.
('16', 4, 10, 31, 11162) 2 Amritlal Thakkar
('16', 5, 0, 1, 11181) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 5, 1, 2, 11221) After Gandhi had delivered his opinion, it was suggested that B. G. Tilak should, after consultation with Gandhi, suggest to the meeting some acceptable amendment.
('16', 5, 1, 3, 11385) On this Gandhi himself suggested an amendment but Tilak insisted on making his own alterations in it before placing it before the meeting.
('16', 5, 1, 4, 11524) The President, after some discussion with Tilak and his party, declared that a certain amendment had been drawn up in agreement with Tilak and his party.
('16', 5, 1, 5, 11678) The amendment was as follows:
('16', 5, 2, 6, 11708) ‘Though the Bombay Provincial Congress Committee is of opinion that there is a strong feeling among the people to support the campaign of passive resistance on account of the coercive measures recently taken by the Government, it advises that, taking into consideration the fact that Mr. Montagu 1 is coming on a visit to this country and that the reasons of his coming are well known, the work of the consideration of and giving opinion on the principles underlying passive resistance and the measures necessary to put them into effect, which has been entrusted to this committee by the All India Congress Committee and the Council of the All India Muslim League, be for the present held in abeyance, and the meeting expresses the hope that the Government will take the necessary steps to allay the bitter feeling aroused among the people by action of internments and coercive measures taken by the authorities.
('16', 5, 2, 7, 12621) This course will enable the Secretary of state to fulfil the work entrusted to him under normal conditions.’
('16', 5, 3, 8, 12730) it was unanimously passed amidst cheers.

('16', 5, 5, 10, 12806) 4. LETTER TO SHANKARLAL ON ‘IDEAS ABOUT SATYAGRAHA’
('16', 5, 6, 11, 12858) [September 2, 1917] 2
('16', 5, 7, 12, 12880) BHAISHRI SHANKARLAL, You want to know my ideas about satyagraha.
('16', 5, 7, 13, 12945) Here they are in brief: The English phrase “passive resistance” does not suggest the power I wish to write about; “satyagraha” is the right word.
('16', 5, 7, 14, 13091) Satyagraha is soul force, as opposed to armed strength.
('16', 5, 7, 15, 13147) Since it is essentially an ethical weapon, only men inclined to the ethical way of life can use it wisely.
('16', 5, 7, 16, 13254) Prahlad, Mirabai, and others were satyagrahis.
('16', 5, 8, 17, 13301) 1 E. S. Montagu (1879 1924), Secretary of State for India, 1917 22 and cosponsor of the Montagu Chelmsford Reforms 2 Published in Gujarati, 2 9 1917
('16', 6, 0, 1, 13450) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 7
('16', 6, 1, 2, 13494) the time of the Morocco fighting, the Arabs were under fire from French guns.
('16', 6, 1, 3, 13572) The Arabs were fighting, as they believed, solely for their religion.
('16', 6, 1, 4, 13642) Reckless of their lives, they advanced running towards the French guns with cries of “Ya Allah” 1. Here, there was no scope at all for fighting back to kill.
('16', 6, 1, 5, 13800) The French gunners refused to fire on these Arabs and, throwing up their caps, ran to embrace these brave Arabs with shouts of joy.
('16', 6, 1, 6, 13932) This is an example of satyagraha and the success it can achieve.
('16', 6, 1, 7, 13997) The Arabs were not satyagrahis by deliberate choice.
('16', 6, 1, 8, 14050) They got ready to face death under pressure of a strong impulse, and had no love in their hearts.
('16', 6, 1, 9, 14148) A satyagrahi bears no ill will, does not lay down his life in anger, but refuses rather to submit to his “enemy” or oppressor because he has the strength himself to suffer.
('16', 6, 1, 10, 14321) He should, therefore, have a courageous spirit and a forgiving and compassionate nature.
('16', 6, 1, 11, 14410) Imam Hassan 2 and Hussain 3 were merely two boys.
('16', 6, 1, 12, 14460) They felt that an injustice had been done to them.
('16', 6, 1, 13, 14511) When called upon to surrender, they refused.
('16', 6, 1, 14, 14556) They knew at the time that this would mean death for them.
('16', 6, 1, 15, 14615) If, however, they were to submit to injustices they would disgrace their manhood and betray their religion.
('16', 6, 1, 16, 14723) In these circumstances, they yielded to the embrace of death.
('16', 6, 1, 17, 14785) The heads of these fine young men rolled on the battlefield.
('16', 6, 1, 18, 14846) In my view, Islam did not attain its greatness by the power of the sword but entirely through the self immolation of its fakirs.
('16', 6, 1, 19, 14975) It is soldierlike to allow oneself to be cut down by a sword, not to use the sword on another.
('16', 6, 1, 20, 15070) When he comes to realize that he is guilty of murder, the killer, if he has been in the wrong, will feel sorry forever afterwards.
('16', 6, 1, 21, 15201) The victim, however, will have gained nothing but victory even if he had acted wrongly in courting death.
('16', 6, 1, 22, 15307) Satyagraha is the way of non violence.
('16', 6, 1, 23, 15346) It is, therefore, justified, indeed it is the right course, at all times and all places.
('16', 6, 1, 24, 15435) The power of arms is violence and condemned as such in all religions.
('16', 6, 1, 25, 15505) Even those who advocate the use of arms put various limits on it.
('16', 6, 1, 26, 15571) There are no limits on satyagraha, or rather, none except those placed by the satyagrahi’s capacity for tapascharya, for voluntary suffering.
('16', 6, 1, 27, 15713) Obviously, it is irrelevant to raise issues about the legality of such satyagraha.
('16', 6, 1, 28, 15796) It is for the satyagrahi to decide.
('16', 6, 1, 29, 15832) Observers may
('16', 6, 2, 30, 15846) 1 Glory to God 2 Sons of Ali by his wife Fatima, daughter of the prophet.
('16', 6, 2, 31, 15920) They refused to acknowledge the authority of Yazid (Caliph, 680 3).
('16', 6, 2, 32, 15988) Hussain revolted against him, but was defeated and killed at Karbala.
('16', 7, 0, 1, 16058) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 7, 1, 2, 16098) judge satyagraha after the event.
('16', 7, 1, 3, 16132) The world’s displeasure will not deter a satyagrahi.
('16', 7, 1, 4, 16185) Whether or not satyagraha should be started is not decided by any mathematical rule.
('16', 7, 1, 5, 16270) A man who believes that satyagraha may be started only after weighing the chances of defeat and victory and assuring oneself of the certainty of victory, may be a shrewd enough politician or an intelligent man, but he is no satyagrahi.
('16', 7, 1, 6, 16506) A satyagrahi acts spontaneously.
('16', 7, 1, 7, 16539) Satyagraha and arms have both been in use from time im memorial.
('16', 7, 1, 8, 16604) We find them praised in the extant scriptures.
('16', 7, 1, 9, 16651) They are the expressions, one of the daivi sampad 1 and the other of the asuri sampad 1. We believe that in former times in India the daivi sampad was much the stronger of the two.
('16', 7, 1, 10, 16832) Even today that is the ideal we cherish.
('16', 7, 1, 11, 16873) Europe provides the most striking example of the predominance of the asuri sampad.
('16', 7, 1, 12, 16956) Both these forms of strength are preferable to weakness, to what we know by the rather plain but much apter word ‘cowardice’.
('16', 7, 1, 13, 17082) Without either, swaraj or genuine popular awakening is impossible.
('16', 7, 1, 14, 17149) Swaraj achieved otherwise than through resort to one or the other will not be true swaraj.
('16', 7, 1, 15, 17240) Such swaraj can have no effect on the people.
('16', 7, 1, 16, 17286) Popular awakening cannot be brought about without strength, without manliness.
('16', 7, 1, 17, 17365) Let the leaders say what they like and the Government strive its utmost, unless they and we, all of us, strengthen the forces of satyagraha, the methods of violence are bound automatically to gain ascendancy.
('16', 7, 1, 18, 17574) They are like weeds which grow wild in any soil.
('16', 7, 1, 19, 17623) The crop of satyagraha requires willingness to exert oneself or a venturesome spirit by way of manure.
('16', 7, 1, 20, 17726) Just as, moreover, the seedlings are likely to be lost among the weeds if the latter are not plucked out, so also will weeds of violence keep growing unless we keep the land free of them by tapascharya and, with compassion, pluck out those which have already grown.
('16', 7, 1, 21, 17992) We can, with the help of satyagraha, win over those young men who have been driven to desperation and anger by what they think to be the tyranny of the Government and utilize their courage and their mettlesome spirit, their capacity for suffering, to strengthen the daivi sampad of satyagraha.
('16', 7, 1, 22, 18286) It is therefore very much to be desired that satyagraha is propagated as quickly as can be.
('16', 7, 1, 23, 18378) This is in the interest both of the rulers and the ruled.
('16', 7, 1, 24, 18436) The satyagrahi desires to harass neither the Government nor anyone else.
('16', 7, 1, 25, 18509) He takes no step without the fullest deliberation.
('16', 7, 1, 26, 18560) He is never arrogant.
('16', 7, 2, 27, 18582) 1 God like equipment and demoniac equipment (Vide Bhagvad Gita, XVI.
('16', 8, 0, 1, 18651) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 9
('16', 8, 1, 2, 18695) Consequently, he will keep away from ‘boycott’ but be always firm in the vow of swadeshi as a matter of duty.
('16', 8, 1, 3, 18805) He fears God alone, so that no other power can intimidate him.
('16', 8, 1, 4, 18868) He will never, out of fear of punishment, leave a duty undone.
('16', 8, 1, 5, 18931) I need hardly say now that it is our duty to resort to satyagraha to secure the release of the learned Annie Bai and her co workers.
('16', 8, 1, 6, 19064) Whether we approve of every or any action of hers is another question.
('16', 8, 1, 7, 19135) I, for one, certainly do not approve of some of them; all the same, her incarceration by the Government is a great mistake and an act of injustice.
('16', 8, 1, 8, 19283) I know, of course, that the Government does not think it a mistake.
('16', 8, 1, 9, 19351) Maybe the people are wrong in desiring her release.
('16', 8, 1, 10, 19403) The Government has acted according to its lights.
('16', 8, 1, 11, 19453) What can the people do to express their outraged feelings?
('16', 8, 1, 12, 19512) Petitions, etc., are good enough when one’s suffering is bearable.
('16', 8, 1, 13, 19579) When it is unbearable, there is no remedy but satyagraha.
('16', 8, 1, 14, 19637) Only when people find it unbearable will they, and only those who find it unbearable will, devote their all, body, mind and possessions, to securing the release of Annie Bai.
('16', 8, 1, 15, 19812) This will be a powerful expression of popular feeling.
('16', 8, 1, 16, 19867) It is my unshakable faith that before so great a self sacrifice even the power of an emperor will give way.
('16', 8, 1, 17, 19975) People may certainly restrain their feelings in view of the forthcoming visit of Mr. Montagu.
('16', 8, 1, 18, 20069) That will be an expression of faith in his sense of justice.
('16', 8, 1, 19, 20130) If she is not released, however, before his arrival, it will be our duty to resort to satyagraha.
('16', 8, 1, 20, 20228) We do not want to provoke the Government or put difficulties in its way.
('16', 8, 1, 21, 20301) By resorting to satyagraha, we reveal the intensity of our injured feelings and thereby serve the Government.
('16', 8, 2, 22, 20411) From a photostat of the Gujarati draft in Gandhiji’s hand: S. N. 6373
('16', 8, 3, 23, 20481) 5. SATYAGRAHA—NOT PASSIVE RESISTANCE 1
('16', 8, 4, 24, 20520) [About September 2, 1917] 2
('16', 8, 5, 25, 20548) The force denoted by the term ‘passive resistance’ and translated into Hindi as nishkriya pratirodha is not very accurately described either by the original English phrase or by its Hindi rendering.
('16', 8, 5, 26, 20747) Its correct description is ‘satyagraha’.
('16', 8, 5, 27, 20788) Satyagraha was born in South Africa in 1908. There was no word in any Indian language
('16', 8, 6, 28, 20874) 1 The original Gujarati is not available.
('16', 8, 6, 29, 20916) 2 This article appears to belong to the same date as the preceding item.
('16', 9, 0, 1, 20989) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 9, 1, 2, 21030) denoting the power which our countrymen in South Africa invoked for the redress of their grievances.
('16', 9, 1, 3, 21131) There was an English equivalent, namely, ‘passive resistance’, and we carried on with it.
('16', 9, 1, 4, 21221) However, the need for a word to describe this unique power came to be increasingly felt, and it was decided to award a prize to anyone who could think of an appropriate term.
('16', 9, 1, 5, 21396) A Gujarati speaking 1 gentleman submitted the word ‘satyagraha’, and it was adjudged the best.
('16', 9, 2, 6, 21491) ‘Passive resistance’ conveyed the idea of the Suffragette Movement in England.
('16', 9, 2, 7, 21570) Burning of houses by these women was called ‘passive resistance’ and so also their fasting in prison.
('16', 9, 2, 8, 21672) All such acts might very well be ‘passive resistance’ but they were not ‘satyagraha’.
('16', 9, 2, 9, 21758) It is said of ‘passive resistance’ that it is the weapon of the weak, but the power which is the subject of this article can be used only by the strong.
('16', 9, 2, 10, 21911) This power is not ‘passive’ resistance; indeed it calls for intense activity.
('16', 9, 2, 11, 21989) The movement in South Africa was not passive but active.
('16', 9, 2, 12, 22046) The Indians of South Africa believed that Truth was their object, that Truth ever triumphs, and with this definiteness of purpose they persistently held on to Truth.
('16', 9, 2, 13, 22212) They put up with all the suffering that this persistence implied.
('16', 9, 2, 14, 22278) With the conviction that Truth is not to be renounced even unto death, they shed the fear of death.
('16', 9, 2, 15, 22378) In the cause of Truth, the prison was a palace to them and its doors the gateway to freedom.
('16', 9, 3, 16, 22471) WHAT IS SATYAGRAHA?
('16', 9, 4, 17, 22491) Satyagraha is not physical force.
('16', 9, 4, 18, 22525) A satyagrahi does not inflict pain on the adversary; he does not seek his destruction.

('16', 18, 6, 10, 40290) Mr. Gandhi also devised the following rules for the Volunteers to obtain signatures: 1. In taking signatures to the petition, first it must be ascertained whether the person signing correctly understands the scheme described in the petition or not.
('16', 18, 6, 11, 40539) 2. In order to make people understand the scheme, it should be read out to the inhabitants of the place, called together by a notification prepared by the Sabha.
('16', 18, 6, 12, 40701) If in such reading the people raise any new question, which cannot be answered out of the Foreword, then the Volunteer should not decide the point himself but should refer it to the Chief of his own Circle; and the questioner should not be allowed to sign so long as he has not been satisfied.
('16', 18, 6, 13, 40995) 3. It should be clearly kept in mind that no kind of pressure is to be used on any inhabitant of any place.

('16', 20, 6, 7, 43885) [Before September 16, 1917]
('16', 20, 7, 8, 43913) DEAR SATYANAND BABU, Mr. Polak had sent me your letter of inquiry about Passive Resistance.
('16', 20, 7, 9, 44005) I have time only to give you the briefest reply to your questions.
('16', 20, 7, 10, 44072) P. R., as conceived by me, is soul force, and essentially a religious principle.
('16', 20, 7, 11, 44153) Its scope, therefore, takes in every variety of wrong.
('16', 20, 7, 12, 44208) It is a force as old as the world itself.
('16', 20, 7, 13, 44250) Consider the conduct of Prahlad, Daniel, Jesus, Mirabai and others whose guiding principle in life has been religion.
('16', 20, 7, 14, 44368) Indians in South Africa made use, more or less, of this force, and they were successful only to the extent that they used it to the exclusion of every other force.
('16', 20, 7, 15, 44532) From whom did the idea first originate, is your second question.
('16', 20, 7, 16, 44597) In view of the meaning I have given to the expression, no reply seems to be necessary.
('16', 20, 7, 17, 44684) But it may be stated that so far as its use on the political platform is concerned, the idea may be said to have originated with me.
('16', 20, 7, 18, 44817) I knew nothing of it, but Tolstoy drew my attention to it.
('16', 20, 7, 19, 44876) At the time of the Controversy on the Education Bill passed by the House of Commons and the so called Passive Resistance offered by Dr. Clifford 3 and others, Mr. Winston

('16', 21, 4, 12, 46189) 15. THE MORAL BASIS OF CO OPERATION 3
('16', 21, 5, 13, 46227) The only claim I have on your indulgence is that some months ago I attended with Mr. Ewbank a meeting of mill hands to whom he wanted to explain the principles of co operation.
('16', 21, 5, 14, 46404) The chawl 4
('16', 21, 6, 15, 46416) in which they were living was as filthy as it well could be.
('16', 21, 6, 16, 46477) Recent rains had made matters worse.
('16', 21, 6, 17, 46514) And I must frankly confess that had not it been for Mr. Ewbank’s great zeal for the cause he has made his own, I should have shirked the task.
('16', 21, 6, 18, 46657) But there we were, seated on a fairly worn out charpai 5, surrounded by men, women and children.
('16', 21, 6, 19, 46754) Mr. Ewbank opened fire on a man who had put himself forward and who wore not a particularly innocent countenance.
('16', 21, 6, 20, 46868) After he had engaged him and the other people about him in Gujarati conversation,

('16', 22, 1, 2, 47587) he wanted me to speak to the people.
('16', 22, 1, 3, 47624) Owing to the suspicious looks of the man who was first spoken to, I naturally pressed home the moralities of co operation.
('16', 22, 1, 4, 47747) I fancy that Mr. Ewbank rather liked the manner in which I handled the subject.
('16', 22, 1, 5, 47827) Hence, I believe, his kind invitation to me to tax your patience for a few moments upon a consideration of co operation from a moral standpoint.
('16', 22, 1, 6, 47972) My knowledge of the technicality of co operation is next to nothing.
('16', 22, 1, 7, 48041) My brother Devdhar has made the subject his own.
('16', 22, 1, 8, 48090) Whatever he does naturally attracts me and predisposes me to think that there must be something good in it and the handling of it must be fairly difficult.
('16', 22, 1, 9, 48246) Mr. Ewbank very kindly placed at my disposal some literature too on the subject.
('16', 22, 1, 10, 48327) And I have had a unique opportunity of watching the effect of some co operative effort in Champaran.
('16', 22, 1, 11, 48428) I have gone through Mr. Ewbank’s ten main points which are like the commandments, and I have gone through the twelve points of Mr. Collins of Behar, which remind me of the law of the twelve tables.
('16', 22, 1, 12, 48626) There are so called agricultural banks in Champaran.
('16', 22, 1, 13, 48679) They were to me disappointing efforts, if they were meant to be demonstrations of the success of co operation.
('16', 22, 1, 14, 48790) On the other hand, there is quiet work in the same direction being done by Mr. Hodge, a missionary whose efforts are leaving their impression on those who come in contact with him.
('16', 22, 1, 15, 48971) Mr. Hodge is a co operative enthusiast and probably considers that the results which he sees flowing from his efforts are due to the working of co operation.
('16', 22, 1, 16, 49129) I who was able to watch the two efforts had no hesitation in inferring that the personal equation counted for success in the one and failure in the other instance.
('16', 22, 1, 17, 49293) I am an enthusiast myself, but twenty five years of experimenting and experience have made me a cautious and discriminating enthusiast.
('16', 22, 1, 18, 49429) Workers in a cause necessarily, though quite unconsciously, exaggerate its merits and often succeed in turning its very defects into advantages.
('16', 22, 1, 19, 49574) In spite of my caution I consider the little institution 1 I am conducting in Ahmedabad as the finest thing in the world.
('16', 22, 1, 20, 49696) It alone gives me sufficient inspiration.
('16', 22, 1, 21, 49738) Critics tell me that it represents a soulless soul force and that its severe discipline has made it merely mechanical.
('16', 22, 1, 22, 49857) I suppose both—the critics and I—are wrong.
('16', 22, 1, 23, 49901) It is, at best, a humble attempt to place at the disposal of the nation a home where men and women may have scope for free and unfettered development of character, in keeping with the national genius, and if
('16', 22, 2, 24, 50109) 1 Satyagraha Ashram
('16', 23, 0, 1, 50129) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 23, 1, 2, 50170) its controllers do not take care, the discipline that is the foundation of character, may frustrate the very end in view.
('16', 23, 1, 3, 50292) I would venture, therefore, to warn enthusiasts in co operation against entertaining false hopes.
('16', 23, 1, 4, 50390) With Sir Daniel Hamilton, it has become a religion.
('16', 23, 1, 5, 50442) On the 13th January last, he addressed the students of the Scottish Churches College, and in order to point a moral he instanced Scotland’s poverty of two hundred years ago and showed how that great country was raised from a condition of poverty to plenty.
('16', 23, 1, 6, 50699) He said:
('16', 23, 2, 7, 50708) There were two powers which raised her—the Scottish Church and the Scottish banks.
('16', 23, 2, 8, 50791) The Church manufactured the men and the banks manufactured the money to give the men a start in life....
('16', 23, 2, 9, 50896) The Church disciplined the nation in the fear of God which is the beginning of wisdom and in the parish schools of the Church, the children learned that the chief end of man’s life was to glorify God and to enjoy Him for ever.
('16', 23, 2, 10, 51123) Men were trained to believe in God and in themselves, and on the trustworthy character so created, the Scottish banking system was built.
('16', 23, 2, 11, 51261) Sir Daniel then shows that it was possible to build up the marvellous Scottish banking system only on the character so built.
('16', 23, 2, 12, 51387) So far there can only be perfect agreement with Sir Daniel, for ‘Without character there is no co operation’ is a sound maxim.
('16', 23, 2, 13, 51514) But he would have us go much further.
('16', 23, 2, 14, 51552) He thus waxes eloquent on co operation:
('16', 23, 3, 15, 51592) Whatever may be your day dreams of India’s future, never forget this that it is to weld India into one, and so enable her to take her rightful place in the world, that the British Government is here; and the welding hammer in the hand of the Government is the co operative movement.
('16', 23, 3, 16, 51875) In his opinion, it is the panacea of all the evils that afflict India at the present moment.
('16', 23, 3, 17, 51968) In its extended sense it can justify the claim on one condition which need not be mentioned here; in the limited sense in which Sir Daniel has used it, I venture to think, it is an enthusiast’s exaggeration.
('16', 23, 3, 18, 52176) Mark his peroration:
('16', 23, 4, 19, 52197) Credit which is only Trust and Faith, is becoming more and more the money power of the world, and in the parchment bullet into which is impressed the faith which removes mountains, India will find victory and peace.
('16', 23, 4, 20, 52413) Here there is evident confusion of thought.
('16', 23, 4, 21, 52457) The credit which is becoming the money power of the world has little moral basis and is not a synonym for Trust or Faith, which are purely moral qualities.
('16', 23, 4, 22, 52613) After twenty years’ experience of hundreds of men, who had dealings with banks in South Africa, the opinion I had so often heard expressed has become firmly rooted in me, that the greater the rascal,
('16', 24, 0, 1, 52813) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 25
('16', 24, 1, 2, 52858) the greater the credit he enjoys with his banks.
('16', 24, 1, 3, 52907) The banks do not pry into his moral character; they are satisfied that he meets his over drafts and promissory notes punctually.
('16', 24, 1, 4, 53036) The credit system has encircled this beautiful globe of ours like a serpent’s coil, and if we do not mind, it bids fair to crush us out of breath.
('16', 24, 1, 5, 53183) I have witnessed the ruin of many a home through the system, and it has made no difference whether the credit was labelled co operative or otherwise.
('16', 24, 1, 6, 53333) The deadly coil has made possible the devastating spectacle in Europe, which we are helplessly looking on.
('16', 24, 1, 7, 53440) It was perhaps never so true as it is to day that as in law so in war the longest purse finally wins.
('16', 24, 1, 8, 53542) I have ventured to give prominence to the current belief about credit system in order to emphasise the point that the co operative movement will be a blessing to India only to the extent that it is a moral movement strictly directed by men fired with religious fervour.
('16', 24, 1, 9, 53812) It follows, therefore, that co operation should be confined to men wishing to be morally right, but failing to do so, because of grinding poverty or of the grip of the mahajan 1. Facility for obtaining loans at fair rates will not make immoral or unmoral men moral.
('16', 24, 1, 10, 54078) But the wisdom of the State or philanthropists demands that they should help, on the onward path, men struggling to be good.
('16', 24, 1, 11, 54203) Too often do we believe that material prosperity means moral growth.
('16', 24, 1, 12, 54272) It is necessary that a movement which is fraught with so much good to India should not degenerate into one for merely advancing cheap loans.
('16', 24, 1, 13, 54413) I was therefore delighted to read the recommendation in the Report of the Committee on Co operation in India, that
('16', 24, 2, 14, 54528) they wish clearly to express their opinion that it is to true co operation alone, that is, to a co operation which recognises the moral aspect of the question that Government must look for the amelioration of the masses and not to a pseudo co operative edifice, however imposing, which is built in ignorance of co operative, principles.
('16', 24, 2, 15, 54865) With this standard before us, we will not measure the success of the movement by the number of co operative societies formed, but by the moral condition of the co operators.
('16', 24, 2, 16, 55039) The Registrars will in that event ensure the moral growth of existing societies before multiplying them.
('16', 24, 2, 17, 55144) And the Government will make their promotion conditional, not upon the number of societies they have registered, but the moral success of the existing institutions.
('16', 24, 2, 18, 55309) This will mean tracing the course of every pice lent to the members.
('16', 24, 2, 19, 55378) Those responsible for
('16', 24, 3, 20, 55400) 1 Moneylender
('16', 25, 0, 1, 55414) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 25, 1, 2, 55455) the proper conduct of co operative societies will see to it that the money advanced does not find its way into the toddy sellers’ till or into the pockets of the keepers of gambling dens.
('16', 25, 1, 3, 55643) I would excuse the rapacity of the mahajan if it has succeeded in keeping the gambling die or toddy from the ryot’s home.
('16', 25, 2, 4, 55765) A word perhaps about the mahajan will not be out of place.
('16', 25, 2, 5, 55824) Co operation is not a new device.
('16', 25, 2, 6, 55858) The ryots co operate to drum out monkeys or birds that destroy their crops.
('16', 25, 2, 7, 55934) They co operate to use a common thrashing floor.
('16', 25, 2, 8, 55983) I have found them co operate to protect their cattle to the extent of their devoting their best land for the grazing of their cattle.
('16', 25, 2, 9, 56117) And they have been found co operating against a particularly rapacious mahajan.
('16', 25, 2, 10, 56197) Doubt has been expressed as to the success of co operation because of the tightness of the mahajan’s hold on the ryots.
('16', 25, 2, 11, 56317) I do not share the fears.
('16', 25, 2, 12, 56343) The mightiest mahajan must, if he represents an evil force, bend before co operation, conceived as an essentially moral movement.
('16', 25, 2, 13, 56473) But my limited experience of the mahajan of Champaran has made me revise the accepted opinion about his ‘blighting influence’.
('16', 25, 2, 14, 56600) I have found him to be not always relentless, not always exacting of the last pie.
('16', 25, 2, 15, 56683) He sometimes serves his clients in many ways or even comes to their rescue in the hour of their distress.
('16', 25, 2, 16, 56789) My observation is so limited that I dare not draw any conclusions from it, but I respectfully enquire whether it is not possible to make a serious effort to draw out the good in the mahajan and help him or induce him to throw out the evil in him.
('16', 25, 2, 17, 57036) May he not be induced to join the army of co operation, or has experience proved that he is past praying for?
('16', 25, 3, 18, 57146) I note that the movement takes note of all indigenous industries.
('16', 25, 3, 19, 57212) I beg publicly to express my gratitude to Government for helping me in my humble effort to improve the lot of the weaver.
('16', 25, 3, 20, 57334) The experiment I am conducting shows that there is a vast field for work in this direction.
('16', 25, 3, 21, 57426) No well wisher of India, no patriot dare look upon the impending destruction of the handloom weaver with equanimity.
('16', 25, 3, 22, 57543) As Dr. Mann has stated, this industry used to supply the peasant with an additional source of livelihood and an insurance against famine.
('16', 25, 3, 23, 57681) Every Registrar who will nurse back to life this important and graceful industry will earn the gratitude of India.
('16', 25, 3, 24, 57796) My humble effort consists of, firstly, in making researches as to the possibilities of simple reforms in the orthodox handlooms, secondly, in weaning the educated youth from the craving for Government or other service and the feeling that
('16', 26, 0, 1, 58035) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 27
('16', 26, 1, 2, 58080) education renders him unfit for independent occupation and inducing him to take to weaving as a calling as honourable as that of a barrister or a doctor, and, thirdly, by helping those who have abandoned their occupation to revert to it.
('16', 26, 1, 3, 58318) I will not weary the audience with any statement on the first two parts of the experiment.
('16', 26, 1, 4, 58409) The third may be allowed a few sentences as it has a direct bearing upon the subject before us.
('16', 26, 1, 5, 58505) I was able to enter upon it only six months ago.
('16', 26, 1, 6, 58554) Five families that had left off the calling have reverted to it and they are doing a prosperous business.
('16', 26, 1, 7, 58660) The Ashram supplies them at their door with the yarn they need; it volunteers to take delivery of the cloth woven, paying them cash at the market rate.
('16', 26, 1, 8, 58812) The Ashram merely loses interest on the loan advanced for the yarn.
('16', 26, 1, 9, 58880) It has as yet suffered no loss and is able to restrict its loss to a minimum by limiting the loan to a particular figure.
('16', 26, 1, 10, 59002) All future transactions are strictly cash.
('16', 26, 1, 11, 59045) We are able to command a ready sale for the cloth received.
('16', 26, 1, 12, 59105) The loss of interest, therefore, on the transaction is negligible.
('16', 26, 1, 13, 59172) I would like the audience to note its purely moral character from start to finish.
('16', 26, 1, 14, 59255) The Ashram depends for its existence on such help as friends render it.
('16', 26, 1, 15, 59327) We, therefore, can have no warrant for charging interest.
('16', 26, 1, 16, 59385) The weavers could not be saddled with it.
('16', 26, 1, 17, 59427) Whole families that were breaking to pieces are put together again.
('16', 26, 1, 18, 59495) The use of the loan is predetermined.
('16', 26, 1, 19, 59533) And we the middlemen being volunteers obtain the privilege of entering into the lives of these families 1 hope for their and our betterment.
('16', 26, 1, 20, 59674) We cannot lift them without being lifted ourselves.
('16', 26, 1, 21, 59726) This last relationship has not yet been developed, but we hope at an early date to take in hand the education too of these families and not rest satisfied till we have touched them at every point.
('16', 26, 1, 22, 59923) This is not too ambitious a dream.
('16', 26, 1, 23, 59958) God willing, it will be a reality some day.
('16', 26, 1, 24, 60002) I have ventured to dilate upon the small experiment to illustrate what I mean by co operation to present it to others for imitation.
('16', 26, 1, 25, 60135) Let us be sure of our ideal.
('16', 26, 1, 26, 60164) We shall ever fail to realise it, but we should never cease to strive for it.
('16', 26, 1, 27, 60242) Then there need be no fear of “co operation of scoundrels” that Ruskin so rightly dreaded.

('16', 27, 2, 3, 60491) RANCHI, [Adhik Aso Sud 7, September 23, 1917] 1
('16', 27, 3, 4, 60539) MAGANLAL, It is twelve days since I left you.
('16', 27, 3, 5, 60585) Out of the eleven days, nine I spent on the train and only two nights at a friend’s.
('16', 27, 3, 6, 60670) Despite this, my health has not suffered.
('16', 27, 3, 7, 60712) I had regular food today after eleven days.
('16', 27, 3, 8, 60756) I had discussions with Amritlalbhai 2 in Bombay about the Ashram buildings.
('16', 27, 3, 9, 60832) Chhaganlal must have written to you.
('16', 27, 3, 10, 60869) He made some very weighty suggestions, the most important being that we cannot escape using wood.
('16', 27, 3, 11, 60967) There will be some difficulty about the foundation.
('16', 27, 3, 12, 61019) It just will not hold there, and the only way out is to have wood work filled in with brick.
('16', 27, 3, 13, 61112) The library, he said, would have to be lengthened, otherwise there would not be enough light.
('16', 27, 3, 14, 61206) He will himself write in detail about all this.
('16', 27, 3, 15, 61254) I hope you remember that you have to carry with you the lamp, with its post, from Jivanlalbhai’s bungalow.
('16', 27, 3, 16, 61361) We shall need them.
('16', 27, 3, 17, 61381) Amritlalbhai suggested that the wood should be thickly painted all round with coal tar.
('16', 27, 3, 18, 61469) Provide for good latrines and urinals from the very start.
('16', 27, 3, 19, 61528) Money spent on them will be well spent.
('16', 27, 3, 20, 61568) It will also be necessary to provide for quick draining away of sewage.
('16', 27, 3, 21, 61640) I think it needful that you collect in the Ashram stone, gravel, etc., wherever and in whatever quantity available.
('16', 27, 3, 22, 61756) Plan the roads fairly broad and get them ready soon.
('16', 27, 3, 23, 61809) I see that I shall have to stay longer in Ranchi than I had thought.
('16', 27, 3, 24, 61878) The sittings start on Monday.

('16', 28, 1, 2, 62466) 17. EXTRACTS FROM MINUTES OF CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE MEETING
('16', 28, 2, 3, 62523) RANCHI, September 24, 1917
('16', 28, 3, 4, 62550) The President said that he understood that Mr. Gandhi had some remarks to make about the draft report which had been circulated.
('16', 28, 3, 5, 62679) Mr. Gandhi said that he had an interview with His Honour the Lieutenant Governor and understood from him that arbitration on the conflicting claims as to sharahbeshi was possible.
('16', 28, 3, 6, 62859) The President
('16', 28, 4, 7, 62873) said that during the time he had been in Ranchi he had discussed this matter with the local Government and had pointed out that there were three possible courses:
('16', 28, 5, 8, 63036) (1) for the local Government to arbitrate,
('16', 28, 6, 9, 63079) (2) for the Bettiah estate to meet the difference of 25 per cent, or
('16', 28, 7, 10, 63148) (3) for the question to be left to a special tribunal.
('16', 28, 8, 11, 63203) He understood that the local Government was not prepared to arbitrate but was prepared to consider the second suggestion after consulting the local officers.
('16', 28, 8, 12, 63361) The latter were, however, opposed to the idea and when he himself had put it to the planters principally concerned, viz., Messrs Norman, Hill and Irwin, he gathered that they also were not in favour of it.
('16', 28, 8, 13, 63567) He, therefore, understood that the local Government had abandoned all idea of the first and second alternatives and the report was consequently drafted on the assumption that the third alternative would be adopted.
('16', 28, 8, 14, 63782) Mr. Gandhi said that he thought that Sir Edward Gait would be prepared to arbitrate and suggested that the matter might be referred to him.
('16', 28, 8, 15, 63922) Mr. Rainy pointed out that it would he necessary to ascertain first whether the parties were willing.
('16', 28, 8, 16, 64024) The President said that it was necessary, before the matter was referred to His Honour, to decide one or two points.
('16', 28, 8, 17, 64141) The first was as to Turkaulia.
('16', 28, 8, 18, 64172) Mr. Hill had not agreed to a reduction in sharahbeshi larger than 20 per cent and Mr. Gandhi had said that he was prepared to
('16', 28, 9, 19, 64298) consider special cases.
('16', 28, 9, 20, 64322) The President asked, therefore, whether he would agree in the case of Turkaulia for the arbitration to be between the limits of 20 per cent and 40 per cent.
('16', 28, 9, 21, 64479) Mr. Gandhi agreed to this.
('16', 28, 9, 22, 64506) The President said that the second point was, supposing some of the planters agreed and some did not, was the arbitration to be recommended in the case of those who agreed?
('16', 28, 9, 23, 64679) Mr. Gandhi said that he thought if any concerns preferred to fight out their case in the ordinary courts, he would have no objection to their doing so.
('16', 28, 9, 24, 64831) Mr. Reid agreed to this.
('16', 28, 9, 25, 64856) The President then asked whether Mr. Gandhi intended the arbitration to be done by His Honour personally or by the local Government.
('16', 28, 9, 26, 64989) Mr. Gandhi said that he thought it should be done by His Honour personally and the Committee agreed.
('16', 28, 9, 27, 65090) Mr. Reid enquired whether His Honour would fix a separate figure for each factory.
('16', 28, 9, 28, 65173) Mr. Gandhi said he thought it was not necessary
('16', 29, 0, 1, 65221) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 29, 1, 2, 65262) to go into details and that this could be left to His Honour.
('16', 29, 1, 3, 65324) The President then pointed out that, supposing the arbitration was undertaken, it was necessary to give the planters some assurance that the award would be made binding on the raiyats.
('16', 29, 2, 4, 65509) Adami said that this would require legislation.
('16', 29, 2, 5, 65557) Mr. Gandhi, however, thought that it would be simpler and just as binding as legislation, if he got a power of attorney from the raiyats to act on their behalf.
('16', 29, 2, 6, 65718) This would not cause so much delay and probably be
('16', 29, 3, 7, 65769) less troublesome on the whole than special legislation.

('16', 29, 4, 9, 65938) whom the indigo obligation was recorded.
('16', 29, 4, 10, 65979) Mr. Gandhi said that they should have the option of commuting the obligation at whatever rate might eventually be awarded.
('16', 29, 4, 11, 66102) The President pointed out that the Committee had already agreed that the tinkathia
('16', 29, 5, 12, 66185) system was so bad that it ought to be abolished.
('16', 29, 5, 13, 66234) Mr. Gandhi said that in spite of that he could not see why raiyats should be compelled to pay enhanced rents if they did not wish to.
('16', 29, 5, 14, 66368) He was prepared to try and get a power of attorney from such raiyats but the raiyats should not be compelled to agree to the arbitration.
('16', 29, 5, 15, 66506) Mr. Reid said he
('16', 29, 6, 16, 66523) thought that there would be great delay in getting the power of attorney and the President asked what would happen if the raiyats repudiated it subsequently.
('16', 29, 6, 17, 66681) Mr. Gandhi said that in that case the raiyats would have to fight, but that was not likely.
('16', 29, 7, 18, 66773) He would agree to the following being put in the report, “In order to protect the planters in the matter of acceptance by the raiyats of the Lieutenant Governor’s award, Mr. Gandhi would undertake to obtain a power of attorney from the raiyats concerned.” He added that it might be simpler if the raiyats simply signed an
('16', 29, 8, 19, 67095) agreement that they would accept the figure fixed by the Lieutenant Governor.
('16', 29, 8, 20, 67173) The President enquired whether if arbitration was to take place before this agreement was obtained, it would be right to go to the raiyats and ask them to sign it subsequent to
('16', 29, 9, 21, 67350) the arbitration.
('16', 29, 9, 22, 67367) Mr. Gandhi said that in that case it would not be a power of attorney but would be a legal acceptance.
('16', 29, 9, 23, 67470) Mr. Rainy said that what was required was something which the raiyat could not question if the planter had to bring a suit for arrears of
('16', 29, 10, 24, 67608) Mr. Reid pointed out that if the attested rent had to be revised in the record, legislation would be necessary and a separate agreement would be required from each raiyat specifying the terms which had been settled in each particular case.
('16', 29, 11, 25, 67848) President said that the difficulty was that while with the planters the Committee were dealing with principals, with raiyats they were dealing with the representatives.
('16', 29, 12, 26, 68017) two methods which had been proposed to get over this were
('16', 29, 13, 27, 68075) (1) to get a power of attorney from the raiyats before arbitration which
('16', 29, 14, 28, 68148) would be a lengthy process, and
('16', 29, 15, 29, 68180) (2) that Mr. Gandhi should obtain a legal acceptance after arbitration.

('16', 30, 0, 1, 68415) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 31
('16', 30, 1, 2, 68460) that case the expense would be considerable and it would have to be decided who was to bear it.

('16', 30, 1, 4, 68639) Mr. Reid thought that legislation would be preferable.
('16', 30, 1, 5, 68694) Mr. Rainy pointed out that it would be difficult to have the arbitration before the power of attorney was obtained and asked whether Mr. Gandhi would not agree to recommend that the settlement should be made binding by legislation, if necessary.

('16', 30, 1, 7, 68967) Mr. Reid said that he understood that in any case legislation was necessary to abolish the tinkathia system and he saw no reason therefore why provisions as to sharahbeshi should not also be included.
('16', 30, 1, 8, 69168) The President said he thought that the
('16', 30, 2, 9, 69207) proposal for special legislation was to some extent gambling on the Legislative Council but the members generally thought there would be no difficulty about this.
('16', 30, 2, 10, 69370) It was finally agreed that the President should go to His Honour with the unanimous request that he should arbitrate on the following basis:
('16', 30, 3, 11, 69511) (l) In the case of Turkaulia between the limits of 20 per cent and 40 per cent reduction in sharahbeshi.
('16', 30, 4, 12, 69616) (2) In Pipra, Motihari, Jallaha and Sirni between the limits of 25 per cent and 40 per cent reduction.
('16', 30, 5, 13, 69719) The arbitration was only to take place where the concerns agreed.
('16', 30, 5, 14, 69785) Any concern which did not agree would be left to the agency of the ordinary courts.
('16', 30, 5, 15, 69869) The award might vary for different concerns and although Mr. Gandhi would prefer to omit this qualification, he would prefer to retain it rather than that the arbitration should fail.
('16', 30, 5, 16, 70053) Where the indigo obligation was recorded, the raiyat was to have the option of
('16', 30, 6, 17, 70132) continuing under the obligation or of commuting it at the rates fixed by the arbitration.
('16', 30, 6, 18, 70222) Effect was to be given to the award by emergency legislation.
('16', 30, 7, 19, 70284) The President then said that in case His Honour agreed to arbitrate, the report would presumably simply state this fact.
('16', 30, 7, 20, 70405) Mr. Gandhi said that he would prefer the arbitration to take place first of all and the figure arrived at to be incorporated in the report as their recommendation with the additional recommendation that legislation should be undertaken to enforce it.
('16', 30, 7, 21, 70656) The Committee agreed to this.
('16', 30, 8, 22, 70686) The President then said that they had now to consider the report and he asked Mr. Gandhi to put his general views before the meeting.
('16', 30, 8, 23, 70820) Mr. Gandhi said that he thought that for their purpose, the report was too heavy and that the Committee were not warranted in giving such a lengthy history after a summary enquiry.
('16', 30, 8, 24, 71001) He pointed out that the materials were all in the Government record and on the terms of reference they had merely to report conclusions without giving the reasons.
('16', 30, 8, 25, 71165) His experience was that arbitrators who did not give reasons always did well.
('16', 30, 8, 26, 71243) The President agreed, provided that the report was unanimous.
('16', 30, 9, 27, 71305) The President said that one point which had not been dealt with in the report was the case of tawan in mukarrari villages.

('16', 31, 1, 2, 71500) of tawan in thika villages only.

('16', 31, 1, 5, 71726) If necessary, the
('16', 31, 2, 6, 71744) payment could be enforced by special legislation.
('16', 31, 3, 7, 71794) The President then brought forward a note of dissent put in by the Hon’ble Raja Kirtyanand Sinha as to the recommendation made in regard to sections 75 and 58 of the Bengal Tenancy Act.
('16', 31, 3, 8, 71980) As to the amendment in section 75, Mr. Adami pointed out that the principle of having two alternative procedures for dealing with an infringement had already been accepted by the Legislature in section 58, so that the objection on this ground was not valid.
('16', 31, 3, 9, 72238) Mr. Gandhi said that the objection on the ground that a legal point might arise seemed more valid but this would be provided for because there would be an appeal to the Commissioner.
('16', 31, 3, 10, 72421) The President pointed out that the recommendation was practically to make the section the same as in the Chhota Nagpur Tenancy Act and asked the Raja if he would not agree to the recommendation if it was restricted to the Champaran district.
('16', 31, 3, 11, 72663) Raja Kirtyanand Sinha said that on this condition he was willing to agree.

('16', 31, 6, 13, 72802) 18. MINUTES OF CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE MEETING
('16', 31, 7, 14, 72845) RANCHI, September 25, 1917
('16', 31, 8, 15, 72872) The President said he had seen the Lieutenant Governor who had said that he was not prepared to give a definite reply to the proposal that he should arbitrate and pointed out that it would be a somewhat difficult position for him since, as the head of the Government, he would have to deal with the report.
('16', 31, 8, 16, 73179) The Lieutenant Governor had, therefore, suggested that it might be preferable if a High Court Judge was appointed to arbitrate.
('16', 31, 8, 17, 73307) Mr. Gandhi said that he did not contemplate such a stiff and formal arbitration.
('16', 31, 8, 18, 73388) It was not a legal mind that was required for this arbitration but a business mind.
('16', 31, 8, 19, 73472) Mr. Reid said that he was doubtful whether Messers Irwin and Hill would agree to arbitration and he was certain that they would not agree to arbitration by a High Court Judge.
('16', 31, 8, 20, 73648) The President said that in that case it was hardly worthwhile to go on with the proposal to arbitrate.
('16', 31, 8, 21, 73751) Mr. Gandhi agreed but said he still had hopes of bringing about an arbitration.
('16', 31, 9, 22, 73831) Turning to the discussion of the report, the President said that, in considering whether the introductory historical portion should be cut down, it had to be remembered that it was desirable to make the report as a whole intelligent to the
('16', 32, 0, 1, 74071) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 33
('16', 32, 1, 2, 74116) public and not to make it appear as if the Committee had shirked their tasks.
('16', 32, 1, 3, 74194) Mr. Rainy said he had no objection to cutting down Chapter II.
('16', 32, 1, 4, 74257) Mr. Adami was inclined to keep Chapter II as it was.
('16', 32, 1, 5, 74310) Raja Kirtyanand Sinha suggested that the paragraph about the thikadari system might be shortened.
('16', 32, 1, 6, 74408) Mr. Reid said that he saw no objection to
('16', 32, 2, 7, 74450) Chapter II standing.
('16', 32, 2, 8, 74471) It was necessary to enable anyone to grasp the problem as it stood at present.
('16', 32, 2, 9, 74550) Mr. Gandhi said that if the report was not to be unanimous, he could understand and would not resist the desire of the majority to state their argument fully.
('16', 32, 2, 10, 74709) The President said that Mr. Gandhi should indicate precisely the points to which he objected and the report could then be altered, if possible, to meet the views of everybody.
('16', 32, 2, 11, 74885) Mr. Rainy pointed out that if there was anything in Chapter II which was contentious, it could be transferred to the contentious part of the report.
('16', 32, 2, 12, 75034) He added that if the report was to recommend the tribunal, it was unnecessary to discuss the sharahbeshi question at length, because that was the very point which the tribunal
('16', 32, 3, 13, 75210) would have to decide, but if Government was going to decide the question itself, then it would be necessary to give the arguments at some length.
('16', 32, 3, 14, 75356) Mr. Gandhi thought that Government would have to decide between the views of the majority and his own views, as what he wanted was for Government to decide on the equities of the case and legislate at once.
('16', 32, 3, 15, 75563) If Government held sharahbeshi to be illegal and that tinkathia,
('16', 32, 4, 16, 75628) though legal, was accompanied by so much abuse that it should be abolished, they would legislate against it without the necessity of appointing a tribunal.
('16', 32, 4, 17, 75784) If he had come on the scene earlier, he would have advised the raiyats against compensation,
('16', 32, 5, 18, 75877) but as it was, compensation had been paid and he had to recognise that Mr. Reid said that he had only agreed to recommend that tinkathia should be abolished if there was
('16', 32, 6, 19, 76047) compensation for it.
('16', 32, 6, 20, 76068) The President said that the Committee could not bind Government, but he could indicate the view that he thought Government took; if there was a decision by arbitration on the consent of both parties, Government could legislate to give effect to that agreement without any difficulty.
('16', 32, 6, 21, 76352) If there was no agreement, there were two alternatives:
('16', 32, 7, 22, 76408) (1) for Government to decide for itself and legislate accordingly or
('16', 32, 8, 23, 76477) (2) for the matter to be referred to a special tribunal or left to the ordinary courts.
('16', 32, 9, 24, 76565) As to the first alternative, questions affecting important claims to property were involved which it would be rather arbitrary and high handed for Government to decide executively.
('16', 32, 9, 25, 76746) The second alternative would, therefore, be the one probably adopted if no agreements were reached.
('16', 32, 9, 26, 76846) The President added that until the Committee had before them Mr. Gandhi’s specific suggestions as to what he wished to alter in the report, it was impossible to go on.
('16', 32, 9, 27, 77014) What he wanted was a unanimous report as far as possible, that is to say, that any contentious matter should be confined to the one portion regarding sharahbeshi.
('16', 32, 9, 28, 77177) Mr. Gandhi said that there was one master idea
('16', 33, 0, 1, 77224) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 33, 1, 2, 77265) running through the report recognising the legality in certain cases of the tinkathia obligation and the justification for sharahbeshi.
('16', 33, 1, 3, 77401) The President said that if Mr. Gandhi
('16', 33, 2, 4, 77439) would go through the report in detail, each portion of it could be dealt with separately.
('16', 33, 3, 5, 77529) Discussing the possibility of arbitration, Mr. Gandhi said that he thought if the planters believed they had a good case, it was unbusinesslike for them to refuse arbitration.
('16', 33, 3, 6, 77705) The President asked whether if only Mr. Norman agreed to arbitration, it was worthwhile taking up his case alone.
('16', 33, 3, 7, 77819) Mr. Rainy thought that might make one or other of the parties regard the local Government as being incapacitated from dealing with the other cases impartially.
('16', 33, 3, 8, 77979) He suggested that if a special tribunal was set up, it might be left open to the planters to agree to arbitration by the tribunal instead of detailed trial in each case.
('16', 33, 3, 9, 78149) The President said he did not think there would be any advantage in that.
('16', 33, 4, 10, 78223) The President then suggested that the constitution ant duties of the tribunal should be discussed.
('16', 33, 4, 11, 78322) Mr. Adami said that it should consist of three members to provide for a difference of opinion and thought that there should be an appeal to the High Court on any legal point but not on the question of what was the fair amount for the commutation of the obligation.
('16', 33, 4, 12, 78587) The Committee accepted three as the number of members of the tribunal and the personnel was then discussed.
('16', 33, 4, 13, 78695) The President suggested that the tribunal should consist of:
('16', 33, 5, 14, 78756) (1) a Judicial Officer not below the rank of District Judge,
('16', 33, 6, 15, 78817) (2) a Revenue Officer not below the rank of Collector, and
('16', 33, 7, 16, 78876) (3) another Judge or another Revenue Officer.
('16', 33, 8, 17, 78922) As to (1), Mr. Rainy proposed that the Judicial Officer should be a High Court Judge and that there should be no appeal.
('16', 33, 8, 18, 79043) Mr. Gandhi, however, thought that there should be a right of appeal, as tribunals sometimes went wrong.
('16', 33, 8, 19, 79147) His view was the same whether the Judicial Officer in the tribunal was a High Court Judge or a District Judge.
('16', 33, 8, 20, 79258) He agreed that the right of appeal should be confined to legal points.
('16', 33, 8, 21, 79329) Mr. Adami said that if a High Court Judge was on the tribunal, he would allow no appeal, but there was no technical objection to an appeal being allowed from such a tribunal.
('16', 33, 8, 22, 79504) Mr. Reid agreed with Mr. Rainy.
('16', 33, 8, 23, 79536) Raja Kirtyanand Singh said that he would prefer that Mr. Gandhi should agree to a 25 per cent reduction in sharahbeshi, which would
('16', 33, 9, 24, 79668) obviate the appointment of a tribunal, the working of which would obviously give a good deal of trouble.
('16', 33, 9, 25, 79773) The Committee agreed that the second member of the tribunal should be a Revenue Officer not below the grade of Collector.
('16', 33, 9, 26, 79895) As to the third member of the tribunal, Mr. Rainy said he would prefer to leave it to the local Government, who might wish to appoint neither a Judge nor a Revenue Officer.
('16', 33, 9, 27, 80068) Mr. Adami said that he would prefer the third member to be a Judicial Officer.
('16', 33, 9, 28, 80147) Mr. Gandhi also preferred a
('16', 34, 0, 1, 80175) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 35
('16', 34, 1, 2, 80220) Judicial Officer.
('16', 34, 1, 3, 80238) He said that the case here was not the same as in arbitration and, for a formal judicial tribunal, he would prefer a majority of Judicial Officers.
('16', 34, 1, 4, 80386) The President asked if it was possible for a High Court Judge and a District Judge to sit together.

('16', 34, 1, 6, 80691) He thought if they made their recommendation as to the personnel in too much detail, it would tie the hands of Government.
('16', 34, 1, 7, 80814) The President then raised a question of the duties of tribunal.
('16', 34, 1, 8, 80878) He suggested that the necessary legislation should lay down their duties somewhat as follows:
('16', 34, 2, 9, 80972) That on the application of either party within a certain period, the tribunal was to decide (1) If the obligation to grow indigo existed or not.
('16', 34, 2, 10, 81117) (2) If so, what compensation in the form of enhanced rent, if any, should be allowed.
('16', 34, 2, 11, 81203) (3) If the tribunal decided that compensation was to be given, it should have regard in fixing that compensation to the following points:
('16', 34, 3, 12, 81341) (a) in no case was the rent to be greater than fair and equitable rent;
('16', 34, 4, 13, 81413) (b) the existing rent and the period for which it had remained unenhanced; and
('16', 34, 5, 14, 81492) (c) the actual rate of sharahbeshi which had been taken in the concern or in
('16', 34, 6, 15, 81569) neighbouring concerns.
('16', 34, 7, 16, 81592) Mr. Adami said that if the tribunal had to fix a commutation rate, this was probably the best way.
('16', 34, 7, 17, 81691) It had been suggested that a fair and equitable rent should be fixed by the tribunal, irrespective of any conditions.
('16', 34, 7, 18, 81809) Mr. Rainy said that in his view the tribunal should be left entirely free to decide what points to consider.
('16', 34, 7, 19, 81918) There were limits to their discretion because they could not fix the rent lower than the original rent nor one higher than the existing rent including sharahbeshi.
('16', 34, 7, 20, 82082) The President said
('16', 34, 8, 21, 82101) that as Revenue Officer, he would hesitate to carry out the rent settlement without some such guidance as he had proposed.

('16', 34, 8, 26, 82811) Mr. Gandhi pointed out that any recommendation restricting the provisions of the Bengal Tenancy Act would be fought in the Legislative Council, and that as far as possible the Committee’s suggestion should aim at liberalising the Act and not restricting it.

('16', 35, 0, 1, 83165) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 35, 1, 2, 83206) the rent rendered at the settlement and revise it, if necessary.

('16', 35, 2, 6, 83700) Mr. Adami was asked to draft a paragraph embodying these decisions to go at the end of paragraph 24 of the report.

('16', 35, 3, 8, 84052) Mr. Adami
('16', 35, 4, 9, 84062) said that this would take a long time.

('16', 35, 5, 12, 84406) the past the planter had already got sufficient compensation.
('16', 35, 5, 13, 84468) He thought that Mr. Gandhi by this request was going back to his original case that there should be no tribunal.

('16', 35, 5, 16, 84886) Mr. Gandhi said that even if Government found that the equities were in favour of the case, they would appoint a tribunal because as the President had said before, they could not take on themselves the responsibility of passing an arbitrary executive order.
('16', 35, 5, 17, 85144) Mr. Adami said that he thought the widest discretion should be given to the tribunal.
('16', 35, 5, 18, 85230) Mr. Rainy pointed out that the Turkaulia case had been fought largely on the point of coercion and that this might be raised in sharahbeshi cases that came before the tribunal.
('16', 35, 5, 19, 85407) The tribunal, however, was also to deal with cases where sharahbeshi had not been taken, but
('16', 35, 6, 20, 85500) where applications had been made for the obligation to be commuted.
('16', 35, 6, 21, 85568) If the tribunal allowed an enhancement of rent in the latter case, why should they not do so in the former case even when the agreement was void on account of coercion?
('16', 35, 6, 22, 85737) He did not consider, therefore, that the question of coercion came in to any great extent.
('16', 35, 6, 23, 85828) It was to provide for cases of this sort that he proposed that the tribunal should consider anything that they thought relevant.

('16', 35, 6, 25, 86021) The President said presumably Government would pay the cost and enquired of Mr. Gandhi if he could say how long the tribunal would take.
('16', 35, 6, 26, 86158) Mr. Gandhi said he thought it would take at least a month in the most favourable circumstances.
('16', 35, 6, 27, 86254) Mr. Adami thought it would take much longer.
('16', 35, 7, 28, 86299) As regards the printed evidence, Mr. Gandhi said that he wanted the enclosures

('16', 36, 3, 7, 86670) objected to this.

('16', 36, 3, 11, 86976) The President said that that would make a very bulky record.
('16', 36, 3, 12, 87037) The judgements were all public documents and he did not think it more necessary to print them than it was to print Government records that had been placed before them.
('16', 36, 3, 13, 87205) Mr. Gandhi said he thought that Mr. Gourlay’s report should be printed.
('16', 36, 3, 14, 87277) The President said that was a matter for the Government to decide.
('16', 36, 3, 15, 87344) Mr. Gandhi said his idea in wanting these documents printed was that he could refer to them in his report.
('16', 36, 3, 16, 87451) The President pointed out that Mr. Gandhi could refer to them, although they were not printed.
('16', 36, 4, 17, 87546) The meeting then adjourned.
