('16', 36, 7, 19, 87638) 19. LETTER TO THE PRESS ON THIRD CLASS TRAVELLING ON INDIAN RAILWAYS 1
('16', 36, 8, 20, 87709) RANCHI, September 25, 1917
('16', 36, 9, 21, 87736) TO THE EDITOR THE LEADER
('16', 36, 10, 22, 87761) SIR, I have now been in India for over two years and a half after my return from South Africa.
('16', 36, 10, 23, 87856) Over one quarter of that time I have passed on the Indian trains travelling 3rd class by choice.
('16', 36, 10, 24, 87953) I have travelled north as far as Lahore, down south up to Tranquebar, and from Karachi to Calcutta.
('16', 36, 10, 25, 88053) Having resorted to third class travelling among other reasons for the purpose of studying the conditions under which this class of passengers travel, I have naturally made as critical observations as I could.
('16', 36, 10, 26, 88262) I have fairly covered the majority of railway systems during this period.
('16', 36, 10, 27, 88336) Now and then I have entered into
('16', 36, 11, 28, 88369) 1 A copy of this was sent by Gandhiji to the Secretary, Department of Commerce and Industries, Delhi, with a letter making practical suggestions for improvement; vide, “Letter to Commerce and Industries Secretary”, 31 10 1917.
('16', 37, 0, 1, 88596) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 37, 1, 2, 88637) correspondence with the management of the different railways about defects that have come under my notice.
('16', 37, 1, 3, 88744) But I think that the time has come when I should invite the Press and the public to join in a crusade against a grievance which has too long remained unredressed, though much of it is capable of redress without great difficulty.
('16', 37, 1, 4, 88973) On the 12th instant I booked at Bombay for Madras by the mail train and paid Rs. 13 9. It was labelled to carry 22 passengers.
('16', 37, 1, 5, 89100) These could only have seating accommodation.
('16', 37, 1, 6, 89145) There were no bunks in this carriage whereon passengers could lie with any degree of safety or comfort.
('16', 37, 1, 7, 89249) There were two nights to be passed in this train before reaching Madras.
('16', 37, 1, 8, 89322) If not more than 22 passengers found their way into my carriage before we reached Poona, it was because the bolder ones kept the others at bay.
('16', 37, 1, 9, 89466) With the exception of two or three insistent passengers, all had to find their sleep, being seated all the time.
('16', 37, 1, 10, 89579) After reaching Raichur the pressure became unbearable.
('16', 37, 1, 11, 89634) The rush of passengers could not be stayed.
('16', 37, 1, 12, 89678) The fighters among us found the task almost beyond them.
('16', 37, 1, 13, 89735) The guards or other railway servants came in only to push in more passengers.
('16', 37, 1, 14, 89813) A defiant Memon merchant protested against this packing of passengers like sardines.
('16', 37, 1, 15, 89898) In vain did he say that this was his fifth night on the train.
('16', 37, 1, 16, 89961) The guard insulted him and referred him to the management at the terminus.
('16', 37, 1, 17, 90036) There were during this night as many as 35 passengers in the carriage during the greater part of it.
('16', 37, 1, 18, 90137) Some lay on the floor in the midst of dirt and some had to keep standing.
('16', 37, 1, 19, 90211) A free fight was at one time avoided only by the intervention of some of the older passengers who did not want to add to the discomfort by an exhibition of temper.
('16', 37, 1, 20, 90375) On the way, passengers got for tea tannin water with filthy sugar and a whitish looking liquid miscalled milk which gave this water a muddy appearance.
('16', 37, 1, 21, 90527) I can vouch for the appearance, but I cite the testimony of the passengers as to the taste.
('16', 37, 1, 22, 90619) Not during the whole of the journey was the compartment once swept or cleaned.
('16', 37, 1, 23, 90698) The result was every time you walked on the floor or rather cut your way through the passengers seated on the floor, you waded through dirt.
('16', 37, 1, 24, 90839) The closet was also not cleaned during the journey and there was no water in the water tank.
('16', 37, 1, 25, 90932) Refreshments sold to the passengers were dirty looking, handed by dirtier hands, coming out of filthy receptacles and weighed in
('16', 38, 0, 1, 91061) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 39
('16', 38, 1, 2, 91106) equally unattractive scales.
('16', 38, 1, 3, 91135) These were previously sampled by millions of flies.
('16', 38, 1, 4, 91187) I asked some of the passengers who went in for these dainties to give their opinion.
('16', 38, 1, 5, 91272) Many of them used choice expressions as to the quality but were satisfied to state that they were helpless in the matter; they had to take things as they came.
('16', 38, 2, 6, 91432) On reaching the station, I found that the ghariwala 1 would not take me unless I paid the fare he wanted.
('16', 38, 2, 7, 91538) I mildly protested and told him I would pay him the authorized fare.
('16', 38, 2, 8, 91607) I had to turn passive resister before I could be taken.
('16', 38, 2, 9, 91663) I simply told him he would have to pull me out of the ghari or call the policeman.
('16', 38, 3, 10, 91746) The return journey was performed in no better manner.
('16', 38, 3, 11, 91800) The carriage was packed already and but for a friend’s intervention, I could not have been able to secure even a seat.
('16', 38, 3, 12, 91919) My admission was certainly beyond the authorized number.
('16', 38, 3, 13, 91976) This compartment was constructed to carry 9 passengers but it had constantly 12 in it.
('16', 38, 3, 14, 92063) At one place, an important railway servant swore at a protestant, threatened to strike him and locked the door over the passengers whom he had with difficulty squeezed in.
('16', 38, 3, 15, 92235) To this compartment there was a closet falsely so called.
('16', 38, 3, 16, 92293) It was designed as a European closet but could hardly be used as such.
('16', 38, 3, 17, 92364) There was a pipe in it but no water, and I say without fear of challenge that it was pestilentially dirty.
('16', 38, 4, 18, 92471) The compartment itself was evil looking.
('16', 38, 4, 19, 92512) Dirt was lying thick upon the wood work and I do not know that it had ever seen soap or water.
('16', 38, 5, 20, 92607) The compartment had an exceptional assortment of passengers.
('16', 38, 5, 21, 92668) There were stalwart Punjabi Mahommedans, two refined Tamilians and two Mahommedan merchants who joined us later.
('16', 38, 5, 22, 92781) The merchants related [about] the bribes they had to give to procure comfort.
('16', 38, 5, 23, 92859) One of the Punjabis had already travelled three nights and was weary and fatigued.
('16', 38, 5, 24, 92942) But he could not stretch himself.
('16', 38, 5, 25, 92976) He said he had sat the whole day at the Central Station, watching passengers giving bribes to procure their tickets.
('16', 38, 5, 26, 93093) Another said he had himself to pay Rs. 5 before he could get his ticket and his seat.
('16', 38, 5, 27, 93179) These three men were bound for Ludhiana and had still more nights of travel in store for them.
('16', 38, 6, 28, 93274) What I have described is not exceptional but normal.
('16', 38, 6, 29, 93327) I have got down at Raichur, Dhond, Sonepur, Chakardharpur, Purulia, Asansol
('16', 38, 7, 30, 93403) 1 Driver of the carriage
('16', 39, 0, 1, 93428) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 39, 1, 2, 93469) and other junction stations and been at the Mosafirkhana 1 attached to these stations.
('16', 39, 1, 3, 93556) They are discreditable looking places where there is no order, no cleanliness but utter confusion and horrible din and noise.
('16', 39, 1, 4, 93682) Passengers have no benches or not enough to sit on.
('16', 39, 1, 5, 93734) They squat on dirty floors and eat dirty food.
('16', 39, 1, 6, 93781) They are permitted to throw the leavings of their food and spit where they like, sit how they like, and smoke everywhere.
('16', 39, 1, 7, 93903) The closets attached to these places defy description.
('16', 39, 1, 8, 93958) I have not the power to adequately describe them without committing a breach of the laws of decent speech.
('16', 39, 1, 9, 94065) Disinfecting powder, ashes or disinfecting fluids are unknown.
('16', 39, 1, 10, 94128) The army of flies buzzing about them warns you against their use.
('16', 39, 1, 11, 94194) But a third class traveller is dumb and helpless.
('16', 39, 1, 12, 94244) He does not want to complain even though to go to these places may be to court death.
('16', 39, 1, 13, 94330) I know passengers who fast while they are travelling just in order to lessen the misery of their life in the trains.
('16', 39, 1, 14, 94447) At Sonepur flies having failed, wasps have come forth to warn the public and the authorities, but yet to no purpose.
('16', 39, 1, 15, 94564) At the Imperial Capital a certain 3rd class booking office is a Black Hole fit only to be destroyed.
('16', 39, 2, 16, 94665) Is it any wonder that plague has become endemic in India?
('16', 39, 2, 17, 94723) Any other result is impossible where passengers always leave some dirt where they go and take more on leaving.
('16', 39, 3, 18, 94834) On Indian trains alone passengers smoke with impunity in all carriages irrespective of the presence of the fair sex and irrespective of the protest of non smokers.
('16', 39, 3, 19, 94998) And this notwithstanding a bye law which prevents a passenger from smoking without the permission of his fellows in a compartment which is not allotted to smokers.
('16', 39, 4, 20, 95162) The existence of the awful war cannot be allowed to stand in the way of removal of this gigantic evil.
('16', 39, 4, 21, 95265) War can be no warrant for tolerating dirt and overcrowding.
('16', 39, 4, 22, 95325) One could understand an entire stoppage of passenger traffic in a crisis like this, but never a continuation or accentuation of insanitation and conditions that must undermine health and morality.
('16', 39, 4, 23, 95522) Compare the lot of the 1st class passengers with that of the 3rd class.
('16', 39, 4, 24, 95594) In the Madras case, the 1st class fare is over five times as much as the 3rd class fare.
('16', 39, 4, 25, 95683) Does the third class passenger get one fifth, even one tenth, of the comforts of his first class fellow?
('16', 39, 4, 26, 95788) It is but simple justice to claim that some relative proportion be observed between the cost and comfort.
('16', 39, 5, 27, 95894) 1 Passengers’ waiting rooms
('16', 40, 0, 1, 95922) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 41
('16', 40, 1, 2, 95967) It is a known fact that the 3rd class traffic pays for the ever increasing luxuries of 1st and 2nd class travelling.
('16', 40, 1, 3, 96084) Surely a third class passenger is entitled at least to the bare necessities of life.
('16', 40, 2, 4, 96169) In neglecting the 3rd class passengers, opportunity of giving a splendid education to millions in orderliness, sanitation, decent composite life, and cultivation of simple and clean tastes is being lost.
('16', 40, 2, 5, 96373) Instead of receiving an object lesson in these matters, 3rd class passengers have their sense of decency and cleanliness blunted during their travelling experience.
('16', 40, 3, 6, 96538) Among the many suggestions that can be made for dealing with the evil here described, I would respectfully include this: Let the people in high places, the Viceroy, the Commander in chief, the Rajas, Maharajas, the Imperial Councillors and others, who gene rally travel in superior classes, without previous warning, go through the experiences now and then of 3rd class travelling.
('16', 40, 3, 7, 96920) We would then soon see a remarkable change in the conditions of the 3rd class travelling and the uncomplaining millions will get some return for the fares they pay under the expectation of being carried from place to place with the ordinary creature comforts.
('16', 40, 5, 8, 97180) Yours, etc.,
('16', 40, 6, 9, 97193) M. K. GANDHI

('16', 42, 5, 12, 99577) 22. MINUTES OF CHAMPARAN COMMITTEE MEETING
('16', 42, 6, 13, 99620) RANCHI, September 26, 1917
('16', 42, 7, 14, 99647) The President said he had a talk with Mr. Hill on the previous day but found him obdurate.
('16', 42, 7, 15, 99738) Mr. Hill told him that he was certain that Mr. Irwin would not accept arbitration but probably Mr. Norman would.
('16', 42, 7, 16, 99851) Mr. Hill also said that he was sorry he had made any offer of reduction and would prefer to have the matter settled by a court.
('16', 42, 7, 17, 99979) It was not only a matter of money but of reputation.
('16', 42, 7, 18, 100032) The President thought that, in these circumstances, any idea of arbitration must be dropped, but the question arose as to whether it was worthwhile going on with arbitration in Mr. Norman’s case.
('16', 42, 7, 19, 100228) The difficulty was that two methods of settlement would be going on at the same time and two kinds of legislation would be necessary.
('16', 42, 7, 20, 100362) Mr. Rainy pointed out that it was open to Mr. Norman to have his case arbitrated separately apart from any recommendation of the Committee and he might be contented to do so without binding legislation.
('16', 42, 7, 21, 100565) Mr. Gandhi said that in Mr. Norman’s case, there would be no difficulty in giving effect to a settlement in his concern by consent.
('16', 42, 7, 22, 100697) The agreements could be registered village by village.
('16', 42, 7, 23, 100752) The President observed that it would be difficult to legislate for one concern only.
('16', 42, 7, 24, 100837) Mr. Adami said that this would not be necessary.
('16', 42, 7, 25, 100886) The legislation could be on the lines that either the parties could apply to the tribunal for settlement of rent or could go to arbitration, in which case it could be provided that the award should be given effect to by the tribunal.
('16', 42, 7, 26, 101120) There would be no need in this case to specify any particular concern in the legislation.
('16', 42, 7, 27, 101210) Mr. Gandhi said that it was doubtful

('16', 44, 1, 19, 107119) If it was put to him that if without prejudice he was prepared to offer more, it would be accepted and he might be inclined to agree to it.
('16', 44, 1, 20, 107259) He (Mr. Hill) was not prepared to accept what he regarded as a censure on his conduct except by a legally constituted tribunal.
('16', 44, 1, 21, 107387) It was not a matter of business but of conscience.

('16', 45, 2, 6, 108288) Mr. Reid raised the question as to whether the abolition of tinkathia should
('16', 45, 3, 7, 108365) not be made compulsory.
('16', 45, 3, 8, 108389) Mr. Gandhi said he thought the Legislative Council would not accept this, but in all probability the raiyats would apply for commutation
('16', 45, 4, 9, 108526) voluntarily.
('16', 45, 4, 10, 108539) Mr. Reid said he doubted if all of them would apply and it would be inconvenient to have one or two raiyats with the tinkathia obligation still attached.
('16', 45, 5, 11, 108693) The President said that he understood that His Honour was in favour of having it abolished.
('16', 45, 5, 12, 108785) Mr. Gandhi said he saw legal difficulties but would be willing to accept the view that it should be abolished as a recommendation of the Committee.
('16', 45, 5, 13, 108933) The President pointed out that, on the one side, the raiyat was not to be allowed to enter into contract and it was reasonable, on the other side, that the raiyat should not be allowed to it even if he wanted it.
('16', 45, 5, 14, 109146) The raiyat was fully safeguarded because the tribunal
('16', 45, 6, 15, 109200) could not fix more than a fair rent.
('16', 45, 6, 16, 109237) He added that in Turkaulia, five per cent of the raiyats was still doing tinkathia which was one of the points on which Mr. Hill relied to prove his case.
('16', 45, 6, 17, 109392) Mr. Gandhi said that, when khushki indigo was grown on a large scale, as he hoped it would be, the raiyats, under the tinkathia obligation, would
('16', 45, 7, 18, 109538) soon find it to their advantage to commute.
('16', 45, 7, 19, 109582) Mr. Rainy pointed out that if the old system survived in any case, it might affect prejudicially the working of the new khushki system.
('16', 45, 7, 20, 109718) Mr. Gandhi said he would accept the recommendation as part of the
('16', 45, 8, 21, 109784) whole compromise but not if a tribunal was appointed.
('16', 45, 8, 22, 109838) In that case, the legislation would abolish the tinkathia obligation and leave the landlord the option of applying
('16', 45, 9, 23, 109953) for the settlement of additional rent as compensation if he wished.
('16', 45, 10, 24, 110021) The Committee then adjourned.

('16', 46, 1, 2, 110191) 23. FOREWORD TO “WHAT INDIA WANTS: AUTONOMY WITHIN THE EMPIRE”
('16', 46, 2, 3, 110254) September 27, 1917 1
('16', 46, 3, 4, 110275) I have read Mr. Natesan’s 2 booklet with the greatest pleasure.
('16', 46, 3, 5, 110339) It is a fine vade mecum for the busy politician and worker.
('16', 46, 3, 6, 110399) Mr. Natesan has provided him with a connected narrative of the movement of self government in a very attractive and acceptable form.
('16', 46, 3, 7, 110532) By reproducing in their historical sequence the extracts from official records, he has allowed them to speak for themselves.
('16', 46, 3, 8, 110657) The book is in my opinion a great help to the controversialist and the student of our present day politics who does not care to study musty blue books or has no access to them.
('16', 46, 3, 9, 110834) With reference to the joint scheme 3 of self Government, though I do not take so much interest in it as our leaders, I feel that from the Government stand point it must command their attention as a measure which has agitated the public mind as no other has, and I venture to think that there will be no peace in the country until the scheme has been accepted by the Government.

('16', 53, 5, 6, 123306) 32. SPEECH ON COW PROTECTION, BETTIAH 2
('16', 53, 6, 7, 123346) [About October 9, 1917] 3
('16', 53, 7, 8, 123372) I am thankful to the Gaurakshini Sabha and to you all for inviting me to lay the foundation stone of the gaushala 4 in this town.
('16', 53, 7, 9, 123502) For the Hindus, this is sacred work.
('16', 53, 7, 10, 123539) Protection of the cow is a primary duty for every Indian.
('16', 53, 7, 11, 123597) It has been my experience, however, that the way we set about this important work leaves much to be desired.
('16', 53, 7, 12, 123706) I have given some thought to this serious problem and wish to place before you the conclusions I have formed.
('16', 53, 7, 13, 123816) These days cow protection has come to mean only two things: first, to save cows from the hands of our Muslim brethren on occasions like the Bakr i Id 5 and, secondly, to put up gaushalas for decrepit cows.
('16', 53, 7, 14, 124022) We do not go the right way to work for protecting the cows against our Muslim brethren.
('16', 53, 7, 15, 124110) The result has been that these two great communities of India are always at odds with each other and cherish mutual distrust.
('16', 53, 7, 16, 124236) Occasionally, they even fight.
('16', 53, 7, 17, 124267) The riot at Shahabad a few days ago bears out my statement.
('16', 53, 7, 18, 124327) The problem calls for some serious thinking on the part of both the communities.
('16', 53, 7, 19, 124408) Hundreds of Hindu friends indulged in rioting and looted the property of innocent Muslims.
('16', 53, 7, 20, 124499) What virtue could there be in this ?
('16', 53, 7, 21, 124536) In fact, it was a very sinful thing to do.
('16', 53, 7, 22, 124579) The activities of the Gaurakshini Sabha result in a far larger number of cows being killed than are saved.
('16', 53, 7, 23, 124686) Hinduism
('16', 53, 8, 24, 124695) 1 “Salutations to the motherland !” This had become a national slogan ever since Bankim Chandra Chatterjee’s poem beginning with this phrase, in Anandmath, was adopted as a national song by the Indian National Congress.
('16', 53, 8, 25, 124915) 2 The meeting was held under the auspices of the Gaurakshini Sabha at Bettiah, a small town in the Champaran district of Bihar, about 25 miles from Motihari.
('16', 53, 8, 26, 125073) 3 The date is inferred from the reference, in the speech, to the communal riots in Shahabad, Bihar, which occurred between September 28 and October 9. 4 Institution for care of infirm and disabled cows 5 A Muslim festival
('16', 54, 0, 1, 125295) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 55
('16', 54, 1, 2, 125340) attaches special importance to non violence.
('16', 54, 1, 3, 125385) It is the very oppositeof religious conduct to kill a Muslim in order to save a cow.
('16', 54, 1, 4, 125470) If we wish the Muslims not to kill cows, we should bring about a change of heart in them.
('16', 54, 1, 5, 125560) We shall not succeed by force.
('16', 54, 1, 6, 125591) We should reach their hearts with prayer and entreaty and achieve our purpose by awakening their sense of compassion.
('16', 54, 1, 7, 125709) In adopting this course, we should take a pledge that, while seeking to protect the cows, weshall bear no ill will or malice towards Muslims or be angry with them or fight with them.
('16', 54, 1, 8, 125892) It is when we have taken up such a reassuring attitude that we shall be qualified to raise the matter with them.
('16', 54, 1, 9, 126005) It should be remembered that what we regard as sin is not seen in the same light by our Muslim brethren.
('16', 54, 1, 10, 126110) On the contrary, for them it is a meritorious act to kill cows on certain occasions.
('16', 54, 1, 11, 126195) Every person should follow his own religion.
('16', 54, 1, 12, 126240) If it were true that killing of cows was enjoined by Islam, India would have had no genuine peace any time; as I understand the matter, however, killing of cows on occasions like Bakr i Id is not obligatory, but Muslim friends imagine it their duty to do so when we seek to prevent them by force.
('16', 54, 1, 13, 126537) Be this as it may, I have no doubt in my mind that this problem can be solved only by tapascharya 1. The height of tapascharya on such occasions is to lay down one’s life for the sake of cows.
('16', 54, 1, 14, 126730) However, all Hindus are not qualified for such supreme tapascharya.
('16', 54, 1, 15, 126798) Those who want to stop others from sinning must be free from sin themselves.
('16', 54, 1, 16, 126875) Hindu society has been inflicting terrible cruelty on the cow and her progeny.
('16', 54, 1, 17, 126954) The present condition of our cows is a direct proof of this.
('16', 54, 1, 18, 127015) My heart bleeds when I see thousands of bullocks with no blood and flesh on them, their bones plainly visible beneath their skin, ill nourished and made to carry excessive burdens, while the driver twists their tails and goads them on.

('16', 57, 2, 13, 133465) We do not and cannot explain to our mothers anything of what we learn.

('16', 57, 2, 15, 133618) One will never find this sad state of affairs in an English family.
('16', 57, 2, 16, 133686) In England and in other countries where education is imparted through the mother tongue, students, when they return home, discuss with their parents what they learn at school; the servants in the home, and others too, become familiar with it.
('16', 57, 2, 17, 133929) Thus, the other members of the family also benefit from what the children learn at school.
('16', 57, 2, 18, 134020) We, on the other hand, leave behind in the school what we learn there.

('16', 57, 2, 22, 134366) No one who is guilty of it deserves to be called a patriot.

('16', 100, 3, 5, 239981) This idea finds no place at all in our schools.

('16', 100, 3, 12, 240829) It has accordingly been decided, in consultation with some educated gentlemen, to start a national school.
('16', 100, 3, 13, 240936) EDUCATION IN THE SCHOOL Education in the school will be entirely through the mother tongue.
('16', 100, 3, 14, 241028) It is surprising that, while among other nations the mother tongue enjoys pride of place, among us this place belongs to English.
('16', 100, 3, 15, 241158) This state of affairs is ultimately harmful to the people.
('16', 100, 3, 16, 241217) The President of the first Gujarat Educational Conference, too, expressed the view that the medium of education should be the mother tongue.
('16', 100, 3, 17, 241358) The Chairman of the Reception Committee was very emphatic in his speech that education should be through the mother tongue.
('16', 100, 3, 18, 241482) The matter was specifically mentioned in the Government dispatch of 1854. It is not easy to understand how, in spite of that, the basis of education was altered.
('16', 100, 3, 19, 241644) The dispatch said:
('16', 100, 4, 20, 241663) It is neither our aim nor our desire to substitute the English for the vernacular dialects of the country.
('16', 100, 4, 21, 241770) We have always been most sensible of the importance of the use of the languages, which alone are understood by the great mass of the population.
('16', 100, 4, 22, 241915) These languages, not English, have been, put by us in the place of Persian in the administration of justice and in the intercourse between the officers of the Government and the people.
('16', 100, 4, 23, 242101) It is indispensable, therefore,

('16', 101, 1, 2, 242318) that in any general system of education, the studio of vernaculars should be assiduously attended to.
('16', 101, 1, 3, 242420) And any acquaintance with improved European knowledge which is to be communicated to the great mass of the people whose circumstances prevent them from acquiring a high standard of knowledge and who cannot be expected to overcome the difficulty of a foreign language, can only be conveyed to them through one or other of these vernacular languages.
('16', 101, 1, 4, 242769) We look, therefore to the English language and the vernacular languages of India together as media for the diffusion of European knowledge, and it is our desire to see them cultivated in all schools in India of a sufficiency high class to maintain a school master possessing the requisite qualifications.
('16', 101, 1, 5, 243074) His Excellency Lord Chelmsford, the Viceroy, also gave an idea, in his address to the Conference of Directors [of Education] held in Delhi on February 22, of the harm that has resulted from English instead of the mother tongue having been assigned the chief place.
('16', 101, 1, 6, 243339) He asked where the British people would have been if they had had to receive their education through a foreign tongue.

('16', 101, 2, 12, 243965) Students endeavour to grapple with abstruse subjects through the medium of a foreign tongue and in many cases, thanks to their mediocre acquaintance with that tongue, have perforce to memorize their text books.
('16', 101, 2, 13, 244176) We criticize adversely this tendency to memorize but to my mind it reflects credit on the zeal of the student who, rather than abandon their quest for knowledge, memorize whole pages, whole books which they understand but imperfectly.

('16', 102, 3, 13, 246225) The pupils here will be trained in two occupations: (1) agriculture and (2) weaving.

('16', 102, 3, 16, 246457) In India, the foregoing occupations occupy the most important place and anyone who learns them will never have to go in search of a job.
('16', 102, 4, 17, 246594) Every pupil will be taught the means of preserving health and home remedies for common ailments.
('16', 102, 4, 18, 246691) The pupil’s physical training will receive no less attention than the education of his mind.

('16', 102, 6, 23, 247181) During the last year, Philosophy of History and Sociology will also be taught.
('16', 102, 6, 24, 247260) In Geography, the standard will not be inferior to what obtains in the schools at present.

('16', 103, 1, 2, 247393) In Astronomy, the elements of the subjects will be taught.
('16', 103, 1, 3, 247452) A study of Economics is also essential and will, accordingly, be provided for.
('16', 103, 1, 4, 247531) Some knowledge of law is useful to every person and provision will, therefore, be made for teaching it for practical purposes.
('16', 103, 1, 5, 247658) Drill has been introduced in the first year to provide recreation and exercise to the pupils.

('16', 103, 1, 10, 248176) Hence this aid to education will also be utilized as an integral part of the method.
('16', 103, 1, 11, 248261) India never knew the institution of examinations.
('16', 103, 1, 12, 248311) The method is of recent introduction.
('16', 103, 1, 13, 248349) It received no great importance in the dispatch of 1854. The system has lent itself to serious abuse, every subject being taught with an eye on the examination and the conviction firmly planted in the pupil’s mind that passing the examination was all that was necessary.
('16', 103, 1, 14, 248620) The teacher, too, has got into the habit of doing his work in the same spirit, as so much drudgery.
('16', 103, 1, 15, 248720) Hence any knowledge that is acquired is superficial.
('16', 103, 1, 16, 248773) Not a single subject is taught with thoroughness.
('16', 103, 1, 17, 248823) The following passage is worth quoting in this context:
('16', 103, 2, 18, 248879) In recent years, they [examinations] have grown to extravagant dimension and their influence has been allowed to dominate the whole system of education in India with the result that instruction is confined to the rigid frame of prescribed courses, that all forms of training which do not admit of being tested by a written examination are liable to be neglected, and that most teachers and pupils are tempted to concentrate their energies not so much on genuine study as upon questions likely to be set by the examiner.
('16', 103, 2, 19, 249399) Having regard to the view that examinations are quite undesirable, pupils in this institution will be tested periodically from two points of view—whether the teacher has made the right effort and whether the pupil has followed.
('16', 103, 2, 20, 249627) The pupil will be freed from the fear of examinations.
('16', 103, 2, 21, 249682) The tests will be held by the teachers of the school and by others familiar with the institution.
('16', 103, 2, 22, 249780) The expectation is that a pupil who has attended the school for ten years will be as well

('16', 104, 1, 2, 249916) equipped as the present day graduate.
('16', 104, 1, 3, 249954) In addition, he will have a practical knowledge of agriculture and weaving.
('16', 104, 1, 4, 250030) The use to which the student puts his abilities after leaving school will be the true measure of the worth of his education.
('16', 104, 1, 5, 250155) Every opportunity will be taken to rid his mind of the fallacious notion that the aim of education is to get employment.
('16', 104, 1, 6, 250276) At present, it is the general practice among business men to select for the better posts men who know English, and that from among those educated under the Government controlled system.
('16', 104, 1, 7, 250462) But they will have an alternative field for selection when scholars of this school go out on the completion of their studies.
('16', 104, 1, 8, 250588) The people will then have some idea of the effectiveness of the method of education followed here.
('16', 104, 1, 9, 250687) A businessman is not in love with a “degree”; his choice will fall on the efficient man.
('16', 104, 1, 10, 250776) If, after ten years of study, anyone wants to pursue a subject further, necessary arrangements for the purpose are left to the future.

('16', 125, 1, 4, 299902) A committee had been appointed in London to consider certain measures about the supply of indentured labour to Fiji and the other sister islands.

('16', 125, 1, 13, 300710) I come now to the last subject.
('16', 125, 1, 14, 300742) There are two methods of attaining one’s goal.
('16', 125, 1, 15, 300789) Satyagraha 1 and duragraha 2. In our scriptures, they have been described, respectively, as divine and devilish modes of action.
('16', 125, 1, 16, 300918) In satyagraha, there is always unflinching adherence to truth.
('16', 125, 1, 17, 300981) It is never to be forsaken on any account.
('16', 125, 1, 18, 301024) Even for the sake of one’s country, it does not permit resort to false hood.
('16', 125, 1, 19, 301101) It proceeds on the assumption of the ultimate triumph of truth.
('16', 125, 1, 20, 301165) A satyagrahi does not abandon his path, even though at times it seems impenetrable and beset with difficulties and dangers, and a slight departure from that straight path may appear full of promise.
('16', 125, 1, 21, 301364) Even in these circumstances, his faith shines resplendent like the midday sun and he does not despond.
('16', 125, 1, 22, 301467) With truth for sword, he needs neither a steel sword nor gun powder.
('16', 125, 1, 23, 301536) Even an inveterate enemy he conquers by the force of the soul, which is love.
('16', 125, 1, 24, 301614) Love for a friend is not put to the test.
('16', 125, 1, 25, 301656) There is nothing surprising in a friend loving a friend; there is no merit in it and it costs no effort.
('16', 125, 1, 26, 301761) When love is bestowed on the so called enemy, it is tested, it becomes a virtue and requires an effort, and hence it is an act of manliness and real bravery.
('16', 125, 1, 27, 301919) We can cultivate such an attitude
('16', 125, 2, 28, 301953) 1 Literally, “holding to truth”, pursuit of a right cause, a method of political agitation which found expression later in successive civil disobedience campaigns in India.

('16', 126, 1, 2, 302236) even towards the Government and, doing so, we shall be able to appre ciate their beneficial activities and, as for their errors, rather than feel bitter on their account, point them out in love and so get them rectified.
('16', 126, 1, 3, 302457) Love does not act through fear.
('16', 126, 1, 4, 302489) Weakness there certainly cannot be.
('16', 126, 1, 5, 302525) A coward is incapable of bearing love, it is the prerogative of the brave.

('16', 126, 2, 8, 302885) Love can fight; often, it is obliged to.
('16', 126, 2, 9, 302926) In the intoxication of power, man fails to see his error.

('16', 126, 2, 15, 303458) In the event, no bitterness develops between the satyagrahi and those in power; the latter, on the contrary, willingly yield to him.
('16', 126, 2, 16, 303591) They discover that they cannot command the satyagrahi’s obedience.
('16', 126, 2, 17, 303658) They cannot make him do anything against his will.

('16', 126, 2, 23, 304026) It is as true as an algebraic equation.
('16', 126, 2, 24, 304066) This satyagraha is India’s distinctive weapon.
('16', 126, 2, 25, 304113) It has had others but satyagraha has been in greater use.

('16', 126, 2, 29, 304393) Even as the eyelashes automatically protect the eyes, so does satyagraha, when kindled, automatically protect the freedom of the soul.
('16', 126, 3, 30, 304528) But duragraha is a force with the opposite attributes.

('16', 126, 3, 33, 304781) The strong are

('16', 133, 1, 2, 318655) 7. This Conference is of the view that the Sub divisional Officer of every district should have his residence, during the monsoon months, in the principal town of his division instead of at the district headquarters.
('16', 133, 1, 3, 318872) For some time past, the office of the District Deputy Collector of Dohad is shifted to Godhra during the monsoon months and this results in considerable hardship to the people of Zalod, Bhimdi, etc., and also puts them to heavy expense on transport.
('16', 133, 1, 4, 319122) This Conference therefore requests the Government that the said office should remain in Dohad as in former years.
('16', 133, 2, 5, 319236) 8. This Conference requests the Government of India to release all Indians, men and women, who had been detained for political reasons under the Defence of India Act and declares its view that the desire expressed by His Excellency the Viceroy to see peace prevail in India during Mr. Montagu’s visit here will be better realized if the detenus are released.
('16', 133, 3, 6, 319595) 9. In revenue matters as also for the maintenance of peace and order in his district, the Collector is at present dependent on the one sided reports of the Mamlatdar and the police and this often leads to serious errors in the administration of the district and injustice to the people.
('16', 133, 3, 7, 319882) This Conference therefore recommends to the Government that it appoint an advisory board of elected members for each district.
('16', 133, 3, 8, 320009) 10. Recently, some persons have set up, in disregard of the interests of the people, plants for the processing of milk and the Government has also been doing the same, with the result that people have to go without the nourishing items of milk and ghee in their food.
('16', 133, 3, 9, 320277) This Conference therefore suggests to the Government that such plants be closed forthwith.

('16', 134, 2, 3, 320743) November 5, 1917
('16', 134, 3, 4, 320760) MY DEAR BRETHREN, We are in the midst of those people, call them Dheds, Bhangis, Antyajas 2, or by whatever appellation you like.
('16', 134, 3, 5, 320890) Beside me there are lawyers and doctors, I believe, and other gentlemen; we have today joined hands with the so called backward classes; now we are sure to get swaraj.
('16', 134, 3, 6, 321058) (Hear, hear.) We, Hindus and Muhammadans, have become one; here we are in association with this Dhed community.
('16', 134, 3, 7, 321170) Do not suppose that that community belongs to a lower status; let the fusion take place between you and that community, and then you will be fit for swaraj.
('16', 134, 3, 8, 321327) We lost the right to swaraj before, because we committed a sin before God in treating this community with such neglect.
('16', 134, 3, 9, 321447) Why should we hesitate to touch the Antyajas?
('16', 134, 3, 10, 321493) It is not mentioned in any religious book that this community should not be touched, or treated as we are doing now.
('16', 134, 3, 11, 321610) It is a fallacy to give that community the lowest place in the scale of castes.
('16', 134, 3, 12, 321690) Where the union of hearts takes place, there, I am sure, God is present.
('16', 134, 3, 13, 321763) God is omnipotent, though some of us do not believe it.
('16', 134, 3, 14, 321819) Therefore, we quarrel among ourselves.
('16', 134, 3, 15, 321858) Where is the difference between us and this community?
('16', 134, 3, 16, 321913) There is the same heart, the same nose, the same tongue, the same feeling—everything the same.
('16', 134, 3, 17, 322008) (Cheers.) Where there is a divided heart, there Ramachandra cannot be.
('16', 134, 3, 18, 322079) There is no Imam.
('16', 134, 3, 19, 322097) (Laughter.) I do not know whether God was present at the political conference (Laughter.), but I am sure he is here.
('16', 134, 3, 20, 322214) (Hear, hear.) I have not come here to make a long speech; I came to set an object lesson.
('16', 134, 3, 21, 322304) (Hear, hear.) This lesson on social reform is not to be had elsewhere.
('16', 134, 3, 22, 322375) (Cheers.) Here is a vast assemblage.
('16', 134, 3, 23, 322412) It is like an ocean.

('16', 136, 3, 6, 325489) 51. A STAIN ON INDIA’S FOREHEAD
('16', 136, 4, 7, 325521) [GODHRA, After November 5, 1917]
('16', 136, 5, 8, 325554) That the untouchables are a separate class is a blot on India’s forehead.
('16', 136, 5, 9, 325628) The caste system is a hindrance, not a sin.
('16', 136, 5, 10, 325672) But untouchability is a sin, a great crime, and if Hinduism does not destroy this serpent while there is yet time, it will be devoured by it.
('16', 136, 5, 11, 325814) The untouchables must not be considered as falling outside Hinduism.
('16', 136, 5, 12, 325883) They should be treated as respectable members of Hindu society and should be assigned their varnas according to their vocations.
('16', 136, 5, 13, 326012) The varna system, as I have defined and described it, is not practised by Hinduism today.
('16', 136, 5, 14, 326102) Those who call themselves Brahmins have given up the pursuit of learning.
('16', 136, 5, 15, 326176) They have taken to various other occupations.
('16', 136, 5, 16, 326222) The same is true more or less of the other varnas.
('16', 136, 5, 17, 326273) As a matter of fact, owing to our subjection to foreign rule, we are all slaves and are, in the eyes of the Westerners, untouchables lower even than the Sudras.
('16', 136, 5, 18, 326434) Why does God permit this atrocity?
('16', 136, 5, 19, 326469) Ravana was a rakshasa, but this rakshasi 2 of untouchability is even more terrible than Ravana.
('16', 136, 5, 20, 326565) And when we worship this rakshasi in the name of religion, the gravity of our sins is further increased.
('16', 136, 5, 21, 326670) Even the slavery of the Negroes is better than this.
('16', 136, 5, 22, 326723) This religion, if it can be called such, stinks in my nostrils.
('16', 136, 5, 23, 326787) This certainly cannot be the Hindu religion, It was through the Hindu religion that I learnt to respect Christianity and Islam.
('16', 136, 5, 24, 326915) How then can this sin be a part of the Hindu religion?
('16', 136, 5, 25, 326970) But then what is to be done?
('16', 136, 5, 26, 326999) I shall put up a lone fight, if need be, against this hypocrisy.
('16', 136, 5, 27, 327064) Alone I shall undergo penance and die with His name on my lips.

('16', 147, 1, 2, 351670) 54. NEWS PAPERS
('16', 147, 2, 3, 351686) [Before November 14, 1917]
('16', 147, 3, 4, 351713) I promised the Editor a contribution for the Diwali 1 Number of Hindustan.
('16', 147, 3, 5, 351788) I find that I have no time to make good the promise, but, thinking that I must write something, I place before the readers my views on newspapers.
('16', 147, 3, 6, 351935) Under pressure of circumstances, I had to work in a newspaper office in South Africa and this gave me an opportunity to think on the subject.
('16', 147, 3, 7, 352077) I have put into practice all the ideas which I venture to advance here.
('16', 147, 3, 8, 352149) In my humble opinion, it is wrong to use a newspaper as a means of earning a living.
('16', 147, 3, 9, 352234) There are certain spheres of work which are of such consequence and have such bearing on public welfare that to undertake them for earning one’s livelihood will defeat the primary aim behind them.
('16', 147, 3, 10, 352431) When, further, a newspaper is treated as a means of making profits, the result is likely to be serious malpractices.
('16', 147, 3, 11, 352548) It is not necessary to prove to those who have some experience of journalism that such malpractices do prevail on a large scale.
('16', 147, 3, 12, 352677) Newspapers are meant primarily to educate the people.
('16', 147, 3, 13, 352731) They make the latter familiar with contemporary history.
('16', 147, 3, 14, 352788) This is a work of no mean responsibility.
('16', 147, 3, 15, 352830) It is a fact, however, that readers cannot always trust newspapers.
('16', 147, 3, 16, 352898) Often facts are found to be quite the opposite of what has been reported.
('16', 147, 3, 17, 352972) If newspapers realized that it was their duty to educate the people, they could not but wait to check a report before publishing it.
('16', 147, 3, 18, 353105) It is true that, often, they have to work under difficult conditions.
('16', 147, 3, 19, 353175) They have to sift the true from the false in but a short time and can only guess at the truth.
('16', 147, 3, 20, 353270) Even then, I am of opinion that it is better not to publish a report at all if it has not been found possible to verify it.
('16', 147, 3, 21, 353394) The reporting of speeches in Indian newspapers is generally defective.
('16', 147, 3, 22, 353465) There are very few who can take down a speech verbatim, so that speeches are generally found to be a mere hotchpotch.
('16', 147, 3, 23, 353583) The best thing to do would be to send the proofs of the reported speech to the speaker for correction and the paper should publish its own report of the speech only if the speaker does not correct anything in the proofs sent to him.

('16', 150, 2, 19, 360904) The idea, however, that spending time in a temple, unmindful of other tasks, is the furthest limit of selflessness is sheer superstition.
('16', 150, 2, 20, 361042) Likewise, to wait on men of holy life, who stand in no need of services from others, and to serve them in all manner of ways, is unwholesome for both parties and waste of one’s time.
('16', 150, 2, 21, 361225) To draw widows away from such activities and induce them to take up the task of serving India, work which will promote their ultimate good, is to help them to remarriage of the purest kind.
('16', 150, 2, 22, 361415) Why do not the educated women embark upon this mission?
('16', 150, 2, 23, 361471) Those of them who might think of doing so should themselves take the first lesson in the school of industry, namely, spin cotton and weave.
('16', 150, 3, 24, 361611) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI
('16', 150, 4, 25, 361638) [From Gujarati]

('16', 151, 4, 7, 362013) I have put there the best volunteer teachers from among those who have offered their assistance.

('16', 151, 5, 12, 362453) and another in the Tarkaulia Dehat, and I hope to open one in the Belwa Dehat, As this attempt is in the nature of an experiment, I do not want to open more than four or five schools, until some definite result is obtained.
('16', 151, 5, 13, 362677) I hope that I shall have the co operation of the local officials in an experiment which, I know, is full of difficulty, but which is fraught with important consequences if it becomes successful.

('16', 153, 1, 2, 365034) 59. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('16', 153, 2, 3, 365064) MOTIHARI, New Year’s Day, 1974 [November 15, 1917] 1
('16', 153, 3, 4, 365117) What shall I give you on this auspicious day?
('16', 153, 3, 5, 365163) I am trying to give you what you, I and many others lack.
('16', 153, 3, 6, 365221) If one has that, one has everything.
('16', 153, 3, 7, 365258) Only he who has it can give it.
('16', 153, 3, 8, 365290) If that is the truth, what can I give?
('16', 153, 3, 9, 365329) However, we may strive for it together.
('16', 153, 4, 10, 365369) Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal.
('16', 153, 5, 11, 365498) And though I have the gift of prophecy, and understand all mysteries, and all knowledge; and though I have all faith, so that I could remove mountains, and have not charity, I am nothing.
('16', 153, 6, 12, 365686) And though I bestow all my goods to feed the poor, and though I give my body to be burned, and have not charity, it profiteth me nothing.
('16', 153, 6, 13, 365824) Charity suffereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not, charity vaunteth not itself, is not puffed up, doth not behave itself unseemly, seeketh not her own, is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil; rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth in the truth; beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth all things.
('16', 153, 7, 14, 366162) Charity never faileth; but whether there be prophecies, they shall fail; whether there be tongues, they shall cease; whether there be knowledge, it shall vanish away.
('16', 153, 8, 15, 366329) For we know in part, and we prophesy in part.
('16', 153, 8, 16, 366375) But when that which is perfect is come, then that which is in part shall be done away.
('16', 153, 8, 17, 366462) When I was a child, I spake as a child, I understood as a child, I understood as a child, I thought as a child: but when I became a man, I put away childish things.
('16', 153, 8, 18, 366627) For now we see through a glass, darkly; but then face to face: now I know in part; but then shall I know even as also I am known.
('16', 153, 9, 19, 366757) And now abideth faith, hope, charity, these three; but the greatest of these is charity.

('16', 157, 1, 2, 373135) 62. LETTER TO J.L. MERRIMAN
('16', 157, 2, 3, 373163) MOTIHARI,
('16', 157, 3, 4, 373173) November 19, 1917
('16', 157, 4, 5, 373191) DEAR MR. MERRIMAN,
('16', 157, 5, 6, 373210) In the schools I am opening, children under the age of 12 only are admitted.
('16', 157, 5, 7, 373287) The idea is to get hold of as many children as possible and to give them an all round education, i.e., a knowledge of Hindi or Urdu and, through that medium, of Arithmetic, rudim ents of History and Geography, a knowledge of simple scientific principles and some industrial training.
('16', 157, 5, 8, 373571) No cut and dried syllabus has been yet prepared, because I am going along an unbeaten track.
('16', 157, 5, 9, 373664) I look upon our own present system with horror and distrust.
('16', 157, 5, 10, 373725) Instead of developing the moral and the mental faculties of the little children, it dwarfs them.
('16', 157, 5, 11, 373822) In my experiment, whilst I shall draw upon what is good in it, I shall endeavour to avoid the defects of the present system.
('16', 157, 5, 12, 373947) The chief thing aimed at is contact of the children with men and women of culture and unimpeachable moral character.
('16', 157, 5, 13, 374064) That to me is education.
('16', 157, 5, 14, 374089) Literary training is to be used merely as a means to that end.
('16', 157, 5, 15, 374152) The industrial training is designed to give the boys and girls who may come to us, an additional means of livelihood.
('16', 157, 5, 16, 374270) It is not intended that on completing their education, they should leave their hereditary occupation, viz., agriculture, but make use of the knowledge gained in the school to refine agriculture and agricultural life.
('16', 157, 5, 17, 374487) Our teachers will also touch the lives of the grown up people and, if at all possible, penetrate the purdah.
('16', 157, 5, 18, 374596) Instructions will, therefore, be given to grown up people in hygiene and about the advantages of joint action for the promotion of communal welfare, such as the making of village roads proper, the sinking of wells, etc.
('16', 157, 5, 19, 374816) And as no school will be manned by teachers who are not men or women of good training, we propose to give free medical aid, so far as is possible.
('16', 157, 5, 20, 374963) In Badharwa for instance, Mrs. Avantikabai Gokhalay who is a trained nurse and midwife and who, assisted by her husband, is in charge of the school, has already dispensed castor oil and quinine to scores of patients during the four days that she has been at work and visited several female patients.
('16', 157, 6, 21, 375263) If you desire any further information, I shall be only too glad to supply you with it.
('16', 157, 6, 22, 375350) My hope is that I shall be able to enlist in my work full co operation of the local authority.
('16', 157, 6, 23, 375445) I am opening another school
('16', 158, 0, 1, 375473) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 159
('16', 158, 1, 2, 375519) tomorrow near Shrirampur, about two miles from Amolwa.
('16', 158, 1, 3, 375574) Regarding the raiyats, complaints about documents, evidently the point I wished to make was not made by me.
('16', 158, 1, 4, 375682) I know that the raiyats can go to court about compulsion.
('16', 158, 1, 5, 375740) The difficulty is that they are neither trained nor organized enough for orderly work.
('16', 158, 1, 6, 375827) What is morally compulsion may not be compulsion in law.
('16', 158, 1, 7, 375884) My experience of the Champaran raiyat is that he is extremely unintelligent and is easily made to assent mentally to any proposition.
('16', 158, 1, 8, 376018) I hold, therefore, that the Government, as the guardian of such people, have to save them from their own ignorance.
('16', 158, 1, 9, 376134) I do not say that in the Saraiya case brought to your notice, any compulsion has been used.
('16', 158, 1, 10, 376226) I simply suggested that, in order that there might be no allegation of compulsion after such documents as I have referred to in my previous letter are signed, you might, if you deemed it proper, inquire about the contracts now offered to the raiyats for their signatures.
('16', 158, 3, 11, 376498) Yours truly, M. K. GANDHI
('16', 158, 4, 12, 376524) From the original signed by Gandhiji; also Select Documents on Mahatma Gandhi’s Movement in Champaran

('16', 159, 1, 2, 377379) 64. LETTER T0 J. L. MERRIMAN
('16', 159, 2, 3, 377408) MOTIHARI, November 22, 1917 DEAR MR. MERRIMAN, I went over to Bhitiharva on Tuesday last and opened a school there.
('16', 159, 2, 4, 377524) Mr. Soman, a public worker from Belgaum, and a B.A. LL.B., has been left in charge, and he will be assisted by Mr. Balkrishna, a young man from Gujarat.
('16', 159, 2, 5, 377677) Mrs. Gandhi will join them on the 24th.
('16', 159, 2, 6, 377717) Her work will be chiefly confined to moving among the women.
('16', 159, 2, 7, 377778) I was in Badharwa yesterday, and Mrs. Gokhalay and my son were just returning from a visit to a dying man.
('16', 159, 2, 8, 377885) They told me that the people in the District were woefully neglectful of the patients, and they believed that many preventible deaths must occur in the District for want of a simple observance of the rudimentary principles of hygiene.
('16', 159, 2, 9, 378120) I know that this will not come to you as news, because it is not a peculiar condition of the District in which Mrs. Gokhalay is working, or of Champaran, but it is a chronic condition among the peasantry of India.
('16', 159, 2, 10, 378334) I simply mentioned the incidents in order that, as soon as I have advanced a little more in my experiment, I may enlist your active sympathy and help in a Department in which all can meet without reserve.
('16', 159, 2, 11, 378539) Dr. Dev 1, who is a qualified and experienced surgeon and physician, and Secretary of the Servants of India Society came on Tuesday.
('16', 159, 2, 12, 378672) His services have been lent for this work by the Society.
('16', 159, 2, 13, 378730) He has come with three more volunteers including a lady from Prof.
('16', 159, 2, 14, 378797) Karwe’s Widows’ Home.
('16', 159, 2, 15, 378819) Dr. Dev will chiefly supervise the Medical Branch of the work.
('16', 159, 2, 16, 378882) I may state that I shall be away from Champaran for over a fortnight.
('16', 159, 2, 17, 378952) Babu Brijkishore Prasad will represent me in my absence.

('16', 160, 1, 2, 379550) 65. LETTER T0 CHANDULAL
('16', 160, 2, 3, 379574) MOTIHARI, Kartak Sud 8 [November 22, 1917]
('16', 160, 3, 4, 379617) BHAISHRI CHANDULAL,
('16', 160, 4, 5, 379637) I have your letter.
('16', 160, 4, 6, 379657) You have been keeping your vows well enough and they are good ones to take.
('16', 160, 4, 7, 379733) It is my conviction that one cannot build one’s character without the help of vows.
('16', 160, 4, 8, 379817) They are to a man what anchor is to a ship.
('16', 160, 4, 9, 379861) A ship without an anchor is tossed to and fro and finally broken on the rocks; without vows, human beings meet a similar fate.
('16', 160, 4, 10, 379988) The vow of truth includes all others.
('16', 160, 4, 11, 380026) How would a man who respects truth violate brahmacharya or steal anything?
('16', 160, 4, 12, 380101) “ Brahma alone is real; all else is non existent.” If this sutra 1 is true, knowledge of Brahma is implied in the observance of truth.
('16', 160, 5, 13, 380236) Non violence and truth are convertible terms.
('16', 160, 5, 14, 380282) This seems to be the idea behind the saying, “One must speak truth, truth that is agreeable.” 2 That is genuine truth which causes no pain, for that alone is non violent.
('16', 160, 5, 15, 380453) Truth may sound harsh but it can never result in suffering.
('16', 160, 5, 16, 380513) Our employment of truth may offend the other person, but his conscience will tell him that what was said about him was true and was said with the best of motives.
('16', 160, 5, 17, 380676) We are here interpreting truth in its widest connotation.
('16', 160, 5, 18, 380734) Truth does not mean merely being truthful in speech; the term “truth” means exactly the same thing as it does in the sutra about Brahma alone being true.
('16', 160, 5, 19, 380888) The English word “truth” also carries the same meaning.
('16', 160, 5, 20, 380944) I remember to have told you that you are not made to work for women’s education.

('16', 163, 1, 2, 384156) 68. SPEEGH AT ALIGARH 1
('16', 163, 2, 3, 384180) November 28, 1917
('16', 163, 3, 4, 384198) He gave his hearers to understand that the plea of benefit to the community would be of no avail to procure Home Rule unless unity prevailed among them.
('16', 163, 3, 5, 384351) In referring to the Arrah riots, he expressed contempt of the contemptible and detestable barbarism exhibited by the Hindus.
('16', 163, 3, 6, 384476) It was for the Hindus to mend the gap.
('16', 163, 3, 7, 384515) Hindu Mohammedan quarrels should be settled like those of [a] private family.
('16', 163, 3, 8, 384593) He made many references to the Ali brothers .
('16', 163, 4, 9, 384639) Bombay Secret Abstracts, 1917
('16', 163, 5, 10, 384669) 69. SPEECH AT ALIGARH COLLEGE 2
('16', 163, 6, 11, 384701) November 28, 1917
('16', 163, 7, 12, 384719) He said that he had hoped to visit the college in the company of the Ali brothers.
('16', 163, 7, 13, 384802) He had seen Aligarh working for the nation and the country, but the Mohammedans were not so absorbed in endeavouring to uplift their country as their brothers—the Hindus were.
('16', 163, 7, 14, 384978) He would like to see some, if not all, of the College students nation uplifters, such as Mr. Gokhale was.
('16', 163, 7, 15, 385084) He made a reference to his dress (white kurta, dhoti and topi) and said that it was the only suitable dress for Indians; the depressed class would listen to and consult persons dressed in the garb of ancient India more readily than they would those dressed in modern clothes....
('16', 163, 8, 16, 385363) Bombay Secret Abstracts, 1917
('16', 163, 9, 17, 385393) 1 On his arrival, Gandhiji was met by a large number of students at the railway station and taken in a procession to the Lyall Library Grounds where he spoke to about 2,000 people on Hindu Muslim unity.

('16', 163, 9, 20, 386016) Later, he went to Khwaja Abdul Majid’s house and from there to the station and left for Calcutta.

('16', 164, 6, 18, 387051) 71. SOME GENERAL SUGGESTIONS CONCERNING PLAGUE
('16', 164, 7, 19, 387098) NADIAD, December 6, 1917
('16', 164, 8, 20, 387123) HOW TO PREVENT 1T ?
('16', 164, 8, 21, 387143) 1. If one’s blood is pure, it has the power of destroying the germs of every type of disease.
('16', 164, 9, 22, 387237) 2. If, therefore, we maintain our body in a healthy state, thanks to the pure blood, it will remain well protected even in an epidemic of contagious disease.
('16', 164, 10, 23, 387395) 3. For maintaining purity of blood, one must eat simple food, in limited quantity and at fixed hours.
('16', 164, 10, 24, 387497) Any diet containing excessive fat or sugar, or cooked with spices, must be avoided.
('16', 164, 10, 25, 387581) One must eat nothing for at least three hours before bed time.
('16', 164, 10, 26, 387644) Air too is food.
('16', 164, 11, 27, 387661) 1 The first three pages of the letter are not available.
('16', 164, 11, 28, 387718) 2 Gandhiji was in Ahmedabad on December 4 and 5.
('16', 165, 0, 1, 387767) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 165, 1, 2, 387809) should not, therefore, sleep except in a house with proper windows and doors, and these should be kept open.
('16', 165, 1, 3, 387918) Nor should one sleep with one’s face entirely covered with the sheet.
('16', 165, 1, 4, 387988) If the head feels cold, one may wear a cap, but the face should always be left uncovered.
('16', 165, 1, 5, 388078) If the mouth is kept closed and air inhaled only through the nostrils, there is no risk of one’s feeling cold.
('16', 165, 1, 6, 388189) Water, too, must be clean.
('16', 165, 1, 7, 388216) It is an excellent practice always to drink water that has been boiled and strained through thick cloth.
('16', 165, 1, 8, 388321) The latter should be carefully washed every day.
('16', 165, 1, 9, 388370) And so, also, the inside of the water pot should be properly cleaned every day.
('16', 165, 1, 10, 388450) Every man or woman should have as much exercise daily as may be got by walking for two hours.
('16', 165, 2, 11, 388544) 4. Even a person who does all this and keeps healthy may have his blood affected if the home and its surroundings are not clean.
('16', 165, 2, 12, 388673) The doors and windows, the ceiling, the floor, the staircase—in short, every part of the house—should be kept perfectly clean.
('16', 165, 2, 13, 388800) For this purpose, such part of the house as can be washed should be washed properly and then allowed to dry.
('16', 165, 2, 14, 388909) Cobwebs, dust, straw and rubbish of every description should every day be carefully swept out of the house.
('16', 165, 2, 15, 389017) It should be ensured that no part of the house remains wet.
('16', 165, 2, 16, 389077) Carpets and floor coverings should be daily taken up [for dusting] and not left in their place day after day.
('16', 165, 2, 17, 389187) Doctors say that the plague spreads through fleas.
('16', 165, 2, 18, 389238) In a well swept house with plenty of air and light, fleas will hardly ever enter.
('16', 165, 2, 19, 389320) They say, too, that the disease spreads through rats.
('16', 165, 2, 20, 389374) One should, therefore, examine all the corners of the floor and the entire plastering and see that there are no holes anywhere.
('16', 165, 2, 21, 389502) This can be done easily enough, and at no expense.
('16', 165, 2, 22, 389553) It is because of our laziness that rats make their holes in our houses.
('16', 165, 2, 23, 389625) Keeping a cat in the house will prevent it from being so infested.
('16', 165, 3, 24, 389692) 5. But the most important cause of illness in India is the defective and extremely harmful methods we follow for answering calls of nature.
('16', 165, 3, 25, 389832) A large number of people do this in the open.
('16', 165, 3, 26, 389878) The excreta are not covered over with earth or otherwise, and this leads to the breeding of millions of flies every day.
('16', 165, 3, 27, 389999) They come into contact, first, with excreta and then with our body, food and clothes.
('16', 165, 3, 28, 390085) Several kinds of poisonous gases are generated by the excreta all the time and these pollute the air all round.
('16', 165, 3, 29, 390197) It is obvious that when air, which is men’s best food, is being thus continually polluted, they cannot maintain good health.
('16', 165, 3, 30, 390322) The filth in our latrines is equally or even more harmful.
('16', 165, 3, 31, 390381) For it is in our very homes.
('16', 165, 3, 32, 390410) If, therefore, we go out into the open, after
('16', 166, 0, 1, 390456) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 167
('16', 166, 1, 2, 390502) defecating we must cover the excreta with earth as people in other countries do.
('16', 166, 1, 3, 390583) Latrines should have arrangements for dry dust to be sprinkled in sufficient quantity every time after use.
('16', 166, 1, 4, 390691) The excreta should be collected in some sort of a bucket.
('16', 166, 1, 5, 390749) The refuse pit should be avoided altogether and all conduits should be closed up.
('16', 166, 1, 6, 390831) Urine and water should also be collected in the bucket.
('16', 166, 1, 7, 390887) If we did not cherish false notions in the name of religion, we would never tolerate such hellish filth.
('16', 166, 1, 8, 390992) The latrine should be so constructed as to permit the scavenger access to every part of it.
('16', 166, 1, 9, 391084) Unless these improvements are carried out, cities in India will never be free from infectious diseases.
('16', 166, 2, 10, 391188) 6. The air gets polluted also by reason of people urinating or spitting or throwing litter and other rubbish anywhere on the roads.
('16', 166, 2, 11, 391320) Doctors have discovered that germs spread even from the spittle of certain categories of patients, of tuberculous patients for instance, and infect others.
('16', 166, 2, 12, 391476) We must certainly consider what we do and where.
('16', 166, 2, 13, 391525) Millions of people in this country walk bare foot.
('16', 166, 2, 14, 391576) It is a sorry state of affairs that they have to walk on filth.
('16', 166, 2, 15, 391640) Our roads, our streets or the verandahs of our houses should be so clean that one would not hesitate to sit down or even sleep on them,
('16', 166, 3, 16, 391776) We would do well to do some careful thinking why it is that, in cities with an English population, the English localities are unaffected even when an epidemic of the plague is raging.
('16', 166, 3, 17, 391960) The reason is nothing else than the cleanliness of the place.
('16', 166, 3, 18, 392022) Maintaining cleanliness requires no money but merely intelligent care.
('16', 166, 4, 19, 392093) TREATMENT
('16', 166, 5, 20, 392103) 7. The plague will never spread to cities where these rules are carefully observed.
('16', 166, 5, 21, 392187) Let us now consider what should be done when it has actually broken out.
('16', 166, 5, 22, 392260) Whenever a case of plague is detected, one must search out rats and, if one finds any dead ones, they must be removed with a pair of tongs to a distant place and burnt with the help of hay or kerosene or buried in a deep pit far away from human habitation.
('16', 166, 5, 23, 392517) The place where a dead rat is found should be covered with live ashes and whitewashed, the room emptied of everything, swept clean and fumigated with neem leaves.
('16', 166, 5, 24, 392680) If the walls permit of being whitewashed, they should be.
('16', 166, 5, 25, 392738) If there are any rat holes, they should be opened up to make sure that there are no dead rats inside and then filled in.
('16', 166, 5, 26, 392859) Any holes elsewhere in the house should be treated in the same manner.
('16', 166, 5, 27, 392930) The doors and windows should be kept open and
('16', 167, 0, 1, 392976) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 167, 1, 2, 393018) plenty of light and heat let in; if the roofs are covered with country tiles, they should also be removed so as to let in air and light.
('16', 167, 1, 3, 393155) Having cleaned up the house in this manner, we should leave it empty and, if possible, live in tents or huts put up in the open.
('16', 167, 1, 4, 393284) We should avoid contact with other people in the town and even when shopping be careful not to touch the shopkeeper.
('16', 167, 1, 5, 393401) If in this way immediate remedial measures are taken, the plague will not spread further.
('16', 167, 1, 6, 393491) It will not affect other families in the same town or neighbouring towns through the families which have already been affected.
('16', 167, 1, 7, 393619) If, after 31 days outside, one finds that the infection has not spread elsewhere or that no dead rats are found in the unoccupied house, the family can return to it.
('16', 167, 2, 8, 393785) 8 In any town where a case of the plague has occurred, the other families should immediately inspect their own houses.
('16', 167, 2, 9, 393904) They should remove the household things outside and look for rats.
('16', 167, 2, 10, 393971) If they find any dead ones, they should leave the house and go to live outside as advised above.
('16', 167, 2, 11, 394068) Even if no dead rats are found, the house should be thoroughly swept and kept very clean afterwards.
('16', 167, 2, 12, 394169) It should be whitewashed.
('16', 167, 2, 13, 394195) If there are no arrangements for ventilation, the necessary structural improvements should be carried out.
('16', 167, 2, 14, 394302) Measures should also be adopted to maintain the utmost cleanliness in the surroundings.
('16', 167, 2, 15, 394390) If the neighbours’ houses are not clean, it should be seen to it that they are cleaned.
('16', 167, 3, 16, 394478) 9. Nothing should be done to put the patient into a fright.
('16', 167, 3, 17, 394538) No one except the person nursing him should be allowed to go near him.
('16', 167, 3, 18, 394609) He should be kept only in a room with plenty of air and light.
('16', 167, 3, 19, 394672) If there is a public hospital, he should be removed there.
('16', 167, 3, 20, 394731) All food should be discontinued.
('16', 167, 3, 21, 394764) If he has had no food for three hours at the time the symptoms of the plague are detected, he should be immediately given an enema.
('16', 167, 3, 22, 394896) He should be placed in a tub, filled with cold water, for two minutes or, if he prefers, for five minutes so that his legs and chest remain out of water, and the portion from the knees to the hips under water.
('16', 167, 3, 23, 395106) If he feels thirsty, he may be given as much as he needs of water that has been boiled, cooled, and filtered.
('16', 167, 3, 24, 395216) Apart from this, he should have nothing to eat, or even to drink.
('16', 167, 3, 25, 395282) If the head feels very hot, a mud poultice or a wet sheet pack should be applied to it.
('16', 167, 3, 26, 395370) Very likely, these measures will suffice to secure the patient against the risk of death.
('16', 167, 3, 27, 395460) If he survives the next day and if he feels hungry, he may be given lime juice or orange juice to drink, mixed with boiling water or cold water.
('16', 167, 3, 28, 395605) When the temperature has become quite normal, he may be started on
('16', 168, 0, 1, 395672) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 169
('16', 168, 1, 2, 395718) If there is a tumour, it should be treated with hot water poultice, which should be changed often.
('16', 168, 1, 3, 395817) A piece of thick cloth 1_ ft.
('16', 168, 1, 4, 395847) long and 9 in.
('16', 168, 1, 5, 395862) broad should be wetted with hot water and the water drained out, placing the cloth in a dry handkerchief.
('16', 168, 1, 6, 395968) The cloth should then be folded up into four layers and placed on the tumour, as hot as the patient can bear, and the tumour should be bandaged up.
('16', 168, 1, 7, 396116) The poultice should be changed after every 30 minutes.
('16', 168, 1, 8, 396171) In this disease, the patient’s heart grows very weak and he should, therefore, be given complete rest.
('16', 168, 2, 9, 396274) 10. The man attending on the patient should keep away from others and avoid any work which requires contacts with them.
('16', 168, 2, 10, 396394) To ensure his own safety, he should reduce his food to a minimum and otherwise be very careful of his health.
('16', 168, 2, 11, 396504) He should not worry at all.
('16', 168, 2, 12, 396532) If he feels constipated, he should take an enema to clear the intestines and live only on fruits.
('16', 168, 3, 13, 396630) 11. The patient’s clothes should not be washed in a river or at any other place where others’ clothes are washed.
('16', 168, 3, 14, 396744) They should be soaked in boiling soap water.
('16', 168, 3, 15, 396789) If they are very dirty, they should be burnt away.
('16', 168, 3, 16, 396840) The bedding, etc., should not be used by anyone else and, if clean enough, it should be dried in the sun daily for eight days, exposing both sides by turns to sunshine.
('16', 168, 3, 17, 397009) If one can afford it, one should have it burnt away.

('16', 168, 5, 19, 397106) 72. LETTER TO A. H. WEST
('16', 168, 6, 20, 397131) MOTIHARI, December 10, 1917
('16', 168, 7, 21, 397159) MY DEAR WEST, I have your important letter before me.
('16', 168, 7, 22, 397213) My view is that if you can turn out Indian Opinion only by removing to Town 1, you should suspend publication.
('16', 168, 7, 23, 397324) I do not like the idea of your competing for jobs or advertisements.
('16', 168, 7, 24, 397393) I think that when that time comes we shall have outlived our purpose.
('16', 168, 7, 25, 397463) I would rather that you sold out Phoenix and
('16', 168, 8, 26, 397508) 1 Durban; the paper was being printed at Phoenix.
('16', 169, 0, 1, 397558) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 169, 1, 2, 397600) you and Sam 1 were engaged in some other independent work.
('16', 169, 1, 3, 397659) If you can make of Phoenix something without the Paper, I shall like the idea.
('16', 169, 1, 4, 397738) But if you cannot even eke out a living from agriculture at Phoenix, Phoenix should be sold.
('16', 169, 1, 5, 397831) Hilda’s education can remain in your own hands.
('16', 169, 1, 6, 397879) Surely some drastic steps are necessary for a due fulfilment of one’s ideals.
('16', 169, 2, 7, 397957) If you cannot support yourself out of Phoenix with or without the Paper and cannot secure a decent job for yourself, I must find your maintenance from here.
('16', 169, 2, 8, 398114) You will then let me know how much you will require and for how long.
('16', 169, 2, 9, 398184) For I presume that you will try to secure work there.
('16', 169, 2, 10, 398238) I am quite willing to have Devi 2 here if she would come and even you if you could come alone for a time.
('16', 169, 2, 11, 398344) But I know that Mrs. Pywell 3 and perhaps Mrs. West too may not like the climate or the surroundings here.
('16', 169, 3, 12, 398451) If Manilal wants to try his hand at turning out a sheet himself at any cost, he may be allowed to do it.
('16', 169, 4, 13, 398556) This I know that the proposed attempt in Town must become a dismal failure.
('16', 169, 4, 14, 398632) We left it because we found it unworkable.
('16', 169, 4, 15, 398675) We have arrived at all the stages after careful deliberation and as they were found necessary.
('16', 169, 4, 16, 398770) Your methods cannot be those of ordinary business men.
('16', 169, 4, 17, 398825) You will soon tire.
('16', 169, 4, 18, 398845) Why try what is foredoomed to failure?
('16', 169, 4, 19, 398884) I would like to let Manilal have a hand if he will but try.
('16', 169, 4, 20, 398944) I am writing 4 to him.
('16', 169, 5, 21, 398967) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('16', 175, 1, 2, 407447) 79. LETTER T0 “INDIAN OPINION” 1
('16', 175, 2, 3, 407480) MOTIHARI, December 15, 1917
('16', 175, 3, 4, 407508) When I left South Africa, I had fully intended to write to my Indian and English friends there from time to time, but I found my lot in India to be quite different from what I had expected it to be.
('16', 175, 3, 5, 407707) I had hoped to be able to have comparative peace and leisure but I have been irresistibly drawn into many activities.
('16', 175, 3, 6, 407825) I hardly cope with them and local daily correspondence.
('16', 175, 3, 7, 407881) Half of my time is passed in the Indian trains.
('16', 175, 3, 8, 407929) My South African friends will, I hope, forgive me for my apparent neglect of them.
('16', 175, 3, 9, 408012) Let me assure them that not a day has passed when I have not thought of them and their kindness.
('16', 175, 3, 10, 408109) South African associations can never be effaced from my memory.
('16', 175, 3, 11, 408173) You will not now be surprised when I tell you that it was only today that I learnt from Indian Opinion to hand, about the disastrous floods.
('16', 175, 3, 12, 408314) During my travels I rarely read newspapers and I have time merely to glance at them whilst I am not travelling.
('16', 175, 3, 13, 408426) I write this to tender my sympathy to the sufferers.
('16', 175, 3, 14, 408479) My imagination enables me to draw a true picture of their sufferings.
('16', 175, 3, 15, 408549) They make one think of God and His might and the utter evanescence of this life.
('16', 175, 3, 16, 408630) They ought to teach us ever to seek His protection and never to fail in the daily duty before us.
('16', 175, 3, 17, 408728) In the divine account books only our actions are noted, not what we have spoken.
('16', 175, 3, 18, 408809) These and similar reflections fill my soul for the moment and I wish to share them with the sufferers.
('16', 175, 3, 19, 408912) The deep poverty that I experience in this country deters me even from thinking of financial assistance to be sent for those who have been rendered homeless.
('16', 175, 3, 20, 409070) Even one pie in this country counts.
('16', 175, 3, 21, 409107) I am, at this very moment, living in the midst of thousands who have nothing but roasted pulse or grain flour mixed with water and salt.
('16', 175, 3, 22, 409244) We, therefore, can only send the sufferers an assurance of our heartfelt grief.
('16', 175, 3, 23, 409324) I hope that a determined movement will be set on foot to render residence on flats exposed to visitations of death dealing floods illegal.
('16', 175, 3, 24, 409463) The poor will, if they can, inhabit even such sites regardless of consequences.
('16', 175, 3, 25, 409543) It is for the enlightened persons to make it impossible for them to do so.
('16', 175, 4, 26, 409618) The issues of Indian Opinion that acquainted me with the
('16', 175, 5, 27, 409675) 1 This was published under the caption “Advice to South African Indians”.
('16', 176, 0, 1, 409749) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 177
('16', 176, 1, 2, 409795) destruction caused by the floods gave me also the sad news of Mr. Abdul Gani’s 1 death.
('16', 176, 1, 3, 409883) Please convey my respectful condolences to the members of our friend’s family.
('16', 176, 1, 4, 409962) Mr. Abdul Gani’s services to the community can never be forgotten.
('16', 176, 1, 5, 410029) His sobriety of judgment and never failing courtesy would have done credit to anybody.
('16', 176, 1, 6, 410116) His wise handling of public questions was a demonstration of the fact that services to one’s country could be effectively rendered without a knowledge of English or modern training.
('16', 176, 1, 7, 410298) I note, too, that our people in South Africa are not yet free from difficulties about trade licences and leaving certificates.
('16', 176, 1, 8, 410425) My Indian experience has confirmed the opinion that there is no remedy like passive resistance against such evils.
('16', 176, 1, 9, 410540) The community has to exhaust milder remedies, but I hope that it will not allow the sword of passive resistance to get rusty.
('16', 176, 1, 10, 410666) It is our duty, whilst the terrible war lasts, to be satisfied with petitions, etc., for the desired relief, but I think the Government should know that the community will not rest until the questions above mentioned are satisfactorily solved.

('16', 176, 1, 13, 411114) We, who seek justice, must be above suspicion, and I hope that our leaders will not rest till they have purged the community of internal defects.
