('16', 178, 5, 8, 413735) 82. LETTER T0 REVENUE SECRETARY
('16', 178, 6, 9, 413767) MOTIHARI, December 19, 1917
('16', 178, 7, 10, 413795) TO THE SECRETARY GOVERNMENT OF BIHAR AND ORISSA REVENUE DEPARTMENT [PATNA
('16', 178, 8, 11, 413869) SIR,] I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter No.
('16', 178, 8, 12, 413935) 116 II T 44 R.T. of the 6th December 1917, enclosing copy of the Champaran Agrarian Bill and inviting my remarks thereon.
('16', 178, 8, 13, 414057) 3 I beg to submit as follows:— (1) With reference to Section 4, I observe that although both sub sections (a) and (b) apply to the same transaction, sub section (a) covers a wider area than sub section (b), I have not been able to conjecture any reason for it.
('16', 178, 8, 14, 414318) But I suggest that the wording of sub section (b) may be copied for sub section (a) and, therefore, the word “condition” occurring in the second line of sub section (a) be removed.
('16', 178, 8, 15, 414499) And the words “Section 3” occurring in line 3 thereof may be replaced by “sub section 2 of Section 3”.
('16', 178, 8, 16, 414602) (2) With reference to Section 5, I beg to state that the Commit tee’s recommendations cover contracts between landlords and raiyats, not their tenants as well as their tenants.
('16', 178, 9, 17, 414779) 1 An inmate of Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati 2 Kasturba Gandhi was working in a school at Motihari.
('16', 178, 9, 18, 414878) 3 Copies of the Champaran Agrarian Bill, after it had been referred to the Select Committee were forwarded by the Revenue Secretary to Gandhiji, the Bihar Land Holders’ Association and the Bihar Planter’s Association for opinion.
('16', 179, 0, 1, 415108) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 179, 1, 2, 415150) There are numerous cases in which raiyats enter into contracts with zamindars who are not their landlords.
('16', 179, 1, 3, 415257) It is necessary, therefore, to amend the wording “a tenant whether holding under him” occurring in line 2 thereof by saying “a tenant whether holding, under him or otherwise”, and by removing the words “grown upon the land of his tenancy or any portion thereof” occurring in lines 3 and 4 of the Section.
('16', 179, 1, 4, 415562) It is suggested that these last words are redundant.
('16', 179, 1, 5, 415615) It is intended that the Legislature should protect the raiyats in respect of all contracts as between zamindars and the raiyats concerning the sale of produce.
('16', 179, 1, 6, 415775) (3) With reference to Section 6, I fear that as it stands it is calculated to produce results the reverse of what is contemplated by the Government and the Committee.
('16', 179, 1, 7, 415942) Under sub section (1) thereof, an agent who is a mere straw may be put up by an unscrupulous landlord to collect abwab 1. Such an agent, if he is detected, will unhesitatingly suffer the penalties prescribed by the Section, as the landlord of the type mentioned by me will always make [it] worth his while to do so.
('16', 179, 1, 8, 416258) I, therefore, suggest that it is necessary in every case to make the landlord liable.
('16', 179, 1, 9, 416344) Sub section (1), therefore, should be amended by removing the words “or his agent” occurring in line 1 and by adding the words “whether directly or through an agent” after the pronoun “who” in the said line.
('16', 179, 1, 10, 416552) Sub section 3 of the said Section should be entirely removed.
('16', 179, 1, 11, 416614) It is possible for a poor ignorant raiyat to be in the right and yet be unable to prove his case.
('16', 179, 1, 12, 416712) It will be a gross injustice if such an innocent raiyat is punished.
('16', 179, 1, 13, 416781) Moreover, the existence of such sub section will act as an effective deterrent against any raiyats lodging a complaint about abwab.
('16', 179, 1, 14, 416913) It should be added that the power of punishing complainants for lodging false complaints is to be sparingly used.
('16', 179, 1, 15, 417027) It requires a highly trained judicial mind to arrive at a firm conclusion as to complaints being false.
('16', 179, 1, 16, 417131) It is, therefore, a dangerous thing to give summary powers to a Collector who will not be acting judicially.
('16', 179, 1, 17, 417240) Lastly, a single abortion of justice under sub section 3 is bound to result in an unscrupulous landlord being bolder in his exactions, for he will know that the raiyats after proceedings under sub section 3 will have been cowed down.
('16', 179, 1, 18, 417474) Considering all the above circumstances, I trust that the sub section in question will be removed.
('16', 179, 1, 19, 417573) If, however, it is found difficult to carry the amendments to
('16', 179, 2, 20, 417635) 1 Cesses assessed on land over and above the actual rent
('16', 180, 0, 1, 417692) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 181
('16', 180, 1, 2, 417738) Section 6 as proposed by me, I suggest that the whole of the Section be withdrawn.
('16', 180, 1, 3, 417821) I would far rather have the less effective protection of Section 75 of the Bengal Tenancy Act than have the doubtful protection of Section 6.
('16', 180, 2, 4, 417963) (4) I observe that cart sattas 1 dealt with by the Committee have been covered by the proposed law.
('16', 180, 2, 5, 418063) There are such sattas running into anything between 7 and 20 years with the same rate of payment throughout.
('16', 180, 2, 6, 418172) Several planters in reply to questions by the Committee not being able to justify the terms of their sattas said that they did not enforce them as a matter of fact.
('16', 180, 2, 7, 418337) I venture to suggest that there ought to be a section declaring such sattas to be void.
('16', 180, 2, 8, 418425) New sattas, if necessary for short periods, may be entered into after the rate of hire is fixed in consultation with the Divisional Commissi oner.
('16', 180, 2, 9, 418572) I may state, even at the present moment, proceedings for damages for breach of these sattas are pending.
('16', 180, 3, 10, 418677) I have read the correspondence in the Press carried on by Messrs Irwin 2 and Jameson 3 and I have read also the speeches delivered by Messrs Jameson and Kennedy 4 in the Council on the Bill.
('16', 180, 3, 11, 418868) Regarding both I wish merely to state that there is a complete answer to every one of the statements made by these writers and speakers.
('16', 180, 3, 12, 419005) I have refrained from saying anything about them for fear of unnecessarily burdening the Government.
('16', 180, 3, 13, 419106) But should any point raised by these gentlemen require elucidation from me, I shall be pleased to offer my views on any such point on hearing from you.
('16', 180, 4, 14, 419258) Select Documents on Mahatma Gandhi’s Movement in Champaran

('16', 183, 3, 7, 423735) 85. LETTER T0 AMBALAL SARABHAI
('16', 183, 4, 8, 423766) MOTIHARI, December 21, 1917
('16', 183, 5, 9, 423794) DEAR BHAI AMBALALJI, I do not wish to interfere with your business affairs at all.
('16', 183, 5, 10, 423877) However, I have had a letter from Krishnalal 1 today which leaves me no option but to write.
('16', 183, 5, 11, 423970) I think you should satisfy the weavers for the sake of Shrimati Anasuyabehn 2 at any rate.
('16', 183, 5, 12, 424061) There is no reason to believe that, if you satisfy these, you will have others clamouring.
('16', 183, 5, 13, 424152) Even if that should happen, you can do what you think fit then.
('16', 183, 5, 14, 424216) Why should not the mill owners feel happy paying a little more to the workers?
('16', 183, 5, 15, 424295) There is only one royal road to remove their discontent: entering their lives and binding them with the silken thread of love.
('16', 183, 5, 16, 424422) This is not beyond India.
('16', 183, 5, 17, 424448) Ultimately, the right use of money is to spend it for the country; if you spend money for the country, it is bound to yield fruit.
('16', 183, 5, 18, 424579) How could a brother be the cause of suffering to a sister?—and that, too, a sister like Anasuyabehn?
('16', 183, 5, 19, 424680) I have found that she has a soul which is absolutely pure.
('16', 183, 5, 20, 424739) It would be nothing strange if you took her word to be law.
('16', 183, 5, 21, 424799) You are, thus, under a double obligation: to please the workers and earn a sister’s blessings.
('16', 183, 5, 22, 424894) My presumption, too, is doubly serious; in a single letter I have meddled in your business and your family affairs.
('16', 183, 5, 23, 425010) Do forgive me.
('16', 183, 6, 24, 425025) Vandemataram from MOHANDAS GANDHI [From Gujarati] Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. IV

('16', 184, 1, 2, 425268) 86. LETTER T0 H. KALLENBACH 1
('16', 184, 2, 3, 425298) MOTIHARI, December 21, 1917
('16', 184, 3, 4, 425326) MY DEAR FRIEND,
('16', 184, 4, 5, 425342) I have been irregular of late.
('16', 184, 4, 6, 425373) I have been wandering so much that I never have the leisure to write love letters especially when they get lost.
('16', 184, 4, 7, 425486) From you I had had only three letters during the past three months.
('16', 184, 4, 8, 425554) Polak has however written to me about you and so has Miss Winterbottom 2. How often do I not want to hug you.
('16', 184, 4, 9, 425664) Daily do I have novel experiences here which I should like you to share with me.
('16', 184, 4, 10, 425745) But this monstrous War never seems to be ending.
('16', 184, 4, 11, 425794) All the peace talk only enhances the agony.
('16', 184, 4, 12, 425838) However, like all human institutions it must have an end, and our friendship must be a poor affair if it cannot bide its time and be all the stronger and purer for the weary waiting.
('16', 184, 4, 13, 426021) And what is this physical form after all?
('16', 184, 4, 14, 426063) As I was whizzing through the air yesterday and looking at the trees, I saw that beneath all the change that these mighty trees daily underwent, there was a something that persisted.
('16', 184, 4, 15, 426246) Every leaf has its own separate life.
('16', 184, 4, 16, 426284) It drops and withers.
('16', 184, 4, 17, 426306) But the tree lives on.
('16', 184, 4, 18, 426329) Every tree falls in process of time or under the cruel axe, but the forest of which the tree is but a part lives and so with us leaves of the human tree.
('16', 184, 4, 19, 426483) We may wither, but the eternal in us lives on, changeless and endless.
('16', 184, 4, 20, 426554) I derived much comfort last evening as I was thus musing.
('16', 184, 4, 21, 426612) The thoughts went on to you and I sighed, but I regained self possession and said to myself, “I know my friend not for his form but for that which informs him.”
('16', 184, 5, 22, 426773) With love,
('16', 184, 6, 23, 426784) Your old friend,
('16', 184, 7, 24, 426801) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('16', 184, 7, 25, 426847) Courtesy: Narayan Desai
('16', 184, 8, 26, 426871) 1 Hermann Kallenbach, German architect, sympathizer of the Indian cause in South Africa and a friend of Gandhiji.
('16', 184, 8, 27, 426985) He wanted to accompany Gandhiji to India in December 1914, but could not get a passport due to the War and was interned in England; vide An Autobiography, Part IV, Ch. ('16', 186, 3, 4, 429438) 90. RESOLUTION AT ALL INDIA SOCIAL SERVICE
('16', 186, 4, 5, 429481) CONFERENCE 1
('16', 186, 5, 6, 429494) CALCUTTA, December 30, 1917
('16', 186, 6, 7, 429522) That this Conference is of opinion that the measures adopted by the Government and certain associations for the education and elevation of the depressed classes have served the purpose of drawing public attention to the existence of degrading social inequality and to their detrimental influence on the general progress of the country.
('16', 186, 6, 8, 429858) But in the opinion of this Conference, the measures hitherto adopted are quite inadequate to meet these evils.
('16', 186, 6, 9, 429969) This Conference, therefore, urges upon the Government and Social Reform Bodies (1) to provide greater facilities for the education of the depressed classes, and (2) to enforce equality of treatment in all public institutions so as to remove the prejudice and disabilities of untouchableness.

('16', 188, 7, 12, 433009) 95. SPEECH AT UNIVERSITY INSTITUTE 3
('16', 188, 8, 13, 433046) CALCUTTA, December 31, 1917
('16', 188, 9, 14, 433074) .Mr. Gandhi regretted that there should be a lack of the understanding and knowledge of Hindi by Indians.
('16', 188, 9, 15, 433180) All were eager, he said, to do national service, but there could be no national service without a national tongue.
('16', 188, 9, 16, 433295) He regretted that his Bengali friends were committing national suicide by omitting to use their national tongue, without which one cannot reach hearts of the masses.
('16', 188, 9, 17, 433461) In that sense, the wide use of Hindi would come within the purview of humanitarianism.
('16', 188, 10, 18, 433548) 1 Vide the preceding item.

('16', 188, 10, 21, 433805) In deference to the wish expressed by the audience, he addressed them in English; this is a summary of the speech.

('16', 189, 0, 1, 433996) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 189, 1, 2, 434038) Mr. Gandhi next passed to another phase of humanitarianism, viz., sacrifice of animals before goddesses and slaughter for food.
('16', 189, 1, 3, 434166) The Hindu shastras do not really advocate animal sacrifice.
('16', 189, 1, 4, 434226) This current practice is one of the many things which have passed under the name of Hinduism.
('16', 189, 1, 5, 434320) The Hindu religion aptly finds expression in the two apphorisms—”Harmlessness is the best form of religion” and “There is no force higher than Truth”, and these principles are incompatible with the cruel practice of animal sacrifice.
('16', 189, 1, 6, 434554) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 2 1 1918
('16', 189, 2, 7, 434585) 96. ADDRESS AT ALL INDIA SOCIAL SERVICE CONFERENCE
('16', 189, 3, 8, 434636) CALCUTTA, December 31, 1917
('16', 189, 4, 9, 434664) Mr. Gandhi in taking the chair spoke as follows:
('16', 189, 5, 10, 434713) If I want to hear music, I must come to Bengal.
('16', 189, 5, 11, 434761) If I want to listen to poetry, I must come to Bengal.
('16', 189, 5, 12, 434815) India is contained in Bengal, but not Bengal in India.
('16', 189, 5, 13, 434870) I heard some Marwari boys singing songs.
('16', 189, 5, 14, 434911) It was like jargon.
('16', 189, 5, 15, 434931) I told them to associate with the Bengalis.
('16', 189, 6, 16, 434975) He then delivered the following presidential address.
('16', 189, 7, 17, 435029) FRIENDS.
('16', 189, 7, 18, 435038) I thank you for the honour you have conferred upon me.
('16', 189, 7, 19, 435093) I was totally unprepared for the invitation to preside over the deliberations of this assembly.
('16', 189, 7, 20, 435189) I do not know that I am fitted for the task.
('16', 189, 7, 21, 435234) Having fixed views about the use of Hindi at national gatherings, I am always disinclined to speak in English.
('16', 189, 7, 22, 435345) And I felt that the time was not ripe for me to ask to be allowed to deliver the presidential speech in Hindi.
('16', 189, 7, 23, 435456) Moreover, I have not much faith in conferences.
('16', 189, 7, 24, 435504) Social service to be effective has to be rendered without noise.
('16', 189, 7, 25, 435569) It is best performed when the left hand knoweth not what the right is doing.
('16', 189, 7, 26, 435646) Sir Gibble’s work told because nobody knew it.
('16', 189, 7, 27, 435693) He could not be spoiled by praise or held back by blame.
('16', 189, 7, 28, 435750) Would that our service were of this nature !
('16', 189, 8, 29, 435795) 1 This presidential address was to have been delivered at the opening session of the conference on December 27, which was postponed; vide “Speech at All India Social Service Conference”, 27 12 1917. Taking no notice of the postponement, however, New India published it in its issue dated December 28. Gandhiji presided over and addressed the conference in the Y.M.C.A. premises.
('16', 190, 0, 1, 436174) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 191
('16', 190, 1, 2, 436220) Holding such views, it was not without considerable hesitation and misgivings that I obeyed the summons of the Reception Committee.
('16', 190, 1, 3, 436352) You will, therefore, pardon me if you find in me a candid critic rather than an enthusiast carrying the conference to its goal with confidence and assurance.
('16', 190, 2, 4, 436510) It seems to me then that I cannot do better than draw attention to some branches of social service which we have hitherto more or less ignored.
('16', 190, 3, 5, 436654) The greatest service we can render society is to free ourselves and it from the superstitious regard we have learnt to pay to the learning of the English language.
('16', 190, 3, 6, 436818) It is the medium of instruction in our schools and colleges.
('16', 190, 3, 7, 436879) It is becoming the lingua franca of the country.
('16', 190, 3, 8, 436928) Our best thoughts are expressed in it.
('16', 190, 3, 9, 436967) Lord Chelmsford hopes that it will soon take the place of the mother tongue in high families.
('16', 190, 3, 10, 437061) This belief in the necessity of English training has enslaved us.
('16', 190, 3, 11, 437127) It has unfitted us for true national service.
('16', 190, 3, 12, 437173) Were it not for force of habit, we could not fail to see that, by reason of English being the medium of instruction, our intellect has been segregated, we have been isolated from the masses, the best mind of the nation has become gagged and the masses have not received the benefit of the new ideas we have received.
('16', 190, 3, 13, 437490) We have been engaged these past sixty years in memorizing strange words and their pronunciation instead of assimilating facts.
('16', 190, 3, 14, 437617) In the place of building upon the foundation, training received from our parents, we have almost unlearnt it.

('16', 197, 4, 5, 453794) [DEAR MR MAFFEY,] It grieves me to have to worry His Excellency in the midst of his many and onerous engagements.

('16', 197, 4, 13, 454788) I am sure that it is not a healthy feeling.

('16', 197, 4, 15, 454882) Discharge of the two brothers will, I am sure, greatly mitigate it.
('16', 197, 4, 16, 454950) It will not remove it entirely so long as the war lasts.
('16', 197, 4, 17, 455007) I had the privilege of supporting the resolution passed at the League about the release of the brothers.
('16', 197, 4, 18, 455112) 1 The audience were weeping whilst their mother’s address was being recited.
('16', 197, 4, 19, 455189) I am prepared to give due assurances to the Government about their future conduct.
('16', 197, 4, 20, 455272) I feel that, in order to be able to live a healthy public life, either the brothers should be discharged or should be properly tried and convicted.
('16', 197, 4, 21, 455420) I recognize the danger at the present moment of having a public trial and all it means.
('16', 197, 4, 22, 455508) But I am certain that the continued imprisonment is no less dangerous.
('16', 197, 4, 23, 455579) I therefore suggest that I should be allowed to go to Chindwara and visit the brothers.

('16', 199, 1, 2, 457326) 100. SPEECH AT AHMEDABAD MEETING 1
('16', 199, 2, 3, 457361) AHMEDABAD, January 1, 1918
('16', 199, 3, 4, 457388) We meet here today on a matter which is important because it is but an aspect of swaraj.
('16', 199, 3, 5, 457477) In saying this, we are guilty of no exaggeration.
('16', 199, 3, 6, 457527) Swaraj means rule over oneself.
('16', 199, 3, 7, 457559) A meeting which asks whether the Ahmedabad Municipality is able to manage its affairs well is surely a meeting in the cause of swaraj.
('16', 199, 3, 8, 457694) The subject to be discussed at this meeting has a bearing on public health.
('16', 199, 3, 9, 457770) Air, water and grains are the three chief kinds of food.
('16', 199, 3, 10, 457827) Air is free to all, but, if it is polluted, it harms our health.
('16', 199, 3, 11, 457892) Doctors say that bad air is more harmful than bad water.
('16', 199, 3, 12, 457949) Inhalation of bad air is harmful by itself and this is the reason we [sometimes] need change of air.
('16', 199, 3, 13, 458050) Next comes water.
('16', 199, 3, 14, 458068) We are generally very careless about it.

('16', 199, 3, 20, 458771) Under one of the sections of the [Municipal] Act, the Municipal Commissioner is appointed by the Government.

('16', 199, 3, 22, 459040) The larger the attendance at a meeting like this, discussing an issue of public importance, the weightier will be its protest.

('16', 202, 1, 2, 463764) 104. LETTER TO ESTHER FAERING
('16', 202, 2, 3, 463794) MOTIHARI, January 13, 1918 1
('16', 202, 3, 4, 463823) MY DEAR ESTHER, Having been wandering about, I have not been able to reply to your letters.
('16', 202, 3, 5, 463915) I was in Calcutta, thence went to Bombay and the Ashram and returned only yesterday.
('16', 202, 3, 6, 464000) I had varied experiences which I cannot describe for want of time.
('16', 202, 3, 7, 464067) To say that perfection is not attainable on this earth is to deny God.
('16', 202, 3, 8, 464138) The statement about impossibility of ridding ourselves of sin clearly refers to a stage in life.
('16', 202, 3, 9, 464235) But we need not search scriptures in support of the assertion.
('16', 202, 3, 10, 464298) We do see men constantly becoming better under effort and discipline.
('16', 202, 3, 11, 464368) There is no occasion for limiting the capacity for improvement.
('16', 202, 3, 12, 464432) Life to me would lose all its interest if I feel that I could not attain perfect love on earth.
('16', 202, 3, 13, 464528) After all, what matters is that our capacity for loving ever expands.
('16', 202, 3, 14, 464598) It is a slow process.
('16', 202, 3, 15, 464620) How shall you love the men who thwart you even in well doing?
('16', 202, 3, 16, 464682) And yet that is the time of supreme test.
('16', 202, 3, 17, 464724) I hope that you are now enjoying greater peace of mind.
('16', 202, 3, 18, 464780) Let your love for the Ashram be a source 2 of strength in your attempt to do your duty there.
('16', 202, 3, 19, 464874) 3 The Ashram is undoubtedly intended to teach us to do our assigned task with the utmost attention and with cheerfulness.
('16', 202, 3, 20, 464996) There is meaning in our wishes (however pure) not being fulfilled.
('16', 202, 3, 21, 465063) Not our will but His will be done.
('16', 202, 3, 22, 465098) I hope you are making progress in your Tamil lessons.
('16', 202, 3, 23, 465152) Did you receive from Messrs Natesan & Co.
('16', 202, 3, 24, 465194) a book they have brought out containing my speeches and writings ?
('16', 202, 3, 25, 465261) I am sending you a copy of my speech in Calcutta on Social Service.
('16', 202, 4, 26, 465329) With love.
('16', 202, 5, 27, 465340) Yours, BAPU My Dear Child, pp.

('16', 203, 1, 2, 465689) 105. LETTER TO CHIMANLAL CHINAIWALA
('16', 203, 2, 3, 465725) [MOTIHARI,] Posh Sud I [January 13, 1918]
('16', 203, 3, 4, 465767) BHAISHRI CHIMANLAL (CHINAIWALA), I have your letter.
('16', 203, 3, 5, 465820) It is our duty to help every class of workers.
('16', 203, 3, 6, 465867) I have no doubt about this.
('16', 203, 3, 7, 465895) I have little faith in what goes under the name of “co operation”.
('16', 203, 3, 8, 465962) I think our first task is to make a careful survey of the conditions of the working class.
('16', 203, 3, 9, 466053) What does the worker earn?
('16', 203, 3, 10, 466080) Where does he live?
('16', 203, 3, 11, 466100) In what condition?
('16', 203, 3, 12, 466119) How much does he spend ?
('16', 203, 3, 13, 466144) How much does he save ?
('16', 203, 3, 14, 466168) What debts does he incur?
('16', 203, 3, 15, 466194) How many children has he?
('16', 203, 3, 16, 466220) How does he bring them up?
('16', 203, 3, 17, 466247) What was he previously?
('16', 203, 3, 18, 466271) What brought about the change in his life?
('16', 203, 3, 19, 466314) What is his present condition?
('16', 203, 3, 20, 466345) It does not seem proper at all to start a co operative society straightway, without finding answers to all these questions.
('16', 203, 3, 21, 466469) It is necessary that we go into the midst of the working class.
('16', 203, 3, 22, 466533) If we do, we can solve a number of problems in a very short time.
('16', 203, 3, 23, 466599) For the moment, I should just advise you to mix with the workers and make yourself familiar with their condition.
('16', 203, 3, 24, 466713) More when we meet.

('16', 206, 5, 8, 470643) I see that I must revise the view that I took of Mr. Kennedy’s amendment 2 in my conversation with you.
('16', 206, 5, 9, 470747) I fear that his amendment will not meet the case if it is to cover the whole of section 3. I can accept Amendment marked A in place of clause 2, section 3. Mr. Kennedy’s proviso marked B by you is wholly unacceptable.

Section 5 subject to the amendment suggested by me in my letter to the Government, dated l9th December, is necessary to give effect to the other recommendation of the Committee beyond recognition of khuski 4 contracts.
('16', 206, 5, 11, 471262) My position is clear.
('16', 206, 5, 12, 471284) I would consider pledging of a tenant’s land for the growing of particular crops as a revival of tinkathia.
('16', 206, 5, 13, 471392) Mr. Kennedy’s effort, if I have understood him correctly, is devoted to securing such pledging.
('16', 206, 5, 14, 471488) Between these two extremes there is no meeting ground.
('16', 206, 6, 15, 471543) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI Select Documents on Mahatma Gandhi’s Movement in Champaran

('16', 207, 1, 2, 472183) 110. LETTER TO “THE STATESMAN”
('16', 207, 2, 3, 472214) MOTIHARI, January 16, 1918
('16', 207, 4, 4, 472241) THE EDITOR
('16', 207, 5, 5, 472252) THE STATESMAN [CALCUTTA]
('16', 207, 7, 6, 472277) Mr. Irwin’s latest letter published in your issue of the 12th instant 1 compels me to court the hospitality of your columns.
('16', 207, 7, 7, 472402) So long as your correspondent confined himself to matters directly affecting himself, his misrepresentations did not much matter, as the real facts were as much within the knowledge of the Government and those who are concerned with the agrarian question in Champaran, as within mine.
('16', 207, 7, 8, 472687) But in the letter under notice, he has travelled outside his jurisdiction as it were, and unchivalrously attacked one of the most innocent women walking on the face of the earth (and this I say although she happens to be my wife) and has unpardonably referred to a question of the greatest moment, I mean, the cow protection question, without taking the precaution, as behoves a gentleman, of ascertaining facts at first hand.
('16', 207, 7, 9, 473114) My address to the Gau Rakshini Sabha 2 he could have easily obtained upon application to me.
('16', 207, 7, 10, 473207) This at least was due to me as between man and man.
('16', 207, 7, 11, 473259) Your correspondent accuses me of “making a united attack on Saheb log (the landlords) who slaughter and eat cows daily”.
('16', 207, 7, 12, 473380) This presupposes I was addressing a comparatively microscopic audience of the planters’ ryots.
('16', 207, 7, 13, 473475) The fact is that the audience was composed chiefly of the non ryot class.
('16', 207, 7, 14, 473549) But I had in mind a much bigger audience, and not merely the few thousand hearers before me.
('16', 207, 7, 15, 473642) I spoke under a full sense of my responsibility.
('16', 207, 7, 16, 473691) The question of cow protection is, in my opinion, as large as the Empire to which Mr. Irwin and I belong.
('16', 207, 7, 17, 473797) I know that he is a proud father of a young lad of twenty four, who has received by his gallantry the unique honour of a colonelcy at his age.
('16', 207, 7, 18, 473940) Mr. Irwin can, if he will, obtain a greater honour for himself by studying the cow
('16', 207, 8, 19, 474023) 1 Irwin’s letter of January 8 was published actually on January 11; vide Appendix “W.S. Irwin’s Letter to The Statesman”, 8 1 1918. 2 Vide “Speech on Cow Protection, Bettiah” about October 9, 1917.
('16', 208, 0, 1, 474221) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 209
('16', 208, 1, 2, 474267) question and taking his full share in its solution.
('16', 208, 1, 3, 474319) He will, I promise, be then much better occupied than when he is dashing off his misrepr esentations to be published in the Press and most unnecessarily preparing to bring 2,200 cases against his tenants for the sake of deriving the questionable pleasure of deeming me responsible for those cases.
('16', 208, 1, 4, 474617) I said at the meeting that the Hindus had no warrant for resenting the slaughter of cows by their Mahomedan brethren, who kill them from religious conviction, so long as they themselves were a party to the killing by inches of thousands of cattle who were horribly ill treated by their Hindu owners, to the drinking of milk drawn from cows in the inhuman dairies of Calcutta, and so long as they calmly contemplated the slaughter of thousands of cattle in the slaughter houses of India for providing beef for the European and Christian residents of India.
('16', 208, 1, 5, 475173) I suggested that the first step towards procuring full protection for cows was to put their own house in order by securing absolute immunity from ill treatment of their cattle by Hindus themselves, and then to appeal to the Europeans to abstain from beef eating whilst resident in India, or at least to procure beef from outside India.
('16', 208, 1, 6, 475509) I added that in no case could the cow protection propaganda, if it was to be based upon religious conviction, tolerate a sacrifice of Mahomedans for the sake of saving cows, that the religious method of securing protection from Christians and Mahomedans alike was for Hindus to offer themselves a willing sacrifice of sufficient magnitude to draw out the merciful nature of Christians and Mahomedans.
('16', 208, 1, 7, 475910) Rightly or wrongly, worship of the cow is ingrained in the Hindu nature and I see no escape from a most bigoted and sanguinary strife over this question between Christians and Mahomedans on the one hand and Hindus on the other except in the fullest recognition and practice by the Hindus of the religion of ahimsa, which it is my self imposed and humble mission in life to preach.
('16', 208, 1, 8, 476291) Let the truth be faced.
('16', 208, 1, 9, 476315) It must not be supposed that Hindus feel nothing about the cow slaughter going on for the European.
('16', 208, 1, 10, 476415) I know that their wrath is today being buried under the awe inspired by the English rule.
('16', 208, 1, 11, 476505) But there is not a Hindu throughout the length and breadth of India who does not expect one day to free his land from cow slaughter.
('16', 208, 1, 12, 476638) But contrary to the genius of Hinduism as I know it, he would not mind forcing, even at the point of the sword, either the Christian or the Mahomedan to abandon cow slaughter.
('16', 208, 1, 13, 476814) I wish to play my humble part in preventing such a catastrophe and I thank Mr. Irwin for having provided me with
('16', 209, 0, 1, 476927) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 209, 1, 2, 476969) an opportunity of inviting him and your readers to help me in my onerous mission.
('16', 209, 1, 3, 477051) The mission may fail to prevent cow slaughter.
('16', 209, 1, 4, 477098) But there is no reason why by patient plodding and consistent practice it should not succeed in showing the folly, the stupidity and the inhumanity of committing the crime of killing a fellow human being for the sake of saving a fellow animal.
('16', 209, 1, 5, 477342) So much on behalf of the innocent cow.
('16', 209, 1, 6, 477381) A word only for my innocent wife who will never even know the wrong your correspondent has done her.
('16', 209, 1, 7, 477482) If Mr. Irwin would enjoy the honour of being introduced to her he will soon find out that Mrs. Gandhi is a simple woman, almost unlettered, who knows nothing of the two bazaars mentioned by him, even as I knew nothing of them until very recently and some time after the establishment of the rival bazaar referred to by Mr. Irwin.
('16', 209, 1, 8, 477812) He will then further assure himself that Mrs. Gandhi has had no hand in its establishment and is totally incapable of managing such a bazaar.
('16', 209, 1, 9, 477954) Lastly, he will at once learn that Mrs. Gandhi’s time is occupied in cooking for and serving the teachers conducting the school established in the dehat (interior) in question, in distributing medical relief and in moving amongst the women of the dehat with a view to giving them an idea of simple hygiene.
('16', 209, 1, 10, 478261) Mrs. Gandhi, I may add, has not learnt the art of making speeches or addressing letters to the Press.
('16', 209, 1, 11, 478363) As to the rest of the letters, the less said the better.
('16', 209, 1, 12, 478420) It is so full of palpable misrepresentations that it is difficult to deal with them with sufficient self restraint.
('16', 209, 1, 13, 478536) I can only say that I am trying to the best of my ability to fulfil the obligation I hold myself under, of promoting good will between planters and ryots, and if I fail, it would not be due to want of efforts on my part, but it would be largely, if not entirely, due to the mischievous propaganda Mr. Irwin is carrying on openly and some others sub rosa in Champaran in order to nullify the effect of the report published by the Agrarian Committee, which was brought into being— not as Mr. Irwin falsely suggests at my request—but by the agitation carried on, as your files would demonstrate, by Mr. Irwin and his friends of the Anglo Indian Association.
('16', 209, 1, 14, 479191) If he is wise, he will abide by his written word, voluntarily and after full discussion and deliberation, given by him at Ranchi.
('16', 209, 2, 15, 479321) Yours, etc.,
('16', 209, 3, 16, 479334) M. K. GANDHI The Statesman, l9 1 1918

('16', 210, 4, 5, 479489) I am dictating this letter to Mr. Desai as, owing to an acute pain in the left side, I am disinclined to do much writing.
('16', 210, 4, 6, 479611) What I want from you, if I can get it, is not a hastily written letter about the vernaculars, but a full, enthusiastic and eloquent plea for them which I can use for rousing the public to a sense of its duty in this matter.
('16', 210, 4, 7, 479835) Why should you have teaching [in] the vernacular and answers in English?
('16', 210, 4, 8, 479908) Why should every lad have to know English?
('16', 210, 4, 9, 479951) Is it not enough if some men are specially trained in English in each Province so that they may diffuse among the nation through the vernaculars a knowledge of new discoveries and researches?
('16', 210, 4, 10, 480143) So doing, our boys and girls will become saturated with the new knowledge and we may expect a rejuvenation such as we have never witnessed during the past sixty years.
('16', 210, 4, 11, 480311) I feel more and more that, if our boys are to assimilate facts of different sciences, they will only do so if they receive their training through the vernaculars.
('16', 210, 4, 12, 480474) No half measures will bring about this much needed reform.
('16', 210, 4, 13, 480533) Until we attain this state of things, I fear that we shall have to let the Englishmen think for us and we must continue slavishly to imitate them.
('16', 210, 4, 14, 480680) No scheme of self government can avert the catastrophe if it does not involve this much needed change.
('16', 210, 4, 15, 480783) If you feel with me, I want your letter expressing the above views in your own language.

('16', 213, 13, 18, 485844) 1 The Gujarat Sabha advised the Kheda farmers on January 10 to refrain from paying land revenue.
('16', 213, 13, 19, 485941) This was criticised by the Collector of Kheda district in a statement on January 14: “The Collector has full authority either to recover land revenue or to grant postponement, and I have issued my final orders only after a careful investigation of the crops in the district.
('16', 213, 13, 20, 486216) In some villages of the district, where I felt relief was necessary, I have issued orders giving postponement of a part of the land revenue.
('16', 213, 13, 21, 486357) Land holders must now, therefore, pay up their land revenue and the outstanding taqavi.
('16', 213, 13, 22, 486445) If, nevertheless, anyone influenced by the wrong advice which is being given to them refuses to pay up his land revenue dues, I shall be compelled to take stringent legal measures against him.” This was followed by a statement from the Government of Bombay on January 16, which supported the Collector’s action, questioned the locus standi of the Gujarat Sabha in Ahmedabad in advising the farmers of Kheda, described the issue of such advice as “thoughtless and mischievous” and asserted that the Government would not allow “any intervention in the normal work of the collection of land revenue dues” in the “rich and fertile district”.
('16', 213, 13, 23, 487083) On being telegraphically informed of this statement, Gandhiji sent this telegram to the Sabha.

('16', 220, 2, 3, 498673) MOTIHARI, Posh Sud 8 [January 20, 1918]
('16', 220, 3, 4, 498713) MAGANLAL, I am likely to have a battle royal over Mahomed Ali.
('16', 220, 3, 5, 498776) If India carries out my plan, the Government of India will be properly humbled.
('16', 220, 3, 6, 498856) Hindus and Muslims, never united, will become so, mother cow will be safe and we shall hear the triumph of non violence proclaimed all over the world.
('16', 220, 3, 7, 499007) Before all this comes to pass, however, I shall have to go through an ordeal myself.
('16', 220, 3, 8, 499092) A power which has till now brooked opposition from no Indian is sure to fight as if for its very life when defied by a handful of Indians.
('16', 220, 3, 9, 499231) Its fury then will be almost unbearable.
('16', 220, 3, 10, 499272) But I am resolved to face it all.
('16', 220, 3, 11, 499306) I mention this to remind you to be careful that in the storm that will follow we do not lose, whether in our wisdom or folly, the money that we have received for the Ashram.

('16', 220, 3, 16, 499764) My name in it should be replaced by yours.

('16', 220, 3, 18, 499909) Your plan of work has been chalked out.
('16', 220, 3, 19, 499949) You must devote yourself to weaving and agriculture.
('16', 220, 3, 20, 500002) You should so train Santok 1 that she may join you whole heartedly in this work.
('16', 220, 3, 21, 500083) Simultaneously with this and in order that you may succeed in it, you have to address yourself to the almost superhuman task of moulding Radha 2 and Rukhi 3 to be ideal girls.

('16', 220, 3, 23, 500324) Naturally enough, therefore, you will be daily advancing towards moksha, and so in this work your satyagraha and your patriotic services will find their consummation.
('16', 220, 3, 24, 500491) All the money we have is for these two activities and for the National School.
('16', 220, 3, 25, 500570) That will also continue to be the position in law.
('16', 220, 3, 26, 500621) The amounts that will be transferred to your name will not become your property, but will be treated as donations in aid of our activities.

('16', 222, 4, 5, 502955) 122. LETTER TO MESSRS LIENGIER & CO.
('16', 222, 5, 6, 502992) MOTIHARI (BIHAR), January 21, 1918
('16', 222, 6, 7, 503027) MESSRS LIENGIER & CO.
('16', 222, 6, 8, 503049) MADURA The method that I have adopted for reinstating those who have left off weaving is to supply them with yarn, at the lowest market rates, to buy out all the cloth they may manufacture, for cash, at the highest market rates, the yarn to be paid for in instalments, without interest, convenient to the weaver.
('16', 222, 6, 9, 503362) This has enabled them to earn at the rate of about Rs. 17 per month.
('16', 222, 6, 10, 503431) These weavers do not give their whole time to weaving and their manufacture is confined to the coarsest cloth.
('16', 222, 6, 11, 503542) They do not want to aspire higher and what they earn is enough for their wants.
('16', 222, 6, 12, 503622) But I know that a clever weaver manufacturing finer counts, with perhaps a little pattern work, can make twenty five rupees per month.
('16', 222, 6, 13, 503757) Every weaver lost to the country is, in my opinion, so much national waste, and every weaver reinstated is so much national gain.
('16', 222, 6, 14, 503887) Whatever the plan you may adopt, I would like you to keep me informed of your activity from time to time.
('16', 222, 7, 15, 503993) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('16', 222, 7, 16, 504039) Courtesy: Narayan Desai

('16', 223, 0, 1, 504347) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('16', 224, 2, 11, 507010) 125. LETTER T0 REVENUE SECRETARY
('16', 224, 3, 12, 507043) MOTIHARI, January 24, 1918 1
('16', 224, 4, 13, 507072) TO THE SECRETARY TO REVENUE DEPARTMENT THE GOVERNMENT OF BIHAR AND ORISSA The Hon’ble Rai Bahadur Purnendu Narayan Sinha 2 has supplied me with the papers given to him about the Champaran Agrarian Bill.
('16', 224, 4, 14, 507275) I note therein a memorandum submitted by the Champaran members of the Bihar Planters’ Association, 3 as also one from the managers of the Sirnie Concern.
('16', 224, 4, 15, 507429) These memoranda as also certain other papers call for a reply for the consideration of the Select Committee.
('16', 224, 4, 16, 507538) Before, however, offering my observations I wish to submit that, if it is at all the intention of the Government to make material alterations in the Bill, a representative on behalf of the raiyats should
('16', 224, 5, 17, 507742) 1 The original has 1917, which is obviously a misprint.
('16', 224, 5, 18, 507798) 2 Member of Bihar and Orissa Legislative Council.
('16', 224, 5, 19, 507848) He was also on the Select Committee to which the Champaran Agrarian Bill had been referred.
('16', 224, 5, 20, 507940) 3 This was on January 5. Vide Appendix “Memorandum of Bihar Planters’ Association”, 5 1 1918.
('16', 225, 0, 1, 508034) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 225, 1, 2, 508076) be appointed to the Council and should also be on the Select Committee.
('16', 225, 1, 3, 508148) And I feel that nobody is so capable of sufficiently representing these interests as Babu Brajkishore Prasad or myself, and I hope my submission will receive from the Government the attention it deserves.
('16', 225, 1, 4, 508353) In considering the provisions of the Bill, it is, in my humble opinion, of paramount importance for all concerned to remember that the Government have proclaimed to the raiyats their decision upon the Committee’s recommendations.
('16', 225, 1, 5, 508583) 1 It is respectfully suggested that the Bill is in fulfilment of the assurance issued to the raiyats in the said proclamation.
('16', 225, 1, 6, 508710) The Bill, therefore, does not admit of any alteration in any material respect.
('16', 225, 1, 7, 508789) As it is, owing to the acrimonious correspondence going on in the Press and all sorts of rumours set afloat by interested parties, the raiyats are becoming restive.
('16', 225, 1, 8, 508954) Bis dat qui cito dat applies in the present instance with peculiar force.
('16', 225, 1, 9, 509028) Any undue delay in passing the Bill may spell disaster.
('16', 225, 1, 10, 509084) I, therefore, urge that the Bill should be placed on the Statute book of the province as expeditiously as possible.
('16', 225, 1, 11, 509200) Coming to the examination of the papers in question, I shall first take the Champaran Planters’ memorandum.
('16', 225, 1, 12, 509308) Generally speaking, it is a paper containing a series of misrepresentations completely disentitling it to any weight being attached to it.
('16', 225, 1, 13, 509447) The memorandum states that the Agrarian Committee was “admittedly appointed to allay an artificial agitation”.
('16', 225, 1, 14, 509558) The fact is that it was appointed in answer to the agitation set up by the planters in expectation of the raiyats’ agitation being thereby stopped or suppressed.
('16', 225, 1, 15, 509720) I cite in support the following extract from the Pioneer, the leading organ of Anglo Indian opinion in the country.
('16', 225, 1, 16, 509836) In its issue of about the middle of May 1917, it said:
('16', 225, 2, 17, 509891) It appears to us that the Government of Bihar and Orissa would do well forthwith to appoint a commission to investigate the differences which exist between the planters and the raiyats in the Indigo districts.
('16', 225, 2, 18, 510101) It is difficult to see what good can come of Mr. Gandhi’s investigations.
('16', 225, 2, 19, 510175) But an enquiry conducted with strict impartiality by a commission containing possibly a non official element, would give both sides a fair opportunity of stating their case, and ought to result in a lasting peace.
('16', 225, 3, 20, 510389) 1 The orders of the Government were embodied in their resolution of October 18, 1917, which along with the Enquiry Committee Report was published in the Bihar and Orissa Gazette and in local languages for distribution among raiyats.
('16', 226, 0, 1, 510622) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 227
('16', 226, 1, 2, 510668) And by the beginning of June the Government of Bihar and Orissa decided to appoint the Champaran Agrarian Committee.
('16', 226, 1, 3, 510785) On the 8th of June, 1917, the Secretary 1 of the European Association addressed a letter to the Chief Secretary to the Government of Bihar and Orissa saying:
('16', 226, 2, 4, 510943) My Council observe with great satisfaction the decision of your Government to appoint a Committee to enquire and investigate into the relations between landlords and tenants in the Province of Bihar and Orissa.
('16', 226, 3, 5, 511154) The memorandum says that the raiyats’ agitation was, “artificial” and organized outside Champaran.
('16', 226, 3, 6, 511253) The fact is that it was and has been solely confined to Champaran and an agitation in which large masses of men took part could hardly be called an “artificial agitation”.
('16', 226, 3, 7, 511425) The memorandum says “the agitation was in no way the consequence of any widespread grievances”.
('16', 226, 3, 8, 511521) The Government’s own finding and the voluminous papers produced before the Committee by the Government completely contradict this statement.
('16', 226, 3, 9, 511662) It would hardly be dignified for me to notice the many uncalled for and groundless aspersions cast upon the Agrarian Committee.
('16', 226, 3, 10, 511790) I will now take up the various amendments to the provisions of the Bill proposed by the Champaran planters in the memorandum.
('16', 226, 3, 11, 511916) AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 3, CLAUSE (1): Nothing perhaps can surpass in recklessness the statement made in the memorandum that the Bill
('16', 226, 4, 12, 512048) proposes to abolish without compensation and for no adequate reason a system (tinkathia) which has been in existence for over a hundred years.
('16', 226, 5, 13, 512191) Such a statement is made in face of the fact that the Bill is designed to give partial and, in my opinion, inadequate relief from the extortionate compensation taken by the planter for ending a system when it had ceased to become a paying proposition to them.
('16', 226, 5, 14, 512451) One planter has even made a boast in the Press of the fact that he has taken Rs. 3,20,000 from his raiyats as tawan 2 and has made addition to his rent roll of an annual income of Rs. 52,000 by taking sharahbeshi 3. And there are several such planters.
('16', 226, 5, 15, 512704) The whole of the argument advanced in the memorandum
('16', 226, 6, 16, 512757) 1 Alec Marsh 2 Penalty 3 An increase in the rent
('16', 227, 0, 1, 512806) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 227, 1, 2, 512848) about the khushki system simply shows that the signatories desire a modified revival of tinkathia under the name of khushki.
('16', 227, 1, 3, 512973) By khushki I understand a contract voluntarily entered into by the raiyat to supply a particular produce to his landlord for a fair price to be mutually agreed upon.
('16', 227, 1, 4, 513139) Any clause in the contract binding the raiyat to grow a particular crop on the whole or a portion of his land or in a particular plot even selected by himself would immediately rob it of the voluntary nature, and the raiyat is deprived of the right to use his land as he chooses.
('16', 227, 1, 5, 513419) Such a clause would contravene the provisions of Section 23 read with Section 178 (3) (b) of the Bengal Tenancy Act.
('16', 227, 1, 6, 513536) The system of advances has in the past operated as a bait and as a snare.
('16', 227, 1, 7, 513610) A khushki contract should have nothing to do with the land of the raiyat.
('16', 227, 1, 8, 513684) It should only provide for the delivery by the raiyat to the planter of so much of indigo by weight at a rate mutually agreed upon.
('16', 227, 1, 9, 513816) The raiyat may produce the indigo on his own land or purchase it from others or get it from any other source.
('16', 227, 1, 10, 513926) Once his land is brought in the contract, the inevitable result will be that the same sense of obligation with which the growing of indigo has up to now been connected and which it is the desire of the Agrarian Committee and of the Government to remove, in the interest of the future peace of the district, will gradually creep in the mind of the raiyat and will in time overpower him.
('16', 227, 1, 11, 514312) It might be mentioned that the prime concern of the Legislature is not so much the prosperity or even the existence of an industry as the welfare of the raiyats.
('16', 227, 1, 12, 514474) If the raiyat is to be freed entirely from the baneful effects of tinkathia, the khushki system must (a) leave him free to obtain the particular crop he undertakes to supply where he likes and how he likes, his obligation being limited to supply the quantity agreed upon; (b) make the period of khushki contracts as short as possible; and (c) give him the market rate of the produce supplied by him.
('16', 227, 1, 13, 514874) The amendments (b) and (c) to Section 3(1) proposed in the memorandum, as they fail to satisfy the tests set forth above, are wholly unacceptable from the raiyats’ standpoint.
('16', 227, 1, 14, 515050) Coming to the amendment (a) to Section 3(1) proposed in the memorandum extending the period of termination of tinkathia, whether as an incident of tenancy or whether arising from sattas or agreements, to 1920, it is a most dangerous proposition and in breach of the undertaking of the three principal concerns referred to in the Committee’s report.
('16', 227, 1, 15, 515399) The Committee’s recommendation that it should stand abolished as from October 1917 is the one recommendation
('16', 228, 0, 1, 515508) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 229
('16', 228, 1, 2, 515554) which is already being acted upon.
('16', 228, 1, 3, 515589) Acceptance, now, of the proposal of the Champaran planters who have signed the memorandum, would reopen the sore and give rise to unthinkable result[s].
('16', 228, 1, 4, 515742) The proposal is designed virtually to nullify the effects of the Committee’s report and the Govern ment proclamation based thereon.
('16', 228, 1, 5, 515874) The chief reason for continuing the system is said to be that planters have already got seed and made arrangements for the future growing of indigo.
('16', 228, 1, 6, 516023) It must not, however, be forgotten that khushki is at their disposal and they can make use of the seed, machinery and everything under it.
('16', 228, 1, 7, 516162) It is true that real khushki will not give them that hold on the raiyats which the sattas do and will not give them the exorbitant profits, too, that they have hitherto received.
('16', 228, 1, 8, 516341) But they never had a right in equity to any such onesided advantages.
('16', 228, 1, 9, 516411) Consider [it] how we may, it is difficult to find a proper justification for continuing the system.
('16', 228, 1, 10, 516511) As to amendment (d) to Section 3(1) which seeks to continue the obligation until advances are repaid, I am sorry to find that even the Board of Revenue has fallen into the trap.
('16', 228, 1, 11, 516689) A moment’s thought will show that such a continuance may even lead to endless continuation of the obligation, to harassments and to [a] crop of law suits.
('16', 228, 1, 12, 516844) There will be nothing to prevent a planter from never asking a raiyat for a refund of the advance and thus an ignorant raiyat may for ever remain in serfdom.
('16', 228, 1, 13, 517002) I hope it will not be contended that the planter should have security for refund of the advances.
('16', 228, 1, 14, 517100) They do not need it.
('16', 228, 1, 15, 517121) The raiyats are their tenants and they have the fullest hold upon them for any financial obligation, and I cannot help saying that the proposed amendment is merely a device for keeping on foot the pernicious system as long as possible.
('16', 228, 1, 16, 517357) The whole of the soothing effect of the proposed legislation will be practically neutralized if the amendment in question is accepted and [it] will put Champaran in a ferment.
('16', 228, 1, 17, 517533) AMENDMENTS PROPOSED TO SECTION 4 “SHARAHBESHI”: The first amendment to this Section is based on a representation made by the managers of Sirnie Concern.
('16', 228, 1, 18, 517686) But the amendment as it is worded proposes to reopen the question of the rate of reduction to be allowed not only in the case of Sirnie but also of Jalha and Motihari Concerns.
('16', 228, 1, 19, 517863) There is absolutely no reason why the matter should be reopened.
('16', 228, 1, 20, 517928) Mr. Irwin of the Motihari Concern was party to the compromise.
('16', 228, 1, 21, 517991) As to the Sirnie case; I do not know that I am free to interpret the attitude of the Agrarian Committee in the matter.

('16', 230, 4, 9, 521220) DEAR DR.
('16', 230, 4, 10, 521229) KULKARNI, When I posted my last letter to you, I had read the literature [sent by] you, but for me it was not convincing enough to turn me from my experiment.
('16', 230, 4, 11, 521388) What you say is either true or untrue.
('16', 230, 4, 12, 521427) If salt is the panacea for all evils, no effort should be spared to double or even to quadruple its consumption.
('16', 230, 4, 13, 521540) What I require is statistics showing successful treatment of plague, etc., by the saline method.
('16', 230, 4, 14, 521637) Having read a great deal against the use of salt in books on vegetarianism, I wanted to make the experiment on myself.
('16', 230, 4, 15, 521756) Nearly 7 years ago Mrs. Gandhi was suffering from copious haemorrhage.
('16', 230, 4, 16, 521827) I was treating her with Kuhne baths and a strict dietary.
('16', 230, 4, 17, 521885) When I was almost in despair, I thought of the reasoning applied against salt by Mrs. Wallace and against pulses by Dr. Haig.
('16', 230, 4, 18, 522011) Salt, Dr. Wallace has argued, is an irritant and a stimulant.
('16', 230, 4, 19, 522073) Being inorganic it passes out without being assimilated, but in its passage making a great deal of mischief.
('16', 230, 4, 20, 522182) It unduly excites the salivary glands, irritates the stomach and thus induces men to eat more than they need, and taxing the organs unduly, it impoverishes the blood.
('16', 230, 4, 21, 522349) Both Mrs. Gandhi and I were, like most people, lovers of salt and ate large quantities of it.
('16', 230, 4, 22, 522443) I argued to myself that probably the introduction of salt in the system was responsible for the continuation of her illness.
('16', 230, 4, 23, 522568) I need not enter into the reasoning applied by me to the pulses.
('16', 230, 4, 24, 522633) I was myself at this time
('16', 230, 5, 25, 522659) 1 A week later Gandhiji met W. Maude, Member of the Executive Council, Government of Bihar and Orissa, and had a detailed discussion with him on khuskhi, sharahbeshi and related matters.

('16', 231, 1, 5, 523240) There was no other change made in the treatment.

('16', 231, 1, 10, 523755) During the seven years of my experiments, I have treated asthmatics and patients suffering from other lung diseases with a saltless diet, and they have almost invariably responded.
('16', 231, 1, 11, 523936) As for myself, I have not suffered from serious illnesses any more than those with whom I come in daily contact.

('16', 231, 1, 15, 524385) If I receive a wound, it heals more quickly than before.

('16', 231, 1, 21, 524769) My gums have become flabby and the few teeth I have left are more ornamental than useful.

('16', 231, 1, 23, 524930) Of course, there are so many other changes that I have made in my life that it is difficult to single out salt for my condemnation.
('16', 231, 1, 24, 525062) If I had not noticed this deterioration in me— if it is a deterioration—I should have, owing to the many other advantages I have experienced, very actively advocated a saltless diet.
('16', 231, 1, 25, 525245) If I received some enlightened assistance from you, I would like, if it be for a temporary period, to go back to salt and watch its results upon my system.

('16', 236, 2, 3, 534464) [MOTIHARI,] January 27, 1918
('16', 236, 3, 4, 534493) BHAISHRI MAVLANKAR, I have your letter about the Sabha’s draft reply to the Press Note on Kaira.
('16', 236, 3, 5, 534590) I like the first part of our reply.
('16', 236, 3, 6, 534626) The second part is as weak [as the first is good].
('16', 236, 3, 7, 534677) I am not bothering to revise it.
('16', 236, 3, 8, 534710) A stronger reply can be given to the Government’s contention that any body outside the Kaira District is not competent to do anything in matters relating to that district.
('16', 236, 3, 9, 534882) Whether or no that district was represented by any member on the Sabha, it is entitled to address the Government concerning any part of Gujarat.
('16', 236, 3, 10, 535027) It is even its duty to do so.
('16', 236, 3, 11, 535057) It was necessary to mention the names of the members of the Inquiry Committee.
('16', 236, 3, 12, 535136) It was not proper to have made a distinction between senior and junior officers; unwittingly, we seem to have admitted that the inquiry would have been more searching and fair if made by senior officers.
('16', 236, 3, 13, 535340) Our contention is that Government officers, from the very fact of being officers, inspire less confidence than experienced citizens who know their responsibility, for the officers are appointed to safeguard the interests of their class and they have a habit of rejecting anything that the people say.
('16', 236, 3, 14, 535641) Public workers, on the other hand, have no interest of their own to serve.
('16', 236, 3, 15, 535716) They are impartial and conscious that an error by them will not be passed over, they are more careful in conducting an inquiry.
('16', 236, 3, 16, 535844) We ought to have brought out all this very effectively.
('16', 236, 3, 17, 535900) In taking up this issue, our purpose is to educate [the people] and to show that we are as anxious for our prestige as the Government is for its.
('16', 236, 3, 18, 536046) The latter often seeks to uphold its prestige by the strength of its authority.
('16', 236, 3, 19, 536126) We should do ours merely by the justice of our actions.
('16', 236, 3, 20, 536182) A training to this end in every detail [of conduct] and a definite lead for the purpose will provide the people an excellent education in swaraj.
('16', 236, 3, 21, 536328) This is why I have concerned myself to offer all this criticism.
('16', 236, 3, 22, 536393) Another thing I should like to say is that, at a moment like this, timely action wins appreciation.
('16', 236, 3, 23, 536493) The Committee must immediately attend to the problem, setting aside all other work, if need be.
('16', 236, 3, 24, 536589) In short, the Committee can in no circumstances put off its duty.
('16', 236, 3, 25, 536655) It should have able members, men of responsibility, who can attend at any time.
('16', 236, 3, 26, 536735) If we are right in our cause, it involves the safeguarding of the interests of thousands of poor people.

('16', 240, 1, 2, 541621) 136. LETTER TO G. V. MAVLANKAR
('16', 240, 2, 3, 541652) [PATNA,] January 31, 1918
('16', 240, 3, 4, 541678) I can very well realize the moral dilemma in which you find yourself.
('16', 240, 3, 5, 541748) Damayanti found herself in difficulty only when she was face to face with several persons looking like Nala.
('16', 240, 3, 6, 541857) Real firmness is displayed in a situation of this kind.
('16', 240, 3, 7, 541913) That is no easy matter, however, and hence mistakes on such occasions are pardonable.
('16', 240, 3, 8, 541999) I can see the point in our collecting a hundred thousand rupees and paying the revenues from the amount, but the effort will have no effect on the Government.
('16', 240, 3, 9, 542158) I don’t see how our paying up the dues on behalf of the farmers can ever worry the Government.
('16', 240, 3, 10, 542253) On the other hand, auctioning their cattle will be a jaw breaking undertaking.
('16', 240, 3, 11, 542332) The purpose of satyagraha is not to save our face but to instil courage into the people and make them independent in spirit.
('16', 240, 3, 12, 542457) If, because of fear, or distrust of us, people lose heart and pay up, they but deserve to pay [compulsorily].
('16', 240, 3, 13, 542567) We, on our part, should exert ourselves still more to be worthy of their trust.
('16', 240, 3, 14, 542647) This is the royal road of satyagraha.
('16', 240, 3, 15, 542685) If I had a hundred thousand rupees, I would go from house to house telling people to let their cattle be auctioned, but not to borrow money to pay up the revenue dues.
('16', 240, 3, 16, 542853) At the auction I would use the money to bid for the people’s cattle and, in due time, return them to the owners who would have held out through a difficult time.
('16', 240, 3, 17, 543015) I would not tell the people that I intended to see their cattle safe.
('16', 240, 3, 18, 543085) As things are, if everything goes all right, the Government will practically have to apologize.
('16', 240, 3, 19, 543181) All this will appear as wisdom after the event and hence of little value.
('16', 240, 3, 20, 543255) Do what you think the situation demands from time to time.
('16', 240, 3, 21, 543314) I have the invaluable opportunity of watching your work from a distance and you, on your part, are discovering that no one in this world is indispensable.
('16', 240, 3, 22, 543469) [From Gujarati] Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. IV

('16', 242, 10, 18, 545961) Still, I must make it clear here that the responsibility of the notice 4 issued by the Gujarat Sabha lies on me.
('16', 242, 10, 19, 546074) I was at Ahmedabad before that notice was issued, where the matter of Kheda district was being discussed, when it was decided that the
('16', 242, 11, 20, 546209) 1 This was Gandhiji’s comment on being informed that Kasturba Gandhi had been enrolled as a member of the All India Women’s Association; vide “Fragment of Letter to Mrs. Jinarajadas”?
('16', 242, 11, 21, 546393) before 10 2 1918 2 The public meeting, largely attended by merchants and traders, was held at the Moolji Jetha Market.

('16', 243, 0, 1, 546804) 244 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 243, 1, 2, 546846) Gujarat Sabha ought to take part in the matter.
('16', 243, 1, 3, 546894) I think that, as regards this notice, a mountain has been made out of a molehill.
('16', 243, 1, 4, 546976) Everyone knew what the notice was when it was being framed.
('16', 243, 1, 5, 547036) Nobody then even dreamt that Government would misinterpret it.
('16', 243, 1, 6, 547099) The Sabha had with it sufficient data about the plight of the people.
('16', 243, 1, 7, 547169) They came to know that Government officials were collecting taxes and the people were even selling their cattle to pay the taxes.
('16', 243, 1, 8, 547299) The matter had come to such a pass, and, knowing this, the Sabha thought it better to issue a notice to console the people who braved these hardships.
('16', 243, 1, 9, 547450) And the notice was the result of that information, and I have every hope that, in the deputation that is going to wait on the Governor, the result of the deliberations will end in the success of the people.
('16', 243, 1, 10, 547657) If the Commissioner had not been angry with us, and had talked politely with the deputation that waited on him, and had not misinstructed the Bombay Government, such a grave crisis would not have eventuated, and we would not have had the trouble of meeting here this evening.
('16', 243, 1, 11, 547933) The Sabha’s request was to suspend the collection of dues till the negotiations were over.
('16', 243, 1, 12, 548024) But Government did not take this proper course and issued an angry Press Note.
('16', 243, 1, 13, 548103) It was my firm belief—and even now I firmly believe—that the representatives of the people and Government could have joined together and taken the proper steps.
('16', 243, 1, 14, 548264) I regret to have to say that Government has made a mistake.
('16', 243, 1, 15, 548324) Perhaps subordinate officers of Government would say to Government that the notice was issued not from a pure motive, but from some other ulterior motive.
('16', 243, 1, 16, 548479) If Government are impressed with this erroneous belief, those who have stood by the people, I hope, will continue to stand by them to the end and will not retreat.
('16', 243, 1, 17, 548643) Any responsible right thinking man could have given them the same advice.
('16', 243, 1, 18, 548717) People possess the same rights as the authorities have, and public men have every right to advise the people of their rights.
('16', 243, 1, 19, 548843) The people that do not fight for their rights are like slaves (“Hear, hear”), and such people do not deserve Home Rule.
('16', 243, 1, 20, 548963) 1 When authorities think that they can take anything from the people and can interfere, a difficult situation arises and if such a situation arises, I must plainly say that those who have given the people the right advice will stand by
('16', 243, 2, 21, 549199) 1 According to a report of February 10 in Prajabandhu, a Gujarati daily, Gandhiji here observed: “We should place our demands before the Government, even if we have to suffer in consequence.
('16', 243, 2, 22, 549390) India has followers of four different faiths and members of all of these—Hinduism, Islam, Zoroastrianism and Christianity—will need to employ satyagraha often enough.”

('16', 244, 1, 2, 549604) them till the end.
('16', 244, 1, 3, 549623) I have not yet come to any conclusion, and I sincerely trust that those who understand the responsibility will not hesitate to undergo hardships in order to secure justice.(Applause.) And in such an eventuality I hope you will not beat an ignominious retreat.
('16', 244, 1, 4, 549883) The first and the last principle of passive resistance is that we should not inflict hardships on others, but put up with them ourselves in order to get justice, and Government need not fear anything, if we make up our mind, as we are bent on getting sheer justice from it and nothing else.
('16', 244, 1, 5, 550174) To get that justice we must fight with the authorities, and the people that do not so fight are but slaves.
('16', 244, 1, 6, 550282) We can have only two weapons on occasions like this: revolt or passive resistance, and my request is for the second remedy always.
('16', 244, 1, 7, 550413) The right of suffering hardships, and claiming justice and getting one’s demands is from one’s birth.
('16', 244, 1, 8, 550515) Similarly, we have to get justice at the hands of the Government by suffering hardships.
('16', 244, 1, 9, 550604) We must suffer hardships like brave men.

('16', 246, 3, 4, 553751) DEAR MR. PRATT 2,
('16', 246, 4, 5, 553769) I have just been shown a few notices issued under the signature of the Mamlatdar of Kapadvanj Taluka stating that the plots of land referred to therein will be forfeited to the Government, if the parties notified do not pay the dues therein mentioned on or before the 11th instant.
('16', 246, 4, 6, 554051) The notices issued are dated the 2nd instant.
('16', 246, 4, 7, 554097) I have seen most of the parties who appeared to me to be perfectly respectable men fighting for what they consider to be their rights.
('16', 246, 4, 8, 554232) I understand, too, that some of the land referred to in the notices is sanadia land.
('16', 246, 4, 9, 554317) 1 hope that it is not the intention of the Government, whatever may be their ultimate decision, to take extreme and, what may be termed vindictive, measures.
('16', 246, 5, 10, 554475) I have also been shown a circular over the signature of the same Mamlatdar wherein ryots like those mentioned in the notices above referred to [are described] as dandia, meaning, I presume, rascals or loafers.
('16', 246, 5, 11, 554685) In my opinion the language of the circular is undignified and highly offensive.
('16', 246, 5, 12, 554765) I am sure that it is not the Government’s desire that in drafting Gujarati circulars ordinary rules of courtesy may not be observed by officials in charge of such duties.
('16', 246, 7, 13, 554936) Yours truly,

('16', 249, 2, 3, 559038) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 15, 1918
('16', 249, 3, 4, 559079) DEAR MR. PRATT, We were not able on Wednesday last to resume discussion of my complaint about unbecoming language used in Gujarati circulars.
('16', 249, 3, 5, 559221) l enclose copy of a public notice dated the 14th January over the Collector’s signature.
('16', 249, 3, 6, 559310) I have underlined what I have ventured to term undignified and offensive.
('16', 249, 3, 7, 559384) The underlined portion insults both the Secretaries 1 and those who have accepted their advice.
('16', 249, 3, 8, 559480) As I told you I do not think that the Collector had intended to use expressions which in the Gujarati language could not be used about respectable men.
('16', 249, 3, 9, 559632) You will find herewith enclosed a copy of a circular over the Mamlatdar’s signature.
('16', 249, 3, 10, 559717) I venture to suggest that the language of this circular is open to grave objection.
('16', 249, 3, 11, 559801) As to the anti dairy activity, I enclose herewith the circular which is being printed specially for distribution.
('16', 249, 3, 12, 559915) You will notice that it covers the whole ground.
('16', 249, 3, 13, 559964) There is a slight misunderstanding in your letter.
('16', 249, 3, 14, 560015) I have not confined my attention to the milk supply to the infants of the sellers only, but my attention extends to the public at large.
('16', 249, 3, 15, 560152) In my opinion milk supplied to the dairies is so much milk taken away from the infants’ mouths.
('16', 249, 3, 16, 560248) Could you give me some details as to the coercion alleged to have been used by some people against milk sellers intending to deal with the dairies?
('16', 249, 3, 17, 560396) If I knew the villages and perhaps the names of the offenders 1 would try to reach them.
('16', 249, 3, 18, 560485) As for the forfeiture notices 1 would venture to say this.
('16', 249, 3, 19, 560544) To confiscate land worth several thousand rupees’ assessment is, in my opinion, a punishment out of all proportion to the default and can therefore only be termed vindictive.
('16', 249, 3, 20, 560719) I observe that more such notices have been issued.
('16', 249, 3, 21, 560770) I hope they will be withdrawn 2.
('16', 249, 4, 22, 560803) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI From a copy: C.W. 10629. Courtesy: Chhaganlal Gandhi

('16', 250, 1, 2, 561272) 148. LETTER TO VINOBA BHAVE 1
('16', 250, 2, 3, 561302) [SABARMATI, After February 10, 1918] I do not know in what terms to praise you.
('16', 250, 2, 4, 561382) Your love and your character fascinate me and so also your self examination.
('16', 250, 2, 5, 561459) I am not fit to measure your worth.
('16', 250, 2, 6, 561495) I accept your own estimate and assume the position of a father to you.
('16', 250, 2, 7, 561566) You seem almost to have met a long felt wish of mine.
('16', 250, 2, 8, 561620) In my view a father is, in fact, a father only when he has a son who surpasses him in virtue.
('16', 250, 2, 9, 561714) A real son, likewise, is one who improves on what the father has done; if the father is truthful, firm of mind and compassionate, the son will be all this in a greater measure.
('16', 250, 2, 10, 561891) This is what you have made yourself.
('16', 250, 2, 11, 561928) I don’t see that you owe your achievement to any effort of mine.
('16', 250, 2, 12, 561993) Hence, I accept the role you offer to me as a gift of love.
('16', 250, 2, 13, 562053) I shall strive to be worthy of it; and, if ever I become another Hiranyakashipu, oppose me respectfully as Prahlad, who loved God, disobeyed him.
('16', 250, 2, 14, 562199) It is true as you say that, though outside the Ashram, you have scrupulously observed its rules.
('16', 250, 2, 15, 562296) I never doubted that you would return.
('16', 250, 2, 16, 562335) Besides, I had your written messages, read out by Mama.
('16', 250, 2, 17, 562391) May God grant you long life, and use you for the uplift of India.
('16', 250, 2, 18, 562457) I don’t see any need for changes in your diet just yet.
('16', 250, 2, 19, 562513) Do not give up milk for the present.
('16', 250, 2, 20, 562550) On the contrary, increase the quantity, if necessary.
('16', 250, 2, 21, 562604) About the railways, no satyagraha is required.
('16', 250, 2, 22, 562651) What is wanted is intelligent workers to carry on propaganda.
('16', 250, 2, 23, 562713) On the issue in Kheda District, satyagraha may possibly have to be offered.
('16', 250, 2, 24, 562789) I am something of a tramp these days.
('16', 250, 2, 25, 562827) In a day or two, I shall have to leave for Delhi.
('16', 250, 2, 26, 562877) More when you arrive.
('16', 250, 2, 27, 562899) Everyone is looking forward to seeing you.
('16', 250, 3, 28, 562942) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati] Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. IV

('16', 253, 6, 9, 567307) 153. LETTER TO A CO WORKER
('16', 253, 7, 10, 567334) [SABARMATI,] Magha Sud 2 [February 12, 1918]
('16', 253, 8, 11, 567379) BHAISHRI, I have your letter.
('16', 253, 8, 12, 567409) It would serve no purpose to hurt you by using strong words.
('16', 253, 8, 13, 567470) There are quite a few men who speak of their weaknesses as though they were their virtues.
('16', 253, 8, 14, 567561) You are one such.
('16', 253, 8, 15, 567579) It might be claimed that you take part in public life because you have some exceptional gift, but, in your actions, you show yourself weaker than others.
('16', 253, 8, 16, 567733) You made it out that you had been deeply grieved for your former wife, that her dying words had had a profound effect on you.
('16', 253, 8, 17, 567859) Then you forgot all about the wound, and the effect of the dying words faded into nothingness.
('16', 253, 8, 18, 567954) If a man crying in extreme pain had suddenly started laughing aloud he would be considered either an actor or a lunatic.
('16', 253, 8, 19, 568075) You, who were crying yesterday, are all smiles today.
('16', 253, 8, 20, 568129) What epithet can describe you?
('16', 253, 8, 21, 568160) A man whose desires are not under his control, who is incapable of the least self discipline, is such a man fit to be in public life?
('16', 253, 8, 22, 568294) Do not answer back that you are better than many others one comes across in public life and thus sink lower than you have already done.
('16', 253, 8, 23, 568430) The step you have taken has an important bearing on social reform among Hindus.
('16', 253, 8, 24, 568510) It is more needful that widowers show some sense of decency than that widows should remarry.
('16', 253, 8, 25, 568603) You have violated
('16', 254, 0, 1, 568621) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 255
('16', 254, 1, 2, 568667) the most fundamental principle.
('16', 254, 1, 3, 568699) If a Gujarat Sevamandal comes to be formed and I am 1 required to have close association with it, it would be very difficult for me to decide whether you could be admitted to it or not.
('16', 254, 1, 4, 568885) God forbid I should judge you—it is for Him alone to judge— but I would not give up my right to decide who shall be my associates in my life’s work.
('16', 254, 1, 5, 569034) You have let the world know what kind of a wound it was that your former wife’s death had inflicted on you.
('16', 254, 1, 6, 569142) Your action has struck me like a thunderbolt.
('16', 254, 1, 7, 569188) May God save you and grant you good sense.
('16', 254, 2, 8, 569231) MOHANDAS GANDHI [From Gujarati] Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. IV

('16', 257, 1, 2, 574353) 156. LETTER TO F. G. PRATT
('16', 257, 2, 3, 574380) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 15, 1918
('16', 257, 3, 4, 574428) DEAR MR. PRATT,
('16', 257, 4, 5, 574444) After the most mature deliberation, I have come to the conclusion that I dare not leave Gujarat without satisfying myself personally as to the truth or otherwise of the statements made about the failure of crops in a large part of Kaira.
('16', 257, 4, 6, 574682) I have, therefore, decided not to leave Gujarat for the time being, and I am proceeding by the one o’clock train today to Nadiad with a party of co workers.

('16', 263, 3, 27, 587040) I am making a supreme effort to bear equal love to all but, from you, I do hope for something more [than from others].

('16', 264, 9, 21, 589349) 1From the content it is evident that this letter was written the day after Gandhiji’s arrival at Nadiad to conduct an investigation into the reported failure of crops in the Kheda district.
