('16', 265, 1, 2, 589655) benefit from the annual celebrations, the organizers of the anniversary resolved last year to publish, on the occasion, a useful book in the mother tongue.
('16', 265, 1, 3, 589811) They decided, at the same time, what book was to be published and, naturally enough, the choice fell on the speeches of the late mahatma.
('16', 265, 1, 4, 589949) It was everyone’s wish that the translation should be an outstanding work in Gujarati literature and that every effort should be made to preserve in the translation the beauty of the holy word of the mahatma as it stands in the original.
('16', 265, 1, 5, 590187) This could not be secured with money but only through voluntary services.
('16', 265, 1, 6, 590261) These we obtained, but, even so, the future alone can say whether the desired result has been achieved.
('16', 265, 1, 7, 590365) The part to which this is a foreword has been translated by Shri Mahadev Haribhai Desai.
('16', 265, 1, 8, 590454) This is no occasion to say anything of him by way of introduction.
('16', 265, 1, 9, 590521) I shall only mention that he is a lover of Gujarati literature.
('16', 265, 1, 10, 590585) He is no stranger to the subject; besides, he is one of the thousands of the late mahatma’s votaries.
('16', 265, 1, 11, 590687) He has carried out his task with great enthusiasm and devotion and one may justifiably hope, therefore, that this translation will earn a place in Gujarati literature.
('16', 265, 1, 12, 590855) During last year’s anniversary celebrations, as soon as the Home Rule League of Bombay learnt that a decision to publish the volume was about to be announced, its secretaries wired an offer of generous help and later sanctioned a big amount, no less than three thousand rupees, for this project; and so the organizing committee had little worry left for collection of funds and its desire to ensure beauty of printing and the general get up was satisfied even in these times of rising prices.
('16', 265, 1, 13, 591348) The Home Rule League deserves congratulations on this large hearted help.

('16', 267, 1, 6, 595267) In these difficult and degenerate times, the pure spirit of religion is hardly in evidence anywhere.

('16', 267, 2, 17, 596394) Not taking a comprehensive view of things, we run away with the belief that, if but our political conditions improved, we would rise from this fallen state.
('16', 267, 2, 18, 596551) This is only partially true.

('16', 267, 2, 21, 596941) Only a change brought about in our political condition by pure means can lead to real progress.

('16', 268, 1, 2, 597323) that popular awakening could be brought about only through political activity.
('16', 268, 1, 3, 597402) If such activity was spiritualized, it could show the path to moksha.

('16', 270, 0, 1, 601369) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 271
('16', 270, 1, 2, 601415) I merely wish to place before you the principle that it is only through self help that an individual or a race can rise.
('16', 270, 1, 3, 601536) This is not a new principle, but we often forget to act upon it.* The Samaj is at present kept going by the enthusiasm of Bhai Karsandas Chitalia.
('16', 270, 1, 4, 601683) I am looking forward to a time when one of you will take his place and release him from this Samaj for other work.
('16', 270, 1, 5, 601798) Having dedicated his life wholly to the service of women, he will find out some work in the same field.
('16', 270, 1, 6, 601902) The Samaj will come into its own when it elects its office bearers from among its women members and gives a better account of itself than it does today.
('16', 270, 1, 7, 602055) I have close associations, as you know, with both men and women, but I find that I can do nothing in the way of service to women without help from women workers.
('16', 270, 1, 8, 602217) That is why I take ever occasion to protest in no uncertain terms that, so long as women in India remain ever so little suppressed or do not have the same rights [as men], India will not make real progress.
('16', 270, 1, 9, 602424) Hence it will be all to India’s honour if this Samaj succeeds completely in its aims.* It is necessary to understand what we mean when we talk of the regeneration of women.
('16', 270, 1, 10, 602597) It presupposes degeneration and, if that is so, we should further consider what led to it and how.
('16', 270, 1, 11, 602696) It is our primary duty to have some very hard thinking on these points.
('16', 270, 1, 12, 602768) In travelling all over India, I have come to realize that all the existing agitation is confined to an infinitesimal section of our people who are really a mere speck in the vast firmament.
('16', 270, 1, 13, 602958) Crores of people of both the sexes live in absolute ignorance of this agitation.
('16', 270, 1, 14, 603039) Full eighty five per cent of the people of this country pass their innocent days in a state of total detachment from what is going on around them.
('16', 270, 1, 15, 603186) These men and women, ignorant as they are, do their bit in life well and properly.
('16', 270, 1, 16, 603269) Both have the same education or, rather, the absence of education, both are helping each other as they ought to do.
('16', 270, 1, 17, 603385) If their lives are in any sense incomplete, the cause can be traced to the incompleteness of the lives of the remaining fifteen per cent.
('16', 270, 1, 18, 603523) If my sisters of the Bhagini Samaj will make a close study of the lives of these 85 per cent of our people, it will provide them ample material for an excellent programme of work for the Samaj.
('16', 270, 1, 19, 603717) In the observations that I am going to make, I will confine myself to the 15 percent above mentioned and, even then, it would be out of place to discuss the disabilities that are common both to men and women.
('16', 270, 1, 20, 603926) The point for us to consider is the
('16', 271, 0, 1, 603962) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 271, 1, 2, 604004) degeneration of our women relatively to our men.
('16', 271, 1, 3, 604053) Legislation has been mostly the handiwork of men; and man has not always been fair and discriminate in performing that self appointed task.
('16', 271, 1, 4, 604193) What the authors of the various smritis have said about women can in no wise be defended.
('16', 271, 1, 5, 604283) Child marriage, the restrictions on widows and such other evils owe their origin to the injunctions in the smritis.
('16', 271, 1, 6, 604399) Women’s being placed on a level with Sudras has done unimaginable harm to Hindu society.
('16', 271, 1, 7, 604488) These statements of mine may have verbal similarity with the occasional attacks of Christians, but, apart from this similarity, there is no other common ground between us.
('16', 271, 1, 8, 604660) The Christians, in their attacks, seek to strike at the roots of Hinduism.
('16', 271, 1, 9, 604735) I look upon myself as an orthodox Hindu and my attack proceeds from the desire to rid Hinduism of its defects and restore it to its pristine glory.
('16', 271, 1, 10, 604883) The Christian critic, by demonstrating the imperfection of the smritis, tries to show that they are just ordinary books.
('16', 271, 1, 11, 605004) My attempt is to show that the imperfection of the smritis comes from interpolated passages, that is to say, verses inserted by persons accepted as smritikaras 1 in the period of our degeneration.
('16', 271, 1, 12, 605201) It is easy to demonstrate the grandeur of the smritis minus these verses.
('16', 271, 1, 13, 605275) I do not have the slightest desire to put up a weak defence of Hinduism, believing out of false pride or in ignorance, and wanting others to believe, that there is no error in the smritis or in the other accepted books of the Hindu religion.

('16', 271, 1, 15, 605614) A religion which gives the foremost place to truth can afford no admixture of untruth.* The largest part of our effort in promoting the regeneration of women should be directed towards removing those blemishes which are represented in our shastras as the necessary and ingrained characteristics of women.

('16', 271, 1, 19, 606234) Their words will have the same authority as the shastras.

('16', 272, 1, 3, 606677) We have now discussed the root cause of the degeneration of our women and have considered the ideals by the realization of which the present condition of our women can be improved.
('16', 272, 1, 4, 606858) The number of women who can realize those ideals will be necessarily very few and, therefore, we will now consider what ordinary women can accomplish if they will try.

('16', 272, 1, 9, 607581) I am just returning from a district of Bihar.

('16', 276, 1, 8, 617635) It is useless to expect a child wife to be able to bring round the man who has married her.
('16', 276, 1, 9, 617727) The difficult work must, therefore, for the present at least, be left to man.
('16', 276, 1, 10, 617805) If I could, I would take a census of child wives and would find the friends of their husbands and through such friends, as well as through moral and polite exhortations, I will attempt to bring home to them the enormity of their crimes in linking their fortunes with child wives and will warn them that there is no expiation for that sin unless and until they have by education made their wives fit not only to bear children but also to bring them up properly, and unless, in the meantime, they live a life of absolute celibacy.
('16', 276, 2, 11, 618334) Thus there are many fruitful fields of activity before the members of the Bhagini Samaj for devoting their energies to.
('16', 276, 2, 12, 618454) The field for work is so vast that, if resolute application is brought to bear thereon, the wider movements for reform may, for the present, well be left to themselves and great service can be done to the cause of Home Rule without so much as even a verbal reference to it.
('16', 276, 2, 13, 618728) When printing presses were non existent and scope for speech making very limited, when one could hardly travel twenty four miles in the course of a day instead of a thousand miles as now, we had only one agency for propagating our ideals and that was our ‘acts’; and acts had immense potency.
('16', 276, 2, 14, 619021) We are now rushing to and fro with the velocity of air, delivering speeches, writing newspaper articles, and yet we fall short of our accomplishments and the cry of despair fills the air.
('16', 276, 2, 15, 619209) I for one am of opinion that, as in old days, our acts will have a more powerful influence on the public than any number of speeches and writings.
('16', 276, 2, 16, 619356) It is my earnest prayer to your Association that its members should give prominence to quiet and unobtrusive work in whatever it does.
('16', 276, 3, 17, 619491) The Hindu, 26 2 1918, and Mahatma Gandhini Vicharsrishti

('16', 282, 5, 11, 630258) 173. LETTER TO J. GHOSAL
('16', 282, 6, 12, 630283) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 26, 1918
('16', 282, 7, 13, 630331) DEAR MR. GHOSAL, My co workers and I have so far completed our investigation of a number of villages covering all the talukas.
('16', 282, 7, 14, 630458) I attach hereto a list containing the names of such villages with the annawari found by us and hope shortly to send another containing the remaining villages.
('16', 282, 7, 15, 630617) I have already explained to you the method adopted for finding the annawari.
('16', 282, 7, 16, 630694) The rabi and the kharif now standing furnish tangible material enabling one to arrive at absolutely accurate results.
('16', 282, 7, 17, 630812) I do not know that it is contended by any of your Talatis that the harvested kharif crops were in any but the rarest cases more than four annas.
('16', 282, 7, 18, 630957) It is submitted that the crops still standing in the majority of the villages will not yield more than a four anna harvest and I do hope that if you are not satisfied with the first hand testimony 1 of myself and my co workers, you will, whilst there is yet time, secure an independent valuation by appointing a joint committee of inspection.
('16', 282, 7, 19, 631300) I observe that hundreds of villagers have paid the first instalment as they say under pressure brought to bear upon them.
('16', 282, 7, 20, 631422) Many have been made, so it appears, even to pay both the instalments at once.
('16', 282, 8, 21, 631500) 1 On arrival at Nadiad, on February 16, Gandhiji and his fellow workers had themselves divided into groups, each of which undertook investigation of crop conditions in a number of villages.
('16', 282, 8, 22, 631690) In a week’s time reports in regard to 425 out of 600 villages had become available and Gandhiji had personally investigated conditions in 30 villages.
('16', 282, 8, 23, 631841) The findings formed the basis of his letter to the District authorities.

('16', 284, 1, 2, 634047) 174. AHMEDABAD MILL HANDS’ STRIKE
('16', 284, 2, 3, 634081) February 26, 1918
('16', 284, 3, 4, 634099) LEAFLET NO.
('16', 284, 4, 5, 634111) The lock out commenced on February 22. From that date the workers of the Weaving Department have been compelled to go without work.
('16', 284, 4, 6, 634243) When the mill owners issued notices withdrawing the Plague Bonus and there was unrest because of this, the employers resolved to get the dispute settled by arbitration and it was assumed that the workers would agree.
('16', 284, 4, 7, 634460) Accordingly, the mill owners resolved, on February 14, to appoint an arbitration board to decide what increase in lieu of the Plague Bonus was justified by the increase in the cost of living.
('16', 284, 4, 8, 634652) Mahatma Gandhi, Shri Shankarlal Banker and Shri Vallabhbhai Patel representing the workers, and Sheth Ambalal Sarabhai, Sheth Jagabhai Dalpatbhai and Sheth Chandulal representing the employers, with the Collector as Chairman, were appointed to arbitrate.
('16', 284, 4, 9, 634907) Thereafter, workers in some of the mills struck work owing to a misunder standing.
('16', 284, 4, 10, 634990) That was a mistake and the workers were ready to rectify it.
('16', 284, 4, 11, 635051) The employers, however, thought that the workers were in the wrong in striking before the Award was given by the arbitrators and that, therefore, they would be justified in cancelling their resolution regarding arbitration and this they did.
('16', 284, 4, 12, 635293) They simultaneously passed a resolution to the effect that workers be paid their due wages and be discharged if they were not content with a 20 per cent increase.
('16', 284, 4, 13, 635456) The weavers were not satisfied and accepted discharge, and the lock out by the employers commenced.
('16', 284, 4, 14, 635556) But the arbitrators for the workers felt it their responsibility to tell the workers, under the circumstances, what increase they could properlydemand.
('16', 284, 4, 15, 635708) But before doing so, they consulted amongst themselves and, after giving full consideration to the interests of both the mill owners and
('16', 284, 5, 16, 635845) 1 Apart from visits to workers’ houses and public meetings for educating the workers about the struggle, it was decided to “issue instructive leaflets every day with a view to fixing firmly in their minds the principles and significance of the struggle, and to supply them with simple but elevating literature which would conduce to their mental and intellectual development and enable them to leave for posterity a heritage of the means for its progress.” The leaflets were issued in the name of Anasuyabehn Sarabhai but, as stated by Mahadev Desai in Ek Dharmayuddha, of which A Righteous Struggle was the English edition, they were in fact written by Gandhiji.
('16', 284, 5, 17, 636509) This leaflet appeared on the fifth day of the lock out.
('16', 284, 5, 18, 636565) The leaflets were read out at the public meetings in the evenings.
('16', 285, 0, 1, 636632) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 285, 1, 2, 636674) the workers and to all the other circumstances, decided that an increase of 35 per cent was justified and that the workers be advised accordingly.
('16', 285, 1, 3, 636821) But before doing so they intimated their intention to the mill owners and promised to consider if they had anything to say against it.
('16', 285, 1, 4, 636956) The employers did not express their view on this matter.
('16', 285, 1, 5, 637013) The workers, whose demand was for a 50 per cent increase, withdrew it and resolved to ask for a 35 per cent increase.
('16', 285, 2, 6, 637131) WORKERS’ PLEDGE The workers have resolved: (1) that they will not resume work until a 35 per cent increase on the July wages is secured; (2) that they will not, during the period of the lock out, cause any disturbance or resort to violence or indulge in looting, nor damage any property of the employers or abuse anyone, but will remain peaceful.
('16', 285, 2, 7, 637478) How the workers can succeed in their pledge will be discussed in the next leaflet.
('16', 285, 2, 8, 637561) If workers have anything to tell me 1, they are welcome to see me at my place at any hour of the day.
('16', 285, 2, 9, 637663) [From Gujarati] Ek Dharmayuddha
('16', 285, 3, 10, 637695) 175. LETTER ON KHEDA SITUATION 2
('16', 285, 4, 11, 637728) February 26, 1918
('16', 285, 5, 12, 637746) I read your letter on the Gujarat Sabha.
('16', 285, 5, 13, 637787) It is the duty of all of us to do something for the people of Kheda.
('16', 285, 5, 14, 637856) If the Sabha failed to discharge this duty, I think it would forfeit its right to its name.
('16', 285, 5, 15, 637948) The responsibility for the advice that is being given to the people is chiefly mine.
('16', 285, 5, 16, 638033) Their case is that the crops have been less than four annas.
('16', 285, 5, 17, 638094) The Government admits that, when the crop is less than four annas, no revenue can be collected from the ryots that year.
('16', 285, 5, 18, 638215) If the Government does not grant the ryots’ demands, they have only one course open to them and that is to refuse to pay revenue to the Government and even let it auction their properties.
('16', 285, 6, 19, 638404) 1 Anasuyabehn, to whom workers frequently went for advice during the struggle 2 Particulars of the addressee are not known.
('16', 286, 0, 1, 638528) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 287
('16', 286, 1, 2, 638574) Assessment is in proportion to the capacity of the land.
('16', 286, 1, 3, 638631) It is quite plain that, if the land does not yield anything, no tax can be collected.
('16', 286, 1, 4, 638717) The Government’s regulation permitting payment by instalments is not a favour but an absolute necessity.
('16', 286, 1, 5, 638822) I perceive, however, that the difference of opinion between you and the Sabha on this issue is likely to remain.

('16', 288, 2, 7, 643256) 178. AHMEDABAD MILL HANDS’ STRIKE
('16', 288, 3, 8, 643290) February 27, 1918
('16', 288, 4, 9, 643308) LEAFLET NO.
('16', 288, 5, 10, 643320) We saw in yesterday’s leaflet what the workers’ pledge was.
('16', 288, 5, 11, 643380) We have now to consider what we should do to carry out that pledge.
('16', 288, 5, 12, 643448) We know that the employers have crores of rupees and the workers have nothing.
('16', 288, 5, 13, 643527) If workers have no money however, they have hands and feet with which they can work, and there is no part of the world which can do without workers.
('16', 288, 5, 14, 643676) Hence, if only he knows it, the worker holds the key to the situation.
('16', 288, 5, 15, 643747) Wealth is unavailing without him.
('16', 288, 5, 16, 643781) If he realizes this, he can be sure of success.
('16', 288, 5, 17, 643829) But the worker who would wield such power must possess certain qualities of character, without which he would be at the mercy of others.
('16', 288, 5, 18, 643966) Let us see what these qualities are.
('16', 288, 5, 19, 644003) 1. The worker should be truthful.
('16', 288, 5, 20, 644037) There is no reason for him to tell a lie.
('16', 288, 5, 21, 644079) Even if he tells a lie, he will not get the desired wage.
('16', 288, 5, 22, 644137) The truthful man can be firm and a worker who is firm is never defeated.
('16', 288, 5, 23, 644210) 2. He should possess courage.
('16', 288, 5, 24, 644240) Many of us become permanent slaves through fear of what might happen to us if we lost our jobs.
('16', 288, 5, 25, 644336) 3. He should have a sense of justice.
('16', 288, 5, 26, 644374) If he asks for wages higher than his deserts, there will be hardly anyone who will employ him.
('16', 288, 5, 27, 644469) The increase we have demanded in this struggle is reasonable.
('16', 288, 5, 28, 644531) We should, therefore, have faith that sooner or later we are bound to get justice.
('16', 288, 5, 29, 644614) 4. He will not be angry with his employer nor bear him any grudge.
('16', 288, 5, 30, 644681) After all, when everything is over, the worker is to serve under him.
('16', 288, 5, 31, 644751) Every human being is liable to err.
('16', 288, 5, 32, 644787) We think the employers are in the wrong in refusing the increase asked for.
('16', 288, 5, 33, 644863) If we remain straightforward till the end, the employers are sure to revise their attitude.
('16', 288, 5, 34, 644955) At present they are angry.
('16', 288, 5, 35, 644982) Also, they suspect that, if the present demands of the workers are granted, they will repeatedly harass them.
('16', 288, 5, 36, 645092) To remove this
('16', 289, 0, 1, 645107) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 289, 1, 2, 645149) suspicion, we should do our utmost to reassure the employers by our behaviour.
('16', 289, 1, 3, 645228) The first thing to that end is to harbour no grudge against them.
('16', 289, 1, 4, 645294) 5. Every worker should remember that the struggle is bound to involve suffering.
('16', 289, 1, 5, 645375) But happiness follows suffering voluntarily undertaken.
('16', 289, 1, 6, 645431) It is but suffering for the worker to be denied a wage sufficient to enable him to make both ends meet.
('16', 289, 1, 7, 645535) Because of our ignorance, however, we endure this and manage to live somehow.
('16', 289, 1, 8, 645613) Seeking a remedy against this suffering, we have told the employers that it is not possible for us to maintain ourselves without the wage increase demanded and that, if it is not granted to us and we are not saved from continuous starvation, we would rather starve right now.
('16', 289, 1, 9, 645889) How long will the employers remain unmoved by our suffering ?
('16', 289, 1, 10, 645951) 6. Lastly, the poor have their saviour in God.
('16', 289, 1, 11, 645998) Our duty is to make the effort and then, remain fully assured that we are bound to get what He has ordained for us, remain peaceful while our request is not yet granted.
('16', 289, 1, 12, 646168) A worker who behaves in this manner will never find it difficult to keep his pledge.
('16', 289, 1, 13, 646253) We shall discuss in tomorrow’s leaflet how the workers may maintain themselves during the period of the lock out.

('16', 293, 4, 5, 653520) 184. AHMEDABAD MILL HANDS’ STRIKE
('16', 293, 5, 6, 653554) February 28, 1918
('16', 293, 6, 7, 653572) LEAFLET NO.
('16', 293, 7, 8, 653584) We have stated what the workers’ pledge is and considered how best they may fulfil it.
('16', 293, 7, 9, 653671) Today we shall discuss how the workers may keep themselves occupied during the lock out.
('16', 293, 7, 10, 653760) There is a proverb among us that an idle man busies himself with mischief.
('16', 293, 7, 11, 653835) And so it is not at all good that ten thousand men should remain idle here in Ahmedabad.
('16', 293, 7, 12, 653924) A man who has been working all day feels quite lost if he suddenly finds himself without work.
('16', 293, 7, 13, 654019) The subject of this leaflet, therefore, is very important to us if we are to succeed in our aim.
('16', 293, 7, 14, 654116) Let us start by saying what the workers ought not to do: 1. They should not waste time in gambling.
('16', 293, 7, 15, 654216) 2. They should not spend it sleeping during the day.
('16', 293, 7, 16, 654269) 3. They should not keep talking, all the time, of the employers and the lock out.
('16', 293, 7, 17, 654351) 4. Many are in the habit of frequenting tea stalls and idling away their time in gossip or eating and drinking when they don’t need to.
('16', 293, 7, 18, 654487) Workers should keep away from such tea stalls.
('16', 293, 7, 19, 654534) 5. They should not go to the mills while the lock out continues.
('16', 293, 7, 20, 654599) Now about what the workers should do: 1. Many workers’ dwellings and their surroundings are generally dirty.
('16', 293, 7, 21, 654708) They are unable to attend to this when they are at work.
('16', 293, 7, 22, 654765) Now that they will have an enforced holiday, they should utilize some of the time in cleaning and repairing their houses and compounds.
('16', 293, 7, 23, 654901) 2. Those who are literate should spend their time in reading books and increasing their knowledge.
('16', 293, 7, 24, 655000) They can also teach the illiterate.
('16', 293, 7, 25, 655036) This way, they will learn to help each other.
('16', 293, 7, 26, 655082) Those who are fond of reading should go to the Dadabhai Library and Reading Room or other free
('16', 294, 0, 1, 655177) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 295
('16', 294, 1, 2, 655223) reading rooms.
('16', 294, 1, 3, 655238) 3. Those who know skilled work, such as tailoring, cabinet making or wood carving and engraving, can seek work for themselves.
('16', 294, 1, 4, 655365) If they fail to find any, they may approach us for help.
('16', 294, 1, 5, 655422) 4. Every person ought to have some knowledge of a subsidiary occupation besides the one from which he earns his livelihood.
('16', 294, 1, 6, 655546) Workers, therefore, can spend their time in learning some new and easy work.
('16', 294, 1, 7, 655623) They will have our help in this.
('16', 294, 1, 8, 655656) In India, a person in one occupation thinks it below his dignity to follow any other.
('16', 294, 1, 9, 655742) Besides, some occupations are considered low and degrading in themselves.
('16', 294, 1, 10, 655816) Both these ideas are wrong.
('16', 294, 1, 11, 655844) There is no question of inferiority or superiority among occupations which are essential for man’s existence.
('16', 294, 1, 12, 655954) Nor should we be ashamed of taking up an occupation other than the one we are used to.
('16', 294, 1, 13, 656041) We believe that weaving cloth, breaking stones, sawing or splitting wood or working on a farm are all necessary and honourable occupations.
('16', 294, 1, 14, 656181) We hope, therefore, that instead of wasting their time in doing nothing, workers will utilize it in some such useful work.
('16', 294, 1, 15, 656304) Having considered what workers should do, it is necessary to say what they may expect of me.
('16', 294, 1, 16, 656397) We shall say this in the next leaflet.
('16', 294, 1, 17, 656436) [From Gujarati] Ek Dharmayuddha

('16', 296, 8, 9, 659594) LEAFLET NO.
('16', 296, 9, 10, 659606) We have said how workers can fulfil their pledge and what they should do during the lock out.
('16', 296, 9, 11, 659700) In this leaflet we shall explain how we propose to help them.
('16', 296, 9, 12, 659762) It is our duty to do this.
('16', 296, 10, 13, 659789) LET US STATE, FIRST, WHAT WE CANNOT DO:
('16', 296, 11, 14, 659829) (1) We shall not help the workers in doing anything which is wrong.
('16', 296, 11, 15, 659897) (2) We shall have to abandon the workers and cease helping them if they do anything wrong or make inflated demands or commit violence.
('16', 296, 11, 16, 660032) (3) We can never wish ill to the employers ; in all that we do, we are bound to consider their interests.
('16', 296, 11, 17, 660138) We shall promote the workers’ interest while duly safeguarding the employers.
('16', 296, 12, 18, 660216) NOW ABOUT WHAT WE SHALL DO FOR THE WORKERS:
('16', 296, 13, 19, 660260) (1) We are with the workers so long as they conduct themselves well, as they have done so far.
('16', 296, 13, 20, 660355) (2) We shall do all we can to obtain for them 35 per cent increase in wages.
('16', 296, 13, 21, 660432) (3) We are, as yet, only entreating the employers.
('16', 296, 13, 22, 660483) We have not tried so far to win public sympathy or educate public opinion.
('16', 296, 13, 23, 660558) But we shall be prepared, if the situation demands it, to acquaint the whole of India with the workers’ plight and hope that we shall succeed in obtaining public sympathy for our cause.
('16', 296, 14, 24, 660744) 1 Gandhiji made this observation while commenting on the last paragraph of Leaflet No.
('16', 296, 14, 25, 660831) 3. The rest of the speech is not available.
('16', 297, 0, 1, 660875) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 297, 1, 2, 660917) (4) We shall not rest till the workers get what they are entitled to.
('16', 297, 1, 3, 660987) (5) We are making an effort to inform ourselves of the condition of the workers in its economic, moral and educational aspects.
('16', 297, 1, 4, 661115) We shall show the workers how they may improve their economic condition ; we shall strive to raise their moral level; we shall think out and teach them ways and means of living in cleanliness and we shall work for the intellectual improvement of such of them as live in ignorance.
('16', 297, 2, 5, 661396) (6) We shall not ourselves eat or dress without providing food and clothing to such of the workers as are reduced to destitution in the course of the struggle.
('16', 297, 3, 6, 661556) (7) We shall nurse the sick among them and get for them the services of vaids and doctors.

('16', 297, 4, 8, 661718) We consider the workers’ demand to be entirely reasonable and it is because we believe that satisfaction of their demand will even tually serve rather than harm the employers’ interests that we have taken up this cause.

('16', 298, 1, 2, 662341) 188. LETTER TO SIR E. A. GAIT
('16', 298, 2, 3, 662371) SABARMATI, March 1, 1918
('16', 298, 3, 4, 662396) E.A. GAIT 1
('16', 298, 4, 5, 662408) LT. GOVERNOR OF BIHAR & ORISSA PATNA
('16', 298, 5, 6, 662445) Your kind letter of the 18th ultimo has been redirected here.
('16', 298, 6, 7, 662507) I have been wandering about in Gujarat attending to one or two rather delicate questions.
('16', 298, 6, 8, 662597) Hence the delay in replying.
('16', 298, 6, 9, 662626) Sir Frank Sly’s version is quite correct and, as soon as the Bill becomes law, I shall endeavour to have the suits withdrawn.
('16', 298, 6, 10, 662752) When we discussed the matter, we had not contemplated legalization of the agreement.
('16', 298, 6, 11, 662837) Now that the enhancements are being legalized, subject to reduction after the year 1325 3, the planters’ protection will not rest solely on my influence with the raiyats.
('16', 298, 6, 12, 663008) I would nevertheless strain every nerve to see that the cases are withdrawn without resort to law.
('16', 298, 6, 13, 663107) There is just a possibility of a few raiyats proving obdurate.
('16', 298, 7, 14, 663170) Select Documents on Mahatma Gandhi’s Movement in Champaran
('16', 298, 8, 15, 663229) 1 Sir Edward Albert Gait, Lt. Governor, 1915 20 2 Sir Edward Gait had written: “In connection with the legislation to carry out the recommendations of the Champaran Agrarian Committee Messrs Norman and Hill say that a number of suits are still pending with their raiyats in which the sharahbeshi enhancement is disputed.
('16', 298, 8, 16, 663550) We referred the matter to Mr. Sly who says that the question of pending suits was discussed at the meeting between the Committee and the representative planters, and that you then agreed on behalf of the raiyats that such suits should be settled in accordance with the terms of the agreement, the raiyats no longer contesting the legality of sharahbeshi and paying the recorded rent in full up to Fasli 1325. ('16', 299, 1, 2, 664261) 189. LETTER TO AMBALAL SARABHAI
('16', 299, 2, 3, 664293) SABARMATI, March 1, 1918
('16', 299, 3, 4, 664318) DEAR FRIEND, Early this morning as I got up, I fell thinking what we were after.
('16', 299, 3, 5, 664399) What would be the issue of what I had been doing ?
('16', 299, 3, 6, 664450) And of what you had been doing ?
('16', 299, 3, 7, 664483) I suppose, if I succeeded, you would accept the workers’ demands; alternatively, if you hold firm till the last, the mill hands will take to other occupations.
('16', 299, 3, 8, 664643) If they go back on their resolve and accept the wages proposed by you, my efforts will have ended in nothing.
('16', 299, 3, 9, 664753) These results, however, have no serious consequences for the people.
('16', 299, 3, 10, 664822) What about your efforts, though?
('16', 299, 3, 11, 664855) If you succeed, the poor, already suppressed, will be suppressed still more, will be more abject than ever and the impression will have been confirmed that money can subdue everyone.
('16', 299, 3, 12, 665038) If, despite your efforts, the workers succeed in securing the increase, you, and others with you, will regard the result as your failure.
('16', 299, 3, 13, 665176) Can I possibly wish you success in so far as the first result is concerned ?
('16', 299, 3, 14, 665253) Is it your desire that the arrogance of money should increase ?
('16', 299, 3, 15, 665317) Or that the workers be reduced to utter submission ?
('16', 299, 3, 16, 665370) Would you be so unkindly disposed to them as to see no success for you in their getting what they are entitled to, may be even a few pice more ?
('16', 299, 3, 17, 665515) Do you not see that in your failure lies your success, that your success is fraught with danger for you ?
('16', 299, 3, 18, 665621) How if Ravana had succeeded ?
('16', 299, 3, 19, 665651) Do you not see that your success will have serious consequences for the whole society ?
('16', 299, 3, 20, 665739) Your efforts are of the nature of duragraha 1. My success everyone will accept as success.
('16', 299, 3, 21, 665830) My failure, too, will not harm anyone ; it will only prove that the workers were not prepared to go farther than they did.
('16', 299, 3, 22, 665953) An effort like mine is satyagraha.
('16', 299, 3, 23, 665988) Kindly look deep into your heart, listen to the still small voice within and obey it, I pray you.
('16', 299, 3, 24, 666086) Will you dine with me?
('16', 299, 3, 25, 666109) [From Gujarati] Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. IV
('16', 299, 4, 26, 666154) 1 Holding on to wrong, as opposed to satyagraha, holding on to truth.
('16', 299, 4, 27, 666224) The mill owners remained obstinate at this time.
('16', 299, 4, 28, 666273) Mahadev Desai thus analysed the situation: “.
('16', 299, 4, 29, 666319) .it appeared that the non acceptance of the workers’ demand by the employers was not due to their inability to pay 35 per cent, but to sheer obstinacy.
('16', 299, 4, 30, 666471) They had adopted this perverse attitude fearing that if once the workers succeeded, they would be a source of constant nuisance and the advisers of labour would get a permanent footing.”

('16', 300, 7, 13, 667261) 5 We have so far considered the situation from our point of view.
('16', 300, 7, 14, 667327) It is rather difficult to do so from that of the employers Workers’ efforts may have one of these two results: 1. They may get a 35 per cent increase in wages, or 2. They may have to resume work without getting such increase.
('16', 300, 7, 15, 667553) If the workers get an increase, they will be benefited and the employers will have earned credit.
('16', 300, 7, 16, 667651) If they have to resume work without any increase, they will be demoralized and obliged to bow before the employers as so many slaves.
('16', 300, 7, 17, 667785) It is, therefore, in the interests of both sides that the workers get an increase.
('16', 300, 7, 18, 667868) At any rate, a defeat will cost the workers very much indeed.
('16', 300, 7, 19, 667930) Employers’ efforts too may have one of these two results: 1. They may concede the workers an increase.
('16', 300, 7, 20, 668033) 2. They may not do so.
('16', 300, 7, 21, 668056) If the employers concede it, the workers will be contented and justice will have been done to them.
('16', 300, 7, 22, 668156) The employers are afraid that, if the workers’ demands are conceded, they will become overbearing.
('16', 300, 7, 23, 668255) This fear is baseless.
('16', 300, 7, 24, 668278) Even if workers are suppressed today, it is not impossible that, when opportunity arises, they will take to such ways.
('16', 300, 8, 25, 668397) 1 The speech evidently refers to Leaflet No.
('16', 300, 8, 26, 668442) 4 2 The rest of the speech is not available.
('16', 301, 0, 1, 668487) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 301, 1, 2, 668529) is even possible that the workers, on being suppressed, will become vindictive.
('16', 301, 1, 3, 668609) The history of the world shows that, wherever the workers have been suppressed, they have risen in revolt later when they got an opportunity.
('16', 301, 1, 4, 668751) The employers feel that conceding the workers’ demand will strengthen their advisers’ influence on them.
('16', 301, 1, 5, 668856) If the advisers are right in their stand, if they are devoted to the cause, the workers will never leave them whether they are defeated or victorious, and be it noted that the advisers also will not abandon the workers.
('16', 301, 1, 6, 669076) Those who have dedicated themselves to service of others will not forsake it even if they have to incur the displeasure of those whom they oppose.
('16', 301, 1, 7, 669223) The more cause for disappointment they have, the more devoted will they become in their service.
('16', 301, 1, 8, 669320) Strive as they may, the employers will never succeed in dividing the advisers from the workers.
('16', 301, 1, 9, 669416) What, then, will they get by defeating the workers ?
('16', 301, 1, 10, 669469) The only reply can be: nothing but the workers’ discontent.
('16', 301, 1, 11, 669529) The employers will always distrust the suppressed workers.
('16', 301, 1, 12, 669588) By granting the increase as demanded, the employers will have contented workers.
('16', 301, 1, 13, 669669) If the latter fail in their duty, the employers can always rely on the help of the advisers ; this way, they can end the loss now being caused to both sides.
('16', 301, 1, 14, 669827) The workers, on their part, will ever remain grateful if their demand is met and there will be increased goodwill between them and the employers.
('16', 301, 1, 15, 669973) Thus, the employers’ success lies in that of the workers ; and the latter’s defeat, likewise, will be their defeat.
('16', 301, 1, 16, 670089) As against this way of pure justice, the employers have adopted the Western, or the modern, Satanic notion of justice.
('16', 301, 1, 17, 670208) [From Gujarati]
('16', 301, 2, 18, 670224) Ek Dharmayuddha
('16', 301, 3, 19, 670240) 192. AHMEDABAD MILL HANDS’ STRIKE
('16', 301, 4, 20, 670274) [March 3, 1918] 1
('16', 301, 5, 21, 670292) LEAFLET NO.
('16', 301, 5, 22, 670304) 6 Pure justice is that which is inspired by fellow feeling and compassion.
('16', 301, 5, 23, 670379) We in India call it the Eastern or the ancient way of justice.
('16', 301, 5, 24, 670442) That way of justice which has no place in it for fellow feeling
('16', 301, 6, 25, 670506) 1 Leaflets numbered 5 and 8 have been assigned by Mahadev Desai to March 2 and March 5, respectively.
('16', 301, 6, 26, 670608) Leaflets numbered 6 and 7 fall naturally on March 3 and March 4.
('16', 302, 0, 1, 670673) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 303
('16', 302, 1, 2, 670719) or compassion is known as Satanic, Western or modern justice.
('16', 302, 1, 3, 670781) Out of compassion or regard, son and father concede many things to each other to the eventual benefit of both.
('16', 302, 1, 4, 670892) One takes pride in giving up a claim and thinks of one’s action as proceeding from strength, not weakness.
('16', 302, 1, 5, 670999) There was a time in India when servants, passing from father to son, used to serve in the same family for generations.
('16', 302, 1, 6, 671118) They were regarded and treated as members of the family.
('16', 302, 1, 7, 671175) They suffered with the employers in their misfortunes and the latter shared the servants’ joys and sorrows.
('16', 302, 1, 8, 671283) In those days, India was reputed for a social order free from friction, and this order endured for thousands of years on that basis.
('16', 302, 1, 9, 671416) Even now this sense of fellow feeling is not altogether absent in our country.
('16', 302, 1, 10, 671495) Where such an arrangement exists, there is hardly any need for a third party or an arbitrator.
('16', 302, 1, 11, 671590) Disputes between a master and a servant are settled between themselves amicably.
('16', 302, 1, 12, 671671) There was no room in this arrangement for increase or reduction in wages according as the changing needs of the two might dictate.
('16', 302, 1, 13, 671802) Servants did not ask for higher wages when there was a dearth of servants and masters did not reduce wages when servants were available in plenty.
('16', 302, 1, 14, 671949) This arrangement was based primarily on considerations of mutual regard, propriety, decorum and affection.
('16', 302, 1, 15, 672056) This sense of mutual obligation was not then, as it is now, considered unpractical but ruled us in most of our affairs.
('16', 302, 1, 16, 672176) History records that many great things have been achieved by our people because they had made this pure justice the law of their life.
('16', 302, 1, 17, 672311) This is the Eastern or ancient justice.
('16', 302, 2, 18, 672351) A totally different way of life prevails in the West today.
('16', 302, 2, 19, 672411) It is not to be supposed that all persons in the West approve of the modern idea of justice.
('16', 302, 2, 20, 672504) There are many saintly persons in the West who lead a blameless life, adopting the ancient standard.
('16', 302, 2, 21, 672605) But in most public activities of the West at present, there is no place for fellow feeling or compassion.
('16', 302, 2, 22, 672711) It is considered just that a master pays his servant what he thinks fit.
('16', 302, 2, 23, 672784) It is not considered necessary to think of the servants’ needs.
('16', 302, 2, 24, 672848) So also the worker can make his own demand, irrespective of the employer’s financial condition and this is considered just.
('16', 302, 3, 25, 672972) 1 Mahadev Desai wrote, in regard to these observations: “Gandhiji had published these ideas years ago in Indian Opinion in his article on Sarvodaya based on Ruskin’s book, Unto This Last.
('16', 302, 3, 26, 673160) The same ideas, having matured in course of time, he discussed in these leaflets in simple, direct and forceful language.” Vide “Letter to H.S.L. Polak”, 14 10 1909.
('16', 303, 0, 1, 673326) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 303, 1, 2, 673368) just, they think, that everyone should look after his own interests and expect others to take these into account.
('16', 303, 1, 3, 673482) The present war in Europe is fought on the same principle.
('16', 303, 1, 4, 673541) No means is considered improper for defeating the enemy.
('16', 303, 1, 5, 673598) Wars must have been fought even in the past, but the vast masses of the people were not involved in them.
('16', 303, 1, 6, 673704) We would do well not to introduce into India this despicable idea of justice.
('16', 303, 1, 7, 673782) When workers make a demand merely because they think themselves strong enough to do so, regardless of the employers’ condition, they will have succumbed to the modern, Satanic idea of justice.
('16', 303, 1, 8, 673975) The employers, in refusing to consider the workers’ demands, have accepted this Satanic principle of justice, may be unintentionally or in ignorance.
('16', 303, 1, 9, 674125) The employers ganging up against the workers is like raising an army of elephants against ants.
('16', 303, 1, 10, 674221) If they had any regard for dharma, the employers would hesitate to oppose the workers.
('16', 303, 1, 11, 674308) You will never find in ancient India that a situation in which the workers starved was regarded as the employers’ opportunity.
('16', 303, 1, 12, 674435) That action alone is just which does not harm either party to a dispute.
('16', 303, 1, 13, 674508) We had confidently hoped that the Jain and Vaishnava employers in the capital city of this worthy land of Gujarat would never consider it a victory to bear down the workers or deliberately to give them less than their due.
('16', 303, 1, 14, 674731) We are sure this wind from the West will pass as quickly as it has come.
('16', 303, 1, 15, 674804) At any rate, we do not want to teach the workers what they do in the West these days.
('16', 303, 1, 16, 674890) We wish to follow, and to make the workers follow, our ancient idea of justice as we have known it and to help them in that manner to secure their rights.
('16', 303, 2, 17, 675045) We shall consider, in the next leaflet, some of the evil consequences of the policy followed in the West in modern times.
('16', 303, 3, 18, 675167) [From Gujarati]

('16', 303, 5, 20, 675199) 1 According to Mahadev Desai, this and some of the succeeding leaflets were intended not only for the workers but also for the employers.
('16', 303, 5, 21, 675337) Their aim was to convert the mill owners, if possible, as much as to educate the workers.

('16', 305, 4, 5, 676987) It bores me to see people blindly worshipping me.

('16', 305, 10, 16, 677498) 7 South Africa is a large British Colony.

('16', 307, 4, 6, 681164) LEAFLET NO.
('16', 307, 4, 7, 681176) 8 In this leaflet, we are not going to talk about satyagrahis who have won fame in the world.
('16', 307, 4, 8, 681270) It would be more profitable for us and inspire us with strength to know what suffering common men like ourselves have found it possible to go through.
('16', 307, 4, 9, 681421) Imam Hassan and Hussain were bold and resolute satyagrahis.
('16', 307, 4, 10, 681481) We revere their names, but merely calling their examples to mind does not help us to become satyagrahis.
('16', 307, 4, 11, 681586) We feel that there can be no comparison between our capacity and theirs.
('16', 307, 4, 12, 681659) An equally memorable name is that of the devotee Prahlad.
('16', 307, 4, 13, 681717) But we think that we are not capable of such devotion, resoluteness, love for truth and courage and so, in the end, we remain what we have been.
('16', 307, 4, 14, 681862) Therefore, let us on this occasion think of what other persons like ourselves have done.
('16', 307, 4, 15, 681951) Such a satyagrahi was Hurbatsingh 2. He was an old man of 75 years.
('16', 307, 4, 16, 682019) He had gone to South Africa on a five year contract to work on an agricultural farm on a monthly wage of seven rupees.
('16', 307, 4, 17, 682138) When the strike of 20,000 Indians, referred to in the last leaflet, commenced, he also joined it.
('16', 307, 4, 18, 682236) Some strikers were jailed, and Hurbatsingh was among them.
('16', 307, 4, 19, 682295) His compani ons pleaded with him and said, “It is not for you to plunge into this sea of suffering.
('16', 307, 4, 20, 682395) Jail is not the place for you.
('16', 307, 4, 21, 682426) No one can blame you if you do not join such a struggle.” Hurbatsingh replied: “When all of you suffer so much for our honour, what shall I do by remaining outside?
('16', 307, 4, 22, 682591) What does it matter even if I die in jail?” And, verily, Hurbatsingh died in jail and won undying fame.
('16', 307, 4, 23, 682695) Had he died outside, no one would have noticed his death.
('16', 307, 4, 24, 682753) But, as he died in jail, the Indian community asked for his dead body and hundreds of Indians joined his funeral procession.
('16', 307, 5, 25, 682878) 1 The rest of the speech is not available.

('16', 312, 5, 13, 691648) 10 In the situation in which we are placed, it is quite necessary to examine the point mentioned in the preceding leaflet.
('16', 312, 5, 14, 691771) It is just about a fortnight since the lock out commenced, and yet some say that they have no food, others that they cannot even pay rent.

('16', 312, 5, 19, 692091) The clothes of the workers are dirty.
('16', 312, 5, 20, 692129) Some wear such clothes because they cannot afford to pay the washerman, others say that they cannot afford soap.
('16', 312, 5, 21, 692242) The workers’ children just play about in the streets.
('16', 312, 5, 22, 692296) They go without schooling.
('16', 312, 5, 23, 692323) Some of the workers even set their tender children to work for money.
('16', 312, 5, 24, 692393) Such extreme poverty is a painful thing indeed.
('16', 312, 5, 25, 692441) But a 35 per cent increase will not by itself cure it.
('16', 312, 5, 26, 692496) Even if wages were to be doubled, in all likelihood the abject poverty would remain unless other measures were also adopted.
('16', 312, 5, 27, 692621) There are many causes for this poverty.
('16', 312, 5, 28, 692661) We shall consider some of them today.
('16', 312, 5, 29, 692699) Questioning the workers, we learn that when they are short of money they pay interest ranging from one anna to four annas per rupee per month.
('16', 312, 5, 30, 692842) The very thought of this makes one shudder.
('16', 312, 5, 31, 692886) Anyone who agrees to pay such interest even once will find it extremely difficult to extricate himself.
('16', 312, 5, 32, 692990) Let us consider this a little.
('16', 312, 5, 33, 693021) Interest on sixteen rupees at one anna per rupee
('16', 312, 6, 34, 693070) 1 Vide the concluding sentence in Leaflet No.9.
('16', 313, 0, 1, 693118) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 313, 1, 2, 693160) is one rupee.
('16', 313, 1, 3, 693174) People who pay interest at this rate pay an amount equivalent to the principal in one year and four months.
('16', 313, 1, 4, 693282) This amounts to 75 per cent interest.
('16', 313, 1, 5, 693320) Even twelve to sixteen per cent interest is considered exorbitant; how, then, can a man paying 75 per cent interest survive at all?
('16', 313, 1, 6, 693452) Then, what shall we say of a man who pays four annas a month on a rupee?
('16', 313, 1, 7, 693525) Such a person pays an amount equal to the principal in four months.
('16', 313, 1, 8, 693593) This amounts to 300 per cent interest.
('16', 313, 1, 9, 693632) People who pay interest at such rates are always in debt and are never able to extricate themselves.
('16', 313, 1, 10, 693733) Prophet Mahomed had realized the crushing burden of interest and so it is that we find in the Holy Koran strict injunctions against charging interest.
('16', 313, 1, 11, 693884) For similar reasons, the rule of damdupat 1 must have been prescribed in the Hindu scriptures.
('16', 313, 1, 12, 693979) If, as part of the present struggle all workers take an oath not to pay such excessive interest, they will have an unbearable burden lifted from them.

('16', 313, 1, 16, 694449) We found some workers in a position to rescue their brethren who were being crushed under the weight of interest.

('16', 313, 4, 26, 694942) DEAR SHRI MANSUKHLAL, I am not pained by your criticism.

('16', 315, 8, 21, 698133) SABARMATI, March 9, 1918
('16', 315, 9, 22, 698158) DEAR MR. GHOSAL, I had a visit early this morning from some of the Kathana cultivators.
('16', 315, 9, 23, 698246) They brought with them a batch of chothai notices.

('16', 315, 9, 25, 698434) I have no justification for this except the feeling that as you permitted me to continue my negotiations about the crops in Kaira District no coercion would be used even it finally collection was decided upon where postponement was urged.

('16', 316, 1, 4, 699003) I now come to Wadthal.
('16', 316, 1, 5, 699026) I thank you for your letter in reply to my query as to the deduction of double cropped area.
('16', 316, 1, 6, 699119) If for a field which normally grew a kharif as well as a rabi crop the assessment was based on this fact, in my opinion the crop would be only 16 annas for that field or a group of similar fields in a village, if it gave 16 annas both of kharif and rabi.
('16', 316, 2, 7, 699374) The process of deducting the double cropped area could only be justified if you held that the field that gave 16 annas of kharif crop should be estimated to have given more than 16 annas to the extent of its rabi crop thus leading to the reductio ad absurdum suggested by my letter of the 6th instant.
('16', 316, 3, 8, 699676) I wholly accept the argument that in finding the annawari there can be no fieldwise calculation except as a sample.
('16', 316, 3, 9, 699792) And on that ground I venture to suggest that the rabi crop as a rule ought not to be taken into consideration, because it is not a general crop.
('16', 316, 3, 10, 699937) If 90 fields of every 100 grow only a kharif crop and have no rabi and if the rabi crop, where grown be 16 annas, it would be a false average annawari for the hundred fields if the rabi crop for the purpose of annawari is a negligible quantity.
('16', 316, 3, 11, 700182) The staple crops are undoubtedly kharif crops and in my humble opinion, agriculturists get less than justice when in order to collect revenue assessments annawari is forced up by taking the rabi into account.
('16', 316, 3, 12, 700391) Indeed my observations supported by my fellow workers now cover nearly 350 villages and they lead me to think that the cultivators pay their assessment from the kharif crops and not out of the rabi.
('16', 316, 3, 13, 700590) No intelligent observer can escape noticing as he passes from field to field that the rabi crops are like an oasis in a big desert.
('16', 316, 3, 14, 700722) It may be added that not all the fields of individual cultivators can be laid under rabi cultivation.
('16', 316, 3, 15, 700824) The season and crop report for the year 1914 15 shows that the rabi crop was only a twelfth and for 1915 16 twentieth of all the other crops.
('16', 316, 3, 16, 700966) I would venture to suggest too that crops such as spices, vegetables, variali, etc., which are grown only by a few cultivators ought not to be taken into account.
('16', 316, 3, 17, 701129) I would put cotton, too, in the same category until it becomes a general crop among the agriculturists.
('16', 316, 3, 18, 701233) It would be obviously unfair to put up the annawari of the village because a big land holder carrying on bold

('16', 319, 3, 14, 708303) I admit that the Kaira District is naturally “rich and prosperous”, its cattle are in a good condition, it has great wealth in its majestic trees.

('16', 320, 1, 4, 709500) It would be cruelty to enforce the Act during this year.
('16', 320, 1, 5, 709557) To recapitulate, (a) In my opinion by a variety of ways your minimum annawari for Wadthal has been successfully challenged and it is less than 4 annas; the case for the large majority of the villages in the District is similar to Wadthal and therefore the cultivators are entitled to full suspension;
('16', 320, 2, 6, 709858) (b) If however my suggestion as to annawari be not accepted l pray that the Government may be pleased to grant half suspension all round in view (1) of the admittedly partial failure of crops and (2) of the distress caused amongst the people by the plague and the high prices, and if this relief is granted I am prepared to advise holders of sanadia lands and others who are well off to pay both the instalments voluntarily.

('16', 323, 7, 11, 715222) 213. AHMEDABAD MILL HANDS’ STRIKE
('16', 323, 8, 12, 715256) March 11, 1918
('16', 323, 9, 13, 715271) LEAFLET NO.
('16', 323, 10, 14, 715283) As days pass, leaflets misleading the workers continue to be issued.
('16', 323, 10, 15, 715352) It is also rumoured that the lock out is to be lifted on Tuesday, and that those workers who return will be taken back.
('16', 323, 10, 16, 715472) We hear, besides, that any worker who persuades five or more other workers to go with him will be given a reward.
('16', 323, 10, 17, 715586) Nothing needs to be done to counter these tactics.
('16', 323, 10, 18, 715637) Employers are entitled to get the workers back to work by employing others to persuade them.
('16', 323, 10, 19, 715730) But what is the workers’ duty?
('16', 323, 10, 20, 715761) They have stated that an increase of 20 per cent is not adequate and have given notices accordingly.
('16', 323, 10, 21, 715862) They have taken an oath not to accept anything less than 35 per cent.
('16', 323, 10, 22, 715932) Placed in this predicament, unless a 35 per cent increase is granted, the workers cannot return to work except by violating their pledge, their honour and their manliness.
('16', 323, 10, 23, 716104) It is possible, however, that every worker may not have such a sense of honour.
('16', 323, 10, 24, 716184) Some may not even have taken such a pledge.
('16', 323, 10, 25, 716228) A few hail from outside Gujarat and they may not even be attending meetings.
('16', 323, 10, 26, 716305) It would be wrong even for such workers to go back to work with a 20 per cent increase.
('16', 323, 10, 27, 716393) Our duty merely is to find out such unthinking workers and acquaint them with the true state of affairs.
('16', 323, 11, 28, 716498) 1 1889 1942; a close associate of Gandhiji, identified with many of his activities; he chose a life of simplicity despite his wealth.

('16', 329, 1, 2, 726723) 219. SPEECH AT AHMEDABAD MEETING 1
('16', 329, 2, 3, 726758) March 13, 1918
('16', 329, 3, 4, 726773) I cannot do full justice, nor can anyone else for that matter, I am sure, to the task of introducing Mrs. Besant.
('16', 329, 3, 5, 726887) I have known her for thirty years, having followed her activities since my youth, though of course I cannot claim that she has known me so long.
('16', 329, 3, 6, 727032) “Home Rule” has become a household word all over India, in places big and small; the credit for this goes to this lady.
('16', 329, 3, 7, 727152) I have often said that there have been, and there may still be, differences between her and me; there are quite a few even today.
('16', 329, 3, 8, 727282) If I had the Home Rule movement under my charge, I would go to work differently.
('16', 329, 3, 9, 727363) Having said this, I admit I cannot but look up to her with reverence, honour her, pay tribute to her for her excellent qualities, for she has dedicated her very soul to India.
('16', 329, 3, 10, 727539) She lives only for India to live thus is her sole aspiration.
('16', 329, 3, 11, 727601) No matter if she commits hundreds of mistakes, we shall honour her.
('16', 329, 3, 12, 727669) In my view, Ahmedabad has covered itself with unsurpassed honour by honouring one who has rendered such great services as she has.
('16', 329, 3, 13, 727800) With regard to the subject of today’s address, it seems the present audience is not likely to be much interested in it.
('16', 329, 3, 14, 727920) Mrs. Besant told me a moment ago that she might manage to speak on swaraj before you, but that she wondered what she could say on national education.
('16', 329, 3, 15, 728070) There are not enough educated people in the audience.
('16', 329, 3, 16, 728124) She will speak, all the same.
('16', 329, 3, 17, 728154) I have her permission for speaking in Gujarati.
('16', 329, 3, 18, 728202) Whatever I wish to tell you, I can say only in Gujarati.
('16', 329, 3, 19, 728259) Her speech will later be summarized for you in Gujarati.
('16', 329, 3, 20, 728316) The agitation she has launched in the present circumstances has been useful in several ways.
('16', 329, 3, 21, 728409) India has benefited from her work, her organizing ability and her eloquence; to honour her, the first thing to do is to hear her in silence.

('16', 330, 1, 2, 728735) 220. SPEECH AT AHMEDABAD MEETING 1
('16', 330, 2, 3, 728770) March 13, 1918
('16', 330, 3, 4, 728785) Gandhiji started by requesting the people to maintain silence and stressed the importance of being punctual at a meeting.
('16', 330, 3, 5, 728907) He suggested that anyone who turned up from that time onwards should remain outside the gate.
('16', 330, 3, 6, 729001) The subject of today’s speech concerns our own interest; it is about swaraj.
('16', 330, 3, 7, 729078) Wealth, honour, strength—all these follow from swaraj.
('16', 330, 3, 8, 729133) One statement of this lady deserves to be engraved in our hearts and in the Government’s, that India would have Home Rule or go on hunger strike.
('16', 330, 3, 9, 729279) Everyone should ponder over this.
('16', 330, 3, 10, 729313) Being without political power, India is growing poorer and so abject is this poverty that thousands have been driven by it to inhuman crimes.
('16', 330, 3, 11, 729455) The idea of hunger strike is intended to bring home to us that a man who has been starving for some days would stop at nothing.
('16', 330, 3, 12, 729583) She is speaking today to explain this point.
('16', 330, 3, 13, 729628) If some of Mrs. Besant’s detractors succeed against her, that is only because she believes in action and has no interest except in her work.
('16', 330, 3, 14, 729769) She has dedicated herself, body and soul, and all she has, to her mission.
('16', 330, 3, 15, 729844) She has put before us what she had to say but it is not by following her way that we shall succeed in swimming across to the other side, we shall do so only by following our own.
('16', 330, 3, 16, 730023) If the honour Ahmedabad has accorded her today is sincere, you should pray to God that He may grant the strength she has to us as well.
('16', 330, 3, 17, 730159) And, with the same regard for her listen to her in silence.
('16', 330, 3, 18, 730219) Those who cannot follow English may read a translation tomorrow.
('16', 330, 4, 19, 730284) Concluding the proceedings, Shri Gandhi suggested that her speech should be translated into Gujarati and copies of the translation distributed among the people.
('16', 330, 4, 20, 730445) He described the speech as historic.
('16', 330, 4, 21, 730482) He then read out the names of those who had presented Mrs. Besant with purses and thanked them.
('16', 330, 4, 22, 730578) He advised everyone to ponder over her speech.

('16', 332, 3, 4, 732686) LEAFLET NO.
('16', 332, 3, 5, 732698) 14 As the weapon of the rich is money, that of the workers is their labour.
('16', 332, 3, 6, 732774) Just as a rich man would starve if he did not employ his wealth, even so if the worker did not employ his wealth— did not work—he would also starve.
('16', 332, 3, 7, 732923) One who does not work is not a worker.
('16', 332, 3, 8, 732962) A worker who is ashamed of working has no right to eat.
('16', 332, 3, 9, 733018) If, therefore, the workers desire to fulfil their pledge in this great struggle, they should learn to do some work or other.
('16', 332, 3, 10, 733143) Those who collect funds and, remaining idle, maintain themselves out of them do not deserve to win.
('16', 332, 3, 11, 733243) Workers are fighting for their pledge.
('16', 332, 3, 12, 733282) Those who want food without working for it do not, it may be said, understand what a pledge means.
('16', 332, 3, 13, 733381) He alone can keep his pledge who can feel shame or has self respect.
('16', 332, 3, 14, 733450) Is there anyone who will not look down on those who desire to be maintained on public funds without doing any work?
('16', 332, 3, 15, 733566) It behoves us, therefore, that we maintain ourselves by doing some work.
('16', 332, 3, 16, 733639) If a worker does not work, he is like sugar which has lost its sweetness.
('16', 332, 3, 17, 733713) If the sea water lost its salt, where would we get our salt from?
('16', 332, 3, 18, 733779) If the worker did not work, the world would come to an end.
('16', 332, 3, 19, 733839) This struggle is not merely for a 35 per cent increase; it is to show that workers are prepared to suffer for their rights.
('16', 332, 3, 20, 733963) We are fighting to uphold our honour.
('16', 332, 3, 21, 734001) We have launched on this struggle in order to better ourselves.
('16', 332, 3, 22, 734065) If we start using public funds improperly, we shall grow worse and not better.

('16', 333, 1, 2, 734998) We hope, therefore, that every worker will work to maintain himself so that he may be able to keep his oath and remain firm.

('16', 341, 1, 12, 755587) It is likely that, because of my vow, the mill owners may be moved by consideration for me and come to grant the workers’ [demand for] thirty five per cent increase.
('16', 341, 1, 13, 755753) My desire is that they should grant the demand only if they see its justice and not out of charity.
('16', 341, 1, 14, 755853) But the natural result would be that they would do so out of charity and to that extent this pledge is one which cannot but fill me with shame.
('16', 341, 1, 15, 755997) I weighed the two things, however, against each other: my sense of shame and the mill hands’ pledge.
('16', 341, 1, 16, 756098) The balance tilted in favour of the latter and I resolved, for the sake of the mill hands, to take no thought of my shame.
('16', 341, 1, 17, 756221) In doing public work, a man must be prepared to put up even with such loss of face.
('16', 341, 1, 18, 756305) Thus, my pledge is not at all by way of a threat to the mill owners; on the contrary, I wish they clearly understand this and grant the 35 per cent to the mill hands only if they think it just to do so.
('16', 341, 1, 19, 756508) To the mill hands, too, I would say that they should go to the owners and tell them as much.

('16', 344, 2, 6, 760883) I feel that some of the teachings of our sacred books are the result of profound experience.

('16', 345, 3, 9, 763195) Let me say one thing.

('16', 345, 3, 11, 763248) Before the struggle commenced, we had tried to ascertain their point of view, but they did not respond to our request.
('16', 345, 3, 12, 763367) The mill owners now accept the principle of arbitration.

('16', 347, 8, 13, 767557) LEAFLET NO.
('16', 347, 9, 14, 767569) VICTORY FOR BOTH We have said in earlier leaflets that in satyagraha both the parties invariably succeed.
('16', 347, 9, 15, 767675) He who fought for truth and attained his object would of course have won.
('16', 347, 9, 16, 767749) But even he who first opposed the truth and subsequently recognized it as such and conceded it should also be considered to have won.
('16', 347, 9, 17, 767883) From this point of view, because the workers’ pledge has been fulfilled, both the parties have won.
('16', 347, 9, 18, 767983) The employers had taken an oath that they would not give more than 20 per cent.
('16', 347, 9, 19, 768063) We have respected their oath, too.
('16', 347, 9, 20, 768098) Thus the honour of both has been upheld.
('16', 347, 9, 21, 768139) Let us now see what the settlement is: 1. Workers are to resume work tomorrow, i.e., on the 20th; for that day they will get a 35 per cent increase; and for the 21st, a 20 per cent increase.
('16', 347, 9, 22, 768330) 2. From the 22nd, they will get an increase not exceeding 35 per cent, as the arbitrator may decide.
('16', 347, 9, 23, 768431) 3. Prof.
('16', 347, 9, 24, 768440) Anandshankar Bapubhai Dhruva, M.A., LL.B., a prominent man of letters of Gujarat and a man of saintly character, a professor in Gujarat College and its Vice Principal, will be the arbitrator.
('16', 347, 9, 25, 768632) 4. The arbitrator should give his award within three months.
('16', 347, 9, 26, 768693) During the period, workers will be paid an increase of 27_ per cent, i.e., the workers give up half of their demand and the employers half
('16', 347, 10, 27, 768832) 1 Gandhiji probably sent the wire on the day of the settlement.

('16', 348, 1, 4, 769360) Two things have been accomplished by this settlement.
('16', 348, 1, 5, 769414) First, the honour of the workers has been upheld; secondly, it has been accepted as a principle that any serious dispute between the two parties should be settled not by resort to a strike but by arbitration.
('16', 348, 1, 6, 769623) It is not one of the terms of the settlement that in future the parties will settle their differences by arbitration; but, as the settlement has come about through arbitration, it is presumed that on a similar occasion in future also an arbitrator will be appointed.

('16', 351, 3, 7, 776819) 237. LETTER TO F. G. PRATT

('16', 351, 5, 9, 776871) DEAR MR. PRATT, Messages have been coming to me, and one has arrived just this very moment, to the effect that in several villages Talatis are putting undue pressure upon the villagers to pay the dues.
('16', 351, 5, 10, 777073) Representations have come from Matar Taluka asking me to go over to the District and speak to the people.
('16', 351, 5, 11, 777179) From everywhere in the Kaira District people have been coming in and asking for some public pronouncement.
('16', 351, 5, 12, 777286) As you are aware beyond speaking to the people as to what they ought to do I have scrupulously refrained from making any public announcement or inviting public agitation.
('16', 351, 5, 13, 777457) Indeed I have gone so far as to tell friends on whom I exercise any influence to avoid discussion in the press.
('16', 351, 5, 14, 777569) Before making public declaration and holding meetings, etc., I do want to make a final appeal to you.
('16', 351, 5, 15, 777671) Is it impossible to anounce a general suspension of the collection of the second instalment, practically for the whole District, coupled with a declaration to the effect that the Government would still expect holders of sanadia land to pay the dues in full?
('16', 351, 5, 16, 777929) This will avoid a ferment and it will be a graceful concession which I verily believe is demanded by the circumstances of the case.
('16', 351, 6, 17, 778061) I am at your service should you want it.

('16', 353, 4, 20, 781985) The occasion which has brought us here is so important that it will be enshrined in your memory for ever.
('16', 353, 4, 21, 782091) For some months past, an agitation has been going on in this district for securing the suspension of land revenue.

('16', 353, 4, 24, 782450) My co workers did the same.

('16', 353, 4, 26, 782582) The Government, too, claims to have made an inquiry, but it is not prepared to give the needed relief to the farmers.
('16', 353, 4, 27, 782700) It has decided to collect the dues.

('16', 355, 1, 2, 785791) In fact revenue should be paid from the sale value of the crops; it is intolerable, when the crops have failed, that the Government should recover it forcibly.
('16', 355, 1, 3, 785951) But, in this country, it has become a practice with the Government to insist that it is always in the right.
('16', 355, 1, 4, 786060) It is intolerable that, however just the people’s case, the Government should have its own way.
('16', 355, 1, 5, 786156) Justice must prevail and injustice yield.
('16', 355, 1, 6, 786198) The agriculturists claim, and the evidence collected by those who conducted the inquiry bears them out, that the crops have failed and yet the Government insists that they have been plentiful.
('16', 355, 1, 7, 786391) In the circumstances, the people have every right to tell the Government that, surely, they could see and judge things as well as the Government, and that they would not submit to injustice done by the officers.
('16', 355, 1, 8, 786603) That people would tell lies, for the sake of saving at the most a year’s interest by asking for a postponement of the assessment, is inconceivable.
('16', 355, 1, 9, 786751) That the officers should suggest anything of the kind is intolerable.
('16', 355, 1, 10, 786821) We must show, therefore, that our case is just; placed in the situation that we are, I would tell you that, if the Government does not accept our request, we should declare plainly that we shall not pay land revenue and will be prepared to take the consequences.
('16', 355, 1, 11, 787084) All nations which have risen have done so through suffering.
('16', 355, 1, 12, 787145) If the people have to sacrifice their land, they should be ready to do so and suffer.
('16', 355, 1, 13, 787231) Some will even argue that this is treason or rebellion; it is nothing of the kind.
('16', 355, 1, 14, 787314) It means suffering ourselves, no treason.
('16', 355, 1, 15, 787356) When the crops have failed, to pay up the dues out of fear is cowardice.
('16', 355, 1, 16, 787429) We are human beings, not animals.
('16', 355, 1, 17, 787463) To refuse a thing firmly and plainly in the name of truth—that is satyagraha.
('16', 355, 1, 18, 787541) We have assembled today to do the spade work for satyagraha.
('16', 355, 1, 19, 787602) We don’t propose to pay up the revenue to the Government; we want to fight it out.
('16', 355, 1, 20, 787685) We have to prepare ourselves, then, for the suffering that may follow.

('16', 355, 1, 22, 787896) (2) It may impose fines.
('16', 355, 1, 23, 787921) (3) It may confiscate jagirs.
('16', 355, 1, 24, 787951) (4) It may even put people in jail on the ground that they are defiant 1. The word has been used by the Government and I don’t like it.

('16', 356, 1, 2, 788169) How can they say that you are defiant merely because you speak the truth?
('16', 356, 1, 3, 788243) Indeed, such a person is brave, not defiant.
('16', 356, 1, 4, 788288) It is an act of bravery, and no defiance, for a man who, though he can afford to pay, refuses to do so in the interests of the poor.
('16', 356, 1, 5, 788421) If in the process this man has to leave the village for ever, he will do so; he alone may take the pledge today who is ready for this.
('16', 356, 1, 6, 788556) It is very difficult to take the pledge of satyagraha; it is still more difficult to carry out one.
('16', 356, 1, 7, 788656) I cannot bear to think of any one breaking a pledge once taken, forsaking his God.
('16', 356, 1, 8, 788739) It would cause me very great pain, indeed, if you took a pledge which you did not mean to keep.
('16', 356, 1, 9, 788835) In the intensity of my suffering, I may take an extreme step.
('16', 356, 1, 10, 788897) I may have to fast.
('16', 356, 1, 11, 788917) I don’t suffer when I fast; fasting hurts me less than that people should deceive me by breaking their pledge.
('16', 356, 1, 12, 789028) In satyagraha, a pledge is the most valuable thing of all; it must be kept up to the very end.
('16', 356, 1, 13, 789123) A pledge taken in God’s name must never be broken.
('16', 356, 1, 14, 789174) I would not hesitate to sacrifice my life if that might ensure that thousands would keep their pledge.
('16', 356, 1, 15, 789277) Those who want to fight must make up their minds once for all.
('16', 356, 1, 16, 789340) I would not mind very much if people just said that they would hold out as long as possible but that they were not sure of themselves in case of severe repression.
('16', 356, 1, 17, 789504) I would far rather that they cut my throat than that they break my heart by betraying their pledge.
('16', 356, 1, 18, 789604) The man who cuts my throat, I would pray to God to forgive, but I would not forgive the other man.
('16', 356, 1, 19, 789703) I would tell you, therefore, in all humility, whatever you decide, do so with full thought and consideration.
('16', 356, 1, 20, 789813) Only those who are determined to carry their decision through are able to raise themselves.
('16', 356, 1, 21, 789905) When you have so raised yourselves, the Government will respect you, for it will know then, that it was dealing with men who would honour their plighted word and not betray it.
('16', 356, 1, 22, 790082) A man who breaks his word can do no service to his country, or to his Government or to God.
('16', 356, 1, 23, 790174) I want, therefore, to know whether you agree; I ask you: “Are you ready to fight ?” I shall prepare a written pledge.
('16', 356, 1, 24, 790292) Those friends who wish to take it should come to the Ashram and give their signatures.
('16', 356, 1, 25, 790379) I have only one request: “Suffer everything and honour the pledge; refuse to pay the revenue and prove to the Government thereby that you are prepared for sacrifices.” The Government cannot use force against everyone.

('16', 357, 5, 9, 791058) [NADIAD, March 22, 1918]
('16', 357, 6, 10, 791083) Our village has had crops under four annas.
('16', 357, 6, 11, 791127) We therefore requested the Government to postpone collection to the next year, but they did not do so.
('16', 357, 6, 12, 791230) We the undersigned therefore solemnly declare that we shall not pay the assessment for the year whether it be wholly or in part; we shall leave it to the Government to take any legal steps they choose to enforce recovery of the same and we shall undergo all the sufferings that this may involve.
('16', 357, 6, 13, 791526) We shall also allow our lands to be confiscated should they do so.

('16', 357, 6, 16, 791914) The reason why the well to do amongst us would not pay is that, if they do, the needy ones would, out of fright, sell their chattels or incur debts and pay the revenue and thus suffer.
('16', 357, 6, 17, 792099) We believe that it is the duty of the well to do to protect the needy against such a plight.

('16', 359, 2, 8, 794640) 242. CIRCULAR REGARDING KHEDA SITUATION 2
('16', 359, 3, 9, 794682) HINDU ANATH ASHRAM, NADIAD Phagun Sud 15, March, 27, 1918
('16', 359, 4, 10, 794740) THE DUTY OF THE RYOTS OF KAIRA DISTRICT
('16', 359, 5, 11, 794780) As the crops in the Kaira district have been poor, that is to say, below 4 annas in most of the villages, the Government rule is that the collection of Land Revenue this year should be postponed.
('16', 359, 5, 12, 794976) Repeated appeals have been made to the Government on behalf of the ryots to make this postponement.
('16', 359, 5, 13, 795076) On behalf of the people the Gujarat Sabha, the honourable Messrs G. K. Parekh and V. J. Patel and Messrs Deodhar, Amritlal Thakkar and Joshi of the Servants of India Society made inquiries about the crops and all came to the conclusions that the Kharif crop practically came to nothing.
('16', 359, 5, 14, 795363) With the help of many responsible and respectable assistants, I also made minute inquiries into the crops of about 400 villages and found the same thing that, in almost all the villages the anna valuation was below four annas.
('16', 359, 5, 15, 795590) I also saw that many of the ryots had no money, and that the granaries of many were empty; further that many poor people were importing maize whole sale from outside in place of grain grown in this district and living on that.
