('16', 361, 1, 2, 798307) 243. LETTER TO THE PRESS 1
('16', 361, 3, 3, 798334) TO THE EDITOR THE LEADER ALLAHABAD
('16', 361, 4, 4, 798369) SIR, Perhaps I owe an explanation to the public with regard to my recent fast.
('16', 361, 4, 5, 798448) Some friends consider the action to have been silly, others cowardly and some others still worse.
('16', 361, 4, 6, 798546) In my opinion, I would have been untrue to my Maker and to the cause I was espousing, if I had acted otherwise.
('16', 361, 4, 7, 798658) When over a month ago I reached Bombay, I was told that Ahmedabad mill hands had threatened a strike and violence if the bonus that was given to them during the plague was withdrawn.
('16', 361, 4, 8, 798841) I was asked to intervene and I consented.
('16', 361, 4, 9, 798883) Owing to the plague the men were getting as much as 70 per cent bonus since August last.
('16', 361, 4, 10, 798972) An attempt to recall that bonus had resulted in grave dissatisfaction among the labourers.
('16', 361, 4, 11, 799063) When it was almost too late, the mill owners offered in the place of the plague bonus and for the sake of the high prices a rise of 20 percent.
('16', 361, 4, 12, 799207) The labourers were unsatisfied.
('16', 361, 4, 13, 799239) The matter was referred to arbitration, Mr. Chatfield, the collector, being the umpire.
('16', 361, 4, 14, 799327) The men in some mills however struck work.
('16', 361, 4, 15, 799370) The owners, thinking that they had done so without just cause, withdrew from the arbitration and declared a general lock out to be continued till the labourers were exhausted into accepting 20 per cent increase they had offered.
('16', 361, 4, 16, 799599) Messrs Shankarlal Banker, V. J. Patel and I, the arbitrators appointed on behalf of the labourers thought that they were to be demoralized if we did not act promptly and decisively.
('16', 361, 4, 17, 799781) We, therefore, investigated the question of increase they had offered.
('16', 361, 4, 18, 799852) We sought the mill owners’ assistance.
('16', 361, 4, 19, 799891) They would not give it.
('16', 361, 4, 20, 799915) Their one purpose was to organize themselves into a combination that could fight a similar combination of their employees.
('16', 361, 4, 21, 800038) One sided technically though our investigation was, we endeavoured to examine the mill owners’ side and came to the conclusion that a 35 percent increase was fair.
('16', 361, 4, 22, 800202) Before announcing the figure to the mill hands, we informed the employers of the result
('16', 361, 5, 23, 800290) 1 Evi dentl y thi s was iss ued gen erall y to the Pre ss, and was als o pub lis hed in The Hindu
('16', 362, 0, 1, 800388) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 363
('16', 362, 1, 2, 800434) of our inquiry and told them that we would correct ourselves if they could show any error.
('16', 362, 1, 3, 800525) The latter would not co operate.
('16', 362, 1, 4, 800558) They sent a reply saying as much, but they pointed out in it that the rate of increase granted by the Government as also the employers in Bombay was much less than the one contemplated by us.
('16', 362, 1, 5, 800750) I felt that the addendum was beside the point and at a huge meeting 1 announced 35 per cent for the mill hands’ acceptance.
('16', 362, 1, 6, 800874) Be it noted that the plague bonus amounted to 70 per cent of their wages and they had declared their intention of accepting not less than 50 per cent as high prices increase.
('16', 362, 1, 7, 801049) They were now called upon to accept the mean (the fixing of the mean was quite an accident) between the mill owners 20 per cent, and their own 50 per cent.
('16', 362, 1, 8, 801205) After some grumbling, the meeting accepted the 35 per cent increase, it always being understood that they would recognize, at the same time, the principle of arbitration whenever the mill owners’ did so.
('16', 362, 1, 9, 801409) From that time forward, i.e., 26th February last, day after day thousands of people gathered together under the shade of a tree outside the city walls, people walking long distances in many cases, and solemnly repeated their determination in the name of God not to accept anything less than 35 per cent.
('16', 362, 1, 10, 801713) No pecuniary assistance was given to them.
('16', 362, 1, 11, 801756) It was easy enough to understand that many must suffer from the pangs of starvation and that they could not, while they were without employment, get any credit.
('16', 362, 1, 12, 801917) We who were helping them came, on the other hand, to the conclusion that we would only spoil them if we collected public funds and utilized them for feeding them unless the able bodied among them were ready to perform bread labour.
('16', 362, 1, 13, 802149) It was a difficult task to persuade men, who have worked at machines, to shoulder baskets of sand or bricks.
('16', 362, 1, 14, 802258) They came but they did so grudgingly.
('16', 362, 1, 15, 802296) The mill owners hardened their hearts.
('16', 362, 1, 16, 802335) They were equally determined not to go beyond 20 per cent and they appointed emissaries to persuade the men to give in.
('16', 362, 1, 17, 802455) Even during the early part of the lock out, whilst we had declined to help those who would not work, we had assured them that we would feed and clothe ourselves after feeding and clothing them.
('16', 362, 1, 18, 802649) Twenty two days had passed by.
('16', 362, 1, 19, 802680) Hunger and the mill owners’ emissaries were producing their effect and Satan was whispering to the men that there was no such thing as God on earth who would help them and that vows were dodges resorted to by weaklings.
('16', 362, 1, 20, 802900) One morning instead of an eager and enthusiastic crowd of 5 to 10
('16', 362, 2, 21, 802966) 1 Vide “Speech to Ahmedabad Mill hands”, February 26, 1918.
('16', 363, 0, 1, 803026) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 363, 1, 2, 803068) thousand men with determination written on their faces, I met a body of 2000 men with despair written on their faces.
('16', 363, 1, 3, 803186) We had just heard that mill hands living in a particular chawl had declined to attend the meeting, were preparing to go to work and accept 20 per cent increase and were taunting us (I think very properly) that it was very well for us who had motors at our disposal and plenty of food, to attend their meetings and advise staunchness even unto death.
('16', 363, 1, 4, 803536) What was I to do?
('16', 363, 1, 5, 803554) I held the cause to be just.
('16', 363, 1, 6, 803583) I believe in God as I believe that I am writing this letter.
('16', 363, 1, 7, 803644) I believe in the necessity of the performance of one’s promise at all costs.
('16', 363, 1, 8, 803721) I knew that the men before us were God fearing men, but that the long drawn out lock out or strike was putting an undue strain upon them.
('16', 363, 1, 9, 803859) I had the knowledge before me during my extensive travels in India, hundreds of people were found who as readily broke a promise as they made them.
('16', 363, 1, 10, 804007) I knew, too, that the best of us have but a vague and indistinct belief in soul force and in God.
('16', 363, 1, 11, 804105) I felt that it was a sacred moment for me, my faith was on the anvil, and I had no hesitation to rising and declaring to the men that a breach of their vow so solemnly taken was unendurable by me and that I would not take any food until they had the 35 per cent increase given or until they had fallen.
('16', 363, 1, 12, 804408) A meeting that was up to now unlike the former meetings, totally unresponsive, woke up as if by magic.
('16', 363, 1, 13, 804511) Tears trickled down the cheeks of every one of them and men after men rose up saying that they would never go to the mills unless they got the increase and that they would go about the city and steal the hearts of those who had not attended the meeting.
('16', 363, 1, 14, 804765) It was a privilege to witness the demonstration of the efficacy of truth and love.
('16', 363, 1, 15, 804848) Every one immediately realized that the protecting power of God was as much with us today as it used to be in the days of yore.
('16', 363, 1, 16, 804976) I am not sorry for the vow but with the belief that I have, I would have been unworthy of the trust undertaken by me, if I had done anything less.
('16', 363, 1, 17, 805123) Before I took the vow I knew that there were serious defects about it.
('16', 363, 1, 18, 805194) For me to take such a vow in order to affect in any shape or form the decision of the mill owners would be cowardly injustice done to them and that I would prove myself unfit for the friendship which I had the privilege of enjoying with some of them.
('16', 363, 1, 19, 805445) I knew that I ran the risk of being misunderstood.
('16', 363, 1, 20, 805496) I could not prevent my fast from affecting their decision.
('16', 363, 1, 21, 805555) Their knowledge, moreover, put a responsibility on me which I was ill able to bear.
('16', 363, 1, 22, 805639) From now I disabled myself from gaining concessions for the men, which ordinarily, in a struggle such as this, I would be entirely justified in securing.
('16', 363, 1, 23, 805793) I knew, too, that I would have
('16', 364, 0, 1, 805824) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 365
('16', 364, 1, 2, 805870) to be satisfied with the minimum I could get from the mill owners and with a fulfilment of the letter of the men’s vow rather than its spirit and so hath it happened.
('16', 364, 1, 3, 806037) I put the effect of my vow in one scale and the merits of it in the other.
('16', 364, 1, 4, 806112) There are hardly any acts of human beings which are free from all taint.
('16', 364, 1, 5, 806185) Mine, I know, was exceptionally tainted but I preferred the ignominy of having unworthily compromised by my vow the position and independence of the mill owners rather than that it should be said by posterity that 10,000 men had suddenly broken a vow which they had for over twenty days solemnly taken and repeated in the name of God.
('16', 364, 1, 6, 806520) I am fully convinced that no body of men can make themselves into a nation or perform great tasks unless they become as true as steel and unless their promises come to be regarded by the world like the law of the Medes and Persians, inflexible and unbreakable, and whatever may be the verdict of friends, so far as I can think at present, on given occasions I should not hesitate in future to repeat the humble performance which I have taken the liberty of describing in this communication.
('16', 364, 2, 7, 807011) I cannot conclude this letter without mentioning two names of whom India has every reason to be proud.
('16', 364, 2, 8, 807114) The mill owners were represented by Mr. Ambalal Sarabhai who is a gentlemen in every sense of the term.
('16', 364, 2, 9, 807218) He is a man of culture and equally great abilities.
('16', 364, 2, 10, 807270) He adds to these qualities a resolute will.
('16', 364, 2, 11, 807314) The mill hands were represented by his sister Anasuyabehn.
('16', 364, 2, 12, 807373) She possesses a heart of gold.
('16', 364, 2, 13, 807404) She is full of pity for the poor.
('16', 364, 2, 14, 807438) The mill hands adore her.
('16', 364, 2, 15, 807464) Her word is law with them.
('16', 364, 2, 16, 807491) I have not known a struggle fought with so little bitterness and such courtesy on either side.
('16', 364, 2, 17, 807586) This happy result is principally due to the connections with it of Mr. Ambalal Sarabhai and Anasuyabehn.
('16', 364, 4, 18, 807691) Yours, etc.,
('16', 364, 5, 19, 807704) M. K. GANDHI
('16', 364, 6, 20, 807717) The Leader, 3 4 1918

('16', 365, 7, 27, 809058) 245. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS ON KHEDA SITUATION
('16', 365, 8, 28, 809105) NADIAD, March 28, 1918
('16', 365, 9, 29, 809128) In the district of Kheda, the crops for the year 1917 18 have, by common admission, proved a partial failure.
('16', 365, 9, 30, 809238) Under the Revenue rules
('16', 365, 10, 31, 809262) 1 This was in reply to Kripalani’s letter conveying news about the deaths of his brother and sister in law and expressing the fear that he might have to give up social service.
('16', 365, 10, 32, 809439) 2 Jivatram B. Kripalani (b.
('16', 365, 10, 33, 809467) 1886); educationist, politician and President, Indian National Congress, 1946
('16', 366, 0, 1, 809545) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 367
('16', 366, 1, 2, 809591) if the crops are under four annas, the cultivators are entitled to full suspension of the Revenue assessment for the year; if the crops are under six annas, half the amount of assessment is suspended.
('16', 366, 1, 3, 809792) So far as I am aware, the Government have been pleased to grant full suspension with regard to one village out of every 600, and half suspension in the case of over 103 villages.
('16', 366, 1, 4, 809971) It is claimed on behalf of the ryots that the suspension is not at all adequate to the actuality.
('16', 366, 1, 5, 810069) The government contended that in the vast majority of villages, crops have been over six annas.
('16', 366, 1, 6, 810165) The only question before at issue is, whether the crops have been under four annas or six annas, as the case may be, or over the latter figure.
('16', 366, 1, 7, 810309) Government valuation is in the first instance made by the Talatis assisted by the chief men of the villages concerned.
('16', 366, 1, 8, 810428) As a rule, no check on thier figures is considered necessary, for it is only during partial failure that Government valuation of crops may have been challenged.
('16', 366, 1, 9, 810589) The Talatis are as a class obsequious, unscrupulous and tyrannical.
('16', 366, 1, 10, 810657) The chief men are especially selected for their docility.
('16', 366, 1, 11, 810715) The Talatis’ one aim is naturally to collect full assessment as promptly as possible.
('16', 366, 1, 12, 810801) We sometimes read accounts of assiduous Talatis having been awarded pugree for making full collection.
('16', 366, 1, 13, 810904) In applying to the Talatis the adjectives I have given, I wish to cast no reflections on them as men.
('16', 366, 1, 14, 811006) I merely state the fact.
('16', 366, 1, 15, 811031) The Talatis are not born; they are made; and rent collectors all the world over have to cultivate a callousness without which they could not do their work to the satisfaction of their masters.
('16', 366, 1, 16, 811224) It is impossible for me to reproduce the graphic description given by the ryots of the rent collectors which the Talatis chiefly are.
('16', 366, 1, 17, 811358) My purpose in dealing with the Talatis is to show that the Governments valuation of the crops is derived in the first instance from the tainted source and is presumably biased against the ryots.
('16', 366, 1, 18, 811553) As against their valuation, we have the universal testimony of ryots, high and low, some of whom are men of position and considerable wealth, who have a reputation to lose and who have nothing to gain by exaggeration except the odium of Talatis and possibly higher officials.
('16', 366, 1, 19, 811829) I wish to state at once that behind this movement there is no desire to discredit the Government, or an individual official.
('16', 366, 1, 20, 811954) The movement is intended to assert the right of the people to be effectively heard in matters concerning themselves.
('16', 366, 2, 21, 812071) It is known to the public that the Hon’ble Mr. G. K. Parekh and Mr. V. J. Patel, invited and assisted by the Gujarat Sabha, carried on investigations as also Messrs Deodhar, Joshi and Thakkar of the Servants of India Society.
('16', 366, 2, 22, 812297) Their investigation was necessary
('16', 367, 0, 1, 812331) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 367, 1, 2, 812373) preliminary and brief and therefore confined to a few villages only.
('16', 367, 1, 3, 812442) But the result of their inquiry went to show that the crops in the majority of cases was under four annas.
('16', 367, 1, 4, 812549) As their investigation, not being extensive enough, was capable of being challenged, and it was challenged.
('16', 367, 1, 5, 812657) I undertook a full inquiry with the assistance of over 20 capable, experienced and impartial men of influence and status.
('16', 367, 1, 6, 812779) I personally visited over 50 villages and met as many men in the villages as I could, inspected in these villages most of the fields belonging to them and after a searching cross examination of the villagers, came to the conclusion that their crops were under four annas.
('16', 367, 1, 7, 813051) I found that among the men who surrounded me, there were present those who were ready to check exaggerations and wild statements.
('16', 367, 1, 8, 813181) Men knew what was at stake if they departed from the truth.
('16', 367, 1, 9, 813241) As to the rabi crops and the still standing Kharif crops, I was able by the evidence of my own eyes to check the statements of the agriculturists.
('16', 367, 1, 10, 813388) The method adopted by my co workers were exactly the same.
('16', 367, 1, 11, 813447) In this manner nearly 400 villages were examined and with but a few exceptions, crops were found to be under four annas, and only in three cases they were found to be over six annas.
('16', 367, 1, 12, 813630) The method adopted by us was, so far as the Kharif crops were concerned, to ascertain the actual yield of the whole of the crops of individual villages and the possible yield of the same village in a normal year.
('16', 367, 1, 13, 813843) Assuming the truth of the statements made by them, this is admittedly an absolute test, and any other method that would bring about the same result must be rejected as untrue and unscientific; and as I have already remarked, all probability of exaggeration was avoided in the above named investigation.
('16', 367, 1, 14, 814146) As to the standing rabi crops, there was the eye estimate and it was tested by the method above mentioned.
('16', 367, 1, 15, 814253) The Government method is an eye estimate and therefore a matter largely of guess work.
('16', 367, 1, 16, 814340) It is moreover open to fundamental objections which I have endeavoured to set forth in a letter to the Collector of the District.
('16', 367, 1, 17, 814470) I request him to treat Vadthal a well known and ordinary well to do village of the district with the railway line passing by it and which is near a trade centre as a test case and I suggest that if the crops were in that village proved to be under four annas, as I hold they were, it might be assumed that in other villages less fortunately situated, crops were not likely to be more than four annas.
('16', 367, 1, 18, 814871) I have added to my request a suggestion that I should be permitted to be present at the inquiry.
('16', 367, 1, 19, 814968) He made the inquiry but rejected my suggestion and therefore it proved to be one sided.
('16', 367, 1, 20, 815056) The Collector has made an elaborate report on the crops of that village which, in my opinion, I have successfully challenged.
('16', 367, 1, 21, 815182) The original Government valuation, I understand, was twelve annas, the Collector’s minimum
('16', 368, 0, 1, 815273) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 369
('16', 368, 1, 2, 815319) valuation is seven annas.
('16', 368, 1, 3, 815345) If the probably wrong methods of valuation to which I have drawn attention and which have been adopted by the Collector are allowed for, the valuation according to his own reckoning would come under six annas and according to the agriculturists it would be under four annas.
('16', 368, 1, 4, 815620) Both the report and my answer are too technical to be of value to the public.
('16', 368, 1, 5, 815698) But I have suggested that, as both the Government and agriculturists hold themselves in the right, if the Government have any regard for popular opinion, they should appoint an impartial committee of inquiry with the cultivators’ representatives upon it, or gracefully accept the popular view.
('16', 368, 1, 6, 815992) The Government have rejected both the suggestions and insist upon applying coercive measures for the collection of revenue.
('16', 368, 1, 7, 816116) It may be mentioned that these measures have never been totally suspended and in many cases the ryots have paid simply under pressure.
('16', 368, 1, 8, 816251) The Talatis have taken away cattle and have returned them only after the payment of assessment.
('16', 368, 1, 9, 816347) In one case, I witnessed a painful incident.
('16', 368, 1, 10, 816392) A man having a milch buffalo taken away from him and it was only on my happening to go to the village that the buffalo was released; this buffalo was the most valuable property the man possessed and a source of daily bread for him.
('16', 368, 1, 11, 816624) Scores of such cases have already happened and many more will no doubt happen hereafter if the public opinion is not ranged on the side of the people.
('16', 368, 1, 12, 816775) Every means of seeking redress by prayers has been exhausted.
('16', 368, 1, 13, 816837) Interviews with Collector, the Commissioner and His Excellency have taken place.
('16', 368, 1, 14, 816918) The final suggestion that was made is this; Although in the majority of cases, people are entitled to full suspension, half suspension should be granted throughout the district except for villages which show, by common consent, crops over six annas.
('16', 368, 1, 15, 817168) Such a gracious concession may be accompanied by a declaration that the Government would expect those who have ready means voluntarily to pay the dues, we the workers on our part undertaking to persuade such people to pay up the Government dues.
('16', 368, 1, 16, 817414) This will leave only the poorest people untouched.
('16', 368, 1, 17, 817465) I venture to submit that acceptance of this suggestion can only bring credit and strength to the Government.
('16', 368, 1, 18, 817574) Resistance of popular will can only produce discontent which, in the case of fear stricken peasantry such as of Kaira, can only find an underground passage and thus demoralize them.
('16', 368, 1, 19, 817756) The present movement is an attempt to get out of such a false position, humiliating alike for the Government and the people.
('16', 368, 1, 20, 817881) And how do the Government propose to assert their position and so called prestige?
('16', 368, 1, 21, 817964) They have a Revenue Code giving them unlimited powers without a right of appeal to the ryots against the decisions of the Revenue Authorities.
('16', 368, 1, 22, 818107) Exercise of these powers in a case like the one
('16', 369, 0, 1, 818155) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 369, 1, 2, 818197) before us, in which the ryots are fighting for a principle and the authorities for prestige, would be a prostitution of justice, of a disavowal of all fair play.
('16', 369, 1, 3, 818359) These powers are: (1) Right of summary execution.
('16', 369, 1, 4, 818409) (2) Right of exacting a quarter of the assessment as punishment.
('16', 369, 1, 5, 818474) (3) Right of confiscation of land, not merely rayatwari but even inami or sanadia, and the right of keeping a man under hajat.
('16', 369, 2, 6, 818601) Those remedies may be applied singly or all together, and unbelievable though it may seem to the public, it may be mentioned that the notices of the application of all these remedies but the last have been issued.
('16', 369, 2, 7, 818815) Thus a man owning two hundred acres of land in perpetuity and valued at thousands of rupees, paying a small assessment rate, may at will of the authority lose the whole of it, because for the sake of principal he respectfully refuses voluntarily to pay the assessment himself and is prepared meekly but under strong protest to penalties that may be inflicted by law.
('16', 369, 2, 8, 819182) Surely vindictive confiscation of property ought not to be the reward for orderly disobedience which, properly handled, can only result in progress all roung and in giving the Government a bold and frank peasantry with a will of its own.
('16', 369, 2, 9, 819420) I venture to invite the Press and the public to assist these cultivators of Kaira who have dared to enter up a fight for what they consider is just and right.
('16', 369, 2, 10, 819579) Let the public remember this also that unprecedentedly severe plague has decimated the population of Kaira.
('16', 369, 2, 11, 819687) People are living outside their homes in specially prepared thatched cottages at considerable expense to themselves.
('16', 369, 2, 12, 819804) In some villages mortality has been tremendous.
('16', 369, 2, 13, 819852) Prices areruling high of which, owing to the failure of crops, they can but take little advantage and have to suffer all the disadvantages thereof.
('16', 369, 2, 14, 820000) It is not money they want so much as the voice of a strong unanimous and emphatic public opinion.

('16', 377, 1, 26, 839525) If we give up these and imitate European civilisation, we shall be doomed.

('16', 377, 1, 28, 839677) Be fearless.
('16', 377, 1, 29, 839690) So long as you live under various kinds of fears, you can never progress, you can never succeed.

('16', 377, 1, 31, 839834) Never, never give up truth and love.

('16', 377, 1, 33, 839912) If you wish to make Hindi the national language, you can do so in a short time through the principles of truth and non violence.

('16', 378, 1, 2, 840149) 248. LETTER T0 THE PRESS
('16', 378, 2, 3, 840174) INDORE, March 31,1918 At the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan, just closing, a committee consisting of the Hon’ble Rai Bahadur Bishen Dutta Shukla, Rai Bahadur Saryoo Prasad, Babu Shiva Prasad Gupta, Babu Purushottam Das Tandon, Babu Gauri Shanker Prasad, Pandit Venkatesha Narayan Tiwari and myself were appointed as a special committee to give effect to certain resolutions of the Sammelan.
('16', 378, 2, 4, 840557) One of the instructions given to the committee is to find out six Tamil and Telugu youths of promise and good character who would undertake to learn Hindi with a view to ultimately becoming missionaries for the propagation of Hindi among the Tamil and the Telugu people.
('16', 378, 2, 5, 840828) It has been proposed to locate them either at Allahabad or at Benares, and to teach them Hindi.
('16', 378, 2, 6, 840924) Expenses of their board and lodging as well as instruction will be paid for by the committee.
('16', 378, 2, 7, 841018) It is expected that the course will not take longer than a year at the most and, as soon as they have attained a certain standard of knowledge of Hindi, they would be entrusted with the missionary work, that is, the work of teaching Hindi to the Tamil or the Telugu people, as the case may be, for which they would get a salary to maintain themselves suitably.
('16', 378, 2, 8, 841379) The committee will guarantee such service for at least a period of three years, and will expect applicants to enter into a Contract with the committee to render the stipulated service faithfully and well for that period.
('16', 378, 2, 9, 841600) The committee expects that the services of these youths will be indefinitely prolonged and that they will be able to serve themselves as well as the country.
('16', 378, 2, 10, 841758) The desire of the committee is to offer liberal payment and expect in return absolute faithfulness and steadfastness.
('16', 378, 2, 11, 841876) I trust that you agree with the Sammelan that Hindi and Hindi alone, whether in Sanskrit form or as Urdu, can become the language of intercourse between the different provinces.
('16', 378, 2, 12, 842054) It is already that amongst the Mahomedans all over India, as also amongst the Hindus except in the Madras Presidency.
('16', 378, 2, 13, 842172) I exclude the English educated Indians who have made English, in my humble opinion, much to the detriment of the country, the language of mutual intercourse.
('16', 378, 2, 14, 842330) If we are to realize the swaraj ideal, we must find a common language that can be easily learnt and that can be understood by the vast masses.
('16', 378, 2, 15, 842473) This has always been Hindi or Urdu and is so even now, as I can say from personal experience.
('16', 378, 2, 16, 842567) I have faith enough in the patriotism, selflessness and the sagacity of the people of the Madras Presidency to know that those, who at all want to render national service or to come in touch with the other Provinces, will undergo the sacrifice, if it is one, of learning Hindi.
('16', 378, 2, 17, 842845) I suggest that they should consider it a privilege to be able to learn a language that
('16', 379, 0, 1, 842932) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 379, 1, 2, 842974) will enable them to enter into the hearts of millions of their countrymen.
('16', 379, 1, 3, 843049) The proposal set forth is a temporary makeshift.
('16', 379, 1, 4, 843098) An agitation of great potency must arise in the country that would compel the educational authorities to introduce Hindi as the second language in the public schools.
('16', 379, 1, 5, 843265) But it was felt by the Sammelan that no time should be lost in popularizing Hindi in the Madras Presidency.
('16', 379, 1, 6, 843373) Hence the above mentioned proposal which, I hope, you will be able to commend to your readers.
('16', 379, 1, 7, 843468) I may add that the committee proposes to send Hindi teachers to the Tamil as also to the Andhra districts in order to teach Hindi free of charge to those who would care to learn it.
('16', 379, 1, 8, 843650) I hope that many will take advantage of the proffered tuition.
('16', 379, 1, 9, 843713) Those youths who wish to apply for the training above mentioned should do so under cover addressed to me care of Hindi Sahitya Sammelan, Allahabad, before the end of April.

('16', 382, 2, 3, 848429) LIMBASI, April 2, 1918
('16', 382, 3, 4, 848452) DEAR MR. PRATT, I returned from Indore yesterday.
('16', 382, 3, 5, 848502) 1 am passing the day at Limbasi.
('16', 382, 3, 6, 848535) I observe that the whole of the crops of this Division has been placed under distraint.
('16', 382, 3, 7, 848623) This seems to me to be a cruel procedure.
('16', 382, 3, 8, 848665) Again complaints are being made that violence is being used against the people in other parts.
('16', 382, 3, 9, 848760) This, I know, can have no countenance from the higher officials.
('16', 382, 3, 10, 848825) The Government resist the people, and the latter the former on a matter of principle.
('16', 382, 3, 11, 848911) I think that the fight can be fought without bitterness.
('16', 382, 3, 12, 848968) Both will have gained in the end if none but the fairest means be adopted by the parties to gain their respective ends.

('16', 383, 1, 2, 850017) 255. SPEECH AT LIMBASI
('16', 383, 2, 3, 850040) April 2, 1918
('16', 383, 3, 4, 850054) We call the fight satyagraha.
('16', 383, 3, 5, 850084) We have made truth our weapon; hence, if you tell lies and deceive me, we shall go down and all over the country they will say that ours was a cowardly fight.
('16', 383, 3, 6, 850243) Let those who have not paid the full amount of the Government dues raise their hands; 1 and those who have paid the full amount raise theirs.
('16', 383, 3, 7, 850385) 2 This proves that most of the farmers have not paid the dues.
('16', 383, 3, 8, 850448) Indeed, this is a matter for joy.
('16', 383, 3, 9, 850482) If such a large number of people remain firm, victory is ours.
('16', 383, 3, 10, 850545) We should know what we mean by “victory”.
('16', 383, 3, 11, 850587) What are we fighting for?
('16', 383, 3, 12, 850613) We are fighting so that the Government may suspend the collection of revenue.
('16', 383, 3, 13, 850691) Where crops are less than four annas, the full amount of the assessment should be suspended and, where they have been between four and six annas, half the amount should be suspended; that is the law.
('16', 383, 3, 14, 850891) Many have had less than four annas yield, but some of them have paid up half the amount.
('16', 383, 3, 15, 850980) Our fight is to see that they don’t have to pay the remainder.
('16', 383, 3, 16, 851043) The Government says that, in most places, crops have been more than six annas; that being its view, we request the Government, in the interests o f justice, to appoint a committee of inquiry; this the Government refuses to do.
('16', 383, 3, 17, 851270) The question, here, is not merely one of land revenue.
('16', 383, 3, 18, 851325) I am pained to see that the Government should always insist that it is in the right and the people are in the wrong.
('16', 383, 3, 19, 851442) This bespeaks a state of slavery [for us].
('16', 383, 3, 20, 851485) We shall endure it no longer; of course, you won’t.
('16', 383, 3, 21, 851537) That is how you should feel.
('16', 383, 3, 22, 851566) We are fighting that you may taste the joy of freedom.
('16', 383, 3, 23, 851621) The people’s will is pitted against the Government’s.
('16', 383, 3, 24, 851675) Our stubbornness is in a right cause, hence we call it satyagraha.
('16', 383, 3, 25, 851742) If, in the fight, the Government attaches all our property and even then we do not pay the revenue, the victory will be ours.
('16', 383, 3, 26, 851868) Let the women give the same advice to their husbands.
('16', 383, 3, 27, 851922) If our crops have been less than what the Government says they are, we should stand firm in the truth we have stated.
('16', 383, 3, 28, 852040) If, out of fear of others, a man does what he ought not to, he will be ruined in his soul.
('16', 383, 3, 29, 852131) The true end of human effort, real manliness, consists in not acting thus.
('16', 383, 3, 30, 852206) We are not slaves; we are free.
('16', 383, 3, 31, 852238) The Government says that, if the people are allowed to raise their heads once, they will always hold them high.
('16', 383, 4, 32, 852350) 1 Some 200 hands were raised.
('16', 383, 4, 33, 852380) 2 Only three responded.

('16', 384, 1, 2, 852450) people have no time to go about unnecessarily raising their heads in defiance.
('16', 384, 1, 3, 852529) So much of their time is taken up in earning their bread.
('16', 384, 1, 4, 852587) We fight through voluntary suffering.
('16', 384, 1, 5, 852625) If any millionaire should offer to pay up the land revenue for you, you should flatly refuse the offer.

('16', 385, 3, 11, 855700) NADIAD, April 4, 1918
('16', 385, 4, 12, 855722) DEAR SIR JAMES DUBOULAY, Although the Kaira matter is not under your Department, I feel that as you are a member of the Executive Council and as perhaps of all the members you know me best, I would not hesitate to place the position before you.

('16', 385, 4, 18, 856362) Were they quietly to sell their treasured belongings or incur debts to pay the Government dues and be noted liars in the bragain?

('16', 385, 4, 20, 856608) The people naturally look up to public workers for advice.
('16', 385, 4, 21, 856667) For me to have advised them to suffer the wrong would have been to increase their weakness and send their discontent underground.
('16', 385, 4, 22, 856797) What I have done enables the people to state their case boldly and if they are in the wrong or the Government unbending to suffer their property to be sold.
('16', 385, 4, 23, 856954) This is at best a striking and orderly demonstration of their grief and of their faith in the ultimate triumph

('16', 386, 1, 2, 857171) of truth and in the desire of the Government to do justice.

('16', 386, 1, 5, 857457) They can only gain in prestige.

('16', 386, 3, 11, 857822) 257. SPEECH AT KARAMSAD
('16', 386, 4, 12, 857846) April 4, 1918
('16', 386, 5, 13, 857860) When we met in Nadiad a few days ago and resolved on satyagraha, I said that I would have to go to Delhi for the sake of Mahomed Ali and Shaukat Ali.
('16', 386, 5, 14, 858010) It may seem that I take but a casual interest in this issue but I alone know how much, in fact, I am occupied with it.

('16', 391, 5, 9, 869682) 261. SPEECH AT VADATHAL
('16', 391, 6, 10, 869706) April 5, 1918
('16', 391, 7, 11, 869720) From the very beginning, the village of Vadathal has taken a leading part in this struggle.
('16', 391, 7, 12, 869812) I have moved from farm to farm here and assured myself that on the average the crop in this village is less than four annas.
('16', 391, 7, 13, 869937) The Collector came over for a fresh inquiry.
('16', 391, 7, 14, 869982) I wrote to him that I had ascertained the facts myself and found that the crop was less than four annas, but he did not agree with me.
('16', 391, 7, 15, 870117) I have told him that ours is a struggle through self suffering.
('16', 391, 7, 16, 870181) I have seen people suffer in satyagraha much more than you do.
('16', 391, 7, 17, 870244) I shall have you swallow bitter draughts.
('16', 391, 7, 18, 870286) You should celebrate the days on which they sell your buffaloes here, auction away your things and confiscate your belongings.
('16', 391, 7, 19, 870413) If anyone in Vadathal is jailed, the prison will have been sanctified.
('16', 391, 7, 20, 870484) Especially the women should have a feast when their husbands go to jail.
('16', 391, 7, 21, 870557) Notices of confiscation have been issued, by way of threats; in spite of them, we remain the owners of our lands.
('16', 391, 7, 22, 870671) Whatever the value of these lands, we should not falter ever so little in our duty.
('16', 391, 7, 23, 870755) In case you should lose your all in this struggle, not one of you will be allowed to starve.
('16', 391, 7, 24, 870848) We shall go and beg but provide for you.
('16', 391, 7, 25, 870889) Bear your sufferings for the sake of your pledge.

('16', 392, 1, 2, 870985) If I pay you money for the buffaloes, I and all of you will have deceived the people.

('16', 404, 10, 19, 894798) I twice offered my services but they were not accepted.
('16', 404, 10, 20, 894854) I feel ashamed that since my arrival in India I can show no war work record in the conventional sense of the term.
('16', 404, 10, 21, 894969) On the contrary I seem to be making myself responsible for embarrassing situations and I may find myself in the midst of an agitation which might from its very magnitude cause grave anxiety to the Government.

('16', 422, 6, 15, 934928) This, it is held, constitutes the strength of to the British Constitution.
('16', 422, 6, 16, 935003) The Commissioner has on principle rejected this position and invited a crisis.
('16', 422, 6, 17, 935082) And he has made such a fetish of it that he armed himself beforehand with a letter from Lord Wellingdon to the effect that even
('16', 422, 7, 18, 935210) 1 The addressee in reply wrote that the purport of the interview sent by Gandhiji did not adequately cover all the aspects discussed.

('16', 423, 1, 2, 935966) he should not interfere with the Commissioner’s decision.
('16', 423, 1, 3, 936024) He brings in the War to defend his position and adjures the ryots and me to desist from our cause at this time of peril to the Empire.
('16', 423, 1, 4, 936159) But I venture to suggest that the Commissioner’s attitude constitutes a peril far graver than the German peril, and I am serving the Empire in trying to deliver it from this peril from within.
('16', 423, 1, 5, 936352) There is no mistaking the fact that India is waking up from its long sleep.
('16', 423, 1, 6, 936428) The ryots do not need to be literate to appreciate their rights and their duties.
('16', 423, 1, 7, 936510) They have but to realize their invulnerable power and no Government, however strong, can stand against their will.
('16', 423, 1, 8, 936625) The Kaira ryots are solving an Imperial problem of the first magnitude in India.
('16', 423, 1, 9, 936706) They will show that it is impossible to govern men without their consent.
('16', 423, 1, 10, 936780) Once the Civil Service realizes this position, it will supply to India truly Civil Servants who will be the bulwark of the people’s rights.
('16', 423, 1, 11, 936920) Today the Civil Service rule is a rule of fear.
('16', 423, 1, 12, 936968) The Kaira ryot is fighting for the rule of love.
('16', 423, 1, 13, 937017) It is the Commissioner who has produced the crisis.
('16', 423, 1, 14, 937069) It was, as it is now, his duty to placate the people when he saw that they held a different view.
('16', 423, 1, 15, 937167) The revenue of India will be no more in danger because a Commissioner yields to the popular demands and grants concessions than the administration of justice was in danger, when Mrs. Maybrick was reprieved purely in obedience to the popular will, or the Empire was in danger because a corner of a mosque in Cawnpore was replaced in obedience to the same demand.
('16', 423, 1, 16, 937529) Had I hesitated to advise the people to stand against the Commissioner’s refusal to listen to their prayer, instead of taking the open and healthy course it has taken, their discontent would have burrowed under and bred ill will.
('16', 423, 1, 17, 937759) That son is a true son of his father, who rather than harbour ill will against him, frankly but respectfully tells him all he feels and equally respectfully resists him, if he cannot truthfully obey his commands.
('16', 423, 1, 18, 937972) I apply the same law to the relations between the Government and the people.
('16', 423, 1, 19, 938049) There cannot be seasons when a man must suspend his conscience.
('16', 423, 1, 20, 938113) But just as a wise father will quickly agree with his son and not incur his ill will, especially if the family was in danger from without, even so a wise Government will quickly agree with the ryots, rather than incur their displeasure.
('16', 423, 1, 21, 938350) War cannot be permitted to give a licence to the officials to exact obedience to their orders, even though the ryots may consider them to be unreasonable and unjust.
('16', 423, 1, 22, 938516) The Commissioner steels the hearts of the ryots for continuing their course by telling them that for a revenue of four lakhs of rupees, he will for ever confiscate his hundred and fifty thousand acres of

('16', 424, 1, 2, 938766) land worth over 3 crores of rupees, and for ever declare the holders, their wives and children unworthy of holding any lands in Kaira.
('16', 424, 1, 3, 938901) He considers the ryots to be misguided and contumacious in the same breath.
('16', 424, 1, 4, 938977) These are solemn words:
('16', 424, 2, 5, 939001) Do not be under the impression that our mamlatdars and our Talatis will realize the assessment by attaching and selling your movable property.

('16', 424, 2, 22, 939937) The Commissioner has done the Ahmedabad strikers and me a cruel wrong in saying that the strikers knowingly broke their vow.
('16', 424, 2, 23, 940062) He was present at the meeting where the settlement was declared.
('16', 424, 2, 24, 940127) He may hold that the strikers had broken their vow (though his speech at the meeting produced a contrary impression) but there is nothing to show that the strikers knowingly broke their vow.
('16', 424, 2, 25, 940318) On the contrary, it was entirely kept by their resuming their work on their getting for the first day wages demanded by them, and the final decision as to wages being referred to arbitration.
('16', 424, 2, 26, 940510) The strikers had suggested arbitration which the mill owners had rejected.
('16', 424, 3, 27, 940585) Their struggle in its essence was for a 35 per cent increase in their wages or such increase as an arbitration board may decide.

('16', 427, 7, 14, 945110) 296. SPEECH AT OD
('16', 427, 8, 15, 945128) April 16, 1918 If a person whose name we chance to mention appears unexpectedly at the spot, we usually say that he will live to be a hundred years.
('16', 427, 8, 16, 945277) Thus has it happened here.
('16', 427, 8, 17, 945304) The moment we thought of Vallabhbhai, we sighted him coming this way.
('16', 427, 8, 18, 945374) I had hoped to meet you last week, but I could not come here as I had to go to Bombay, and was then at Ahmedabad to see Mr. Pratt.
('16', 427, 8, 19, 945505) Before I acquaint you with the talks I have had with the top officers whom I met in Bombay, let me tell you what I heard about you in Nadiad.
('16', 427, 8, 20, 945647) I was told that the people of Od are quite spirited but that they have, till now, used their courage and strength, not for their good, but in quarrelling and wrangling among themselves.
('16', 427, 8, 21, 945833) And so it happens that this soil of Kheda, fertile and lovely, which your forefathers had transformed into a land of gold, has been ruined while you have been stubbornly fighting of your claims against one another.
('16', 427, 8, 22, 946048) 2 We shall not succeed in a struggle of any kind so long as this state of affairs continues.
('16', 427, 9, 23, 946141) 1 A translation of this appeared also in New India, 23 4 19l8. 2 The Bombay Chronicle, 20 4 1918, reports Gandhiji as having said: “For years you have been exhausting your energy and fearlessness in fighting each other.
('16', 427, 9, 24, 946361) For once, rise and be united and use the same strong elements to fight the ‘fear of Sirkar’, the common enemy.”
('16', 428, 0, 1, 946473) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 429
('16', 428, 1, 2, 946519) have taken the pledge to carry on our struggle to the bitter end and secure justice.
('16', 428, 1, 3, 946604) I can assure you that, if we could forget our past enmities and live together harmoniously, success is ours.
('16', 428, 1, 4, 946713) Mr. Pratt, Mr. Carmichael and [Sir James] Duboulay shook heads and strongly disapproved of our struggle.
('16', 428, 1, 5, 946818) During the course of our talks, they remarked: “You do not know the people of Kheda.
('16', 428, 1, 6, 946903) We do not agree that this struggle will result in their progress and uplift or raise them morally.
('16', 428, 1, 7, 947002) Rather, it will teach them to be defiant.” I am telling you what opinion the top officials of the Revenue Department hold about you.
('16', 428, 1, 8, 947135) In the struggle you have embarked upon, you must maintain the utmost truthfulness, not partial.
('16', 428, 1, 9, 947231) When Prahlad was asked, “Where is your God Vishnu?”, he replied: “On land and in water, in the sky and in the nether regions; I see the Almighty Vishnu wherever I look.” In the same way, only if we find truth all round us may we call this struggle satyagraha.
('16', 428, 1, 10, 947491) We cannot have one set of manners in public and another in private.
('16', 428, 1, 11, 947559) Truth is all pervasive as the Essence that we know as Vishnu.
('16', 428, 1, 12, 947621) Just as we cannot say that Vishnu is non existent in a certain place, so also we cannot say that truth exists at one place but not at some other.
('16', 428, 1, 13, 947767) As you all belong to the same village and the same community and follow the same profession, you must learn to apologize to one another [for your errors] and live harmoniously.
('16', 428, 1, 14, 947944) Anyone who says that satyagraha may be used only against the Government has not understood the meaning of satyagraha at all.
('16', 428, 1, 15, 948069) We do not want to fight the Government with threats and arrogant defiance; we want to fight it by submitting ourselves voluntarily to suffering.
('16', 428, 1, 16, 948214) Those who suffer with understanding and knowledge to end suffering always succeed.
('16', 428, 1, 17, 948297) This is the only way for you if you wish to win in this struggle.
('16', 428, 1, 18, 948363) In Nayaka, notices of confiscation were issued to twenty five farmers and their lands were confiscated.
('16', 428, 1, 19, 948467) I wrote a letter 1 to congratulate these brave friends when I heard of this.
('16', 428, 1, 20, 948544) I told them that the confiscation would remain only in the Government records.
('16', 428, 1, 21, 948623) All the same, I said, their pledge was that they would remain adamant even if their lands were confiscated, that there was no need to cheer up satyagrahis.
('16', 428, 1, 22, 948779) They should have nothing but congratulations.
('16', 428, 1, 23, 948825) This being an occasion for rejoicing, I sent them congratulations, not consolations.
('16', 428, 1, 24, 948910) I appeal to you also to welcome gladly orders of confiscation.
('16', 428, 1, 25, 948973) I cannot even dream that the Government will ever be able to confiscate our lands.
('16', 428, 2, 26, 949056) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('16', 429, 0, 1, 949083) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 429, 1, 2, 949125) That is impossible under British rule.
('16', 429, 1, 3, 949164) Should the impossible become possible, I shall have no way open to me but to make myself an outlaw against the British Government, which boils down to this, that the lands will not really be confiscated.
('16', 429, 1, 4, 949368) You have committed no crime in taking the pledge; on the contrary, by doing so, you have averred your loyalty to the State.
('16', 429, 1, 5, 949492) The crops having been less than four annas, we appealed for suspension of the collection of land revenue as provided in their law, made petitions, held meetings to ask for some relief and our representatives in the legislature tried all remedies provided in law.
('16', 429, 1, 6, 949755) The Government turned a deaf ear to all this.
('16', 429, 1, 7, 949801) What, then, should a brave, manly and loyal people do under the circumstances ?
('16', 429, 1, 8, 949881) The right relation between the Government and the people is that, in case of difference between the two, the former should always bow to popular opinion.
('16', 429, 1, 9, 950035) We do not demand that the Government should accept what we say and yield.
('16', 429, 1, 10, 950109) We ask that, if our case is proved, justice be done to us.
('16', 429, 1, 11, 950168) We asked for the appointment of arbitrators, but the Government turned down even that request.
('16', 429, 1, 12, 950263) Mr. Pratt believes that the people should have no say in the matter.
('16', 429, 1, 13, 950332) We have been victims of this policy for the last fifty years; we have become impoverished through fear.
('16', 429, 1, 14, 950436) We have not money enough for repairs to our houses.

('16', 435, 4, 22, 965485) 299. INSTRUCTIONS TO VOLUNTEERS
('16', 435, 5, 23, 965517) SATYAGRAHA CAMP, NADIAD, April 17, 1918
('16', 435, 6, 24, 965557) 1. The volunteers must remember that, as this is a satyagraha campaign, they must abide by truth under all circumstances.
('16', 435, 7, 25, 965679) 2. In satyagraha, there can be no room for rancour; which means that a satyagrahi should utter no harsh word about anyone, from a ravania
('16', 436, 0, 1, 965817) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 437
('16', 436, 1, 2, 965863) to the Governor himself; if someone does so, it is the volunteer’s duty to stop him.
('16', 436, 2, 3, 965948) 3. Rudeness has no place in satyagraha.
('16', 436, 2, 4, 965988) Perfect courtesy must be shown even to those who may look upon us as their enemies and the villagers must be taught to do the same.
('16', 436, 2, 5, 966120) Rudeness may harm our cause and the struggle may be unduly prolonged.
('16', 436, 2, 6, 966190) The volunteers should give the most serious attention to this matter and think out in their minds as many examples as possible of the advantages accruing from courtesy and the disadvantages resulting from rudeness and explain them to the people.
('16', 436, 3, 7, 966436) 4. The volunteers must remember that this is a holy war.
('16', 436, 3, 8, 966493) We embarked upon it because, had we not, we would have failed in our dharma.
('16', 436, 3, 9, 966570) And so all the rules which are essential for living a religious life must be observed here too.
('16', 436, 3, 10, 966666) 5. We are opposing the intoxication of power, that is, the blind application of law, and not authority as such.
('16', 436, 3, 11, 966778) The difference must never be lost sight of.
('16', 436, 3, 12, 966822) It is, therefore, our duty to help the officers in their other work.
('16', 436, 3, 13, 966891) 6. We are to apply here the same principle that we follow in a domestic quarrel.
('16', 436, 3, 14, 966972) We should think of the Government and the people as constituting a large family and act accordingly.
('16', 436, 3, 15, 967073) 7. We are not to boycott or treat with scorn those who hold different views from ours.
('16', 436, 3, 16, 967160) It must be our resolve to win them over by courteous behaviour.
('16', 436, 3, 17, 967224) 8. We must not try to be clever.
('16', 436, 3, 18, 967257) We must always be frank and straightforward.
('16', 436, 3, 19, 967302) 9. When they stay in villages, the volunteers should demand the fewest services from the village folk.
('16', 436, 3, 20, 967405) Wherever it is possible to reach a place on foot, they should avoid using a vehicle.
('16', 436, 3, 21, 967490) We must insist on being served the simplest food.
('16', 436, 3, 22, 967540) Restraining them from preparing dainties will add grace to the service we render.
('16', 436, 3, 23, 967622) 10. As they move about in villages, the volunteers should observe the economic condition of the people and the deficiencies in their education and try, in their spare time, to make them good.

('16', 438, 5, 13, 970567) 301. SPEECH AT DANTALI
('16', 438, 6, 14, 970590) April 17, 1918
('16', 438, 7, 15, 970605) We are carrying on this struggle to secure justice from the Government.
('16', 438, 7, 16, 970677) Whilst coming here, I observed people using goads to urge bullocks yoked to carts or ploughs.

('16', 459, 6, 8, 1019469) Messrs Irwin, Hill and Norman to be summoned to Ranchi to consider three alternatives:
('16', 459, 7, 9, 1019556) A. Each should state the percentage by which he is prepared to reduce the sharahbeshi, on conditions:
('16', 459, 8, 10, 1019658) (1) that it should be a substantial advance on their previous offer; any advance made by the planters will be accepted as being substantial, in the hope of mutual goodwill in the future.
('16', 459, 9, 11, 1019845) (2) that this will be fully accepted by Mr. Gandhi as a satisfactory settlement and that he will use his influence fully with the raiyats to make them loyally accept it and to bring about future peace in the relations of planters and their tenants.
('16', 459, 10, 12, 1020094) (3) that fully binding effect will be given to the settlement by legislation.
('16', 459, 10, 13, 1020172) B. Failing the above, the question of sharahbeshi should be submitted to arbitration.
('16', 459, 10, 14, 1020258) Such arbitration to be conducted on one or other of the following alternatives: (1) The appointment of a single arbitrator, who shall have the power to arbitrate between the limits of reduction of 20 and 40 per cent for Turkaulia and 25 and 40 per cent for Motihari and Peeprah.
('16', 459, 10, 15, 1020537) Such arbitrator to be selected with mutual agreement of planters and of Mr Gandhi.
('16', 459, 11, 16, 1020620) (2) The appointment of three arbitrators, one to be appointed by the planters, one by Mr Gandhi and the umpire to be appointed by these two, and failing agreement between these two, the umpire to be appointed Sir Edward Gait.
('16', 459, 11, 17, 1020846) The arbitration court so appointed shall have power to arbitrate between the limits of no reduction at all and a full reduction of 100 per cent.
('16', 459, 11, 18, 1020991) The arbitrators to be informed that for a settlement by consent the planters have offered a reduction of 20 per cent in Turkaulia and
('16', 460, 0, 1, 1021125) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 461
('16', 460, 1, 2, 1021171) 25 per cent in Motihari and Peeprah, and that Mr. Gandhi on behalf of the raiyats has offered to accept reduction of 40 per cent, but that those offers are now withdrawn and the arbitrators have full power to make any award they may settle.
('16', 460, 2, 3, 1021412) Under both alternatives, conditions (2) and (3) of A will apply.
('16', 460, 2, 4, 1021477) In addition under all the proposals, it shall be a condition that the existing obligation recorded in the settlement records shall be abolished and that in lieu thereof sharahbeshi shall be fixed at the rate at which it would have stood had commutation in their case taken place together with the others, less reduction that may be agreed upon or awarded by the arbitration.
('16', 460, 2, 5, 1021852) Under proposals for arbitration, both the planters and Mr. Gandhi would submit written statements of their case, and both would have the option of submitting a written reply to such statements.
('16', 460, 2, 6, 1022046) The parties will not be permitted to be represented by counsel or to be heard personally as of right.
('16', 460, 2, 7, 1022148) The arbitrator or arbitrators to have the power to call for any papers they may desire to question the planters or any other person, and to give their award within one week of the filing of the written statements and rejoinders of the parties.

('16', 461, 1, 2, 1023503) APPENDIX IV
('16', 461, 2, 3, 1023515) REPORT OF CHAMPARAN AGRARIAN ENQUIRY COMMITTEE
('16', 461, 3, 4, 1023562) October 3, 1917
('16', 461, 4, 5, 1023578) CHAPTER I
('16', 461, 5, 6, 1023588) CONSTITUTION AND PROCEDURE OF THE COMMITTEE
('16', 461, 6, 7, 1023632) APPOINTMENT OF COMMITTEE AND TERMS OF REFERENCE
('16', 461, 7, 8, 1023680) The Champaran Agrarian Enquiry Committee was appointed by the Government of Bihar and Orissa in Resolution No.
('16', 461, 7, 9, 1023791) 1890 C, dated the 10th June, 1917, which is reproduced below.
('16', 461, 8, 10, 1023853) “On various occasions during the past fifty years, the relations of landlords and tenants and the circumstances attending the growing of indigo in the Champaran district have been the cause of considerable anxiety.
('16', 461, 8, 11, 1024068) The conditions under which indigo was cultivated when the industry was flourishing required re adjustment when it declined simultaneously with a general rise in the prices offoodgrains; and it was partly on this account and partly owing to other local causes that disturbances broke out in certain indigo concerns in 1908. Mr. Gourlay was deputed by the Government of Bengal to investigate the causes of the disturbances; and his report and recommendations were considered at a series of conferences presided over by Sir Edward Baker and attended by the local officers of Government and representatives of the Bihar Planters’ Association.
('16', 461, 8, 12, 1024707) As the result of these discussions, revised conditions for the cultivation of indigo, calculated to remove the grievances of the raiyats, were accepted by the Bihar Planters’ Association.
('16', 461, 9, 13, 1024895) “In 1912 fresh agitation arose, connected not so much with the conditions under which indigo was grown as with the action of certain factories which were reducing their indigo manufacture and taking agreements from their tenants for the payment, in lieu of indigo cultivation, of a lump sum in temporarily leased villages or of an increase of rent in villages under permanent lease.
('16', 461, 9, 14, 1025278) Numerous petitions on this subject were presented from time to time to the local officers and to Government, and petitions were at the same time filed by raiyats of villages in the north of the
('16', 461, 10, 15, 1025472) Bettiah sub division in which indigo had never been grown, complaining of the levy of abwab or illegal additions to rent by their leaseholders, both Indian and European.
('16', 461, 11, 16, 1025642) The issues raised by all these petitions related primarily to rent and tenancy conditions; and as the revision settlement of the district was about to be undertaken, in the course of which the relations existing between landlords and tenants would come under detailed examination, it was thought advisable to await the report of the settlement officers before passing final orders on the petitions.
('16', 461, 11, 17, 1026041) The revision
('16', 462, 0, 1, 1026054) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 463
('16', 462, 1, 2, 1026100) settlement was started in the cold weather of 1913. On the 7th April, 1915, a resolution was moved in the local Legislative Council, asking for the appointment of a mixed committee of officials and non officials to enquire into the complaints of the raiyats and to suggest remedies.
('16', 462, 1, 3, 1026383) It was negatived by a large majority, including 12
('16', 462, 2, 4, 1026434) out of the 16 non official members of the Council present, on the ground that the appointment of such a committee at that stage was unnecessary, as the settlement officers were engaged in the collection of all the material required for the decision of the questions at issue, and an additional enquiry of the nature proposed would merely have the effect of further exacerbating the relations of landlord and tenant, which were already feeling the strain of the settlement operations.
('16', 462, 3, 5, 1026918) “The settlement operations have now been completed in the northern portion of the district and are approaching completion in the remainder, and a mass of evidence regarding agricultural conditions and the relations between landlords and tenants has been collected.
('16', 462, 3, 6, 1027183) A preliminary report on the complaints of the tenants in the leased villages in the north of the Bettiah subdivision, in which no indigo is grown, has been received and action has already been taken to prohibit the levy ofillegal cesses and, in the case of the Bettiah Raj, to review the terms of the leases on which the villages concerned are held.
('16', 462, 3, 7, 1027533) As regards the complaints of the raiyats in
('16', 462, 4, 8, 1027577) other parts of the district, the final report of the settlement officer has not yet been received, but recent events have again brought into prominence the whole question of the relations between landlords and tenants and, in particular, the taking of agreements from the raiyats for compensation or for enhanced rent in return for the
('16', 462, 5, 9, 1027913) abandonment of indigo cultivation.
('16', 462, 5, 10, 1027948) In these circumstances, and in deference to representations which have been received from various quarters that the time has come when an enquiry by a joint body of officials and non officials might materially assist the Local Government in coming to a decision on the problems which have arisen, the Lieutenant Governor in Council has decided, without waiting for the final report of the settlement operations, to refer the questions at issue to a Committee of Enquiry, on which all interests concerned will be represented.
('16', 462, 6, 11, 1028473) “The following committee has accordingly been appointed with the approval of the Government of India:
('16', 462, 7, 12, 1028575) PRESIDENT
('16', 462, 8, 13, 1028585) F. G. Sly, Esq., C.S.I., Commissioner, Central Provinces.
('16', 462, 9, 14, 1028643) MEMBERS
('16', 462, 10, 15, 1028651) The Hon’ble Mr. L. C. Adami, I.C.S, Superintendent and Remembrancer of Legal Affairs, Bihar and Orissa.
('16', 462, 11, 16, 1028755) The Hon’ble Raja Harihar Prasad Narayan Singh, Member of the Bihar and Orissa Legislative Council.
('16', 463, 0, 1, 1028854) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 463, 1, 2, 1028896) The Hon’ble Mr. D. J. Reid, Member of the Bihar and Orissa Legislative Council.
('16', 463, 2, 3, 1028976) G. Rainy, Esq., I.C.S., Deputy Secretary in the Finance Department of the Government of India.
('16', 463, 3, 4, 1029071) M. K. Gandhi, Esq.
('16', 463, 4, 5, 1029090) SECRETARY
('16', 463, 5, 6, 1029100) E. L. Tanner, Esq., I.C.S., Settlement Officer, South Bihar.
('16', 463, 6, 7, 1029161) “The duty of the Committee will be
('16', 463, 7, 8, 1029196) (1) to inquire into the relations between landlord and tenant in the Champaran district, including all disputes arising out of the manufacture and cultivation of indigo;
('16', 463, 8, 9, 1029366) (2) to examine the evidence on these subjects already available, supplementing it by such further inquiry, local and otherwise, as they may consider desirable; and
('16', 463, 9, 10, 1029530) (3) to report their conclusions to Government, stating the measures they recommend in order to remove any abuses or grievances which they may find to exist.
('16', 463, 10, 11, 1029687) “The Lieutenant Governor in Council desires to leave the Committee a free hand as to the procedure they will adopt in arriving at the facts.
('16', 463, 11, 12, 1029828) “The Committee will assemble about the 15th July and will, it is hoped, complete their labours within three months.”
('16', 463, 12, 13, 1029945) PROCEDURE FOLLOWED BY THE COMMITTEE
('16', 463, 13, 14, 1029981) 2. A notice was published by the Committee in the provincial newspapers and posted at the Motihari Collectorate and the Bettiah Sub divisional Office, inviting all persons, associations and public bodies who desired to give written evidence to send the same to the address of the Secretary of the Committee, and stating that the Committee would hold sittings at Bettiah, Motihari and any other centres where it was considered necessary, commencing about the 15th July.
('16', 463, 14, 15, 1030450) In response to this notice, written statements were received from the Bihar Planters’ Association and two managers, one of an indigo and the other of a non indigo concern, from twenty five raiyats, from Mr. Whitty, C.I.E., I.C.S.,
('16', 463, 15, 16, 1030681) Manager of the Bettiah estate, and from Mr. Sweeney, I.C.S., Settlement Officer, North Bihar, Mr. Lewis, I.C.S., Sub divisional Officer of Bettiah, Mr. L. F. Morshead, I.C.S., Commissioner of Tirhut, and Mr. E. H. Johnston, I.C.S., formerly Sub divisional Officer of Bettiah.
('16', 463, 15, 17, 1030957) The Bihar Landholders’ Association was specially invited to submit a memorandum of its views, but replied that it was not in possession of the material and facts concerning the agrarian conditions in
('16', 464, 0, 1, 1031157) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 465
('16', 464, 1, 2, 1031203) Champaran and was not therefore in a position to submit a written opinion.
('16', 464, 2, 3, 1031278) The Committee held a preliminary meeting at Ranchi on the 11th July to decide the procedure and extent of its inquiry, and its public sittings commenced at Bettiah on Tuesday, the 17th July.
('16', 464, 2, 4, 1031469) Eight public sittings were held at Bettiah and Motihari at which nineteen witnesses were examined, consisting of four Government officers (the Settlement Officer, the Sub divisional Officer of Bettiah, the Collector of the Champaran district, and the Manager of the Bettiah estate), three representatives of the raiyats the representative of the Bihar Planters’ Association,
('16', 464, 3, 5, 1031844) and twelve managers of concerns.
('16', 464, 3, 6, 1031877) We also made local investigations at eight concerns, where we examined in detail the managers together with the factory registers and accounts and the raiyats who had submitted written memoranda, and then made numerous enquiries from the large bodies of raiyats assembled to meet us.
('16', 464, 4, 7, 1032161) We desire to acknowledge the great assistance derived by us from the official records placed at our disposal by the local Government and the full information given to us by the managers of concerns and the facilities afforded by them for the examination of their records and registers.
('16', 464, 5, 8, 1032447) CHAPTER II
('16', 464, 6, 9, 1032458) GRIEVANCES CONNECTED WITH INDIGO
('16', 464, 7, 10, 1032491) PRELIMINARY—THE LANDLORDS
('16', 464, 8, 11, 1032517) 3. The Government has supplied us with previous records relating to the history, economic condition and former agrarian disputes of the Champaran district.
('16', 464, 8, 12, 1032673) Our enquiry has not been sufficiently prolonged for us to be able to add usefully to that information, and we do not propose to reproduce in this report the materials already available, but only to state a few broad facts directly relevant to our present enquiry.
('16', 464, 8, 13, 1032937) For historical reasons, the district has always been one of large landed estates, and more than three fourths of it is still held by three large proprietors, viz., the Bettiah estate which has been under the management of the Court of Wards since 1898, the Ramnagar estate which has also been taken under management, and the Madhuban estate.
('16', 464, 8, 14, 1033279) The system of leasing villages to thikadars has always been largely followed by the Bettiah and Ramnagar estates, the number of villages managed direct and leased to thikadars now being as follows:

('16', 465, 1, 2, 1033703) The thikadari system has never prevailed to the same extent in the Madhuban
('16', 465, 2, 3, 1033779) estate of 163 villages, but some are also leased.
('16', 465, 3, 4, 1033829) The European indigo planters form much the most important class of thikadars in the district.
('16', 465, 3, 5, 1033923) Some of the older indigo concerns (e.g..
('16', 465, 3, 6, 1033964) Turkaulia, Peeprah,
('16', 465, 4, 7, 1033984) Motihari and Rajpur) have held many villages continuously in lease from the Bettiah estate since the first decade of the 19th century, while others have been established at later dates.
('16', 465, 4, 8, 1034170) In the north west of the district there are also European thikadars who
('16', 465, 5, 9, 1034242) have never grown indigo or have not done so until the last two years.
('16', 465, 5, 10, 1034312) In the Settlement of 1892 99 it was found that the European thikadars exercised landlord
('16', 465, 6, 11, 1034401) rights over 46 per cent of the district, and it seems likely that the area is now slightly larger.
('16', 465, 6, 12, 1034500) Broadly, it may be said that about half the district is in lease to European thikadars, and much more than half the district to thikadars of all kinds.
('16', 465, 6, 13, 1034652) Permanent leases known as mukarrari have in some cases been granted both by the Bettiah and Ramnagar estates.
('16', 465, 6, 14, 1034762) The Bettiah mukarrari leases date from the year 1888 and their
