('16', 465, 9, 18, 1035113) grant formed part of a large transaction for the raising of the sterling loan by which the debts of the estate were consolidated and the rate of interest payable on them reduced.
('16', 465, 9, 19, 1035292) Under the terms of these leases the position of the lease holder concerns is practically that of a zamindar, the rent being fixed in perpetuity.
('16', 465, 9, 20, 1035437) We have not succeeded in ascertaining the circumstances in which mukarrari leases were
('16', 465, 10, 21, 1035524) granted by the Ramnagar estate, but there seems little doubt that as in Bettiah their origin is to be found in the financial embarrassments of the proprietor.
('16', 465, 11, 22, 1035683) AREA UNDER INDIGO AND METHODS OF CULTIVATION
('16', 465, 12, 23, 1035728) 4. The area under indigo at the time of the Settlement of 1892 99 was
('16', 465, 13, 24, 1035798) 98,000 acres which was 6.63 per cent of the net cropped area, but its importance in
('16', 465, 14, 25, 1035882) the agricultural economy of the district was much greater than this percentage
('16', 465, 15, 26, 1035961) indicates.
('16', 465, 15, 27, 1035972) About one third of this area was cultivated by the indigo concerns in their
('16', 465, 16, 28, 1036048) own lands and about two thirds by tenants.
('16', 465, 16, 29, 1036091) Owing to the competition of synthetic
('16', 465, 17, 30, 1036129) indigo the area had fallen to 52,600 acres in 1907 and to 8,100 acres in 1914, but
('16', 465, 18, 31, 1036212) under the stimulus of high prices during the war, the area has again expanded to
('16', 465, 19, 32, 1036293) 21,900 acres in 1916. The cultivation of indigo carried on by the factories in lands
('16', 465, 20, 33, 1036378) which they occupy directly either as proprietors or tenure holders (commonly known as zirat cultivation) does not call for special notice.
('16', 465, 20, 34, 1036517) But the condition under which
('16', 466, 0, 1, 1036547) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 467
('16', 466, 1, 2, 1036593) indigo is grown by the tenants for the factories has in the past been the cause of disputes on several occasions, and though we do not consider it necessary to enter into the history of these disputes, we cannot explain the causes of the present unrest without giving some account of the system.
('16', 466, 1, 3, 1036889) In essentials it does not appear to have varied during the last 100 years.
('16', 466, 1, 4, 1036964) Under this system, the tenant agrees to grow indigo for the factory in a portion of his holding.
('16', 466, 1, 5, 1037061) The fraction of the holding so cultivated appears at one time to have been as high as five kathas in the bigha ( = one fourth), but before 1867 it had already been reduced to four kathas, and in 1868 it was fixed at three kathas, whence the name tinkathia which is commonly applied to this system.
('16', 466, 1, 6, 1037359) In 1910 the fraction was fixed at two kathas ( = one tenth) by a bye law of the Planters’ Association, but the name tinkathia has survived.
('16', 466, 1, 7, 1037499) Where indigo is grown
('16', 466, 2, 8, 1037521) under this system, the terms of the agreement between the landlord and the tenant are usually embodied in a document which is called the satta.
('16', 466, 2, 9, 1037665) In it the tenant
('16', 466, 3, 10, 1037682) acknowledges the receipt of an advance and binds himself to cultivate a specified area with indigo annually.
('16', 466, 3, 11, 1037791) The preparation and weeding of the selected fields, and the cutting of the crop when ripe, are done by the cultivator at his own expense the seed is given by the factory, and the sowing is done by the factory and raiyat jointly; the
('16', 466, 4, 12, 1038024) green crop is carted from the field to the factory at the factory’s expense.
('16', 466, 4, 13, 1038101) The rate to be paid for the bigha of indigo is fixed by the satta and does not vary with the actual
('16', 466, 5, 14, 1038201) outturn of plant.
('16', 466, 5, 15, 1038219) If owing to ca uses for which the tenant is not responsible the crop is a failure, only half rates are paid, provided the tenant is allowed to plough up the indigo in time to sow another crop during the same season.
('16', 466, 5, 16, 1038435) A portion of the price is given as an advance free of interest to the tenant at the beginning of the cultivating season, but is usually credited in the rent account and is not paid in cash.
('16', 466, 5, 17, 1038625) The satta
('16', 466, 6, 18, 1038635) also contains a penalty clause specifying the amount of the damages which the factory may recover from the tenant if he fails to carry out the agreement, e.g., if he sows other crops in the land measured for indigo.
('16', 466, 7, 19, 1038851) The khushki system by which the raiyat grows indigo for the factory but not
('16', 466, 8, 20, 1038927) under factory supervision and sells the produce by weight or some method of appraisement seems to have been rare in Champaran until a very recent date.
('16', 466, 8, 21, 1039079) It will be more fully discussed in a later paragraph.
('16', 466, 9, 22, 1039133) THE PRICE PAID FOR INDIGO
('16', 466, 10, 23, 1039159) 5. The price paid to the tenants for the indigo so cultivated has varied from time to time.
('16', 466, 10, 24, 1039251) We find that in 1869 after a period of friction and disturbance, the price generally paid by the factories was raised from approximately Rs. 6 8 0 to Rs. 9 per acre and again in 1877 after another troubled period to Rs. 11 5 0. In that year, it was also for the first time distinctly laid down—previous practice had varied—that the rent of the land under indigo was to be remitted.
('16', 466, 10, 25, 1039633) In 1897, the Bihar Planters’ Association spontaneously raised the rate to Rs. 12 per acre.
('16', 466, 10, 26, 1039724) Finally, in 1910, after.
('16', 467, 0, 1, 1039749) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 467, 1, 2, 1039791) Mr. Gourlay’s enquiry, the price was raised to Rs. 13 per acre at which it now stands.
('16', 467, 1, 3, 1039878) If the remission of the rent of the indigo lands be taken into account, the price received by the tenant is approximately Rs. 15 8 0 per acre.
('16', 467, 1, 4, 1040021) A general complaint was made to us by the tenant that the cultivation of indigo at this rate of payment caused them substantial pecuniary loss compared to the profits that they could derive from country crop at their present level of prices.
('16', 467, 1, 5, 1040263) Some leading planters have admitted, and it is not, we believe, seriously disputed by any that the direct return to the cultivator in money from indigo is less than from country crops, but stress is laid on certain indirect advantages, such as the undoubted value of indigo as a rotation crop, and also the benefit derived by the tenant from an advance free of interest at the beginning of the cultivating season which amounts to half the price of the crop.
('16', 467, 1, 6, 1040721) Finally, it is urged that the low rates of rent at which the tenants hold their land are directly connected with the growing of indigo and must be taken into account when the fairness of the price is considered.
('16', 467, 1, 7, 1040933) It is unnecessary for us to attempt the difficult task of estimating the pecuniary position of the tenant under the tinkathia system of indigo cultivation,
('16', 467, 2, 8, 1041089) because we are satisfied that on other grounds the system is radically defective and should be discontinued.
('16', 467, 3, 9, 1041198) DEFECTS IN THE SYSTEM UNDER WHICH INDIGO IS GROWN
('16', 467, 4, 10, 1041248) 6. There are several points connected with the system which in our opinion are directly responsible for its worst features.
('16', 467, 4, 11, 1041372) The first is that the price paid to the cultivator is fixed and remains unchanged for a long period of years.
('16', 467, 4, 12, 1041482) We are aware that the prices fixed by the Bihar Planters’ Association are minimum prices, but as soon as they have received the imprimatur of the Association, they are regarded as the
('16', 467, 5, 13, 1041666) authorized rates and in practice are paid by all concerns.
('16', 467, 5, 14, 1041725) In the course of fifty years, the price paid to the tenant has been doubled in order to adjust the price paid for indigo to the general rise in the level of prices during that period.
('16', 467, 5, 15, 1041909) But the price of indigo being fixed at each stage and the rise in general prices being continuous, it follows that, if the price was fair at the beginning of any period, it had become too low by the end of it.
('16', 467, 5, 16, 1042119) Of itself, this would tend to cause discontent, and it will be noticed that with the exception of the increase made in 1897, every rise in price was preceded by a period of friction and discontent, and a valid objection to the system is that an increase in the price of indigo was seldom effected except by disturbance and agitation.
('16', 467, 6, 17, 1042453) The second point is that the price is fixed on the area and does not vary with the outturn of the crop.
('16', 467, 6, 18, 1042557) This leads directly to two defects.
('16', 467, 6, 19, 1042593) The selection by the factory of the plots to be cultivated with indigo is a feature of the system which has often been called in question.
('16', 467, 6, 20, 1042732) It is certainly liable to abuse, e.g., it is asserted that homestead lands in the immediate vicinity of the village site and which are consequently the best manured are frequently selected for indigo.
('16', 467, 6, 21, 1042933) The real gravamen of
('16', 468, 0, 1, 1042954) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 469
('16', 468, 1, 2, 1043000) the charge about the selection of lands does not, however, lie in the possibility of abuse, but in the fact that the system itself is bad.
('16', 468, 1, 3, 1043139) So long as the planter has to pay the same price for a good or a bad crop, he will select for indigo the better lands in the holding.
('16', 468, 1, 4, 1043273) This selection of lands is resented by the cultivator not merely from the fact that the best lands are selected but because it involves interference with his freedom of action.
('16', 468, 1, 5, 1043450) We believe that this is a principal cause of the unpopularity of indigo, and in this respect the system is radically defective.
('16', 468, 2, 6, 1043578) The payment of a fixed rate per acre leads directly to another feature of the system which is equally responsible for its unpopularity, namely, the close supervision of the indigo cultivation exercised by the factory subordinates.
('16', 468, 2, 7, 1043809) This supervision undoubtedly affords an opportunity for a great deal of petty tyranny, and the cultivator resents being compelled to carry out the various cultivation processes not at the time most convenient to himself, but at the time when the work is considered necessary by factory subordinates.
('16', 468, 2, 8, 1044109) The system gives opportunities to the factory servants to harass cultivators against whom they may have a grudge; or to exact payment as the price of their favour.
('16', 468, 2, 9, 1044273) A good manager accessible to his raiyats
('16', 468, 3, 10, 1044314) may be able to keep the oppression of his subordinates within small limits, but even the best of managers cannot prevent altogether oppressive acts by low paid subordinates placed in a position of authority.
('16', 468, 3, 11, 1044522) So long as the payment is made on the area and does not vary with the outturn, and the tenant has no interest in the outturn, close supervision will be essential.
('16', 468, 3, 12, 1044685) In this respect also, we consider that the system is inherently bad.
('16', 468, 4, 13, 1044754) Another important objection to the tinkathia system is the fact that the
('16', 468, 5, 14, 1044827) growing of indigo is connected with a sense of obligation.
('16', 468, 5, 15, 1044886) We are satisfied that for the last fifty years the growing of tinkathia indigo has been disliked by the raiyat
('16', 468, 6, 16, 1044997) and that he would at any time have been glad to relinquish it.
('16', 468, 6, 17, 1045060) Whether such sense of obligation had any legal foundation is a matter for the decision of a legal tribunal, but its unpopularity is shown by the large extent to which the tenants have in recent years purchased their release.
('16', 468, 6, 18, 1045285) In the interests of the future peace of the districts, it is essential that the relations of landlord and tenant should be clearly defined by the law, and that the growing of indigo should cease to be connected with any sense of obligation or any customary right.
('16', 468, 7, 19, 1045549) PROPOSAL THAT THE “TINKATHIA” SYSTEM SHOULD BE ABOLISHED
('16', 468, 8, 20, 1045606) 7. We find therefore that the tinkathia system is unpopular with the raiyats who
('16', 468, 9, 21, 1045687) regard it as unprofitable, is radically defective in some important respects, and is inconsistent with the relations that should exist between landlord and tenant under modern conditions.
('16', 468, 9, 22, 1045875) We accordingly recommend that this system of growing indigo in Champaran should be altogether abolished, and that legislation should be undertaken to effect this change.
('16', 468, 9, 23, 1046045) This proposal will affect tenancies in which the growing of
('16', 469, 0, 1, 1046105) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 469, 1, 2, 1046147) indigo has been recorded as an incident of the tenancy in the Record of Rights and a recommendation on this point will be made in a later paragraph.
('16', 469, 2, 3, 1046296) FUTURE SYSTEM OF GROWING INDIGO
('16', 469, 3, 4, 1046328) 8. It is not our intention of course that indigo should cease to be grown but that it should be grown under fair and reasonable conditions.
('16', 469, 3, 5, 1046468) Indigo is already grown by some factories on the voluntary system (khushki), and we consider that this is the
('16', 469, 4, 6, 1046578) system which alone should be permitted for the future.
('16', 469, 4, 7, 1046633) The essential features of such a system are:
('16', 469, 5, 8, 1046678) (1) The tenant must be absolutely free to enter into the contract or to refrain from making it.
('16', 469, 6, 9, 1046774) (2) The particular plots to be devoted to indigo must be entirely at the option of the raiyat.
('16', 469, 7, 10, 1046869) (3) The price paid for the indigo must be settled by voluntary agreement and entirely on a commercial basis.
('16', 469, 8, 11, 1046978) (4) The price must be fixed on the weight of the crop, but such weight may, if agreed, be settled by appraisement of the weight by a selected panch 1
('16', 469, 9, 12, 1047128) instead of by actual weighment.
('16', 469, 10, 13, 1047160) (5) The contract must be for an emphatically short period not exceeding three years.
('16', 469, 11, 14, 1047245) To the last condition we attach importance.
('16', 469, 11, 15, 1047289) In the interests of the tenant, we do not think that he should be allowed to bind himself to his landlord to grow a particular crop at a rate of payment fixed for many years in advance, and in Champaran long contracts would directly tend to keep alive the sense of obligation which we desire to end.
('16', 469, 12, 16, 1047589) We are in general averse from fixing by outside authority the minimum prices to be paid for particular crops, because of the strong tendency of such prices to become maximum prices.
('16', 469, 12, 17, 1047771) In view, however, of the past history of the indigo industry, we believe that a safeguard of some kind will be necessary for the first few years.
('16', 469, 12, 18, 1047917) We recommend therefore that, until the Local Government is satisfied that the safeguard can be dispensed with, a minimum price for indigo should be fixed by the Bihar Planters’ Association, subject to the approval of the Commissioner of the Division.
('16', 469, 13, 19, 1048168) CONVERSION OF THE INDIGO OBLIGATION
('16', 469, 14, 20, 1048204) 9. The manufacture in Germany in the middle nineties of synthetic indigo, which enabled the German firms to undersell the natural product, produced a profound
('16', 469, 15, 21, 1048363) 1 Arbitrator
('16', 470, 0, 1, 1048376) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 471
('16', 470, 1, 2, 1048422) effect on the indigo industry in Bihar.
('16', 470, 1, 3, 1048462) The price of the natural dye steadily diminished and though efforts were made to reduce the cost of production and to increase the outturn (e.g., by the introduction of the Java plant which gave a larger outturn of colouring matter per acre), these efforts met with but indifferent success.
('16', 470, 1, 4, 1048753) One by one, the factories abandoned the hope of successful competition with the synthetic dye and began to turn their attention to other measures, the principal being the taking of compensation in one form or another for releasing the tenant from the cultivation of indigo.
('16', 470, 2, 5, 1049027) Two concerns in the north of the district substituted a fixed payment of paddy in lieu of the cultivation of indigo, but this practice was recently abandoned owing to the disapproval expressed by Government.
('16', 470, 2, 6, 1049235) Some other concerns substituted sugarcane or oats for indigo.
('16', 470, 2, 7, 1049297) We have been informed that the Bara concern has in some cases substitued sattas for l_ kathas of sugar in lieu of 3 kathas of indigo.
('16', 470, 3, 8, 1049431) are still grown to a limited extent in lieu of indigo by the Mallahia, Bairia and Kuria concerns.
('16', 470, 3, 9, 1049529) The growing of crops other than indigo under satta conditions is expressly
('16', 470, 4, 10, 1049604) forbidden by a bye law of the Bihar Planters’ Association adopted in 1910 at the instance of Government after the disturbances which took place at the end of 1908. Those disturbances affected four factories, of which Mallahia, Bairia and Kuria are three.
('16', 470, 4, 11, 1049859) It is, we think, regrettable that those factories should have continued to act in direct contravention of a bye law which was passed with special reference to practices in these concerns.
('16', 470, 5, 12, 1050047) In 1911, a general movement towards the abandonment of indigo began which continued unchecked till the outbreak of the war in 1914, when a large rise in the price of indigo once more made the manufacture a profitable one.
('16', 470, 5, 13, 1050269) Two different methods of commutation were generally adopted.
('16', 470, 5, 14, 1050330) In some cases, agreements were executed by the tenants for the payment of enhanced rents, commonly known as sharahbeshi.
('16', 470, 5, 15, 1050451) In other cases, the raiyats purchased freedom from indigo for a
('16', 470, 6, 16, 1050515) lumpsum, sometimes paid in cash and sometimes by a money bond bearing 12 per cent interest.
('16', 470, 6, 17, 1050607) This method is called tawan or tamam.
('16', 470, 6, 18, 1050645) In both cases, a promise was given to the tenant that in consideration of the payment of sharahbeshi or tawan, as
('16', 470, 7, 19, 1050759) the case may be, neither the factory itself nor its successors in interests would in future ask him to grow indigo for them under the tinkathia conditions.
('16', 470, 8, 20, 1050915) Sharahbeshi has been taken by only five concerns, viz., Turkaulia, Motihari,
('16', 470, 9, 21, 1050992) Peeprah, Jallaha and Sirni, the two last being outworks of Turkaulia which were sold in recent years, and only in the villages which the factories held in mukarrari lease
('16', 470, 10, 22, 1051163) from the Bettiah estate and the very few held by them in proprietary right.
('16', 470, 10, 23, 1051239) In the villages held in temporary lease all these concerns, except Peeprah, took tawan, and
('16', 470, 11, 24, 1051331) it was also taken by nine other concerns, of which the most important are Rajpur, Bara, Bairia and Bhelwa.
('16', 470, 11, 25, 1051438) The rates at which sharahbeshi was taken varied widely in
('16', 471, 0, 1, 1051496) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 471, 1, 2, 1051538) the different concerns, but on the average the enhancement amounted to between 50 and 60 per cent of the previous rents.
('16', 471, 1, 3, 1051659) The following table shows the average amount of the enhancement and the proportion it bore to the previous rent in four concerns:
('16', 471, 2, 4, 1051789) Serial No.

('16', 471, 11, 13, 1051965) The percentage is highest in Peeprah where the previous rents had been exceptionally low.
('16', 471, 11, 14, 1052055) The rate of tawan also varied, and was usually calculated on the portion of the holding in which indigo was grown, i.e., three kathas in the bigha.
('16', 471, 12, 15, 1052203) The payment was frequently fixed on the basis of the amount which the factory had realized in indigo damage suits when the tenant had failed to carry out his agreement.
('16', 471, 12, 16, 1052372) The amount taken as tawan varied from Rs. 66 to Rs. 20 per acre and probably on the
('16', 471, 13, 17, 1052456) average was between Rs. 50 and Rs. 60 per acre, which would be equivalent to a payment of Rs. 7 8 0 to Rs. 9 on each acre of the holding.
('16', 471, 14, 18, 1052594) In the concerns affected by this conversion, about 50,000 acres of indigo were formerly cultivated under tinkathia conditions, and of this area over 40,000 acres were released—18,000 acres by taking tawan and 22,000 acres by taking sharahbeshi.
('16', 471, 14, 19, 1052839) At the recent settlement, tinkathia has been recorded as an incident of the tenancy only in the five concerns of Turkaulia, Motihari, Peeprah, Jallaha and Sirni, and the area of
('16', 471, 15, 20, 1053017) indigo over which it is claimed by these factories amounts to 1,910 acres, though we\ have no information as to what extent the incident has been recorded.
('16', 471, 15, 21, 1053173) We have endeavoured to secure statistics of the present indigo cultivation from all factories and, although not quite complete for the whole district, the omissions are insignificant.
('16', 471, 15, 22, 1053357) They show that a total area of 26,848 acres of indigo is made up as follows:
('16', 471, 16, 23, 1053434) Zirat cultivation 10,697 acres
('16', 471, 17, 24, 1053465) Tinkathia cultivation 9,542 ,,
('16', 471, 18, 25, 1053496) Khushki cultivation 6,609 ,,
('16', 471, 19, 26, 1053525) COMMUTATION BY ENHANCED RENT—“SHARAHBESHI”
('16', 471, 20, 27, 1053568) 10. The enhanced rents taken in lieu of indigo in every case exceeded the limit
('16', 472, 0, 1, 1053648) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 473
('16', 472, 1, 2, 1053694) of two annas in the rupee to which enhancement contracts are ordinarily restricted by section 29, clause (b) of the Bengal Tenancy Act.
('16', 472, 1, 3, 1053830) Under the third proviso to the section, however, this limit does not apply when the raiyat has held his land at a
('16', 472, 2, 4, 1053944) specially low rate of rent in consideration of cultivating a particular crop for the convenience of his landlord.
('16', 472, 2, 5, 1054058) It is contended by the concerns that their tenants were under an obligation to grow indigo in three katha in the bigha of their holdings, that
('16', 472, 3, 6, 1054201) the rents of holdings had been determined in consideration of this obligation, and that because of the obligation the concerns had refrained from enhancement of rents.
('16', 472, 3, 7, 1054369) It is asserted, in fact, that the obligation to grow indigo was an incident of the tenancy.
('16', 472, 3, 8, 1054461) In support of this contention, the concerns have referred to certain sattas and kabuliyats executed by some of the tenants before 1880 in which the obligation to grow indigo in three kathas in the bigha is recorded.
('16', 472, 3, 9, 1054677) On behalf of the raiyats, it is
('16', 472, 4, 10, 1054709) contended that in fact they were under no legal obligation to grow indigo or that if there were any obligation they did not hold their land at a specially low rate of rent because of it.
('16', 472, 4, 11, 1054896) It is also urged that whether the enhancements were legal or not, it is inequitable that the tenants should be called on to pay an enhanced rent as the price of relief from a burden under which they had long suffered.
('16', 472, 4, 12, 1055114) Finally, it is urged that the agreements were executed by the raiyats under coercion or under influence or in
('16', 472, 5, 13, 1055224) ignorance of their true legal position.
('16', 472, 6, 14, 1055264) Mr. Sweeney, Settlement Officer, informed us that these enhancements had been the subject of enquiry during the Revision Settlement and he described to us the principles followed by the Settlement Department in dealing with these cases.
('16', 472, 6, 15, 1055501) The legality of the enhancements has also been considered by the Civil Court in nine suits brought by tenants of the Turkaulia concern asking for a declaration that the kabuliyats in which they agreed to pay the enhanced rents should be declared void on
('16', 472, 7, 16, 1055755) the ground that they were executed under coercion and were not in accordance with the law.
('16', 472, 7, 17, 1055846) These suits are now before the High Court in appeal.
('16', 472, 8, 18, 1055899) Our enquiries satisfied us that the feeling of the raiyats against enhancements
('16', 472, 9, 19, 1055979) was very strong and that every legal means would be used to upset them.
('16', 472, 9, 20, 1056051) Without special legislation, prolonged and expensive litigation seemed inevitable.
('16', 472, 9, 21, 1056134) However such litigation might end, it would produce a permanent embitterment of feeling on both sides.
('16', 472, 9, 22, 1056237) We are also impressed with the great desirability of an immediate settlement between landlords and tenants of this difficult question.
('16', 472, 9, 23, 1056372) In these circumstances, it seemed to us very important that if possible a settlement should be arranged by consent with mutual concessions made by both parties in the interests of peace and goodwill.
('16', 472, 9, 24, 1056572) With this object, we entered into negotiations with the representatives of the three principal concerns, and we are glad to report that our efforts have been successful.
('16', 472, 9, 25, 1056742) At a meeting held in Ranchi on 29th September at which Messrs Hill, Irwin, and Norman, the managers of Turkaulia Limited, Motihari
('16', 473, 0, 1, 1056873) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 473, 1, 2, 1056915) Limited, and Peeprah concerns, were present and at which Mr. Gandhi represented the interests of the raiyats, an agreement was reached on the following terms:
('16', 473, 2, 3, 1057074) (1) The enhancement effected by sharahbeshi shall be reduced with effect from the commencement of the fasli year 1325 (October 1917) by 20 per
('16', 473, 3, 4, 1057217) cent in the case of Turkaulia Limited, and by 26 per cent in the case of Motihari Limited and the Peeprah concern, the rents for years prior to 1325 fasli remaining unchanged at the Survey Settlement rates.
('16', 473, 4, 5, 1057424) (2) The existing indigo obligation recorded in the Survey Records shall be abolished from the commencement of the fasli year 1325 and in lieu the enhanced rent (sharahbeshi) shall be fixed at the rate at which it would
('16', 473, 5, 6, 1057643) have stood had commutation taken place together with the others less the reduction now agreed upon.
('16', 473, 6, 7, 1057743) As the representative of the raiyats, our colleague Mr. Gandhi fully accepts
('16', 473, 7, 8, 1057820) this arrangement as a satisfactory settlement and he undertakes to use his influence fully with the raiyats to make them loyally accept it and to bring about future peace in
('16', 473, 8, 9, 1057994) the relations of planters and their tenants.
('16', 473, 8, 10, 1058039) This settlement is subject to the condition that full binding effect must be given to it by legislation.
('16', 473, 8, 11, 1058144) We regard this settlement as equitable to all interests concerned and therefore recommend that action should be immediately taken by emergency legislation to render this settlement by consent binding on all the parties concerned.
('16', 473, 9, 12, 1058374) As regards the two small concerns of Jallaha and Sirni, which are not parties to this settlement by consent, we recommend that the reduction should be fixed at 26 per cent upon the same conditions as in Motihari and Peeprah.
('16', 473, 10, 13, 1058599) COMMUTATION BY MONEY PAYMENTS—“TAWAN”
('16', 473, 11, 14, 1058637) 11. We have still to consider the cases in which the indigo obligation has been commuted for a lump sum payment which method we regard as distinctly prejudicial to the interests of the tenants.
('16', 473, 11, 15, 1058831) The taking of tawan has been defended by
('16', 473, 12, 16, 1058872) the factories in two different ways.
('16', 473, 12, 17, 1058909) Some concerns do not allege that there was anyincident of tenancy or obligation on the tenant to grow indigo apart from the satta and urge that the payment was made by the tenants for the termination of a
('16', 473, 13, 18, 1059114) contract on terms mutually satisfactory to the parties.
('16', 473, 13, 19, 1059170) But this theory that the payment was made by the tenants for the termination of a contract appears to us to be exposed to almost insuperable difficulties.
('16', 473, 13, 20, 1059325) It is not obvious why, when both parties desire to terminate a contract, a large payment should be made by one of them, particularly when the proposal to terminate the contract originates with the party who is to receive the money.
('16', 473, 13, 21, 1059557) In no concern, we believe, did the rate of payment vary according to the length of time which the contract had still to run, though this might certainly have been expected had the contract alone been in question.
('16', 473, 13, 22, 1059770) Again, in every
('16', 474, 0, 1, 1059786) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 475
('16', 474, 1, 2, 1059832) case where tawan was taken, it was a part of the bargain that the tenant received a
('16', 474, 2, 3, 1059916) promise that he would never again be required to grow indigo either by the present proprietors of the factory or by any person to whom the factory might be transferred.
('16', 474, 2, 4, 1060085) There is no doubt, in our opinion, that what the raiyat paid for was a final release
('16', 474, 3, 5, 1060170) from the obligation to grow indigo and that he would not have voluntarily paid such large sums merely for release from the unexpired period of the satta.
('16', 474, 4, 6, 1060324) The older factories which took sharahbeshi in their mukarrari villages and tawan in the villages in temporary lease give a different explanation.
('16', 474, 4, 7, 1060470) They assert in
('16', 474, 5, 8, 1060485) both cases the existence of an incident of tenancy, i.e., an obligation to grow indigo as a part of the condition on which the tenant held his land.
('16', 474, 5, 9, 1060634) But if the factory enhanced rents in a temporarily leased village, nine tenths of the profit would at the next renewal pass to the superior landlord.
('16', 474, 5, 10, 1060784) The result is that a peculiar claim is advanced by the factory.
('16', 474, 5, 11, 1060848) It is asserted that the obligation to grow indigo imposed on the tenant could be claimed only by the factory and not by the superior landlord, and that therefore the factory was entitled to commute the incident and take the whole of the proceeds, in which the superior landlord could claim no share.
('16', 474, 5, 12, 1061148) This assumes that a temporary lease holder, when setting land with a tenant, can create an incident of tenancy the benefit of which can be claimed only by him.
('16', 474, 5, 13, 1061308) No legal authority for this position was placed before us, and we regard it as wholly untenable.
('16', 474, 5, 14, 1061405) If an incident attaches to the tenancy, then the benefit can be enjoyed by the lease holder only so long as he holds the lease and no longer.
('16', 474, 5, 15, 1061547) The indigo incident has not been claimed and is not now claimed by the Bettiah estate, and the claim of the factories in the form in which it has been presented to us must, we think, be wholly rejected.
('16', 474, 6, 16, 1061750) It seems to us, therefore, that whichever theory be adopted, the taking of tawan was not justified in temporarily leased villages.
('16', 474, 6, 17, 1061881) If it be said that the payment
('16', 474, 7, 18, 1061912) was for the termination of a contract, the answer is that that is not what the tenant desired to buy, nor is it the most important thing the factory sold, that is, final release from indigo.
('16', 474, 7, 19, 1062103) If it is said that the tenant was under an obligation to grow indigo as one of the conditions on which he held his land it is evident that the payment was of the nature of capitalized rent and if so the interests of the superior landlord were prejudiced.
('16', 474, 7, 20, 1062358) Since the taking of tawan was within the knowledge of the
('16', 474, 8, 21, 1062416) Bettiah estate, which took no action to stop it, we consider that the estate itself must accept some share of the responsibility.
('16', 474, 8, 22, 1062546) We recommend that where tawan has been
('16', 474, 9, 23, 1062585) taken in temporarily leased villages, the Bettiah estate should make it a condition of the renewal of the temporary leases that 25 per cent of the tawan collected should be
('16', 474, 10, 24, 1062758) paid to the estate, and that the estate should refund it to the tenant concerned.
('16', 474, 10, 25, 1062840) Moreover, since tawan must be regarded at least in part as capitalized rent, we
('16', 474, 11, 26, 1062920) recommend that the Bettiah estate should for a period of seven years forgo any enhancement, which may be granted in the Settlement Courts on the ground of the
('16', 475, 0, 1, 1063079) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 475, 1, 2, 1063121) rise in prices, of the rent of a tenant who has paid tawan.
('16', 475, 2, 3, 1063181) We have been informed that in a few cases where villages had very recently come into lease to a factory, the management procured the execution of sattas by the raiyats and, after growing indigo for one or two years, commuted the indigo rights by taking tawan.
('16', 475, 2, 4, 1063441) Action of this kind seems to us totally indefensible and the Bettiah
('16', 475, 3, 5, 1063510) estate is bound in the interests of its tenants to interfere.
('16', 475, 3, 6, 1063572) We recommend that in such cases, the Court of Wards should refuse to renew the temporary leases of the concern unless the whole of the tawan is refunded.
('16', 475, 4, 7, 1063726) Tawan was also taken in some of the permanently leased villages by a few
('16', 475, 5, 8, 1063799) concerns, of which the most important is Rajpur.
('16', 475, 5, 9, 1063848) In view of the fact that a reduction of sharahbeshi has been accepted under the settlement by consent in the interests of future peace and goodwill, we consider that the mukarraridars should be advised by the Local Government to make a refund on a similar basis of a portion of the tawan taken by them.
('16', 475, 5, 10, 1064151) In consideration of the low rate of tawan taken by the Rajpur concern,
('16', 475, 6, 11, 1064222) we consider that a reduction of ten per cent would be adequate.
('16', 475, 7, 12, 1064286) SPECIAL CASE OF RAJGHAT CONCERN
('16', 475, 8, 13, 1064318) 12. Finally, we desire to refer to the peculiar conditions of the Rajghat factory (manager, Mr. Apperley), where no incident of tenancy is claimed but where written contracts had been entered into by the tenants for the growing of indigo in consideration of freedom from rent enhancement.
('16', 475, 8, 14, 1064607) On the expiry of these contracts, this arrangement was continued by mutual consent, and consequently the factory refrained from applying for rent enhancement at the proper time during the revision settlement.
('16', 475, 8, 15, 1064816) At our local enquiry, we were informed by the tenant that they now desired to abandon indigo.
('16', 475, 8, 16, 1064910) Under these circumstances, it is only reasonable that the factory should be enabled to apply for a general enhancement of rents in accordance with the settlement procedure, but as the time limit for this procedure under section 105 of the Bengal Tenancy Act has already expired, this is impossible unless the Government takes action under section 112 of the Bengal Tenancy Act.
('16', 475, 8, 17, 1065288) Failing this course, we recommend that the special legislation should contain a clause enabling this concern to take advantage of section 105.
('16', 475, 9, 18, 1065431) CHAPTER III “ABWAB” AND THE RENEWAL OF “THIKA” LEASES “ABWAB”
('16', 475, 10, 19, 1065493) 13. Our enquiry has shown that until recently, certain sums were regularly levied from the tenants in addition to the recorded rent by the thikadars of the
('16', 475, 11, 20, 1065649) non indigo concerns in the north west portion of the district, which unauthorized dues are generally known as abwab.
('16', 475, 11, 21, 1065766) The imposition of abwab was forbidden by
('16', 476, 0, 1, 1065807) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 477
('16', 476, 1, 2, 1065853) section 54 of the Decennial Settlement Regulation (VIII of 1793), which definitely laid down that all landlords should consolidate the abwab with the rent into one sum before a fixed date and prohibited under penalty the imposition of any new abwab.
('16', 476, 2, 3, 1066103) This prohibition was again enforced by section 10 of Act X of 1859, and by section 74 of the Bengal Tenancy Act (VIII of 1885).
('16', 476, 2, 4, 1066231) For many years past, no abwab have
('16', 476, 3, 5, 1066266) been realized in villages under the direct management of the Bettiah Estate, but although the estate received no direct benefit therefrom, the thikadars of non indigo
('16', 476, 4, 6, 1066433) concerns continued their realization until this illegal practice was recently brought to notice at the revision settlement, when orders were issued by the Court of Wards prohibiting the levy of anything in excess of the recorded rent and authorized cesses.
('16', 476, 4, 7, 1066690) The evidence taken by us shows that this action has achieved its object.
('16', 476, 4, 8, 1066763) In some indigo concerns we found that the tenants made a small annual payment known as farkhawan, which is usually taken direct by the patwari at the time of rent collection.
('16', 476, 5, 9, 1066938) This practice is also contrary to the law, the landlord being responsible for the patwari’s emoluments.
('16', 476, 5, 10, 1067042) The systematic levy of abwab still prevails in the Ramnagar estate.
('16', 476, 5, 11, 1067110) In one lease produced before us, certain abwab are specified as payable by the thikadar to the estate, and in addition there is a clause binding him to assist in collecting certain dues “which are realized from the tenants and banias according to the ancient custom”.
('16', 476, 5, 12, 1067378) The abwab realized by the thikadars bear many names, 1 most of
('16', 476, 6, 13, 1067441) which are of old standing, but the full development of the system seems to be comparatively recent and does not go back beyond the last quarter of the nineteenth century.
('16', 476, 6, 14, 1067612) It took the form of an amalgamation and an enhancement of the old abwaband the consolidated levy thenceforth passed under a single name, usually salami or panikharcha (irrigation due).
('16', 476, 6, 15, 1067797) Occasionally, as in the Bhasurari concern, this levy is called tinkathia by analogy with the indigo obligation although no indigo is grown.
('16', 476, 6, 16, 1067937) The amount of the levy is usually Rs. 3 to Rs. 3 8 0 per bigha and is
('16', 476, 7, 17, 1068007) equivalent to an addition to the rent of from 60 to 100 per cent.
('16', 476, 7, 18, 1068073) The collection of abwab in this manner has been systematically adopted by the European thikadars of
('16', 476, 8, 19, 1068173) this estate who until recently never grew indigo, and also by a number of Indian thikadars and petty proprietors.
('16', 476, 8, 20, 1068287) We received no complaint of the systematic collection of abwab in the rest of the district, and it appears that at least of recent
('16', 476, 9, 21, 1068418) 1 The names of the principal abwab, according to the report, are Bandhberi (embankment due), Panikharcha (irrigation due), Chulhi awan and Kolhu awan (taxes on turmeric ovens and sugarcane or oil presses), Bapahi putahi (inheritance tax), Marwach and Sagaura (tax on marriages of girls and windows), Hisabana (accountancy fee), Tahrir (writing fee), Jungla Isamnavisi (fee for writing forest lists), Batchhapi (fee on weights and measures), Dasahari and Chaitnawami (festival taxes), Gurubhenti and Uprohiti (priestly dues).
('16', 476, 9, 22, 1068943) These abwab were not always levied under these separate names and varied from village to village
('16', 477, 0, 1, 1069040) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 477, 1, 2, 1069082) years an occasional levy only has been taken by some landlords for a special purpose, such as a marriage in the proprietor’s family.
('16', 477, 2, 3, 1069215) In spite of the general exaction of these irregular dues in the north west tract of the district, not a single suit has been brought under section 75 of the Bengal Tenancy Act, which provides the legal remedy.
('16', 477, 2, 4, 1069425) The Collector is of opinion that the section remained a dead letter because the tenants did not complain and because there are difficulties in enforcing the law.
('16', 477, 2, 5, 1069587) It has been suggested to us that section 75 should be amended in order to give power to the Collector to deal with cases summarily on the lines of section 58 and we agree that a special remedy is required to meet the peculiar conditions of the Champaran district.
('16', 477, 2, 6, 1069851) We also consider that it should be made more generally known that the exaction of abwab is illegal.
('16', 477, 2, 7, 1069951) Connected with this exaction is
('16', 477, 3, 8, 1069983) the practice of landlords’ servants levying a commission on payments made by tenants known as dasturi, which is equally illegal.
('16', 477, 3, 9, 1070112) We, therefore, recommend that:
('16', 477, 4, 10, 1070143) (1) Government should issue a proclamation informing all landlords and raiyats that both abwab and the dasturi taken by landlords’ servants are
('16', 477, 5, 11, 1070287) illegal and must be stopped;
('16', 477, 6, 12, 1070316) (2) the Court of Wards should take steps to enforce those prohibitions in the estates under its charge; and
('16', 477, 7, 13, 1070424) (3) the special legislation recommended by us for the Champaran district should contain a clause providing that the Collector of his own motion may enquire into and punish the exaction by a landlord from a tenant of any sum in excess of the rent payable, his decision being subject to the ordinary appeal.
('16', 477, 7, 14, 1070730) The penalty might appropriately be fixed at a fine not exceeding Rs. 50 or double the amount of the exaction, whichever is greater.
('16', 477, 7, 15, 1070862) Our colleague, the Hon’ble Rajah Kirtyanand Singh, dissents from this proposal for legislation.
('16', 477, 8, 16, 1070958) RENT RECEIPT
('16', 477, 9, 17, 1070971) 14. Where abwab are systematically levied, the practice is to credit the first payments made by a tenant to that demand and a receipt is not given until he has paid off the whole abwab and at least some portion of his rent.
('16', 477, 9, 18, 1071195) This is facilitated by the fact that rent receipt are not usually given until payments for the year have beencompleted.
('16', 477, 9, 19, 1071315) Again, no receipts at all are given for the payment of produce rents.
('16', 477, 9, 20, 1071385) The intention of the Legislature, clearly shown by the form of rent receipt prescribed in schedule II of the Bengal Tenancy Act, was that the first payment of rent in any year should be entered in the receipt given to the raiyat who would produce this receipt for the entry of subsequent payments.
('16', 477, 9, 21, 1071683) We were informed during the course of our local enquiries that such a procedure is unsuitable for Champaran because the tenants fail to produce the first receipt at the time of subsequent payments.
('16', 477, 9, 22, 1071881) The alternative procedure, if the law is to be followed, is to give a full receipt for every
('16', 478, 0, 1, 1071974) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 479
('16', 478, 1, 2, 1072020) payment, which would involve a great increase in clerical labour because rents are frequently paid in small instalments.
('16', 478, 1, 3, 1072141) We consider it essential that some form of receipt should be given for these intermediate payments, though it need not be so elaborate as the prescribed form, and we therefore recommend that the Local Government should use its power under the proviso to section 56 (3) to prescribe a simple form of receipt for intermediate payments, the full receipt being reserved for the final payment.
('16', 478, 1, 4, 1072530) The inter mediate receipt need only contain the name of the tenant and his khatian number, the amount paid with date of payment and the account on which it was paid.
('16', 478, 2, 5, 1072696) RENEWAL OF “THIKA” LEASES
('16', 478, 3, 6, 1072722) 15. We have already described in paragraph 3 the large extent to which the thikadari system prevails in the district.
('16', 478, 3, 7, 1072840) If we believed that the abuses of the
('16', 478, 4, 8, 1072878) past were inseparable from that system, and that good relations between landlord and tenant could not be secured under it in the future, it would be our duty to recommend its abolition.
('16', 478, 4, 9, 1073064) But although we consider that good relations between landlord and tenant can ordinarily best be secured under an efficient system of direct management, which follows the general policy laid down in the Court of Wards Manual, they can also be obtained under a suitable thikadari system.
('16', 478, 4, 10, 1073350) We are opposed
('16', 478, 5, 11, 1073365) to any extension of that system, and if for any reason the lease of a village is not renewed, it seems preferable to take it under direct management rather than to lease it to another thikadar.
('16', 478, 5, 12, 1073559) The thikadari system of the Bettiah and Ramnagar estates was not created by the Court of Wards; many of the thikadars are of very old standing,
('16', 478, 6, 13, 1073703) and there may be other reasons arising out of their previous relations which render it inadvisable to make a sudden change of policy.
('16', 478, 6, 14, 1073837) If the conduct of a thikadar has been detrimental to the interests of the raiyats or of the superior landlord, his conduct
('16', 478, 7, 15, 1073960) should be scrutinized before the lease is renewed.
('16', 478, 7, 16, 1074011) In cases where the Court of Wards decides to renew the leases, we consider it preferable that they should be granted for moderately long periods, subject to cancellation for breach of the conditions, rather than that the periods should be short.
('16', 478, 7, 17, 1074257) In these circumstances, the commission granted to the lessee should be sufficient to cover the cost of collection (including irrecoverable arrears) and a reasonable remuneration for himself.
('16', 478, 7, 18, 1074448) Unlessthe estate offers its thikadars reasonable terms, it cannot evade all responsibility for resulting
('16', 478, 8, 19, 1074553) abuses.
('16', 478, 8, 20, 1074561) What a fair commission would be can no doubt be calculated for each tenure.
('16', 478, 8, 21, 1074637) On the other hand, where the commission to be given to the thikadar exceeds the
('16', 478, 9, 22, 1074717) estimated cost of direct management, the renewal of the leases on such terms requires special justification on the merits of each case.
('16', 478, 9, 23, 1074853) Finally, the leases should contain conditions enforcing such recommendations of the Committee as are accepted by Government, including in particular stipulations that no indigo should be grown except on a voluntary system, and that no abwab should be taken.
('16', 478, 9, 24, 1075111) We consider that the estate should hold itself responsible for the well being of tenants in thika
('16', 479, 0, 1, 1075209) 480 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 479, 1, 2, 1075251) villages and when that well being is in danger, should be responsible for the remedy.
('16', 479, 2, 3, 1075337) CHAPTER IV
('16', 479, 3, 4, 1075348) OTHER GRIEVANCES OF TENANTS
('16', 479, 4, 5, 1075376) FEES ON TRANSFERS
('16', 479, 5, 6, 1075394) 16. It remains for us to deal with various other matters some of which have been sources of trouble in the past and some of which are suggestions made for the improvement of agrarian conditions.
('16', 479, 5, 7, 1075589) The first is the levy of fees on the transfers of occupancy holdings.
('16', 479, 5, 8, 1075659) So far as fees are levied on transfers by inheritance, they are illegal, as the right of inheritance is given by section 26, Bengal Tenancy Act, and no custom exists in derogation of this right.
('16', 479, 5, 9, 1075854) Such fees under the name of Bapahi Putahi have been already referred to as an abwab in Chapter III.
('16', 479, 5, 10, 1075954) As regards transfers
('16', 479, 6, 11, 1075975) otherwise than by inheritance, it may be noted that the consent of the landlord is required by law to the transfer of a portion of a holding since that involves a sub division of the tenancy (section 88, Bengal Tenancy Act).
('16', 479, 6, 12, 1076200) The transferability of an occupancy holding depends on custom.
('16', 479, 6, 13, 1076263) In Champaran, the general custom is stated to be that no transfer can be made without the landlord’s consent, so that legally landlord can take a fee for recognized transfers otherwise than by inheritance, and this appears to be the usual practice.
('16', 479, 6, 14, 1076512) At the same time, however, we think that it would be desirable in the interests of good management to adopt a uniform scale of fees where it is possible to do so; e.g., in estates under the Court of Wards.
('16', 479, 6, 15, 1076718) This scale might be varied from time to time, if necessary, and its existence would not derogate from the right of veto possessed by the landlord even if the transferee offered the prescribed fee, for it would only be taken where the transfer had been approved.
('16', 479, 6, 16, 1076980) We recommend, therefore, that a moderate scale of fees be fixed from time to time in estates under the Court of Wards which should be enforced in villages held direct or under temporary lease, and that as regards villages let in mukarrari lease, the estate should use its best
('16', 479, 7, 17, 1077257) endeavour to induce the lease holder to adopt the same policy.
('16', 479, 7, 18, 1077320) The procedure followed by the Bettiah Estate in dealing with applications for mutation of names has been criticised.
('16', 479, 7, 19, 1077437) At present, the attendance of the parties at Bettiah is required, which causes unnecessary inconvenience, as local enquiries are always necessary.
('16', 479, 7, 20, 1077584) At the same time, we do not think it desirable to entrust thikadars with the power of disposing of such applications even subject to an appeal to the Manager.
('16', 479, 7, 21, 1077743) We recommend, therefore, that the power of sanctioning mutations should rest with the Estate Manager but that the applications may, if the applicant wishes, be made through the thikadar, who would forward it with his report to the Manager and who would communicate to the applicant the orders when received.
('16', 479, 8, 22, 1078051) RIGHTS IN HIDES
('16', 479, 9, 23, 1078067) 17. A complaint that has become prominent lately refers to the right claimed by the Bettiah and Ramnagar Estates and some of their tenure holders to all the hides
('16', 480, 0, 1, 1078230) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 481
('16', 480, 1, 2, 1078276) of dead cattle.
('16', 480, 1, 3, 1078292) With the rise in the value of hides in recent years, the question of ownership has become more important and has led to changes in the old custom under which a chamar took from the estate the lease of the right to the hides of a village for
('16', 480, 2, 4, 1078533) a small sum and supplied the tenants with a fixed number of shoes and other articles, whilst in addition his wife gave her service as midwife.
('16', 480, 2, 5, 1078676) The Charsa Mahal as it is called, of the Bettiah Estate was leased out to various persons, some of whom took the right to the hides over a large area and some of whom were chamars who took the
('16', 480, 3, 6, 1078869) right in individual villages.
('16', 480, 3, 7, 1078899) The total annual income of the Estate from this source is about Rs. 3,000. This right to hides was made over with other miscellaneous assets to the indigo concerns who were granted mukarrari leases in 1887. In the Ramnagar
('16', 480, 4, 8, 1079122) Estate, we understand the income from the Mahal in the past two years has been Rs. 79,000. The Manager of the Bettiah Estate has tried to justify the claim on the ground of custom and supports it on the ground of public policy for the prevention of cattle poisoning.
('16', 480, 4, 9, 1079389) On the other hand, it is urged that the hide is the legal property of the owner of the dead animal and that the present practice grew irregularly out of fees paid by the chamars for the use of waste land for skinning dead animals.
('16', 480, 4, 10, 1079620) The question of
('16', 480, 5, 11, 1079636) the validity by custom of such a right is one for legal decision.
('16', 480, 5, 12, 1079702) We doubt, however, whether such a custom even where proved can override the natural right of the owner of the dead animal to dispose of its hide in any way he pleases.
('16', 480, 5, 13, 1079870) Subject, therefore, to any legal right which the landlords may be held to possess, we are of opinion that the hides are the property of the owner of the dead animal who is entitled to dispose of them as he wishes, whether by sale or in exchange for services.
('16', 480, 6, 14, 1080129) KEROSENE OIL MONOPOLY
('16', 480, 7, 15, 1080151) 18. A somewhat similar claim to the monopoly of the trade in kerosene oil has been abandoned by the Bettiah Estate and we think that the mukarraridars who
('16', 480, 8, 16, 1080306) derive their claim from the estate should also abandon the practice of issuing licencesfor the sale of kerosene oil.
('16', 480, 8, 17, 1080423) Such a practice is clearly not legally enforceable and acts detrimentally in restraint of trade.
('16', 480, 9, 18, 1080520) RIGHTS IN TREES
('16', 480, 10, 19, 1080536) 19. A widespread discontent is manifest among the raiyats in respect of the
('16', 480, 11, 20, 1080612) rights in trees.
('16', 480, 11, 21, 1080629) The legal position has been ascertained both at the settlement of 1892 99 and at the present revision settlement.
('16', 480, 11, 22, 1080743) It appears that trees growing in tenants’ holdings cannot be felled without the consent of the landlord, and half the value of the timber of dead or felled trees belongs to him.
('16', 480, 11, 23, 1080921) The tenant urges that he pays rent for the land and the whole produce of it including the trees should belong to him, but, on the other hand, the rent was fixed in consideration of the custom and there is the legal right of the landlord.
('16', 480, 11, 24, 1081159) The tenant undoubtedly feels the restraint in not being able to take wood even from his own holding when he wants it without
('16', 481, 0, 1, 1081284) 482 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 481, 1, 2, 1081326) obtaining permission and with the possibility of abuse by subordinates.
('16', 481, 1, 3, 1081398) On the other hand, there is the danger that the handing over of all the trees to the raiyats might
('16', 481, 2, 4, 1081497) lead to their rapid destruction.
('16', 481, 2, 5, 1081530) The district is exceptionally well wooded, and we understand that in Saran, where the tenants have full rights in trees in lands for which a cash rent is paid, no evidence of general denudation is apparent.
('16', 481, 2, 6, 1081737) In view of the inconvenience resulting from the present custom, we recommend that in the Bettiah Estate the raiyats should be given the option of purchasing the landlord’s half share
('16', 481, 3, 7, 1081920) in the timber, the valuation to be made on fair principles, and, in case of disputes, referred to assessors.
('16', 481, 3, 8, 1082029) If it is found in practice that applications for purchase are received in such large numbers from any particular area as to make it probable that undue denudation might take place, the Estate would be able to limit the option.
('16', 481, 4, 9, 1082256) GRAZING RIGHTS
('16', 481, 5, 10, 1082271) 20. During our enquiry, we found that practically all the waste land has been recorded as being in the exclusive possession of the landlords, except certain small plots used for communal purposes such as roads, burial grounds, sites for threshing floors and the like.
('16', 481, 5, 11, 1082539) This permits the landlords to break up all waste for cultivation or to enclose it for his exclusive use.
('16', 481, 5, 12, 1082644) It has been urged that this is detrimental to the welfare of the village community and provides a weapon of which unfair use may be made by a bad landlord in cases of dispute with his tenants.
('16', 481, 5, 13, 1082837) There is little doubt that a village is benefited by some land being left for communal use, not necessarily large enough to provide for grazing of all the village cattle but at least adequate to provide the cattle with an exercise ground where they can move about freely without undue risk of trespass on cropped land.
('16', 481, 5, 14, 1083156) We, therefore, recommend that proprietors and permanent tenure holders should be advised to set apart suitable plots of land for communal use in the way suggested, and that the Court of Wards should do this in the villages under their direct management, while in villages on lease a similar reservation should be made after due enquiry before the renewal of any lease, conditions relating to such reservation being inserted in the lease.
('16', 481, 7, 15, 1083594) 21. Complaints were received by us from some raiyats that the rates paid by
('16', 481, 8, 16, 1083670) the landlords for labour are inadequate.
('16', 481, 8, 17, 1083711) No claim was urged before us by any landlord to any right over the labour, ploughs or carts of his tenants, and it is admitted that labour of all kinds should be taken on a voluntary basis and paid for at local market rates.
('16', 481, 8, 18, 1083936) While it is clearly impossible for us to prescribe suitable rates for all classes of labour, we consider that it would be an advantage for the Bihar Planters’ Association to lay down a minimum scale of wages based on the local market rates to be paid by concerns in membership.
('16', 481, 8, 19, 1084214) We recognize the danger that the minimum might in practice be regarded as the maximum, but rates of wages change slowly and the
('16', 482, 0, 1, 1084342) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 483
('16', 482, 1, 2, 1084388) adoption of the proposal would at least enable the Association to ascertain whether a concern was prima facie paying inadequate wages and to exercise a stronger position
('16', 482, 2, 3, 1084558) of control.
('16', 482, 2, 4, 1084570) We, therefore, recommend that all labour should be on a purely voluntary basis and paid for at local market rates, that a minimum tariff of labour wages should be fixed on the basis of local market rates by the Association with the approval of the Commissioner of the Division, and that this tariff should be revised from time to time in accordance with the local rates.
('16', 482, 3, 5, 1084941) CART “SATTAS”
('16', 482, 4, 6, 1084955) 22. Closely connected with the question of labour is the supply of carts.
('16', 482, 4, 7, 1085029) Most indigo factories require a number of carts at particular seasons of the year for the carting of the indigo crop to the factory and the refuse to the fields.
('16', 482, 4, 8, 1085191) Most factories keep sufficient carts for their ordinary requirements throughout the year, but hire the extra carts required on such special occasions.
('16', 482, 4, 9, 1085342) In order to ensure a regular supply of carts, agreements (sattas) are made with the cartmen to supply carts with bullocks at
('16', 482, 5, 10, 1085467) certain seasons for a fixed period of year at a fixed rate, and the consideration for these agreements invariably takes the form of an advance which is in some cases sufficient to cover the initial cost of a cart and pair of bullocks.
('16', 482, 5, 11, 1085702) Generally, however, it is about Rs. 30 or Rs. 40. We recognize that contracts of this nature are essential to the interests of the industry, and the system is unobjectionable provided the rates paid are fair and the periods not too long, but we consider the periods of these contracts extending in some cases to twenty years are prejudicial to the interests of the cartmen.
('16', 482, 5, 12, 1086076) We recommend that the period should be restricted to three years where the advance does not exceed Rs. 50, and to a maximum of five years where it exceeds Rs. 50, and that the Planters’ Association should enforce on its members a bye law to this effect.
('16', 482, 7, 13, 1086330) 23. We received some complaints that a few landlords had imposed and retained fines on tenants in particular cases where their own interests were not concerned and no damage of any kind was sustained by them.
('16', 482, 7, 14, 1086539) Such a practice is clearly illegal and the levy of fines, properly so called, should be stopped.
('16', 482, 9, 15, 1086636) 24. The question of pound management in the Champaran district has been brought to our notice.
('16', 482, 9, 16, 1086731) The pounds are largely leased to factories, which has given rise to complaints that they are sometimes used as improper means of coercing raiyats by
('16', 482, 10, 17, 1086880) the impounding of cattle without cause.
('16', 482, 10, 18, 1086920) While it was impossible for us to enquire into and record a finding on individual complaints, the leasing of pounds to landlords may give an opportunity for abuse, and recommend that a trial should be made as an
('16', 483, 0, 1, 1087132) 484 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 483, 1, 2, 1087174) experiment of the direct management of pounds by the District Board.
('16', 483, 2, 3, 1087243) VILLAGE ADMINISTRATION PAPER
('16', 483, 3, 4, 1087272) 25. We have found that there is no authoritative record of village customs such as exists in other provinces of northern India, the procedure followed at settlement for recording various village customs being to make an entry in the village note which does not form part of the Record of Rights.
('16', 483, 3, 5, 1087568) In most provinces, it has been found desirable to make a regular record of such customs and rights.
('16', 483, 3, 6, 1087668) While we recognize that communal village life in Bihar is not so strong as in some other provinces, and that some of the matters such as irrigation rights recorded in these village administration papers are included in the Record of Rights of Bihar, we think that advantage would result from some better authenticated record than the village note of such matters as the right in hides, grazing rights, customs as to house building and the like.
('16', 483, 3, 7, 1088113) We commend the suggestion to the consideration of Government.
('16', 483, 4, 8, 1088175) MISCELLANEOUS
('16', 483, 5, 9, 1088189) 26. There are two final recommendations that we desire to make which are designed to secure that full effect is given to the orders which Government may pass.
('16', 483, 5, 10, 1088348) The first is that such orders as may be passed should be communicated in the vernacular to the raiyats by as wide publication as possible.
('16', 483, 5, 11, 1088487) The second is that it
('16', 483, 6, 12, 1088509) should be impressed on the district staff and especially on the staff of the Court of Wards estates that, until Government is satisfied that full effect has been given to these orders, an important part of their duties will be to see that these orders are carried out.
('16', 483, 7, 13, 1088778) F. G. SLY (PRESIDENT),
('16', 483, 8, 14, 1088801) L.C. ADAMI,
('16', 483, 9, 15, 1088813) KIRTYANAND SINHA,
('16', 483, 10, 16, 1088831) D. J. REID,
('16', 483, 11, 17, 1088843) G. RAINY,
('16', 483, 12, 18, 1088853) M. K. GANDHI
('16', 483, 13, 19, 1088866) Report of the Committee on the Agrarian Condition in Champaran in the National Archives of India
