('16', 484, 8, 10, 1089565) APPENDIX VI THE CHAMPARAN AGRARIAN BILL, 1917
('16', 484, 9, 11, 1089611) (AS PASSED IN COUNCIL) A
('16', 484, 12, 12, 1089636) SETTLE AND DETERMINE CERTAIN AGRARIAN DISPUTES IN THE
('16', 484, 13, 13, 1089690) DISTRICT OF CHAMPARAN
('16', 484, 14, 14, 1089712) WHEREAS it is expedient to settle and determine disputes subsisting in the district of Champaran between landlords and tenants holding under them regarding certain matters.
('16', 484, 15, 15, 1089885) 4 AND 5 GEO., 5, C. 61
('16', 484, 16, 16, 1089908) AND WHEREAS the previous sanction of the Government of India has been obtained under section 79 of the Government of India Act, 1915, to the passing of this Act:—
('16', 484, 17, 17, 1090071) SHORT TITLE AND EXTENT
('16', 484, 18, 18, 1090094) (1) This Act may be called the Champaran Agrarian Act, 1918,
('16', 485, 0, 1, 1090155) 486 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 485, 1, 2, 1090197) (2) It extends to the district of Champaran.
('16', 485, 2, 3, 1090242) INTERPRETATION CLAUSE
('16', 485, 3, 4, 1090264) 2. In this Act all words and expressions defined in the Bengal Tenancy Act, 1885, shall have the meanings assigned to them respectively in that Act and theexpression “record of rights” shall mean the record of rights finally published under sub section (2) of section 103 of the Bengal Tenancy Act, 1885.
('16', 485, 4, 5, 1090569) ABOLITION OF CERTAIN CONDITIONS AND INCIDENTS
('16', 485, 5, 6, 1090615) 3. (1) On and after the commencement of this Act any agreement, lease or other contract between a landlord and a tenant holding under him which contains a condition to set apart the land of his tenancy or any portion thereof for the cultivation of a particular crop shall be void to the extent of such condition:
('16', 485, 6, 7, 1090928) Provided that if the tenant has in consideration of such condition received any advance under an agreement, lease or contract entered into prior to the commencement of this Act, he shall be bound to refund such advance or if the condition has been partially fulfilled, such proportion of that advance as represents the unfulfilled portion of the condition, and the amount of the said advance or proportion thereof which he is bound to refund shall be determined by an authority to be prescribed by the Local Government and the order of such authority shall be final and shall, on application to a civil court, be enforceable as a decree for rent payable in respect of the said tenancy.
('16', 485, 7, 8, 1091614) (2) On and after the commencement of this Act, a special condition or incident of a tenancy to set apart the land of the tenancy or any portion thereof for the cultivation of a particular crop shall not be valid to any extent.
('16', 485, 8, 9, 1091841) ALTERATION OF RENT IN VIEW OF SUCH ABOLITION AND NOTE
('16', 485, 9, 10, 1091895) OF THE RESULTING RENT IN THE RECORD OF RIGHTS
('16', 485, 10, 11, 1091941) 4. (1)(a) Where, in consideration of the release of a tenant from a condition, special condition or incident of the nature described in section 3, the rent payable by such tenant has, prior to the first day of October, 1917, been enhanced, the amount of such enhancement shall, with effect from the said date, be reduced by twenty per centum in the case of rent payable to Turkaulia, Limited, and by twenty six per centum in all other cases;
('16', 485, 11, 12, 1092383) (b) Where a special condition or incident of the nature described in sub section (2) of section 3 has been entered in the record of rights in respect of a tenancy, the entry of such special condition or incident shall be cancelled and the rent of the tenancy shall, with effect from the first day of October, 1917, be enhanced to an extent proportionate to the reduced enhancement allowed under clause (a) in respect of tenancies in the same village or in neighbouring villages belonging to the same
('16', 486, 0, 1, 1092883) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 487
('16', 486, 1, 2, 1092929) landlord.
('16', 486, 2, 3, 1092939) (2) A note of the rent of a tenancy resulting from reduction under clause (a) or enhancement under clause (b) of sub section (1) of the cancellation under clause (b) of that sub section of an entry and of a special condition or incident shall be made in the record of rights and such note shall, with effect from the 1st day of October; 1917, be deemed part of the record of rights and be conclusive evidence of the amount of such rent.
('16', 486, 3, 4, 1093376) (3) The Local Government may by rule prescribe
('16', 486, 4, 5, 1093423) (a) the authority by whom the proper amount of reduction and of enhancement under the provisions of sub section (1) and the resulting rent of the tenancy shall be determined in each case;
('16', 486, 5, 6, 1093611) (b) the authority by whom the note referred to in sub section (2) shall be made;
('16', 486, 6, 7, 1093692) (c) the procedure to be followed by any such authority.
('16', 486, 7, 8, 1093748) (4) The decision of the authority prescribed under clause (a) of sub section (3) shall be final as regards
('16', 486, 8, 9, 1093855) (a) whether the rent payable by a tenant has been enhanced in consideration of the release of the tenant from a condition, special condition or incident of the nature described in section 3, and the amount of such enhancement;
('16', 486, 9, 10, 1094082) (b) whether any entry in the record of rights is an entry of special condition or incident of the nature described in sub section (2) of section 3;
('16', 486, 10, 11, 1094230) (c) the amount of rent to be noted in the record of rights under the provisions of sub section (2);
('16', 486, 11, 12, 1094330) and the correctness of any such decision shall not be contested in any suit or proceeding in any court.
('16', 486, 12, 13, 1094434) (5) In the case of any tenant referred to in clause (a) of sub section (1), the finally published entry in the record of rights of the rent of his tenancy shall, in any suit or proceeding for the recovery of an arrear or rent which accrued due thereon prior to the first day of October 1917, be conclusive evidence of amount of the yearly rent payable in respect of such tenancy from the date from which the enhancement took effect to the end of the Fasli year 1324.
('16', 486, 13, 14, 1094901) This sub section shall also apply to such suits and proceedings pending at the commencement of this Act.
('16', 486, 14, 15, 1095006) SAVING OF CERTAIN SHORT TERM CONTRACTS TO DELIVER A SPECIFIED WEIGHT OF A PARTICULAR CROP
('16', 487, 0, 1, 1095096) 488 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 487, 1, 2, 1095138) 5. Nothing in this Act shall prevent a tenant from contracting to deliver to his landlord a specified weight of a particular crop to be grown on the land of his tenancy or any portion thereof:
('16', 487, 2, 3, 1095331) Provided
('16', 487, 3, 4, 1095340) (l) That any claim for damages for the breach of such contract shall be based on a failure to deliver the specified weight and not on a failure to cultivate any portion of land;
('16', 487, 4, 5, 1095518) (2) That the term of such contract shall not exceed three years; and
('16', 487, 5, 6, 1095587) (3) That the value of the produce to be supplied shall be determined by weighment thereof or by appraisement by arbitrators of the weight thereof.
('16', 487, 6, 7, 1095734) PROVISIONS TO HAVE EFFECT NOTWITHSTANDING ANY OTHER ENACTMENT
('16', 487, 7, 8, 1095796) 6. The provisions of this Act shall have effect notwithstanding anything contained in any other enactment.
('16', 487, 8, 9, 1095903) Select Documents on Mahatma Gandhi’s Movement in Champaran, pp.
('16', 487, 9, 10, 1095967) APPENDIX VII
('16', 487, 10, 11, 1095980) CONGRESS LEAGUE ADDRESS
('16', 487, 12, 12, 1096004) November 26, 1917]
('16', 487, 14, 13, 1096023) We, the members of the All India Committee of the Indian National Congress and of the Council of the All India Moslem League, welcome you, Sir, His Majesty’s Principal Secretary of State for India, and approach you and Your Excellency the Viceroy and Governor General, His Imperial Majesty’s august representative and the head of his Government in this country, with feelings of gratitude and hope; gratitude, in that proposals of reform formulated by the National Congress and the Moslem League have received the attention of Your Excellency and of His Imperial Majesty’s Ministers in Great Britain whom you, Sir, represent; hope, in that we feel that our proposals being just and in full harmony with British history and policy, will meet with favour at your hands.
('16', 487, 15, 14, 1096791) Sirs, we cannot let this historic occasion pass without acknowledging the great and good work that Great Britain has accomplished in India.
('16', 487, 15, 15, 1096931) The protection of the land from invasion from without and the establishment of peace and order are in themselves no mean achievements; but it is a prouder title to glory that she has produced a new intellectual awakening a national consciousness and an eager longing for freedom among the heirs of ancient civilization who had unfortunately fallen from
('16', 488, 0, 1, 1097284) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 489
('16', 488, 1, 2, 1097330) their high estate.
('16', 488, 1, 3, 1097349) It was a great truth which Lord Ripon of blessed memory felicitously uttered when he described educated Indians as the children of British Rule, and we can assure you, Sirs, that Sir Bartle Frere’s observation is as correct today as when he made it that no section of the people of India appreciate the advantages of that rule more highly than those whose minds have been broadened by the liberal English education which will for all time stand as Britain’s most imperishable monument in India.
('16', 488, 1, 4, 1097844) The ir very pol itica l asp irati ons are a tri bute to the suc cess of her mis sion in the Eas t.
('16', 488, 1, 5, 1097943) “Th e pro udest day in the ann als of Eng land” whi ch Lor d Mac aulay for esaw has com e, and Ind ians tod ay dem and tha t Sel f Gov ernme nt whi ch Eng lishmen hav e alw ays fer ventl y bel ieved to be the ind ispen sable con ditio n of sel f res pecti ng nat ional lif e.
('16', 488, 1, 6, 1098219) The Ind ian Nat ional Con gress , whi ch a ren owned Ind ian sta tesma n des cribe d as “th e gre atest tri umph of Bri tish adm inist ratio n and a cro wn of glo ry to the gre at Bri tish nat ion” is the highe st exp ressi on of thi s sac red nat ional asp irati on, and the ide al of the Con gress is als o the ide al of the mos t imp ortan t org aniza tion of Ind ian Mus alman s, the All Ind ia Mos lem Lea gue.
('16', 488, 1, 7, 1098635) The aut horit ative ann ounce ment whi ch was mad e sim ultan eousl y in England and India on the 20th of August last that His Majesty’s Government with the complete accord of the Government of India, accept responsible government for India as an integral part of the Empire as the goal of British policy was therefore received by the country with no ordinary feeling of satisfaction.
('16', 488, 1, 8, 1099020) For that epoch making declaration, Sirs, we Indians of all creeds, classes and communities are deeply beholden to His Majesty’s Government as well as to the Government of India.
('16', 488, 2, 9, 1099198) We submit however that to ensure the early realization of this ideal the reforms
('16', 488, 3, 10, 1099279) that are to be introduced as a first instalment should confer a substantial measure of
('16', 488, 4, 11, 1099366) power on the people acting through their chosen representatives in Councils, and
('16', 488, 5, 12, 1099447) further, that the determination of future progress should not, as has been proposed, be
('16', 488, 6, 13, 1099535) left entirely to the Government in India and England.
('16', 488, 6, 14, 1099589) It ought to be recognized that
('16', 488, 7, 15, 1099620) the people of India themselves, as the party principally affected, have a right to an
('16', 488, 8, 16, 1099706) effective voice in the decision of a question which is of such supreme moment to
('16', 488, 9, 17, 1099787) This would be in conformity with the principle of the declaration recently made
('16', 488, 10, 18, 1099867) by the Prime Minister of England “that the wishes of the inhabitants must be the
('16', 488, 11, 19, 1099948) supreme consideration in the resettlement”, and that this formula “is to be applied
('16', 488, 12, 20, 1100032) equally in the tropical countries”.
('16', 488, 12, 21, 1100068) It is our settled conviction that the best interests of
('16', 488, 13, 22, 1100124) this Country and of the Empire demand that full responsible Government should be
('16', 488, 14, 23, 1100205) established here as early as practicable.
('16', 488, 14, 24, 1100247) We are therefore anxious to be assured that
('16', 488, 15, 25, 1100291) the progress towards the goal shall be reasonably rapid.
('16', 488, 15, 26, 1100348) We hope that this point will
('16', 488, 16, 27, 1100377) be taken into consideration by His Majesty’s Government.
('16', 489, 0, 1, 1100434) 490 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 489, 1, 2, 1100476) We are not less grateful for the decision to introduce a substantial first
('16', 489, 2, 3, 1100551) instalment of reforms at as early a date as may be practicable.
('16', 489, 2, 4, 1100615) We beg leave to
('16', 489, 3, 5, 1100631) observe, Sirs, that the proceedings of the annual sessions of both the Indian National
('16', 489, 4, 6, 1100718) Congress and All India Moslem League are a living proof of the imperative need of
('16', 489, 5, 7, 1100800) liberal reforms in all directions—constitutional, financial and administrative.
('16', 489, 6, 8, 1100880) Amelioration of the material condition of the masses as well as the satisfaction of the
('16', 489, 7, 9, 1100968) political aspirations of the classes has throughout been the anxious concern of these
('16', 489, 8, 10, 1101054) organizations.
('16', 489, 8, 11, 1101069) They have persistently advocated reforms in land revenue policy and
('16', 489, 9, 12, 1101137) administration; measures for the relief of agricultural indebtedness, agricultural
('16', 489, 10, 13, 1101220) education and agricultural improvement; rapid progress in the construction of
('16', 489, 11, 14, 1101298) irrigation works; an active policy of industrial development and technical education;
('16', 489, 12, 15, 1101384) the wider diffusion of education in all its branches; retrenchment of public
('16', 489, 13, 16, 1101461) expenditure and reduction of taxation, pressing heavily on those least able to bear it;
('16', 489, 14, 17, 1101549) reform of the police, and of the system of administration of justice; temperance
('16', 489, 15, 18, 1101630) reform; lenient forest rules; the improvement of public health, and adequate provision
('16', 489, 16, 19, 1101717) of medical relief; the re institution of village Panchayats;—all of which are designed
('16', 489, 17, 20, 1101804) and calculated to make life more worth living for the tens of millions of our poorer
('16', 489, 18, 21, 1101889) countrymen, with whose condition as it is no one can affect to be satisfied.
('16', 489, 18, 22, 1101966) We submit
('16', 489, 19, 23, 1101976) with confidence that educated Indians cannot justly be blamed if the remedial measures
('16', 489, 20, 24, 1102063) for which they have been striving have not been introduced.
('16', 489, 20, 25, 1102123) It is true that they have
('16', 489, 21, 26, 1102149) been claiming with equal ardour the practical recognition of the rights which
('16', 489, 22, 27, 1102227) legitimately are theirs in their own country; but in doing so they have been actuated
('16', 489, 23, 28, 1102313) at least as much by the earnest desire to exercise them in the interest of their less
('16', 489, 24, 29, 1102399) favoured brethren as by the prompting of their own national self respect.
('16', 489, 24, 30, 1102473) If they have
('16', 489, 25, 31, 1102486) insistently pleaded for some measure of real power for the representatives and
('16', 489, 26, 32, 1102565) spokesmen of the people in the government of the country, if they have declined to
('16', 489, 27, 33, 1102648) reconcile themselves to a position of subordination and inferiority in administration,
('16', 489, 28, 34, 1102735) if they have pressed for the removal of all disabilities and distinction based on racial
('16', 489, 29, 35, 1102824) and religious grounds, if they have expressed their dissatisfaction with the share
('16', 489, 30, 36, 1102907) assigned to them in the defence of the country, and if they have protested against
('16', 489, 31, 37, 1102990) reactionary and repressive measures, they have done so because the assertion of their
('16', 489, 32, 38, 1103076) rights as Indians is to them a compelling public duty.
('16', 489, 32, 39, 1103131) Neither the National Congress
('16', 489, 33, 40, 1103161) nor the Moslem League has ever been slow to acknowledge the value of the
('16', 489, 34, 41, 1103234) progressive measures that have been adopted by Government from time to time.
('16', 489, 35, 42, 1103311) we may therefore be permitted to say with the less hesitation that the experience of
('16', 489, 36, 43, 1103396) years has convinced us that under the existing system social and economic reform has
('16', 489, 37, 44, 1103481) much less chance than the well being and advancement of the people demands, that
('16', 490, 0, 1, 1103562) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 491
('16', 490, 1, 2, 1103608) Indian public opinion is more powerless than effectual, service and sectional
('16', 490, 2, 3, 1103686) interests are not always subordinated to the common weal, and that the system should
('16', 490, 3, 4, 1103771) be so altered as to make the will of the people prevail as far as may be in all matters of
('16', 490, 4, 5, 1103862) internal administration.
('16', 490, 5, 6, 1103887) ESSENTIAL FEATURES OF SCHEME
('16', 490, 6, 7, 1103916) It is in this conviction, Sirs, that the National Congress and the Moslem League considered the constitutional and administrative reforms which they should respectfully urge on the Government here and in England for present adoption.
('16', 490, 6, 8, 1104150) The Joint Scheme of Reforms is the result of careful deliberation of joint conferences of their committees.
('16', 490, 6, 9, 1104258) It may be mentioned here that the Memorandum which was submitted to Your Excellency by nineteen elected members of Your Excellency’s Legislative Council in the autumn of 1916 is in accord with the proposals of the Congress and the League.
('16', 490, 6, 10, 1104497) We now ask permission, Sirs, to dwell on what may be regarded as the essential features of the Scheme of Reforms.
('16', 490, 6, 11, 1104611) The basal principles on which it is founded are, firstly, that the British connection with India should be safeguarded, and secondly, that, subject to this fundamental reservation the character and constitution of the Government of India and the Provincial Governments should be transformed so as to make them representative of and responsible to the people acting through their elected representatives in Councils.
('16', 490, 6, 12, 1105027) To the former end it is proposed that the Government of India should continue to own responsibility to His Maj esty’s Gov ernme nt, and thr ough the m to the Bri tish Par lia ment, in mat ters pertaining to foreign relations and the defence of the country.
('16', 490, 6, 13, 1105284) The Legislature is to have no control over them.
('16', 490, 6, 14, 1105333) Nor will it have any right to interfere with the relations of the Government with the Indian States.
('16', 490, 6, 15, 1105434) This being secured, it is urged that in matters of internal administration the control of the Secretary of State should be replaced by control by the Legislature; the Government of India similarly devolving power on the provincial Governments, which in their turn will own responsibility to their respective Legislatures.
('16', 490, 6, 16, 1105756) It must obviously follow that there should be a strong Indian element in the Executive Governments as well as that the Legislative Councils should be expanded and reformed so as to consist of a substantial majority of members elected directly by the people on as wide a franchise as may be possible.
('16', 490, 6, 17, 1106056) And these Councils should be endowed with real and substantial power, not only over legislation but also over finance and administration.
('16', 490, 6, 18, 1106194) We venture to think that the Congress and the Moslem League make no extravagant proposals when they ask that one half of the Executive Councillors should be Indians, and that four fifths of the Legislative Councils should consist of elected members.
('16', 490, 6, 19, 1106444) Nor, we submit, are the powers proposed for the latter bodies excessive or impracticable.
('16', 490, 6, 20, 1106534) Adequate safeguards have been provided in the Scheme to prevent the adoption of hasty or unsuitable measures— legislative, financial or administrative; as well as to protect the interests of minorities.
('16', 490, 6, 21, 1106737) In connection with the latter point we beg to invite attention to the provision that no non official proposal affecting communal interests to which three fourths of the members belonging to that community object, should be proceeded with in any Legislative Council.
('16', 491, 0, 1, 1107003) 492 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 491, 1, 2, 1107045) The reforms relating to the Secretary of State and his Council are suggested as being consequential on the reform of the system of government in the country itself.
('16', 491, 1, 3, 1107210) They will, it is trusted, be found to make for economy and for harmony between the authorities in the two countries, without in any way impairing efficiency.
('16', 491, 2, 4, 1107368) In the Memora ndum in suppor t of the propos als, which we beg to hand with this addres s, the case for reform is set forth at some length .
('16', 491, 2, 5, 1107509) It discus ses, too, the import ant cognat e subjec t of local self g overnment and a few urgent ly needed admini strative reform s for the introd uction of which both the Congre ss and the League have long been earnes tly appeal ing to Govern ment.
('16', 491, 2, 6, 1107758) The resolu tions of the Congre ss and the Moslem League , the Joint Scheme of Reform s, and the memora ndum of the ninete en member s, are append ed to our Memora ndum to facili tate refere nce.
('16', 491, 2, 7, 1107953) We hope that the countr y will not have to wait longer to see Lord Ripon’s cheris hed scheme of real local self g overnment fully carrie d out; or for the substa ntial Indian ization of the public servic es for which our late revere d countr yman, Mr. Dadabh oy Naoroj i, labour ed so long and so hard; or for the comple te separa tion of the judici al servic es and functi ons from the execut ive, a reform needed even more in the intere st of he backwa rd masses s than of the classe s; or for such an amendm ent of the Arms Act and Rules as will not only do away with the invidi ous racial discri mination agains t Indian s but empower them to possess and carry arms on conditions similar to those which prevail in other civilized countries, in most of the States in this very country, and in the case of Europeans and Americans in British India itself.
('16', 491, 2, 8, 1108810) The country has expressed its gratification at the removal of the bar against the appointment of Indians as commissioned officers in the Army.
('16', 491, 2, 9, 1108953) It trusts that the rules which will regulate their admission will be liberal and open an honourable and patriotic career to the young men of all classes who may satisfy such tests as may be imposed to judge their fitness, that the requisite facilities for their training and examination will be provided in India itself, and that lndians will be appointed in reasonably large numbers.
('16', 491, 2, 10, 1109338) It is a grievance of long standing that Indians are not permitted to enlist as volunteers.
('16', 491, 2, 11, 1109429) If, however, the system of volunteering as it has existed is to disappear, it is believed that the Indian Defence Force will not be disbanded after the war, and it is urged that the Indian section of it may be placed on a level of absolute equality with the European.
('16', 491, 3, 12, 1109697) INDIA’S STATUS IN THE EMPIRE
('16', 491, 4, 13, 1109726) Before taking leave of you, Sirs, we would invite attention to the very important subject of India’s status in the Empire.
('16', 491, 4, 14, 1109849) Our claim in one word is that she should be lifted from the position of a dependency to that of equalitlity with the Dominions.
('16', 491, 4, 15, 1109977) The relation of the two should be mutual in the complete sense of the term.
('16', 491, 4, 16, 1110053) We submit that if the Dominions are to exercise any rights in relation to India, the latter should have the power to exercise the same rights in relation to them.
('16', 492, 0, 1, 1110216) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 493
('16', 492, 1, 2, 1110262) any Council or Parliament of the Empire which may be constituted at a future date, India should be represented in like manner and in an equal measure with the Dominions.
('16', 492, 1, 3, 1110432) Unless this is done, the participation of the Dominions in the governance of our country, without a corresponding right in us to participate in the governance of them, will mean a lowering of even our present unsatisfactory status, which will arouse the strongest opposition in this country.
('16', 492, 1, 4, 1110724) We hope and trust that His Majesty’s Government will never entertain any such proposal.
('16', 492, 1, 5, 1110812) In the meantime we re quest that India may be allowed to be represented in the Imperial Conference (and in the Imperial Cabinet if any such should be constituted) through persons elected by the elected members of our Legislative Councils.
('16', 492, 1, 6, 1111051) We are beholden to His Majesty’s Government and the Government of India for the privilege accorded to India in the beginning of this year, of sending three gentlemen to represent her in the Imperial War Conference and the Imperial War Cabinet.
('16', 492, 1, 7, 1111295) Nor are we less sensible of the value of the unanimous resolution recorded by the former body in favour of the regular representation of India at future ordinary sittings of the Imperial Conference.
('16', 492, 1, 8, 1111494) The consti tutional positi on of the Govern ment of India being what it is in relati on to His Majest y’s Govern ment on the one side and the people of India on the other, its nomine es cannot have the charac ter of repres entatives or spokes men of the people, as have the Ministers of the Dominions, which are endowed with responsible government.
('16', 492, 1, 9, 1111843) In this view of the matter we are constrained to submit that during the period of transition from the existing system to responsible government, the representatives of this country in the Imperial Conference and the Imperial Cabinet should be allowed to be elected by the elected members of the Legislative Councils in India.
('16', 492, 2, 10, 1112169) The Leader, 28 11 1917
('16', 492, 3, 11, 1112192) APPENDIX VIII
('16', 492, 4, 12, 1112206) THE CONGRESS LEAGUE SCHEME
('16', 492, 5, 13, 1112233) (a) That having regard to the fact that the great communities of India are the inheritors of ancient civilisations and have shown great capacity for government and administration, and to the progress in education and public spirit made by them during a century of British Rule, and further having regard to the fact that the present system of Government does not satisfy the legitimate aspirations of the people and has become unsuited to existing conditions and requirements, the Congress is of opinion that the time has come when His Majesty the King Emperor should be pleased to issue a Proclamation announcing that it is the aim and intention of British policy to confer Self Government on India at an early date.
('16', 493, 0, 1, 1112951) 494 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 493, 1, 2, 1112993) (b) That in the reconstruction of the Empire, India shall be lifted towards Self Government by granting the Reforms contained in the scheme prepared by the All India Congress Committee in concert with the Reform Committee appointed by the All India Muslim League (detailed below).
('16', 493, 2, 3, 1113274) (c) That in the reconstruction of the Empire, India shall be lifted from the position of a dependency to that of an equal partner in the Empire with the Self Governing Dominions.
('16', 493, 3, 4, 1113453) REFORM SCHEME I—PROVINCIAL LEGISLATIVE COUNCILS
('16', 493, 4, 5, 1113501) 1. Provincial Legislative Councils shall consist of four fifths elected and of one fifth nominated members.
('16', 493, 5, 6, 1113609) 2. Their strength shall be not less than 125 members in the major Provinces, and from 50 to 75 in the minor Provinces.
('16', 493, 6, 7, 1113728) 3. The members of Councils should be elected directly by the people on as broad a franchise as possible.
('16', 493, 7, 8, 1113833) 4. Adequate provision should be made for the representation of important minori ties by election, and the Muslims should be represented through special electorates on be Provincial Legislative Councils in the following proportions: Punjab One half of the elected Indian Members.
('16', 493, 7, 9, 1114112) United Provinces—30 p.c.

('16', 493, 7, 11, 1114158) ’’ ’’ Bihar—25 p.c.
('16', 493, 7, 12, 1114178) ’’ ’’ Central Provinces—15 p.c.
('16', 493, 7, 13, 1114210) ’’ ’’ Madras—15 p.c.
('16', 493, 7, 14, 1114231) ’’ ’’ Bombay One third ’’ ’’
('16', 493, 8, 15, 1114260) Provided that no Muslim shall participate in any of the other elections to the Imperial or Provincial Legislative Councils, save and except those by electorates representing special interests.
('16', 493, 9, 16, 1114453) Provided further that no bill, nor any clause thereof, nor a resolution introduced by a non official member affecting one or the other community, which question is to be determined by the members of that community in the Legislative Council concerned, shall be proceeded with, if three fourths of the members of that community in the particular Council, Imperial or Provincial, oppose the bill or any clause thereof or the resolution.
('16', 493, 10, 17, 1114888) 5. The head of the Provincial Government should not be the President of the Legislative Council but the Council should have the right of electing its President.
('16', 494, 0, 1, 1115049) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 495
('16', 494, 1, 2, 1115095) 6. The right of asking supplementary questions should not be restricted to the member putting the original question, but should be allowed to be exercised by any other member.
('16', 494, 2, 3, 1115271) 7 (a) Except customs, post, telegraph, mint, salt, opium, railways, army and navy, and tributes from Indian States, all other sources of revenue should be Provincial.
('16', 494, 3, 4, 1115438) (b) There should be no divided heads of revenue.
('16', 494, 3, 5, 1115487) The Government of India should be provided with fixed contributions from the Provincial Governments, such fixed contributions being liable to revision when extraordinary and unforeseen contingencies render such revision necessary.
('16', 494, 4, 6, 1115718) (c) The Provincial Council should have full authority to deal with all matters affecting the internal administration of the Province, including the power to raise loans, to impose and alter taxation and to vote on the Budget.
('16', 494, 4, 7, 1115944) All items of expenditure, and all proposals concerning ways and means for raising the necessary revenue should be embodied in Bills and submitted to the Provincial Council for adoption.
('16', 494, 5, 8, 1116130) (d) Resolution on all matters within the purview of the Provincial Government should be allowed for discussion in accordance with rules made in that behalf by the Council itself.
('16', 494, 6, 9, 1116309) (e) A resolution passed by the Provincial Legislative Council shall be binding on the Executive Government, unless vetoed by the Governor in Council, provided however that if the resolution is again passed by the Council after an interval of not less than one year, it must be given effect to.
('16', 494, 7, 10, 1116603) (f) A motion for adjournment may be brought forward for the discussion of a definite matter of urgent public importance, if supported by not less than one eighth of the members present.
('16', 494, 8, 11, 1116789) 8. A special meeting of the Provincial Council may be summoned on a requisition by not less than one eighth of the members present.
('16', 494, 9, 12, 1116921) 9. A Bill, other than a Money Bill may be introduced in Council in accordance with rules made in that behalf by the Council itself, and the consent of the Government should not be required therefor.
('16', 494, 10, 13, 1117120) 10. All Bills passed by Provincial Legislatures shall have to receive the assent of the Governor before they become law, but may be vetoed by the Governor General.
('16', 494, 11, 14, 1117284) 11. The term of office of the members shall be five years.
('16', 494, 11, 15, 1117343) II PROVINC IAL GOVERNM ENTS
('16', 494, 12, 16, 1117371) 1. The head of every Provincial Government shall be a Governor who shall not ordinarily belong to the Indian Civil Service or any of the permanent services.
('16', 494, 13, 17, 1117528) 2. There shall be in every Province an Executive Council which, with the Governor, shall constitute the Executive Government of the Province.
('16', 495, 0, 1, 1117670) 496 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 495, 1, 2, 1117712) 3. Members of the Indian Civil Service shall not ordinarily be appointed to the Executive Councils.
('16', 495, 2, 3, 1117812) 4. Not less than one half of the members of the Executive Council shall consist of Indians to be elected by the elected members of the Provincial Legislative Council.
('16', 495, 3, 4, 1117979) 5. The term of office of the members shall be five years.
('16', 495, 3, 5, 1118037) III IMPERIA L LEGISLA TIVE COUNCIL
('16', 495, 4, 6, 1118072) 1. The strength of the Imperial Legislative Council shall be 150.
('16', 495, 5, 7, 1118138) 2. Four fifths of the members shall be elected.
('16', 495, 6, 8, 1118186) 3. The franchise for the Imperial Legislative Council should be widened as far as possible on the lines of the electorates for Muslims for the Provincial Legislative Councils, and the elected members of the Provincial Legislative Councils should also form an electorate for the return of members of the Imperial Legislative Council.
('16', 495, 7, 9, 1118519) 4. One third of the Indian elected members should be Muslims elected by separate Muslim electorates in the several Provinces, in the proportion, as nearly as may be, in which they are represented on the Provincial Legislative Councils by separate Muslim electorates.

('16', 495, 10, 13, 1119068) 7. A special meeting of the Council may be summoned on a requisition by not less than one eighth of the members.
('16', 495, 11, 14, 1119181) 8. A Bill, other than a Money Bill, may be introduced in Council in accordance with rules made in that behalf by the Council itself, and the consent of the Executive Government should not be required therefor.
('16', 495, 12, 15, 1119391) 9. All Bills passed by the Council shall have to receive the assent of the Governor General before they become law.
('16', 495, 13, 16, 1119507) 10. All financial proposals relating to sources of income and items of expenditure shall be embodied in Bills.
('16', 495, 13, 17, 1119618) Every such Bill and the Budgets as a whole shall be submitted for the vote of the Imperial Legislative Council.
('16', 495, 14, 18, 1119730) 11. The term of office of members shall be five years.
('16', 495, 15, 19, 1119785) 12. The matters mentioned herein below shall be exclusively under the control of the Imperial Legislative Council.
('16', 495, 16, 20, 1119900) (a) Matters in regard to which uniform legislation for the whole of India is desirable.
('16', 495, 17, 21, 1119988) (b) Provincial legislation in so far as it may affect inter Provincial fiscal relations.
('16', 495, 18, 22, 1120077) (c) Questions affecting purely Imperial Revenue, excepting tributes from Indian State.

('16', 496, 1, 2, 1120210) (d) Questions affecting purely Imperial expenditure, except that no resolution of the Imperial Legislative Council shall be binding on the Governor General in Council in respect of military charges for the defence of the country.
('16', 496, 2, 3, 1120440) (e) The right of revising Indian tariffs and customs duties, of imposing, altering, or removing any tax or cess, modifying the existing system of currency and banking, and granting any aids or bounties to any or all deserving and nascent industries of the country.
('16', 496, 3, 4, 1120705) (f) Resolutions on all matters relating to the administration of the country as a whole.
('16', 496, 4, 5, 1120794) 13. A resolution passed by the Legislative Council should be binding on the Executive Government unless vetoed by the Governor General in Council; provided however that if the resolution is again passed by the Council after an interval of not less than one year, it must be given effect to.
('16', 496, 5, 6, 1121085) 14. A motion for adjournment may be brought forward for the discussion of a definite matter of urgent public importance if supported by not less than one eighth of the members present.
('16', 496, 6, 7, 1121270) 15. When the Crown chooses to exercise its power of veto in regard to a Bill passed by the Provincial Legislative Council, or by the Imperial Legislative Council, it should be exercised within twelve months from the date on which it is passed, and the Bill shall cease to have effect as from the date on which the fact of such veto is made known to the Legislative Council concerned.
('16', 496, 7, 8, 1121654) 16. The Imperial Legislative Council shall have no power to interfere with the Government of India’s direction of the military affairs and the foreign and political relations of India, including the declaration of war, the making of peace and the entering into treaties.
('16', 496, 7, 9, 1121925) IV THE GOVERNM ENT OF INDIA
('16', 496, 8, 10, 1121953) 1. The Governor General of India will be the head of the Government of India.
('16', 496, 9, 11, 1122031) 2. He will have an Executive Council, half of whom shall be Indians.
('16', 496, 10, 12, 1122100) 3. The Indian members should be elected by the elected members of the Imperial Legislative Council.
('16', 496, 11, 13, 1122200) 4. Members of the Indian Civil Service shall not ordinarily be appointed to the Executive Council of the Governor General.
('16', 496, 12, 14, 1122323) 5. The power of making all appointments in the Imperial Civil Services shall vest in the Government of India, as constituted under this scheme, due regard being paid to existing interests subject to any laws that may be made by the Imperial Legislative Council.
('16', 496, 13, 15, 1122585) 6. The Government of India shall not ordinarily interfere in the local affairs of a Province, and powers not specifically given to a Provincial Government shall be deemed to be vested in the former.
('16', 496, 13, 16, 1122784) The authority of the Government of India will
('16', 497, 0, 1, 1122830) 498 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 497, 1, 2, 1122872) ordinarily be limited to general supervision and superintendence over the Provincial Governments.
('16', 497, 2, 3, 1122970) 7. In legislative and administrative matters the Government of India, as constituted under this scheme, shall, as far as possible, be independent of the Secretary of State.
('16', 497, 3, 4, 1123143) 8. A system of independent audit of the accounts of the Government of India should be instituted.
('16', 497, 4, 5, 1123241) V THE SECRETARY OF STATE IN COUNCIL
('16', 497, 5, 6, 1123277) 1. The Council of the Secretary of State for India should be abolished.
('16', 497, 6, 7, 1123349) 2. The salary of the Secretary of State should be placed on the British Estimates.
('16', 497, 7, 8, 1123432) 3. The Secretary of State should, as far as possible, occupy the same position in relation to the Government of India, as the Secretary of State for the Colonies does in relation to the Governments of the Self Governing Dominions.
('16', 497, 8, 9, 1123663) 4. The Secretary of State for India should be assisted by two Permanent Under Secretaries, one of whom should always be an Indian.
('16', 497, 9, 10, 1123794) VI—INDIA AND THE EMPIRE
('16', 497, 10, 11, 1123818) 1. In any Council or other body which may be constituted or convened for the settlement or control of Imperial affairs, India shall be adequately represented in like manner with the Dominions and with equal rights.
('16', 497, 11, 12, 1124033) 2. Indians should be placed on a footing of equality in respect of status and rights of citizenship with other subjects of His Majesty the King throughout the Empire.
('16', 497, 12, 13, 1124200) VII MILITAR Y AND OTHER MATTERS
('16', 497, 13, 14, 1124232) 1. The military and naval services of His Majesty, both in their commissioned and non commissioned ranks, should be thrown open to Indians and adequate provision should be made for their selection, training and instruction in India.
('16', 497, 14, 15, 1124465) 2. Indians should be allowed to enlist as volunteers.
('16', 497, 15, 16, 1124519) 3. Executive Officers in India shall have no judicial powers entrusted to them, and the judiciary in every Province shall be placed under the highest Court of that Province.

('16', 498, 1, 2, 1124791) APPENDIX IX
('16', 498, 2, 3, 1124803) EXTRACT FROM J.T. WHITTY’S LETTER TO L. F. MORSHEAD
('16', 498, 3, 4, 1124855) [BETTIAH,
('16', 498, 4, 5, 1124865) November 17, 1917]
('16', 498, 5, 6, 1124884) It is a fact that very exaggerated ideas as regards Mr. Gandhi’s position are held by the raiyats, but I hear it on good authority that in cases where he has given directions of which the raiyats disapprove they have refused to obey him.
('16', 498, 5, 7, 1125122) I am told for instance that in the Turkaulia Dehat when Mr. Gandhi advised the raiyats that they should pay Sharahbeshi less the 20 per cent
('16', 498, 6, 8, 1125263) agreed on they said definitely that they would do no such thing and are now saying “Who is Gandhi?”
('16', 498, 7, 9, 1125363) Two days ago Mr. Gandhi wrote 1 to me to say that he had a number of enquiries from the raiyats as to why enhancement suits in villages where Tawan had been taken
('16', 498, 8, 10, 1125526) were still going on although no enhancement was to be taken for seven years.
('16', 498, 8, 11, 1125603) It struck me that the enquiry showed an extraordinary lack of knowledge of the law on the subject and the position generally.
('16', 498, 8, 12, 1125729) Obviously we are not going to withdraw our cases as we merely intend to remit the enhancement for seven years but must have it recorded as legal rent and in any case we have as yet no reliable information as to the raiyats who have actually paid Tawan.
('16', 498, 9, 13, 1125982) I replied to Mr. Gandhi that he was under a misapprehension which I should be glad to explain to him if he would call on me but that at the same time I wished to point out that the raiyats had not been to me and that I did not approve of having an
('16', 498, 10, 14, 1126230) intermediary in matters which I can deal with myself.
('16', 498, 11, 15, 1126284) His reply was to the effect that he could not understand Government Offi cers refusing the assistance of public men who are in closer touch with theraiyats
('16', 498, 12, 16, 1126440) than they could hope to be when both were working with the same object.
('16', 498, 12, 17, 1126512) He said he did not wish to come and see me on sufferance.
('16', 498, 13, 18, 1126570) I replied that the matter in which he had intervened between me and my tenants was one of no difficulty whatever, [one] on which I required no assistance from any outsiders and that I objected to the introduction of an intermediary which prevented me from being in direct touch with my own tenants.
('16', 498, 13, 19, 1126869) Mr. Gandhi refused to admit that his intervention was not justified, but expressed his wish to see me as regards his education policy.
('16', 498, 14, 20, 1127004) 1 The correspondence referred to in this letter is not available.
('16', 499, 0, 1, 1127070) 500 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 499, 1, 2, 1127112) I saw him and had a long talk with him and discussed the various points raised in the Commission’s report.
('16', 499, 2, 3, 1127219) As always in conversation I found him generally very reasonable.
('16', 499, 2, 4, 1127284) He expressed regret at the sudden breaking up of indigo cultivation.
('16', 499, 2, 5, 1127353) His own view was that some time might have been given.
('16', 499, 2, 6, 1127408) He told me that the refusal to pay rent is due to the stupidity of the raiyats who misinterpreted the orders passed.
('16', 499, 2, 7, 1127525) Whenever they
('16', 499, 3, 8, 1127539) came to him he explained to them that they must pay rent as usual.
('16', 499, 3, 9, 1127606) His own wish he says now is to utilize his position and any gratitude which he has earned from the raiyats to introduce sanitary ideas and improve agricultural methods.
('16', 499, 3, 10, 1127775) He wishes to
('16', 499, 4, 11, 1127788) improve the relations of planters and their tenants as far as it is in his power to do so.
('16', 499, 5, 12, 1127879) He approved of the action of his lieutenant in going out to enquire into the alleged disturbance in Ammon’s dehat, in which the police were said to be
('16', 499, 6, 13, 1128030) implicated, and this being so he would no doubt be prepared to make similar enquiries if asked to do so by the raiyats.
('16', 499, 7, 14, 1128150) I still consider that Mr. Gandhi himself is disinterested in his ultimate motives, but in order to strengthen and secure his position he has to make use of methods and instruments which are sure to become a danger to the peace of the district.
('16', 499, 8, 15, 1128394) As regards the non payment of rent and the interference with landlords’ admitted rights, he would certainly be on the side of the law and would advise the raiyats accordingly.
('16', 499, 8, 16, 1128570) To this extent at the present time his presence in the district is
('16', 499, 9, 17, 1128637) likely to do good rather than harm.
('16', 499, 9, 18, 1128673) At the same time he must be a continued centre of agitation.

('16', 503, 11, 15, 1137177) December 2, 1917
('16', 503, 12, 16, 1137194) In considering the situation in Champaran we have also to consider the disquieting reports received from other districts north of the river, particularly those from Chapra.
('16', 503, 12, 17, 1137367) There can be no doubt that a wave of unrest has passed through the districts of Muzaffarpur, Darbhanga and Saran.
('16', 503, 12, 18, 1137481) This wave undoubtedly started with Mr. Gandhi’s advent.
('16', 503, 12, 19, 1137537) That there was discontent in Champaran there can be no question but with Mr. Gandhi’s advent the attitude of the raiyats underwent a change for the worse.
('16', 503, 13, 20, 1137692) Rumours of what Mr. Gandhi was going to do spread throughout the districts named and we know it for a fact that raiyats from all districts went to Mr. Gandhi with their
('16', 503, 14, 21, 1137861) grievances.
('16', 503, 14, 22, 1137873) At the time not much attention appears to have been paid to the complaints from other districts but the general impression amongst the raiyats of
('16', 503, 15, 23, 1138019) other districts seems to be that, Mr. Gandhi, when he has done with Champaran, will take up the cause in other districts; in fact our latest information is that, speaking at recent meeting at Muzaffarpur, he promised that later on the tenants of that district would also enjoy the benefits that he, by his efforts, had secured for Champaran.
('16', 503, 15, 24, 1138361) In these circumstances it is not surprising that the simple folk should in Mr. Gandhi recognize someone all powerful.
('16', 503, 15, 25, 1138479) Whatever Mr. Gandhi’s intentions may be, and l am willing to believe they are well meant, the fact remains that he is accompanied by a number of undesirables who are making use of his name to stir up trouble.
('16', 503, 15, 26, 1138688) If Mr. Gandhi’s speeches have been correctly reported, they are calculated toencourage disaffection.
('16', 503, 15, 27, 1138789) Such statements as he wished to see tenants partners with the planters and not slaves, that “the interests of the Hindus lay in trying to stop the wholesale
('16', 504, 0, 1, 1138946) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 505
('16', 504, 1, 2, 1138992) slaughter of cows” appear curious statements for this gentleman to make at the present time, if, as he professes, he is trying to allay unrest.
('16', 504, 1, 3, 1139136) His action in making enquiries into cases that are sub judice almost amounts to contempt of court and
('16', 504, 2, 4, 1139238) certainly lowers the prestige of the local officials.
('16', 504, 2, 5, 1139292) I have no hesitation in saying Mr. Gandhi’s presence is undesirable at the present time.
('16', 504, 2, 6, 1139381) (g) EXTRACT FROM H. McPHERSON’S LETTER TO SECRETARY, HOME DEPARTMENT
('16', 504, 3, 7, 1139450) December 6, 1917
('16', 504, 4, 8, 1139467) Mr. Gandhi’s continued presence in Champaran is a difficult factor in the situation.
('16', 504, 4, 9, 1139552) His objects are doubtless sincere, and he is said to be striving for peace and to have worked with success in certain case to attain this end in co operation with the more responsible planters.
('16', 504, 4, 10, 1139746) His politics, however, are not within the comprehension of the ordinary cultivator, and the actions of the satellites, with whom he is surrounded, are not in all cases inspired with his own honesty of purpose.
('16', 504, 4, 11, 1139956) Mr. Gandhi is a prominent exponent of Home Rule, and the “monster” petition for which signatures are being collected throughout the mofussil was drafted by him.
('16', 504, 5, 12, 1140117) There are other development of Mr. Gandhi’s work which, however well intentioned they may be, are liable to be misunderstood by the raiyats.
('16', 504, 5, 13, 1140258) His activities
('16', 504, 6, 14, 1140273) extend to the foundation of schools where instruction is imparted by educated teachers from Bombay and to the investigation by him and his followers of cases which are being inquired into by the police.
('16', 504, 6, 15, 1140476) Enough is not yet known of his schools and teachers to say what sort of ideas they are instilling into the minds of their pupils, but it is certain that his interference in criminal cases is a cause of embarrassment to the local police and magistracy.

('16', 504, 13, 22, 1140879) You would have arrived at Motihari by the time this reaches you and would like to know how the work here is progressing.
('16', 504, 14, 23, 1141000) Since you were here last, we have been able to put almost all the wells in the village in order by removing the drains which being so close to the wells were polluting the drinking water.
('16', 504, 14, 24, 1141188) In one or two case, it was a difficult task as a drain from
('16', 505, 0, 1, 1141248) 506 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 505, 1, 2, 1141290) the house could not be diverted unless it passed through a neighbour’s property which we managed to divert by appealing to the kindly feeling of the neighbour.
('16', 505, 1, 3, 1141450) In the other case, we had to take assistance of the elders of the village to use some persuasion.
('16', 505, 1, 4, 1141548) Anyhow we have achieved our object.
('16', 505, 2, 5, 1141584) We are now after them for committing nuisance quite close to their house.
('16', 505, 2, 6, 1141658) This we propose to effect through an elderly Mahomedan preaching against [it at] their usual Friday gathering.
('16', 505, 2, 7, 1141769) We propose to adopt a similar course for the Hindus.
('16', 505, 2, 8, 1141822) l think in the course of a few weeks we shall be able to see good results.
('16', 505, 2, 9, 1141897) In the meantime, we have managed to convince the people that there is no loss of prestige in at least covering the faeces with earth by doing it ourselves for them.
('16', 505, 2, 10, 1142062) You will be glad to know that people have now taken to it.
('16', 505, 3, 11, 1142121) As for the schools, the number of students has gone up to over 75. The average daily attendance for the last month was over 60. The boys seem to take great delight in learning their songs and also the new outdoor games that are taught to them after their usual drill.
('16', 505, 3, 12, 1142389) Mrs. Gokhalay visits the village in the neighbourhood almost daily as there is always a female patient requiring medical aid.
('16', 505, 4, 13, 1142515) When the people have gathered their harvest we intend to call them in the evenings and address them on the subjects of hygiene and general culture.
('16', 505, 5, 14, 1142663) Dr. Deva called here last Wednesday and stayed over a day as there are many patients whom we could not have attended.
('16', 505, 5, 15, 1142781) We cannot get his prescriptions dispensed in Dhaka Dispensary and we shall have to apply to higher authorities to make special case and have them dispensed, which would greatly help the poor folk in the neighbourhood but before that we intend to see Hospital Assistant in Dhaka.
('16', 505, 6, 16, 1143060) La st We dn esd ay , we ha d a pr el imi na ry me et ing of th e pr om ine nt vi ll age rs of th e ne ig hbo ur hoo d an d fo rm ed a st ro ng co mm itt ee of bo th Hi nd us and Mahomedans to organize the work of primary education and village sanitation.

('16', 507, 7, 11, 1146137) APPENDIX XIV
('16', 507, 8, 12, 1146150) (a) LETTER FROM L. F. MORSHEAD
('16', 507, 9, 13, 1146181) MOTIHARI,
('16', 507, 10, 14, 1146191) January 14, 1918
('16', 507, 11, 15, 1146208) DEA R MR. GAND HI,
('16', 507, 12, 16, 1146227) In connection with the Champaran Agrarian Bill, I pointed out to the Government that the first clause of section 3, as at present drafted, prohibits khuski agreements, as hitherto understood, no less than tinkathia, because the forra of satta
('16', 507, 13, 17, 1146470) approved by the Planters’ Association contains a stipulation as to the area to be cultivated in order to supply the produce to be paid for by weight.
('16', 507, 14, 18, 1146620) I have had a letter in reply to say that in the opinion of Government there is nothing in section 5 of the Bill to render invalid a khuski satta of the kind hitherto
('16', 507, 15, 19, 1146786) approved, but section 3 would render invalid the penalty for breach of such contract by liquidated damages.
('16', 507, 15, 20, 1146894) Prima facie there is no objection to an agreement to grow indigo on two bighas or, I suppose, any other portion of land provided that the raiyat
('16', 507, 16, 21, 1147039) has entire freedom to select the actual plots to be cultivated, and it was apparently the intention of the Agrarian Committee that the existing system of khuski should be
('16', 507, 17, 22, 1147210) allowed to continue subject to that proviso.
('16', 507, 18, 23, 1147255) I have been accordingly requested to ascertain the views of the raiyats and
('16', 507, 19, 24, 1147331) their representatives both on this point and as to the most suitable way of modifying clause 3, so as not to interfere with khuski sattas.
('16', 507, 20, 25, 1147470) We discussed the matter this morning, and I put before you Mr. Kennedy’s amendment, which is as follows:
('16', 508, 0, 1, 1147575) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 509
('16', 508, 1, 2, 1147621) From the Ist October, 1917, any right, servitude or other interest notwithstanding, all lands within the district of Champaran shall be held by the tenant thereof free from any incident of tenure whereby such tenant is burdened with the obligation to grow any crop for the convenience of his landlord on his land or any part thereof and any previous act or acts permitting such as an incidence of tenure are hereby expressly repealed.
('16', 508, 2, 3, 1148056) Any agreement, contract or hypothecation whereby a tenant agrees, contracts with or hypothecates to his landlord the crop grown on his holding or any part thereof shall be void as regards such condition save the holding or part of the holding be specially defined in such agreement, contract or hypothecation.
('16', 508, 3, 4, 1148366) l understand that you take exception to the second portion of this amendment, which I mark B, but thought that the first portion alone, which I mark A, would be acceptable.
('16', 508, 3, 5, 1148539) Will you kindly let me know if I may inform Government accordingly ?
('16', 508, 3, 6, 1148608) They are anxious to have a reply before the meeting of the Select Committee on the 19th.
('16', 508, 3, 7, 1148697) Could you oblige me with a reply before that date?
('16', 508, 3, 8, 1148748) I shall be in camp at Ramgarhwa on the 15th and 16th and at Chainpatya on the 17th and 18th.
('16', 508, 4, 9, 1148841) Yours sincerely

('16', 508, 10, 16, 1149036) I pointed out to Mr. Gandhi that the first clause of section 3 prohibits khuski, as
('16', 508, 11, 17, 1149120) hitherto understood and approved by the Committee in paragraph 8 of their report, no less than tinkathia.
('16', 508, 11, 18, 1149226) Under that system a raiyat agrees to grow indigo usually in
('16', 508, 12, 19, 1149286) consideration of an advance.
('16', 508, 12, 20, 1149315) He offers land which the concern approves before giving an advance, and is paid on the produce.
('16', 508, 13, 21, 1149411) For purpos es of discus sion I took the Rajpor e system , as I unders tand Mr. Sly an d Mr .
('16', 508, 13, 22, 1149504) Ga nd hi ha d ex am ine d th is sy st em at Ra jp ore an d we re sa ti sfi ed wi th it .
('16', 508, 13, 23, 1149593) Gandhi raised an object ion that if the raiyat failed to grow the plots
('16', 508, 14, 24, 1149665) agreed upon, he would be liable to a suit for specif ic perfor mance of the contra ct and liquid ated damage s; and so he would be, of course , if he took the advanc e and did not fulfil his part of the agreem ent and damage result ed.
('16', 509, 0, 1, 1149901) 510 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 509, 1, 2, 1149943) Mr. Gandhi explained that the Bill was drafted in order to save khuski agreements
('16', 509, 2, 3, 1150025) which otherwise were held in accordance with the opinion of Sir S. P. Sinha to be barred under the Tenancy Act.
('16', 509, 2, 4, 1150137) I then suggested that they might be left to the operation of the Tenancy Act, which at any rate would leave the khuski
('16', 509, 3, 5, 1150256) system in the position in which it stands now, whereas the Bill prohibits it contrary to the Committee’s intention.
('16', 509, 3, 6, 1150372) In order to focus the discussion I showed him Mr. Kennedy’s amendment, and asked if he approved of the first part of it, which confines the new legislation to the prohibition of tinkathia as a condition of tenancy.
('16', 509, 4, 7, 1150587) reading it he declared himself ready to accept the first part of it as a solution.
('16', 509, 4, 8, 1150670) I told him that I did not wish to ‘shoot him sitting’ and he had better think it over.
('16', 509, 4, 9, 1150757) I then wrote the attached letter, and enclose a copy of his reply.
('16', 509, 5, 10, 1150824) I do not myself believe that Mr. Gandhi represents the raiyats.
('16', 509, 5, 11, 1150888) So long as there is no compulsion they are competent to understand their own interests, and they both have been and are willing to grow indigo on the khuski system in Saran, where there is no tinkathia as well as in Champaran and Muzaffarpur a leading advantage of it being that if they require a fairly substantial advance to pay off a mahajan or the like they can get it.
('16', 509, 5, 12, 1151262) They will, however, lose this if they are not allowed to agree upon, at any rate, the description of land to be sown.
('16', 509, 5, 13, 1151380) It might be necessary to stipulate that the rent accounts must be kept entirely separate, but to go beyond this is likely, in my own opinion, to do more harm than good.
('16', 509, 6, 14, 1151549) Yours sincerely,

('16', 509, 10, 18, 1151652) W.S. IRWIN’S LETTER TO ‘‘THE STATESMAN’’
('16', 509, 11, 19, 1151693) January 8, 1918
('16', 509, 13, 20, 1151709) THE EDITOR THE STAT ESMAN
('16', 509, 14, 21, 1151735) [CALC UTTA]
('16', 509, 16, 22, 1151747) It being quite evident that people outside of Champaran, and least of all the Governments of Behar and Orissa and of India (vide the New Year’s Honours’ List) have no adequate conception of the grievous harm done in that district by Mr. Gandhi’s “mission”, and the ill judged recommendations of the egregious Committee
('16', 510, 0, 1, 1152066) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 511
('16', 510, 1, 2, 1152112) of Enquiry, I am once more tempted to draw attention to and emphasize both cause and effect.
('16', 510, 2, 3, 1152205) To Government Mr. Gandhi gave an assurance that when he returned to Champaran all his efforts would be concentrated on the promotion (really renewal) of amicable relations between landlords and tenants (of the disruption of which he and his supporters were the main if not the only cause).
('16', 510, 2, 4, 1152495) I hope and intend that this letter well enable you to decide whether or not he had loyally abided by his undertaking.
('16', 510, 3, 5, 1152613) His instructions to tenants, since his return, have been to resist all the landlords’ rent demands, unless granted a reduction of 20 per cent; 26 per cent Sarabeshi (as the case may be) or a refund gf 25 per cent Tawan,— this in
('16', 510, 4, 6, 1152842) anticipation of the threatened special legislation, and notwithstanding that there is no law at present to that effect.
('16', 510, 4, 7, 1152962) Not only has this advice, which has been closely followed by the tenants, greatly embarrassed factories in their current working expenses, but has also, for the first time in the 32 years since the floating of the Bettiah Sterling Loan, caused the guarantors (or at least some of them) of the interest for that loan, to fail in the payment of the kist (instalment) which fell due on
('16', 510, 5, 8, 1153345) December 15th last, and thus has actually forced the Estate to borrow money again for the purpose.
('16', 510, 5, 9, 1153444) The guarantors can hardly be held responsible by the Courts of Wards for a failure directly caused by the mistaken action of Government, in sanctioning the wholly unnecessary (as was stated by His Honour the Lieutenant Governor himself) Committee.
('16', 510, 6, 10, 1153692) I was asked by the District Officer to submit a rent collection statement for the Ist quarter of the current Fasli year (1325) for comparison with the same period of last year, in order no doubt to explain the default of the Mothihari Ltd., share, amounting to Rs. 48,590 8, of the above interest, and I showed a deficit of Rs. 56,086 8 3, which more than accounted for the non payment.
('16', 510, 6, 11, 1154079) Fisheries which since time immemorial have belonged to the Raj and to the lessees under the Raj have been and are now being stopped ant looted by misguided tenants under, as they have stated in judicial and police inquiries, the instructions of Mr. Gandhi.
('16', 510, 6, 12, 1154336) The average in this concern for the past five years, or ever since Sarabeshi and Tawan were instituted, of rent suits ant trifling criminal cases, was 21, and less than 3, respectively, per annum.
('16', 510, 6, 13, 1154533) This year, thanks to Mr. Gandhi and the Committee’s recommendations, I anticipate not less than, 2,200 of the former, and for the later I cannot of course make any estimate.
('16', 510, 6, 14, 1154707) From the points of view of the lawyers and usurpers who imported Mr. Gandhi this doubtless is satisfactory but alas!
('16', 510, 6, 15, 1154824) I sigh for the happy record of non litigation now hopelessly broken.
('16', 510, 7, 16, 1154893) At a lecture delivered by Mr. Gandhi in what is known as the ‘‘Gaurakshini Sabha” or refuge for aged cows, in Motihari, that gentleman, I am informed and believe, exhorted his Hindu and Mohamedan listeners to cease fighting with each other about the killing of one cow per annum, and make a united attack on the
('16', 511, 0, 1, 1155205) 512 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 511, 1, 2, 1155247) Saheblog (the landlords) who slaughter and eat cows daily.
('16', 511, 1, 3, 1155306) During the absences of her
('16', 511, 2, 4, 1155333) lord and master at Home Rule and suchlike functions Mrs. Gandhi, following in the footsteps of Mrs. Annie Besant, scatters similar advice broadcast, and has recently, under the shallow pretence of opening a school, started a bazaar in the dehat of one of
('16', 511, 3, 5, 1155588) the smaller concerns, in which grain and other articles can be purchased without the payment to the malik (proprietor) or lessee of the customary bazaar dues, octroi, etc.
('16', 511, 4, 6, 1155760) This is obviously and palpably done to shut down and ruin two neighbouring bazaars belonging to the factory.
('16', 511, 4, 7, 1155869) Can all the above be possibly construed into an honest fulfilment of Mr. Gandhi’s undertaking to Government?
('16', 511, 5, 8, 1155978) Court chaprassis have told me that they dare not mention the disloyalty and
('16', 511, 6, 9, 1156054) defiance of all authority which are openly tallced of in villages into which they have to go in the performance of their duties.
('16', 511, 6, 10, 1156183) At least one court peon, whom I know, went into two of my villages to serve summonses, and was there insulted and hustled and turned out, and was told that no authority, civil or criminal, was now recognized other than that of “Gandhi Saheb”.
('16', 511, 6, 11, 1156426) And so on and so on.
('16', 511, 6, 12, 1156447) Instances might be indefinitely multiplied, but will these serve any purpose when the Government wilfully shuts its eyes to the contempt of all legally constituted authority, and to the defiance of all civil and criminal law, and blindly persists in trying to pass a special Bill affecting only 5 factories in all Behar and Orissa ?
('16', 511, 6, 13, 1156780) And even these so unfairly and inequitably that those whose tenants are discontented and out of hand, are compulsorily benefited, while those whose tenants have not complained nor have had any cause of complaint, are to be most unjustly penalized.
('16', 511, 6, 14, 1157028) There is no knowing to what extremes this sort of special legislation may not be carried and all zemindars and landholders should take warning that their liberties may at any moment be similarly sacrificed for the pacification of any political agitation, and the Permanent Settlement be as ruthlessly brushed aside as the Bengal Tenancy Act, if thought to be standing in the way of any preacher of thinly veiled sedition.
('16', 511, 6, 15, 1157450) I would be, perfectly willing to guarantee that if Mr. Gandhi and his satellites were compelled to evacuate the district, in less than two months order and quiet would be re established, for already the raiyats are jeering at the lavishness of his promises to them and the tenuity of their
('16', 511, 7, 16, 1157740) materialisation.
('16', 511, 8, 17, 1157757) Yours, etc.,
('16', 511, 9, 18, 1157770) S. IRWIN

('16', 512, 0, 1, 1157803) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 513
('16', 512, 1, 2, 1157849) APPENDIX XVI
('16', 512, 2, 3, 1157862) MEMORANDUM OF BIHAR PLANTERS’ ASSOCIATION 1
('16', 512, 3, 4, 1157906) January 5, 1918
('16', 512, 4, 5, 1157922) In the opinion of these members, the Champaran Agrarian Bill is both unnecessary and undesirable for the following reasons:
('16', 512, 5, 6, 1158046) (a) Because it is based on the recommendations of a Committee of Enquiry which was admittedly appointed to allay an artificial agitation, organized outside Champaran and not in any way the consequence of any widespread grievances.
('16', 512, 5, 7, 1158277) The Committee has been shown to have made no genuine enquiry into agrarian conditions in Champaran as a whole, but merely to have made a superficial examination of the management of a small number of Indigo and Ticcadari Estates holding leases from the Court of Wards, and that at a time when the minds of the raiyats were inflamed by
('16', 512, 6, 8, 1158612) an agitation, encouraged by the Government, from which they have been led to expect some sort of Agricultural Millenium.
('16', 512, 6, 9, 1158733) Further, this Committee has been shown to have been actuated solely by a desire to produce a report which one of its members, the leader of the agitation mentioned above, could be induced to sign and not by any wish to report on the full and true facts of the case.
('16', 512, 7, 10, 1158999) The present Bihar and Orissa Government and its predecessors have been fully aware of every detail mentioned in the Committee’s Report, which has neither brought forward any new facts, nor shed any new light on the general position, and have not considered that any special legislation was necessary.
('16', 512, 8, 11, 1159300) As a result of the unsatisfactory and partial enquiries made by this Committee the information it acquired was not sufficient to show the general position in the district in its true light, and this fact, combined with its biased attitude and anxiety to pacify a mischievous agitator at any cost, even, if necessary, by a misuse of Trust Funds under control of the Government, render the Report and the recommendations contained in it so grossly one sided and unfair, that no weight whatever should be given to them, and this legislation which is frankly based on them, should be entirely dropped.
('16', 512, 9, 12, 1159898) (b) Because it singles out one district for invidious and unnecessary legislation.
('16', 512, 10, 13, 1159981) (c) Because it proposes to invalidate existing contracts and incidents of the raiyats’ tenancy, both of which have been proved to be perfectly legal, and the
('16', 512, 11, 14, 1160139) former of which received the direct sanction of the Government of Bengal only seven years ago.
('16', 512, 12, 15, 1160234) 1 This was forwarded by the Board of Revenue to the Secretary, Revenue Department, Government of Bihar and Orissa.
('16', 513, 0, 1, 1160349) 514 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 513, 1, 2, 1160391) (d) Because it proposes to abolish without compensation and for no adequate reason a system which has been in existence for over a hundred years and which is still carried on without friction in other districts.
('16', 513, 2, 3, 1160603) (e) Because it proposes, without the consent of the landlord, to forcibly reduce rents which have been declared after an exhaustive enquiry by the Settlement Officials to be perfectly legal, fair and not excessive, and which have been paid willingly for a number of years.
('16', 513, 3, 4, 1160876) In case the Government persists in pressing this Bill in spite of all the cogent reasons in favour of its abandonment, we will point out some of the chief defects and make certain suggestions which may go some way towards remedying them.
('16', 513, 4, 5, 1161114) Section 3 (1),—This section, as it stands, will render the growing of Indigo and Sugarcane under what is usually known as the khuski system, impossible.
('16', 513, 5, 6, 1161267) Admitting, for the sake of argument, that it is not considered desirable to allow the raiyat to make a contract with his landlord binding himself to sell the
('16', 513, 6, 7, 1161425) produce of a particular crop grown on a fixed proportion of his holding for a long term of years at a flat rate based on the area of the land on which this crop is grown, it is still both desirable and necessary that he should be allowed to agree to sell the produce from a specified plot, selected by himself, at a rate based on the amount of the produce obtained.
('16', 513, 6, 8, 1161791) And this principle is admitted in the statement of objects and reasons attached to the Bill.
('16', 513, 6, 9, 1161884) If as is suggested, he is only to be allowed to bind himself to deliver a certain weight of produce, he is at the mercy of climatic conditions ant renders himself liable to damages if he fails to divert the specified amount, whereas if he contracts to deliver the produce of a certain plot, he is only liable for the amount of the balance of his advance if the crop on that plot does not come up to his expectations.
('16', 513, 7, 10, 1162301) Further, the raiyat almost invariably demands a large advance before he
('16', 513, 8, 11, 1162373) begins to prepare his land, and being an exceedingly thriftless person, if no agreement is permitted binding him to grow the particular crop on a specified plot, he is very likely to take the advance and then fail to sow sufficient suitable land to produce the required amount, and for this reason it will be impossible for the landlord to risk the advance and the price of the seed.
('16', 513, 8, 12, 1162757) Also the raiyat instead of getting money
('16', 513, 9, 13, 1162798) from his landlord without interest will be forced to obtain it from the money lender at an extortionate rate.
('16', 513, 10, 14, 1162908) It is also obviously grossly unfair that existing contracts should be an nulled without warning and without compensation and that a system of cultivation which has been carried on for over a hundred years should be abolished without giving planters time to arrange for an alternative system to take its place.
('16', 513, 11, 15, 1163218) Champaran raiyats are both stupid and conservative at the best of times, and
('16', 513, 12, 16, 1163295) look on any innovation with suspicion, and the present disturbed state of the district
('16', 514, 0, 1, 1163382) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 515
('16', 514, 1, 2, 1163428) and the agitation still being carried on by Mr. Gandhi’s followers will render the institution of the khuski system doubly difficult.
('16', 514, 1, 3, 1163562) We, therefore, wish to urge most
('16', 514, 2, 4, 1163595) strongly that contracts now in force should be allowed to continue for three years more or such time as outstanding advances on the original sattas remain unpaid on the understanding that planters will endeavour to replace the tinkathia system by the khuski system during that period.
('16', 514, 3, 5, 1163880) It is often very difficult to collect these sums and raiyats can cause an infinite
('16', 514, 4, 6, 1163963) amount of trouble and expense if they refuse to pay, as they know that the individual amounts are very often so small as not to be worth suing for, though collectively they may amount to a very large sum.
('16', 514, 5, 7, 1164168) It is, therefore, recommended that the above condition in favour of the planter shall be allowed to continue until the balance of the advantage received by the raiyat
('16', 514, 6, 8, 1164335) shall have been completely restored.
('16', 514, 6, 9, 1164372) This could cause no hardship, as the raiyat can at any time refund it either through the post or the civil courts.
('16', 514, 7, 10, 1164487) Select Documents on Mahatma Gandhi's Movement in Champaran

('16', 514, 9, 12, 1164560) NOTE ON INTERVIEW BY W. MAUDE
('16', 514, 10, 13, 1164590) January 31, 1918
('16', 514, 11, 14, 1164607) 1. We first discussed the khuski system.
('16', 514, 11, 15, 1164648) Mr. Gandhi objected to the hypothecation of any particular plot but said he did not object to the raiyat
('16', 514, 12, 16, 1164753) contracting to grow a certain amount of land in indigo.
('16', 514, 12, 17, 1164809) I then suggested substituting in the Champaran Planters’ proposed amendment the words “produce of a certain proportion of his holding” ins tead of the wor ds “pr oduce of any spe cifie d fie ld or plo t sel ected by him self”.

('16', 514, 14, 20, 1165192) continue until advance is paid off.
('16', 514, 14, 21, 1165228) Mr.Gandhi objected altogether to this, though it was explained that it might save much litigation.

('16', 514, 15, 23, 1165356) Mr. Gandhi’s view was that neither Jallaha nor Sirnie deserved any consideration whatever although Sirnie may have taken a less rate of sharabeshi than Turkaulia.
('16', 514, 16, 24, 1165519) 1 This footnote reads: “3(1) Provided that nothing in this sub section shall prevent a raiyat from entering into a contract to grow a particular crop on any portion of his holding in terms of section 5 thereof.
('16', 514, 16, 25, 1165730) To section 5 — Provided that nothing in the contract shall take away or limit the raiyats’ freedom to select the land.”
('16', 515, 0, 1, 1165850) 516 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('16', 515, 1, 2, 1165892) 4. We then discussed the proposal to make the sharabeshi enhancement as
('16', 515, 2, 3, 1165964) reduced binding.
('16', 515, 2, 4, 1165981) Mr. Gandhi agreed on this point but quoted from his letter of 24th January 1918 in which he said that “any amendment will have to carefully guard the right of appeal on grounds of irregularity or want of jurisdiction”, as for instance the Settlement Officer may have wrongly recorded the incident or where there is a manifest clerical error.
('16', 515, 3, 5, 1166323) 5. As to abwab Mr. Gandhi has no objection to the proposal to make it

('16', 515, 5, 7, 1166427) As to Mr. Gandhi’s own amendment to make the landlord liable in all cases it can be put before the Select Committee but Government cannot undertake to withdraw the whole section if it is not accepted.
('16', 515, 5, 8, 1166628) Mr. Gandhi also objects strongly to the retention of sub clause (3) of the clause.
('16', 515, 6, 9, 1166711) 6. As to cart sattas Mr. Gandhi insists that there should be a provision ending these, otherwise there will be [a] crop of law suits on the cart sattas.
('16', 515, 7, 10, 1166864) 7. The question of refund of tawan was mentioned but not discussed at this
