('16', 515, 10, 14, 1167018) APPENDIX XVIII
('16', 515, 11, 15, 1167033) SHANKARLAL BANKER'S LEAFLET
('16', 515, 12, 16, 1167061) This is the first leaflet l write for you.
('16', 515, 12, 17, 1167104) I wish, therefore, to state at the very outset that my right to advise you is only nominal.
('16', 515, 12, 18, 1167196) I have not done any manual labour.
('16', 515, 12, 19, 1167231) I have not suffered the miseries that workers have to endure, nor can I do anything myself to remove that misery.
('16', 515, 12, 20, 1167345) Therefore, I feel hesitant in giving advice on this occasion.
('16', 515, 12, 21, 1167407) But, even though I have done nothing for you in the past it is my keen desire to do what I can hereafter according to my capacity.
('16', 515, 12, 22, 1167538) I write this with that desire.
('16', 515, 13, 23, 1167569) Two days ago our situation had taken a serious turn.
('16', 515, 13, 24, 1167622) Some of you were in straitened circumstances, but instead of taking to labour to get relief from those circumstances as urged so often by Gandhiji, it was apprehended that some of you would break the vow and get back to the mills.
('16', 515, 13, 25, 1167853) But that situation has now passed away.
('16', 515, 13, 26, 1167893) Our dull hearts have been quickened by Gandhiji’s fast.
('16', 515, 13, 27, 1167949) We have become conscious of the seriousness of our oath.
('16', 515, 13, 28, 1168006) We are convinced that ‘we shall not break the oath even at the cost of our lives’ is not a slogan merely to be repeated in meetings but has to be demonstrated in action.
('16', 515, 13, 29, 1168176) As a proof of this change in the situation, those who are in financial difficulty have willingly begun to do manual work.
('16', 515, 13, 30, 1168298) Not only so, but also those who are better off have set an example by assisting from their wages those in need, and have removed the possibility of a split among us
('16', 516, 0, 1, 1168463) VOL. 16: 1 SEPTEMBER, 1917 23 APRIL, 1918 517
('16', 516, 1, 2, 1168509) for all time.
('16', 516, 1, 3, 1168523) But that is not enough.
('16', 516, 1, 4, 1168547) A very heavy responsibility has come over us by Gandhiji’s fast; and if we understand that responsibility fully, we should exert ourselves to the utmost to end this struggle as soon as possible, we should adopt all such means as would shorten the struggle consistently with keeping to our pledge.
('16', 516, 1, 5, 1168844) Our oath is to obtain a 35 per cent increase.
('16', 516, 1, 6, 1168890) And we know that financially it is not difficult for the employers to give the 35 per cent increase.
('16', 516, 1, 7, 1168991) But employers feel that if they gave the 35 per cent, the workers will become domineering and insolent, that they will become unruly at the slightest provocation, and ruin the industry by resorting to strikes on trifling matters.
('16', 516, 1, 8, 1169221) I see no reason for entertaining such a fear.
('16', 516, 1, 9, 1169267) Workers can never desire that an industry which gives them their daily bread should be destroyed.
('16', 516, 1, 10, 1169365) But if workers behave without discretion and without thinking about justice or injustice, such a result is inevitable.
('16', 516, 1, 11, 1169484) If we desire to be saved from it, we should determine to work regularly for the mill owners in good faith.
('16', 516, 1, 12, 1169591) We should decide not to make unreasonable demands, and not to resort to remedies like strikes to secure justice until all other avenues are exhausted.
('16', 516, 1, 13, 1169742) But our task is not over with such a determination.
('16', 516, 1, 14, 1169794) We have to go to the employers, acquaint them with our decision and win their confidence.
('16', 516, 1, 15, 1169884) We have to remove the misapprehension which restrains them from giving us the 35 per cent increase.
('16', 516, 1, 16, 1169984) I strongly urge upon the workers to take immediate steps in this direction.
('16', 516, 2, 17, 1170060) A Righteous Struggle
('16', 516, 3, 18, 1170081) APPENDIX XIX
('16', 516, 4, 19, 1170094) COMMISSIONER PRATT’S SPEECH
('16', 516, 5, 20, 1170122) [AHMEDABAD,
('16', 516, 6, 21, 1170134) April 12, 1918]
('16', 516, 7, 22, 1170150) I would like you to listen to me attentively and repeat to everybody what I say, when you go back to your villages so that what I say to you now may come to be known throughout the district; for what I am going to say to you today is not only for you but for the whole district.
('16', 516, 7, 23, 1170429) You have been given much advice by Mahatma Gandhi and Vallabhbhai Saheb and other gentlemen who are working with them.
('16', 516, 7, 24, 1170548) They have made speeches from village to village but today I would request you to listen to me.
('16', 516, 8, 25, 1170643) The rights of the agricu lturists are such that they can keep the land in their posses sion for genera tions.
('16', 516, 8, 26, 1170753) But those rights carry with them the duty to pay regula rly the land revenu e assess ment fixed accord ing to law.
